Introduction, Location and Vegetation The Prospecting Licence P27/1645 is located approximately 70kms north east of Kalgoorlie Boulder and is centred at 6646312 North, 381259 East (GDA 94) and has an area of 45Ha.

Access to the tenure from Kalgoorlie is via the Yarri Road for approximately 65kms through Kanowna townsite, passing roads to Black Swan Nickel Mine, Carosue Dam and Lindsays Find towards Edjudina and Gindalbie Homestead (Refer: Figure 1).
The climate is semi-arid with an annual rainfall of about 250mm and annual evaporation of about 2300mm.
Rainfall in the area varies from light falls during winter to heavier, patchy falls in summer and autumn.

In some instances this region can become flooded due to very heavy rains brought about by tropical cyclones which move in from the northwest (Ahmat, 1995) The area has moderate dense vegetation and so access to other parts of the property can be achieved by travelling cross country using a four wheel drive vehicle.

Geological Setting The tenement P27/1645 ( Refer: Figure 2) is in the Gindalbie Terrane to the east of the Kalgoorlie Terrane and is bounded by the Mount Monger Fault in the west, the Emu Fault and Penny Dam Conglomerate in the east.
The terrane contains greenstone successions separated by regional lowangle faults.

The tenement geology is restricted to felsic volcanic rocks occurring within the Gindalbie Terrane outcropping in the south western corner including tuff mainly dacitic but ranging from rhyolitic to andesitic in composition.
The majority of P27/1645 is overlain by colluvium and alluvium being transgressed by significant drainage.
No greenstone succession appears to be present.

Work Programme 3.1 Research & Review of Previous Exploration Data Reading of open file reports continued in order to obtain information on the area and prepare a geological base plan for future exploration.
The information from reports indicated the prospectivity of the tenement.
3.2 Auger Drilling A soil sampling programme was undertaken using a tractor supporting an auger drill.
Soils were taken from a depth varying between 0.1 metres and 1 metre depending on the location of a strong carbonate layer in the soil.
Testing of the soil being lifted to the surface was carried out using hydrochloric acid.
Where the strongest reaction to the acid was given the soil was sampled 'whole' and placed in brown paper packet.
For Location data refer Figure 3 and metafile GN_WASL3_COLL2007A.
3.3 Assaying The soil samples were sent for assaying.
Assays are pending.

This report details exploration carried out on the Reidy Swamp Project during the reporting period 1/1/2006 to 31/12/2006.
During the 2004 reporting period Barrick (PD) Australia and Jackson Gold NL entered into the Kanowna Nickel Rights Agreement.
This agreement allowed Jackson Gold NL to acquire 100% of the rights to nickel group minerals on some of Barrick (PD) Australias tenements, including the Reidy Swamp Project.

The terms of the joint venture are such that Barrick (PD) Australia retains 100% ownership of the Reidy Swamp tenements and are responsible for gold exploration, while Jackson Gold NL are responsible for conducting nickel exploration.
The Reidy Swamp tenements lie within the Boorara domain of the Kalgoorlie Terrane.
The late Archaean Kalgoorlie Terrane is defined on the basis of a distinct regional greenstone stratigraphy and deformation history.

The regional stratigraphy consists of a lower basalt unit, followed by a komatiite unit, an upper basalt unit, and a felsic volcanic and sedimentary rock unit that is unconformably overlain by locally developed, coarse clastic sequences.
Work carried out by Barrick Kanowna during the 2006 year reporting period included geological mapping and interpretation.

Nickel exploration during the reporting year comprised general reconnaissance and the interpretation and reporting of a 2005/06 moving loop EM (MLEM) survey and compilation work on the 2005 aircore drilling program.

On-ground exploration consisted of checking RAB/Aircore drill traverses across the extension of the buried Four Mile Hill East ultramafic stratigraphy on E27/191.
The bulk of this unit lies on MLA27/219.
Field inspection of drill-spoils on this application confirm strongly calc-magnesite-talc altered rocks consistent with a high-MgO flow field.
At the Kanowna East ultramafic belt, Anglo-American exploration (1970-1974) data was incorporated into a compilation of all results including 2005/06 MLEM, and the 2005 aircore drilling.
Anglo work comprised shallow-hole bedrock and rock-chip geochemistry, 20 percussion/diamond holes and limited magnetometer and IP surveys.
No geochemical anomalism indicative of nickel sulphide mineralization is evident in the compiled data.
At Harpers Lagoon field reconnaissance continued ahead of RAB/aircore testing.
Exploration activities on the Reidy Swamp tenements for 2007 will focus on the Harpers Lagoon ultramafic stratigraphy which trends through E27/079.
The belt is the stratigraphic equivalent of the Scotia ultramafic and is under-tested below cover.
Approximately 15 RAB/aircore traverses have been designed and approved by DoIR to test basal ultramafic stratigraphy.
Compilation and interpretation work will continue on the Kanowna East, Golden Valley North, and Four Mile Hill West and East ultramafic trends.
Fugro Ground Geophysics completed a MLTEM survey, which commenced in late 2005 and was first reported in the 2005 Reidy Swamp annual report.
The data was not interpreted and reported until 2006.
The survey consisted of 310 stations for 14.55km coverage, and primarily covered parts of E27/191 and the strike extension of the Black Swan ultramafic stratigraphy, see Figure 6.

Parameters for the survey were as follows: Slingram and in-loop configuration In-loop fluxgate: X and Z components In-loop RVR: Z component only Slingram fluxgate: X and Z components (no slingram RVR measurement) Transmitter-receiver slingram offset: 150m Transmitter loop: triple-turn 100m 100m Station spacing: 50m Receiver: EMIT Smartem Transmitter: Zonge ZT-30 powered by motor generator Late-time data defines three strong anomalies on the eastern edge of the survey, and one spurious response due to high noise levels in one reading on the western edge of the survey.
None of the features are supported by geochemical results indicative of nickelsulphide mineralization.
Numerous other responses in the mid-time channels were inspected.
All were found to relate to weak conductors.

Anomalies of interest are shown in Figure 7, and these correspond to prominent late-time responses visible in Figure 8(c), which is an image of the in-loop vertical component b-field data for channel 40 (191.825 ms).

This anomaly is defined on a single line (6817000mN), with the next planned line to the north yet to be read.
The single-peaked in-loop response suggests a shallow dip.
The anomaly has a very long time-constant (approx.
The data is consistent with a plate with a 40,000 Siemen conductance.
On geophysical grounds, this would be a highly ranked target.
Anomaly KE02 has a twin-peaked profile (6620600mN, 374100mE) in the in-loop vertical component, but the X component profile is inconsistent with a single conductor.

The Reidy Swamp tenements lie within the Boorara domain of the Kalgoorlie Terrane.
The late Archaean Kalgoorlie Terrane is defined on the basis of a distinct regional greenstone stratigraphy and deformation history.

The regional stratigraphy consists of a lower basalt unit, followed by a komatiite unit, an upper basalt unit, and a felsic volcanic and sedimentary rock unit that is unconformably overlain by locally developed, coarse clastic sequences.

The regional deformation history includes D1 thrusting, D2 upright folding about North, north-westerly trending axes, D3 sinistral transcurrent faulting and continued east north easterly regional shortening.
I-type granitoids were emplaced during deformation and regional metamorphism at greenschist to amphibolite facies reached peak temperatures late during the D2 to D3 transpressional deformation.

Deposition of the mafic volcanic rocks occurred around 2.70 to 2.69 Ga, and the main regional deformation between 2.68 and 2.61 Ga. Cratonization took place before the emplacement of 2.4Ga, east-striking Proterozoic mafic dykes.
The Kalgoorlie Terrane is subdivided into six domains separated by major faults.
Regional structures such as D1 thrust faults, F2 folds and D3 shears cannot be traced across the domain boundary faults.

The two major central domains (Kambalda and Ora Banda) contain the complete regional stratigraphic sequence, whereas the western and eastern domains (Coolgardie and Boorara) have an upper basalt unit that is thin or absent.
The Boorara domain, bounded by the Bardoc Shear Zone to the west and the Mount Monger Fault to the east, is interpreted as the easternmost part of the Kalgoorlie Terrane.

This terrane is regarded as an originally coherent volcano-sedimentary basin formed between 2.72 Ga and 2.68 Ga, and is characterized by a regional lithostratigraphy of four units, ie, lower tholeiitic basalt, komatiite, upper high-Mg basalt and a composite felsic unit dominated by subaqueous dacitic/rhyolitic lavas and their clastic derivatives.

In the Boorara domain, more complex lithostratigraphic successions are recorded because early felsic volcanism in distinct centres developed at the same time as the regional extensive komatiite volcanic flows.
These units generally trend north-east, and prominent structural lineations in the form of shear zones trend northwesterly.
The Gindalbie Terrane lies to the east of the Kalgoorlie Terrane, and is bounded by the Mount Monger Fault in the west, the Emu Fault in the east and the Randall Fault in the southeast.
The terrane contains three greenstone successions separated by regional lowangle faults.
These early (D1) faults are folded and offset by subsequent (D2 and D3) folds and faults.
The lowermost calc-alkaline succession contains a range of rocks from andesitic basalt to rhyolite, with predominant dacite and andesite.
Lava flows may be present but are subordinate to pyroclastic rocks.
These volcanic rocks are overlain by finergrained sedimentary rocks particularly in the southern hinge and eastern limb of the Bulong Anticline.
They include carbonaceous, locally pyritic, slate close to and along the interpreted fault contact with the overlying mafic-ultramafic association.
A faultbounded, isoclinally folded tholeiitic basaltgabbro package restricted to the western limb of the anticline is regarded as a separate thrust slice with early recumbent folding.
REIDY SWAMP PROJECT 2006 11 The lowermost succession is overlain by mafic-ultramafic rocks dominated by komatiite that contains thin inter-layered felsic tuff layers.
On the eastern limb of the Bulong Anticline, the komatiite is interleaved with increasing volumes of tholeiitic basalt.
On this eastern limb the sequence becomes thinner to the north, and is absent in the northern hinge of the anticline.
The komatiite-tholeiite association is older than the felsic association it overlies.
The massive olivine cumulate in the west is transitional to and interleaved with olivine-spinifex and komatiitic basalt layers that generally increase in volume upwards in the sequence.
The uppermost association forms the northern part of the terrane, and contains a bimodal basalt-felsic volcanic (dacite-rhyolite) sequence.
The Gindalbie Terrane thus contains three distinct greenstone successions bounded by early, low angle faults.
Structurally higher successions are older or show the same age range as the rocks they overlie.
The regional geology of the area is illustrated in Figure 4 using DIR published data.
Much of the Archaean stratigraphy is covered by recent alluvium.
The typical transported profile (true thickness) consists of: 1-2m of aeolian sands 2 -35m of lacustrine clays with 1-2m of silt at its base, (Perkolilli formation).
0-25m of coarse-grained quartz sand and grit with occasional gravel +/- pebbles, (Woolabar formation).
The Archaean rocks in the Kanowna District are subdivided into a Lower Volcanic Sequence and an Upper Sedimentary Sequence.
The sequences are separated by a time break of about 30Ma and exhibit a marked contrast in deposition style from mafic-dominated volcanism to high volume basin fill sedimentation.
The Lower Volcanic Sequence consists of, from oldest to youngest, lower basalt, ultramaficdacite, upper basalt, and turdidite.
The mafic stratigraphy is generally well defined in the Kalgoorlie region.
However, recognition of a coeval ultramafic and old dacite formation in the Kanowna district has strongly influenced rocks in the area are correlated.
The Upper Sedimentary Sequence consists of a package of conglomeratic and felsic volcaniclastic rocks.
The rocks can be further subdivided into units of basal conglomerate, mass-flow volcaniclastics, and polymict conglomerate.
REIDY SWAMP PROJECT 2006 12 The Lower Volcanic Sequence consists of lower basalt, ultramafic-dacite, upper basalt, and turbidite (Black Flag Group).
The lower most unit is generally massive to pillowed, high-Mg to tholeiitic basalt.
Overlying the basalt, komatiitic rocks are intercalated with quartz-phyric dacite.
Contacts between the two lithologies exhibit primary irregular contacts; komatiite apophyses inject into the dacite and magma mingling textures are common.
Komatiite magmatism and volcanism is interpreted to have been contemporaneous with dacitic magmatism and volcanism.
Two komatiite emplacement styles are recognised.
Cumulatetextured komatiite bodies are interpreted as high-level intrusions.
These komatiite units exhibit symmetrically zoned chilled margins and spinifex texture, together with apophyses and xenoliths distributed along the top and basal contacts with adjacent strata.
Extrusive komatiite lavas show typical chill-cumulate-spinifex-chill zonation from base to top of the individual flows.
The Upper Basalt is a massive to pillowed, high-Mg to tholeiitic basalt.
It is distinguished from the Lower Basalt by the presence of differentiated mafic sills near the top of the formation.
The contact of the Upper Basalt and overlying Black Flag Group is conformable.
The sediments are generally well bedded siltstone and wacke which are typical of deposition in a deep marine, low input, environment.
The Upper Sedimentary Sequence consists of a package of conglomeratic and felsic volcaniclastic rocks.
The basal mafic conglomerate and polymict conglomerate are referred to locally as the Ballarat Conglomerate and Kanowna Conglomerate respectively.
Both units are interpreted to have been terrestrially sourced and deposited in a rapidly subsiding, deep marine setting.
Clast types include ultramafic, mafic, dacite, and felsic porphyry, with subordinate granite and chert.
The Grave Dam Grit (GDG) unconformably overlies the conglomerates and occurs in the structural hangingwall of the Kanowna Belle mine.

The GDG is generally a structureless, coarse-grained, quartz crystal-rich, volcaniclastic rock, which is interpreted to be the product of a subaerially sourced pyroclastic flow deposited in a marine environment.
The Government Dam turbidite may be the distal equivalent of the GDG, or a re-sedimented facies at the top of the sequence.
The Golden Valley Conglomerate (GVC) occurs in the structural footwall of the Kanowna Belle mine and is interpreted to occur at the top of the upper sedimentary sequence.
The GVC consists of laterally and vertically graded, gravel-to-boulder size polymict sediments.
Clasts are typically ultramafic, mafic, dacite and felsic porphyry.

This work comprised the interpretation and reporting of a 2005/06 moving loop EM (MLEM) survey and compilation work on the 2005 aircore drilling program.
Several EM conductors remain to be explained in the area but none are supported by geochemical results supportive of nickel-sulphide mineralization.
A series of RAB/aircore traverses have been designed and approved to test buried basal ultramafic stratigraphy on the Harpers Lagoon trend on E27/079.
This work will be carried out during the 2007 reporting year.

Introduction The Exploration Licence E27/318 is located approximately 40kms north northeast of Kalgoorlie Boulder and is centred at 6632500 North, 384500 East (GDA 94) consisting of 23 graticular blocks and an area of approximately 6007 hectares.
Access to the tenure from Kalgoorlie is via the Yarri Road through Kanowna townsite towards Gindalbie (Refer: Location Plan - Figure 1).
The climate is semi-arid with an annual rainfall of about 250mm and annual evaporation of about 2300mm.
Rainfall in the area varies from light falls during winter to heavier, patchy falls in summer and autumn.
In some instances this region can become flooded due to very heavy rains brought about by tropical cyclones which move in from the northwest (Ahmat, 1995).
The area has moderate dense vegetation and so access to other parts of the property can be achieved by travelling cross country using a four wheel drive vehicle.
Geological Setting The Halfway Hill area is situated in the central part of the north northwest trending Archaean greenstone belt that runs between Norseman and Wiluna.

Exposure of the bedrock sequence is largely restricted to the extreme south of the property where there is a north northwest striking sequence of Archaean rocks comprising felsic volcanics, intrusives and volcaniclastics; sediments including slate and shale; and mafic volcanics and intrusives including dolerite, gabbro and basalt.
Superficial cover is present over most of the area and consists of Cainozoic colluvium and laterite and Quaternary alluvium.
There are two major faults inferred as existing in the eastern and western portions of the tenement area Mount Monger Fault and Emu Fault.
Both faults trend north northwest, however the orientation of the western-most fault - Mount Monger Fault - veers further to the west as it extends north.
The northern continuation of the eastern-most fault the Emu Fault - is situated immediately to the east of the Carrick Vale property.
Work Programme 3.1 Research Research on open file reports continued in order to obtain information on the area and prepare a geological base plan for future exploration.
The information from the reports indicated the prospectivity of the tenement in the central and southern areas of the tenement (Refer: Figures 2 & 3).

Significant gold and nickel intersections from previous drilling are given in Department of Mines and Petroleum report A57233; including RAB intersections from GINB801, 615, 570, 576 and RC intersections from drill holes GINC 91, 92.
3.2 Mapping and Site Inspection Mapping of the area was conducted using a handheld GPS.
Site inspection of areas with limited exploration was conducted concurrently making note of land marks such as fence lines, tracks and rock outcrops.
Inspection of recent drill areas and the rehabilitation conducted was carried out ( Refer: Geology E27/318 Figure 4).
3.3 Review of TEM Survey Results from 2007 Results from a surface pulse EM survey conducted in 2007 were reviewed and interpreted to determine prospective areas for future drilling.
Information from the results included prospective areas for the detection of base metals and gold along a long conductor and possible shorter parallel conductor (Refer: Geology E27/318 Figure 4).

Conclusions & Recommendations It has been concluded that the tenement area is prospective with the possible occurrence of nickel sulphides related to strong geochemical and geophysical (TEM) anomalies in the north western sector of this tenement.
It is recommended that further geophysical work giving a more detailed image of the tenement area i.e.
ground magnetics be carried out.
As well an investigation of the anomalous gold values in previous RAB drill holes should be considered.

The Hamersley Province has undergone a complex deformation history, with at least five deformation events (D1-D5) recognised, as follows: D1 is indicated by layer-parallel isoclinal folds and boudinage of chert and BIF horizons.
The event is widespread but does not disrupt stratigraphy significantly.
The structures are interpreted to have developed because of extension and compaction within the early basin.
Mount Elvire Project Annual Technical Report E47/1265 6 D2 (Ophthalmia Orogeny) was the most significant event to affect the Province.
It was most intense along the southern margin of the Province, and resulted in the development of thrusts and local tight folds with axial planes that dip shallowly to moderately to the south.
These features resulted from south-over-north closure of the Hamersley Basin.
D3 (Ashburton Orogeny) was responsible for producing the regional-scale E-W to NWSW trending folds that dominate the structural pattern of the northern and central parts of the Hamersley Province.
These folds and their associated thrusts accommodate N-S shortening across the Province.
D4 and D5 produced upright, open folds that combine with the D3 folds to form local dome and basin fold patterns.
Iron Ore mineralisation in the Hamersley Province is divided into Bedded (BID), Channel (CID) and Detrital (DID) Iron Deposits.
Bedded Iron Deposits are predominantly developed within the Mt Newman Member and Nammuldi Member of the Marra Mamba Formation and the Dales Gorge Member of the Brockman Iron Formation.
There are two main models for the genesis of these deposits.
One model suggests Supergene alteration of the BIF to develop goethitemartite ores.
The resulting mineralisation then undergoes burial metamorphism to form microplaty haematite.
The other model puts forward hypogene alteration of martite enriched BIF by replacement of the gangue with goethite and/or deposition of microplaty haematite.
This is followed by Supergene alteration that deposits goethite and involves some leaching of the rock.
Bedded Iron Deposits in the weathering zone can be subject to the processes of dehydration, hard-capping, hydration and dissolution.
Channel Iron Deposits represent alluvial material rich in ferruginous granules deposited in river channels incised into and draining from the Hamersley Ranges.
CIDs are characteristically comprised of pelletoids (<2mm ferruginous ooids or 2 to 10mm pisoids), peloids (massive, goethite-rich fragments) and wood fragments (commonly goethite replaced).
A goethite matrix, cementing the granules, formed within the palaeochannels.
Detrital Iron Deposits develop from the deposition of eroded BID.
They may contain a range of clast types, sometimes with later cementation, and variable clay content.
Occasional dolerite dykes are striking generally between north-west and north-north west or north-east.

Mount Elvire Project Annual Technical Report E47/1265 5.0 Previous Exploration Robe River Mining Co. Pty Ltd (Robe) and Amax Exploration (Australia) Incorporated are known to have conducted exploration to the south and within the tenement in 1991 to 1992 and 1972 respectively.
Open file reports provide information on these areas.

Robe followed-up a regional helicopter supported mapping and rock chip sampling programme in 1990 with 25 reverse circulation drill holes in 1991, south of the tenement, to investigate whether there was any buried CID, DID or BID.
The best result was one drill hole that intersected about 6m of massive goethite.
The Robe open file report mentions that Cliffs International completed regional mapping in 1971 based on aerial photographs.
Amaxs exploration within the tenement consisted of a photo interpretation of the geology and a field visit that took surface samples of CID and canga deposits (ironcemented DID).
The small extent of CID graded <56% Fe and the canga deposit, that lay outside of their tenement, graded 62 to 65% Fe.

Mount Elvire Project Annual Technical Report E47/1265 2.0 Introduction This report details the exploration activities undertaken by Australian Premium Iron and Aquila Resources Limited on Exploration Licence 47/1265 between 6 January 2007 and 5 January 2008.
Figure 1 shows the location of the tenement in the Hamersley Range of the northern Pilbara region of Western Australia.
The tenement is centred approximately 90km (straight line) east-south-east of Pannawonica.

The nearest unsealed roads and tracks are the old Millstream Road, the new Millstream Road, the Robe River railway line service road (all to the north) and the Hamersley Iron railway service road (to the east).
There are no roads or tracks passing through the tenement except for a disused track that clips the southern edge of the tenement.
The tenement is held by De Beers Australia Exploration Limited.
Management of the tenement is by De Beers for diamonds only, Australian Premium Iron (API) Management Pty Ltd for iron only and Aquila Resources Limited for all other minerals.

4 Mount Elvire Project Annual Technical Report E47/1265 5 3.0 Regional Geology The tenement is located within the Hamersley Province of the Pilbara Craton in Western Australia.
This Province consists predominantly of late Archaean and Lower Proterozoic (2800-2300Ma) sedimentary rocks situated between the large, Achaean Yilgarn and Pilbara Cratons.
The rocks have undergone a complex structural evolution, with the dominant event resulting in the development of major folds and thrusts associated with north-directed thrusting (Ophthalmia Orogeny).
The Mt Bruce Supergroup is predominant in the Hamersley Province.
The Supergroup is subdivided into the Fortescue, Hamersley, and Wyloo Groups.
The Hamersley Group is host to all Bedded Iron Deposits.
The Hamersley Group consists of Banded Iron Formation (BIF), dolomite, shale and felsic volcanic rocks, all of which have been intruded by dolerite sills and dykes.
The Group is divided into seven Formations of which the Marra Mamba Iron Formation and Brockman Iron Formation host all the Bedded Iron Deposits.
The Marra Mamba Formation is the lower-most Formation in the Hamersley Group and forms deposits at mine sites in Newman, Area C, Marandoo, and West Angelas.
The Formation is divided into the Nammuldi, McLeod, and Mount Newman Members.
Of these members, the Mount Newman Member is host to the major deposits presently being mined and consists of a thick succession of BIF, shale, and carbonate rocks.
The Brockman Iron Formation consists of BIF, shale and chert and is divided into the Dales Gorge, Mt Whaleback, Joffre, and Yandicoogina Shale Members.
The Dales Gorge Member is host to the majority of iron ore mineralisation, with Tom Price, Paraburdoo, Whaleback, and Rhodes Ridge being typical examples.
During the Tertiary, a series of erosion-deposition-hardpanisation (ferricrete) cycles resulted in the regionally extensive Hamersley surfaces that can contain economic Detrital Iron Mineralisation.
These surfaces have subsequently been eroded by the existing drainage system, often preserving remnants of the Hamersley surfaces in mesas.
Low, gentle rolling hills with both incised gully-type and broad sheet wash type drainages.
Elevation ranges from about 480m to 550m.
Vegetation is predominantly spinifex grassland with sporadic, small trees and shrubs.
Location: P27/1661 is located 50km northeast of Kalgoorlie, Western Australia.
Geology: The underlying geology of the area comprises a sequence of deeply weathered Archaean sediments and altered mafic volcanics.
Minor fesic volcanics are associated with the sediments.

5.2 Maher Mining The Sullivan (2001) report contained little information on new work.
The Transcontinental work was summarised and although a plan of bore collars at the Mavis was included, the present author was unable to reconcile the plotted collar positions with field locations.
Consequently Sullivans drill-sections are considered doubtful.

Batten: provided photographs of the Mavis workings, recorded that stoped widths ranged from 1m to 10cms, stated the underlay declination (and lode plunge) was 44o at the portal and subsequently flattened to 33o, (but did not record the depth at which this occurred), reported on advise that at the base of the underlay the lode had dimensions exceeding the normal quartz vein width in the upper Mavis shaft.
provided details for 6 grab samples from the Mavis workings, Table 2.

Any additional information available of the Transcontinental drill campaign; especially bore collar location details and assayed interval depths, would be of great assistance to the planning of future studies.
Information from the dump sampling program by a prior party would also be extremely valuable.

All surface and underground mine workings including; drives, stopes, intersections of R-C bores with mine workings, shaft collars, prospect holes, costeans and bore collars should be accurately surveyed.
Reliable surface and underground geological maps, as well as additional sampling, would assist determination of lode attitudes and mineralisation patterns.
Close attention should be paid to the potential for a bonanza shoot at the intersection of the Oakley and Mavis lodes.
Given favourable results from the above work, further drilling and/or underground development would be warranted.
The Oakley and Mavis Au-bearing lodes are structurally controlled quartz lodes striking at approximately right angles.
Potentially minable intersections were made by bores drilled Transcontinental Holdings Pty Ltd.
The base of the Mavis shaft may have reached the intersection of the Mavis and Oakley lodes.
It is highly probable a bonanza shoot developed at this intersection.
The description of the face at the base of the Mavis shaft is consistent with such a bonanza shoot.
Samples HM011 and HM012, 5.53 g/t Au and 1.19 g/t Au, respectively may be from a northern vein set parallel to the Oakley lode.
No evidence was found of any significant Au mineralisation away from quartz veins and not all quartz veins were found to be mineralised.
7 of the 16 Transcontinental R-C/diamond core bores entered mine workings.
Had the underground workings been mapped prior to bore drilling, more significant lode intersections may have been made.

6.2 Surface Mapping Because no suitable surface plan was available, the author prepared a base plan by tape and compass traverses closed to 8 tenement boundary markers for which grid coordinates were obtained from Tengraph.
Surface features, including mine shafts, costeans, bore collars and the authors sample locations, were plotted onto this plan.
Co-ordinates of locations remote from the survey points were supported by hand-held GPS.
See Plan 1.
No attempt was made to obtain reduced levels and position accuracy for individual points is probably of the order of several metres.
However, considerable care was taken to locate the bore collars as precisely as possible.
8 R-C bore collars on 3 drill lines were found 38-92m southeast to southwest of the Mavis Shaft portal.
See Plan 1.
7 of the collars were PVC-cased: declinations were effectively 60o and azimuths were 44o to 48o magnetic.
The uncased collar was only about 10m from the nearest collared bore.
None of the historic reports mentioned bores collared so closely or a bore abandoned at shallow depth.
None of the bore collars bore any identification.
4 PVC-cased R-C bore collars were located 65-90m northeasterly of the Oakley shaft.
See Plan 1.
Collar declinations were all close to 60o while azimuth determinations varied from 300o-307o magnetic.
Cuttings from 2 other R-C bores were found some 30m east-northeast and 50m south, respectively, from the Oakley shaft, but the collars were not found.
Underground Mapping Underground workings were not entered in the present study and no mine plans were located.
However, the author determined the Mavis shaft declination at the portal is 440, azimuth 136o magnetic.
From the portal the shaft was seen to flatten and deviate slightly eastwards after about 15-20m.
Batten (2005) reported the same declination at the surface and that the shaft flattens to 33o but did not advise at what depth.
Because of the deviation to the east the underlay may pass close to vertically under the line of shafts extending south-easterly from the portal.
Plan 1 shows the surface trace of the underlay if it continued at the 44o declination, 136o magnetic azimuth, for the full 274m length.
The base of the underlay would be some 195m from the portal at a depth of 190m.
If however, the easterly deviation and 33o declination continue, the trace of the underlay would be east of the trace shown on Plan 1, the base some 225m from the portal and 150m below the surface.

SUMMARY M30/104 covers the Mavis and Oakley mine workings.
Records of mine production and previous exploration campaigns within this lease and adjacent tenements were examined.
Site inspections were made, an approximate surface plan was prepared for the mine area, and rock chip and ultraviolet lamping programs completed.
Unfortunately the most comprehensive of the historic exploration programs forM30/104 was poorly documented and much useful information has potentially been lost.

In additional to the potential for additional ore resources on both the Mavis and Oakley lode structures, the possibility of bonanza shoot development at the intersections of these structures is considered very real.
A program of future work is outlined.
LOCATION M30/104 is located approximately 5.5 kilometres westerly from the former Davyhurst townsite and 130 kms northwesterly from Kalgoorlie, WA.
See FIGURE 1.
The locations of access tracks and the Oakley and Mavis shafts relative to the boundaries of M30/104 are shown in Figure 2.
M30/104, access tracks and shaft locations.
GEOLOGY 3.1 Regional Geology Davyhurst lies in the central portion of the Archean Norseman-Wiluna Greenstone belt which comprises predominantly mafic volcanics, volcano-sediments and ultramafics.
The greenstone belt is flanked by Archean granites.
Several major faults, including the Ida Fault, the Kunanulling Fault and the Zuleika Shear, pass close to M30/104 within a corridor some 10kms wide.
The area is highly mineralised: the Davyhurst, Callion, Mulline Mulwarrie and Riverina gold mining camps lie within 10kms of M30/104.
Regional geology is shown in Figure 3.
LEGEND: FIGURE 3 Age Symbol Lithology Cainozoic Czc Colluvium, gravel, silt, clay.
Czl Laterite and reworked products Archean Ab Basalt 3.2 Local Geology See Plan 1.
Regionally weathering has been intensive.

Identifiable bedrock outcrops are rare in the vicinity of the lease: the surface is predominantly ferruginous pisoliths (pea gravels), colluvium and sheet wash. Oxidation extends to some 40-45 metres: the depth increasing near the lodes.
Only the deeper mine workings have penetrated to fresh rock and bedrock type is confidently recognised only from mine dumps.
Gold has been won from 2 lode systems: the Mavis and the Oakley, both quartz veins and striking at approximately right angles to each other.
The Mavis lode strikes south-easterly and is reported to dip sub-vertically to 60o south-west, be highly contorted, emplaced within a folded shear and to have both up folded and down folded segments.
Au grades were high and bonanza shoots common.
Mining was reported to have been directly from the Mavis underlay shaft.
Sullivan (2001) reported galena was a significant accessory in the lode but no galena or Pb-oxide minerals were noted by the present author.
Sullivan also reported that the face at the base of the underlay grades 60 grams/tonne Au.
The Oakley lode lies some 200m south of the Mavis portal and strikes north-easterly.
It is reported to be structurally controlled, to dip south at 55-63o and to have been developed by shaft and drives to a depth of 55m.
Mined width was 0.5m.
Drilling has shown strike length is at least 150m.
A significant feature reported for the Oakley lode is its association with a fault controlled porphyry unit; identified by a petrologist as a granodiorite.
No information is available for the attitude of the porphyry.
However, a north-easterly striking massive Fe-oxide horizon that outcrops to the north of the Oakley shaft may represent the surface trace of the associated fault.
Although Au was detected in all 5 of the authors samples from the surface of this structure, the highest was only 0.43 grams Au/tonne.
The porphyry is reported to grade above 0.1 grams/tonne in some drill intersections and consequently it may have had some role in the mineralisation process.
The author found specimens of porphyry on mine dumps but did not locate any in outcrop and did not go underground.
PRODUCTION HISTORY The reported combined production from the Oakley and Mavis lodes since 1897 is: 8275 tonnes @ 27grams/tonne Au for 223.4 kgs, (7,183 ozs).
EXPLORATION HISTORY 5.1 Transcontinental Holdings Pty Ltd Transcontinental Holdings Pty Ltd completed a substantial exploration campaign at both the Mavis and Oakley in the 1980s.

The program included: geological reconnaissance, establishment of a grid with 40m spaced lines, 147m of backhoe trenching in 9 costeans, 101 chip and channel samples from these costeans, a proton-precession ground magnetometer survey with 10m x 40m spaced readings, 625m of Rotary Air Blast (RAB) drilling in 40 bores, 825m of Reverse-Circulation (R-C) drilling with 88m of diamondcore tails in 16 bores, and 333 bore samples.
William Johnson and Associates (1985) (hereafter WJA) managed the program but unfortunately the only copies of their report available has no plans or drill sections and very few assays.
Bore collar locations were also inadequately recorded and bore collars were not identified.
Consequently, the great bulk of the information collected by this campaign is probably no longer available.
Drill results reported by WJA were: MAVIS LODE Total 8 bores collared on traverses 40m, 63m and 79m southeast of the Mavis portal.
40m traverse: 2 bores intersected old workings, 63m traverse: one bore reportedly failed to reach the lode.
Collar spacings on the drill lines were not recorded.

2 other bores made significant intersections: Bore Intersection OKR1: 1m @ 2.73 grams Au/tonne OKR3: 3m @ 9.70 grams Au/tonne Neither intercept depths nor bore collar locations were recorded for these bores.
If the Oakley lode continues northeasterly and the Mavis continues southeasterly, the 2 lodes would intersect.
If, as recorded, the Oakley dip averages 60o and the Mavis underlay declination at depth is constant at 33o, the Oakley lode could pass within 20-30m above the base of the underlay.
With minimal changes in lode and underlay attitudes the base of the underlay and the lode intersection would coincide.
Pipe-like bonanza shoots are commonly developed at the intersections of fracture controlled lodes.

The increased lode dimensions, the 60 grams Au/tonne grade and the fractured Oakley-type quartz reported by Batten (2005) for the base of the Mavis workings could indicate that such a shoot had been located.
If the Mavis underlay declination is constant at 44o, the base of the shaft would be some 70 metres below the nearest point of the Oakley lode.
6.5 Geophysics 6.5.1 Radioactivity Total-count readings of radioactivity were taken with a hand-held Scintrex Model 8GS-1SL scintillometer.
See Table 3 and Figure 4.
M30/104: Total-count scintillometer readings.
Natural radiation emanating from rocks is masked by only a few centimetres of soil and most radiogenic minerals are readily oxidised and leached by groundwater.
Consequently readings at the natural surface are typically low and poor indicators of bedrock radioactivity.
Consequently most readings were taken from pits, shaft collars and associated dumps.
Readings were taken over dumps with both fresh and weathered rocks and 2 surface readings were taken as controls.
All scintillometer readings were at background levels and consequently the radiation presents no health hazard.
Differences between readings taken at the surface and over weathered and fresh bedrock were minimal.
Nevertheless, the 2 highest readings (60 s/s, sites 2 and 12) were from dumps of fresh rock and as Figure bb shows, there is some clustering of values.
For example, there is a group of comparatively low values in the vicinity of the Oakley shaft.
Whether these subtle differences have any relationship to the mineralisation is not known.
6.5.2 Ultraviolet Lamp Study The mineral scheelite, (CaWO4), fluoresces strongly under ultraviolet light.
Significant tonnages of scheelite were produced from the Golden Pole Au mine, less than 5kms east of M30/104,.
An ultraviolet lamping study was completed at night over M30/104.
Particular attention was paid to the Oakley and Mavis mine dumps, costeans and prospect pits.
Fluorescent calcrete was common but scheelite was not detected.
6.6 Rock Chip Sampling Numbered pin flags adjacent to small pits in dump surfaces were taken as evidence of dump sampling but no records of such a campaign were located.
However, in anticipation that details could become available, the authors sample points were kept remote from the earlier ones.
In the present study 31 samples were collected from mine dumps and weathered bedrock exposures and assayed for Au, Ag, Li and W at Kalgoorlie Assay Laboratories by the ICPMS method.
Results are presented in Table bb and the Appendix.
Samples with significant Au grades are presented in bold font in Table 4.
From Table 4, 11 samples were of quartz and of these, 7 reported Au grades >1 ppm.
All samples from other lithologies graded <0.5 ppm.
A definite association of Au with quartz is therefore apparent and no evidence was found of any significant leakage of Au away from the quartz veins and into the country rock.

Apart from the 5.53 grams Au/tonne assay from the shaft 30m northwesterly from the Mavis portal, no significant grades were returned by any samples from prospect pits remote from the Mavis or Oakley workings.
The sampling by Batten, 2005, (Table 2, above) provided support for these conclusions.
His 2 quartz samples both carried significant grades: 1.52 g Au/t and 10.03 g Au/t, respectively.
2 samples from the Mavis hanging wall and 1 from the footwall were described as limonitic clay and returned insignificant assays.
This supports the authors conclusion that there was minimal leakage of Au away from the quartz lode structures.
A second footwall sample Batten described limonitic clay, Fe and Si, assayed 17.00g Au/t.
If the Si referred to here was quartz it reinforces the Au-quartz association.
W grades of all the authors samples were effectively at background levels.
This supports the results of the ultraviolet lamp study.
Ag and Li grades were also low and no relationships were found between any of the 4 elements, Au, Ag, W and Li.

An 893 auger soil sampling programme was completed on E77/1354 during the reporting period.
The sampling was carried out by Regional Exploration Services Western Australia using a 4WD vehicle-mounted auger rig.
Sample spacing was 100x100m and where present the carbonate layer was preferentially collected.
The samples were assayed at KalAssay in Perth for Au, Ag, As, Cr, Cu, Mo, Ni, Pb, Pd, Pt, W & Zn via Aqua Regia ICPMS.
Very little historic exploration has occurred on E77/1354 or previous underlying tenure; subsequently there is limited solid geological information.

The auger programme was designed obtain complete geochemical coverage of E77/1354 to assist in understanding the underlying geology and test some conceptual mineralisation targets generated through aeromagnetic interpretations.

Preliminary analysis of the auger soil results has produced a significant copper, nickel, chromium, platinum and palladium geochemical anomaly located in the north-eastern portion of E77/1354 see Figure 3, Appendix 4.
This geochemical anomaly is co-incident with the newly identified conductor target generated through the recent MLTEM survey.
A broad spaced aircore programme has been designed to test the geochemical anomalies in the next reporting period.
Surface geophysical data and plots are provided in Appendix 1.

The survey was carried out by Outer Rim Exploration Pty Ltd with specifications located below in Table 2 and the survey parameters located in Table 3.
One significant MLTEM conductor target has been identified in the north-eastern portion of E77/1354 see Figure 3, Appendix 4.

The following work was completed on E77/1354 during the reporting period: MLTEM Geophysical Survey FLTEM Geophysical Survey Soil Auger Sampling Aeromagnetic Re-Processing The MLTEM survey over E77/1354 generated one target to be tested by a deep drill hole; at the time of writing this hole is yet to be drilled.
The FLTEM survey over a previously identified (historic exploration by Range Resources) deep conductor was disappointing with no significant results produced in the latest survey.
The extensive auger soil sampling programme was the first complete geochemical survey completed over E77/1354.
The results have identified a strong copper, nickel, chromium, platinum and palladium anomaly over outcropping ultramafics in the north-eastern portion of E77/1354.
The geochemical anomaly is co-incident with the MLTEM conductor target.
Re-processing of both government and multi-client aeromagnetic data by Southern Geoscience Consultants covering the entire Forrestania Belt was completed during the reporting period.
The new imagery has been most useful in identifying large scale lineaments in E77/1354 which are potentially prospective for gold mineralisation.
A broad scale aircore programme has been designed to test several of these auger anomalies and magnetic targets in the next reporting period.

Appendix 1: MLTEM & FLTEM Data and Plots 12 Appendix 2: MLTEM & FLTEM Report 13 Appendix 3: Auger Assay and Sample Data 14 Appendix 4: Figures 15 1.0 INTRODUCTION E77/1354 is located on the western side of the Forrestania Greenstone Belt, within the Yilgarn Craton, Western Australia and is part of the Forrestania Project.
The project was acquired on the basis of a joint venture between Cullen Resources Ltd (20%) and Hannans Reward Ltd (80%).
1.1 Location & Access The tenure is located approximately 128km south of Southern Cross and 77km east of Hyden.
E77/1354 is located approximately 7km north of the Flying Fox Nickel Sulphide Mine operated by Western Areas NL.
Access to the tenure is via maintained gravel roads; the Southern Cross Forrestania Road south of Southern Cross and the Hyden Norseman Road east from Hyden.
Access within the tenement is along cleared grid lines.
See Figure 1 in Appendix 4.
1.2 Climate & Vegetation The climate of the area is semi-arid with high evaporation rates.
Rainfall from winter rains and occasional summer storms averages 300mm per annum.
Vegetation consists of mainly dry sclerophyll woodland with areas of low mallee heath and scrub on areas of laterite and sandplain.
Sandplain Heath Eucalyptus Woodland 1.3 Tenure The tenure is detailed below in Table 1.

Licence Applicant / Holder Project App Date Grant Date AREA Annual Expenditure Requirement E77/1354 Hannans Reward/ Cullen Exploration Forrestania 12/06/2006 23/05/2007 5SB $15,000.00 Table 1: Tenure Details for E77/1354 2.0 REGIONAL GEOLOGY The project is located on the western margin of the Forrestania Greenstone Belt.
Mapping has defined two distinct lithostratigraphic units; a maficultramafic metavolcanic suite and a sequence of immature clastic sediments, which overlie the older mafic-ultramafic assemblage.
Folding has resulting in a large north plunging syncline with E77/1354 located on its western limb.
The sequence has been subsequently cut by Dolerite dykes.
2.1 Prospect Geology The western half of E77/1354 is largely dominated by granitic stratigraphy comprising foliated, medium-coarse grained biotite granite and adamellite.
The eastern stratigraphy is dominated by the prominent BIF (quartz-grunerite-magnetite) ridge of North Ironcap and by a lower north striking ridge of alternating BIF and ultramafic-mafic rocks.
3.0 PREVIOUS EXPLORATION The Forrestania Greenstone Belt has been the subject of intensive exploration since the early 1970s.
Amax Exploration Australia was largely focused on nickel exploration and Gold Mines of Kalgoorlie and Aztec Mining Company Ltd focused on gold exploration.
Numerous joint venture agreements and exploration of the region occurred during the 1980s and 1990s.
The companies included Normandy Exploration Ltd, Forrestania Gold NL and recently Lion Ore Australia Pty Ltd.
In comparison E77/1354 (and previous tenure) has had remarkably little exploration for both gold and nickel.
Range Resources Ltd completed HOISTEM, MLTEM and FLTEM geophysical surveys over the tenement during 2004 which was managed by Newexco; details of these surveys can be found in Appendix 2.
The surveys identified a significant conductor which was re-tested during the current reporting period by Hannans Reward Ltd.
Range Resources Ltd also drilled two reverse circulation drill holes into the tenement now covered by E77/1354 which return no significant results but did intercept ultramafic stratigraphy.
4.0 WORK COMPLETED For an exploration summary see Figure 3 in Appendix 4.
During the reporting period Atlas staff carried out helicopter reconnaissance over its Pilbara projects.
A brief visit was made to the tenements to assess the iron ore potential of the areas.
No samples were collected during this visit.
The group of tenements, E45/2232, E45/2241 and E45/2251 form part of Atlas Iron Limiteds Abydos Project, located approximately70 km south south east of Port Hedland, Western Australia.
The tenements lie within the Wodgina and Wallaringa, 1:100 000 map sheets.
Access to the tenements is via the Great Northern Highway and then via tracks along the Port Hedland Newman Railway line and various station tracks.

The Great Northern Highway lies approximately 18km from the western extent of the tenement and the Port Hedland Newman Railway line lies approximately 7km from south western corner of the tenement as shown in Figure 2.

During the reporting period Atlas Iron Limited conducted exploration activities over the tenements E45/2232, E45/2241 and E45/2251.
These activities included acquisition of open file geophysics and helicopter reconnaissance.
Further exploration is proposed for these tenements during the next reporting period will include target generation activities and field investigations.
The Abydos project comprises tenements covering a number of diverse geological domains.
The project area overlies the Wodgina, Abydos, Pincunah, East Strelley, and Soansville Greenstone Belts as well as the Lalla Rookh Basin.
Atlas Irons Abydos project has excellent potential to host both Channel Iron deposits (CID) and Bedded Iron Deposits (BID).
Extensions of known CID deposits occur within the Abydos Project (ie.
The Cinnamon Creek, Pincunah North, Pincunah South, and Lalla Rookh CID deposits held by BHPB).
Both the Strelley 1and Strelley 2 CID deposits occur wholly within the Abydos Project.
The main targets for bedded iron mineralization within the Abydos Project are banded iron formations (regionally correlated with the Cleaverville Iron Formation) within the Gorge Creek Group.

A number of exploration targets (Pincunah Trend and Strelley Trend) occur along strike from known BID mineralistion occurring just outside the Abydos tenements (ie Iron Mount, Lalla Rookh South and Strelley Gorge Deposits held by BHPB) as shown in Figure 3.

In the Pincunah Greenstone Belt, the Pincunah Hill Formation is located at the contact between arenites and conglomerates of the Corboy Formation and felsic to intermediate volcanics of the Kangaroo Caves Formation.
The Pincunah Hill Formation contains red and black thinly bedded banded iron formation.
Within the Abydos Project this sequence contains zones of enrichment in a region located to the south of Pincunah Hill (Pincunah Trend).
The Corboy Formation also contains a sequence of banded iron formation which has the potential to host zones of bedded iron enrichment.
The Kangaroo Caves Formation which outcrops to the southwest of the Pincunah Hill Formation in the Abydos Project contains interbeds of white-grey layered chert and minor banded iron formation.
4 The East Strelley Greenstone Belt in the northeastern portion of the project contains a sequence of Gorge Creek Formation underlying the Lalla Rookh Formation.
The rocks of the Gorge Creek Formation in this region have been assigned to the Paddy Market Formation.
The Paddy Market Formation contains a thick sequence of banded iron formation comprising thinly bedded black, white, red and grey cherty banded iron formation.

Substantial zones of iron enrichment (Strelley Trend) were observed within the Abydos Project located between the Lalla Rookh South and Strelley Gorge Iron deposits (held by BHPB and located along strike, and outside the Abydos Project tenure).
The Mount Iron Deposit (also held by BHPB) is hosted in the same Paddy Market Formation just to the south of the Strelley Trend.
In addition, the Coucal Formation of the Coonterunah Group contains banded iron formation within the project area to the south of the Lalla Rookh iron deposit (held by BHPB).
The Golden Cockatoo Formation metasediments are an unassigned metasedimentary formation of the Sulphur Springs Group that is confined solely to the Abydos Greenstone Belt.
The formation has been metamorphosed to upper-amphibolite facies and is subdivided into four units dominated by banded iron formation, metapelite, metaquartzite, and rhyolite.
Historic rock chip sampling has identified small zones of iron enrichment in the banded iron formation within the Abydos project which requires further evaluation.

Bedrock gold mineralisation is associated with the major Avoca Shear Zone and with the northeast trending faults.
Gold derived from the bedrock structures has entered the alluvial sequences and was a major source of the gold produced during the active mining period at Kurnalpi.
The gold was noted as being coarse grained and nuggety in distribution.
Nickel mineralisation is present mainly in the west of the Kurnalpi property where it is present both in the laterite weathering profile overlying ultramafic sequences and also in the bedrock.

Introduction Carrick Gold Limited has approximately 90 tenements (Mining Leases, Mining Lease Applications, Prospecting Licences, Prospecting Licence Application Exploration Licences and Exploration Licence Applications) in the Kurnalpi Project.
Aggregate area of the Kurnalpi property is around 165km2.
The Kurnalpi Property is located approximately 75km ENE of Kalgoorlie in the Eastern Goldfields of Western Australia.
The property si discontinuous and extends over around 30km in an east-west direction and over some 18km north-south.
Access to the tenements is via the Pinjin-Kalgoorlie Road and then via station tracks north and south.
This road is well maintained and cuts across much of the tenement group.
The topography is subdued and characterized by low rounded hills with the relief ranging between 100 and 200m.

The only prominent topographic features are low extensive scarps or breakaways that commonly mark an abrupt junction between the old and new plateau surfaces and only occur in deeply weathered or kaolinized rock.
The climate is semi-arid with an annual average rainfall of between 225-250mm.
In general the rainfall is more reliable in the south.
Flood rains occur occasionally caused by cyclonic conditions originating from the northwest.
Summers are hot and dry with maximum temperatures frequently above 360C.
The winter is cool to mild with occasional frosts.
Vegetation is varied and belies the semi-arid nature of the climate.
Dense mulga scrub interspersed with tracts of more open bluebush (Kochia), saltbush (Atriplex), and eucalyptus country is common north of Lake Yindarlgooda.
The sandier areas are covered with mallee, spinifex (Triodia), and occasional native pine (Callistris).
Open eucalyptus woodlands comprising salmon gums, gimlet and mallee, interspersed with saltbush and bluebush cover the flat and undulating country of the south.
Vegetation density increases toward the southern margin of the Sheet.
The salt lakes or playas are bordered by saltbush and numerous varieties of samphire.
Native pines are common on kopai dunes (gypsum) bordering the salt lakes.

The Kurnalpi Property is located on the Norseman-Wiluna greenstone belt, an Archaean sequence of ultramafic, mafic, intermediate and acid intrusive and extrusive volcanic rocks with associated sediments.
The greenstone belt trends northnorthwest.
Flanking the belt are major Archaean intrusive granitic bodies.
The major structural feature of the property area is the northnorthwest trending Avoca Shear Zone that dips to the west.
On the western side of the shear zone, the bedrock sequence comprises basalts, komatiites, sediments and minor felsic volcanics.
To the east of the Avoca Shear, the sequence is dominated by basalt, dolerite and sediments and in the easternmost portions of the Kurnalpi property by felsic volcanic rocks.
Other faults of the area are orientated approximately parallel to the Avoca Shear Zone.

Late stage northeast trending faults cross cut the Avoca Shear Zone and east to eastsoutheast trending thrust faults are interpreted as being present in the north to the south of an intrusive granite.
Tertiary and Quaternary deposits of various origins cover the bedrock sequence and dominate much of the area where outcrops are generally sparse.

The Mt Monger Project Area is prospective for a variety of deposit types including Mt Monger style quartz sulphide gold lodes and Kambalda style nickel mineralisation within ultramafics.
The base outcrop map highlights the structural setting of the leases.
Evidence of cross cutting faulting was expressed as silicified chert outcrop.
Minor topographc highs were defined by the presence of mafic volcanics.
To the south immediate south of the southern boundary of leases P26/3204 limited mining has occurred at a locality called Three Emus.
The mineralisation appears as narrow quartz veining associated with in an east west striking contact zone between igneous mafic volcanics and Felsic sediments and Porphyries.
The Mount Monger mining centres lie within the southern part of the Gindalbie Terrane.
This area exposes an imbricate thrust package of greenstones derived from the Kalgoorlie Terrane that structurally overlies younger felsic volcanic rocks on the western limb of the Bulong Anticline.
The thrust package was emplaced over the felsic volcanic rocks during D1 and subsequently folded about the D2 Bulong Anticline.
The main D1 thrust surface was named the Goddard Fault but, in the Mount Monger mining areas, the floor thrust lies below the Goddard Fault.

The intervening horse contains a D1 anticline that may be a hangingwall fold Felsic volcanic rocks within the thrust package have been dated at 2705 4 Ma, whereas the felsic volcanic rocks below the thrust package were deposited at 2672 12 Ma (Roberts et al, 2006) Gold deposits are in a north-northwesterly trending zone about 9 km long, mainly within the mafic horse beneath the Goddard Fault as well as in overlying metamorphosed felsic volcaniclastic rocks.
The greatest concentration of mining activity is located directly below the Goddard Fault.

Relatively little gold has been produced from above the Goddard Fault and there has been insignificant gold production from rocks above the structurally higher Carowlyme Fault (another D1 thrust) (Roberts et al).
Gold mineralization at Mount Monger is associated with north-northwesterly trending brittleductile shear zones that dip steeply to moderately steeply to the southwest.
Felsic porphyry dykes have the same orientation (Mt Monger Gold Project Pty Ltd, 1995).
Orebodies plunge 4060S, which, is collinear with the intersection between the brittleductile shears and the Goddard Fault.
During the reporting period Synergy Exploration No Liability carried out exploration on tenement P26/3204 (See Figure 1).
Following a review of previous work undertaken a soil sampling program was undertaken in order to test for anomalous concentration of a suit of elements.
Soiling sapling was undertaken a nominal 400m x 200m spacing.
Surface mapping of outcrop was also undertaken to increase accuracy of surface geology.
The tenement is situated on the Mount Monger Pastoral Station and is located south of the Mount Monger Homestead approximately 70 kilometres by road from Kalgoorlie-Boulder townsite (see Figure 1).
Access to the area is via the Mount Monger road and then via tracks constructed to service fence lines.
The tenement is situated adjacent to Tommies Dam, a number of dirt tracks criss-crossing the tenement.

The lease cover an area of 145 hectares and lies south of the highly prospective Mount Monger mineral field which hosts a number of significant historic and operating mines including the Daisy Milano operation.
The area is located immediately above the Three Emus deposit a small producer located immediately south of the south western corner of the lease.

The Lionel Project is focussed on the search for host rock of the Nullagine alluvial diamonds which were located there in 1895 by gold prospectors working Tertiary fluviatile conglomerates and the detritus of the Precambrian conglomerates immediately north of the township.
The diamonds were recovered from the stamper boxes after the conglomerates were crushed to release the gold.
Groom (1896) reported 17 small diamonds which were followed up with a further 25 small diamonds in 1900 recovered from 230 tonnes of conglomerate.
The largest diamond reported was a 3.5 carat stone said to have been found on Grants Flats about 1.6 km north of Nullagine (Figure 1).
This area has been intermittently explored since then for diamonds, partly because of its history and also because it lies within the Pilbara Craton which is a target area for kimberlite emplacement.

LIONEL PROJECT E 45/ 2437 & E 46/ 495 ANNUAL REPORT FOR YEAR ENDING 5th OCTOBER 2006 Page 4 The enigmatic origin of the Nullagine diamonds has enticed exploration companies into the eastern Pilbara Region over the years, with most of the major diamond exploration companies including Stockdale, BHP, CRAE and others having conducted work programmes in the area.
In 1998, Stockdale entered into a joint venture agreement with another explorer for exploration on an exploration licence which covered most of the Paramount tenement E46/495 (Lionel South).
Stockdale interpreted the aerial magnetic data available from the Commonwealth Government, with one priority target being selected.
Follow-up of this target in the field led to the conclusion that it was probably not kimberlitic.
This lies to the east and outside of the Lionel Project area.
The Brockman kimberlite dyke system, lying around 50 kilometres northeast of the Lionel tenements was tested for diamonds by De Beers.
Nine small diamonds were found in the concentrates from the early exploration drilling, and subsequently 22 micro-diamonds were extracted from 1710 kg of kimberlite.
In the period 1999-2000, eight mini-bulk samples comprising 196 tonnes were collected and treated in South Africa, and 13 diamonds weighing 0.875 carats were recovered.
Thus while the kimberlite is clearly diamondiferous, it has an indicated sample grade of less than 1 carat per one hundred tonnes (Wyatt et al, 2003).

A total of six stream sediment samples (three in November 2005 and three in May 2006) were collected for heavy mineral analysis from heavy mineral trap sites in rivers and creeks draining both tenements, E 45/ 2437 & E 46/ 495 (Figure 2).
Sample descriptions with coordinates are provided in Table 1.
The samples were sent to Independent Diamond Laboratories for heavy mineral analysis.
The results are presented in Appendix 1.

Three samples, LL/C1 to LL/C3, were positive, containing chrome spinel with grain morphology descriptions ranging from probably not kimberlitic, possibly kimberlitic and for six grains in sample LL/C2 probably kimberlitic.
Chrome spinel grains were selected from each group for electron microprobe analysis, to a total of 33 grains.
The plots and results are presented in Appendix 2.
The results demonstrate that there is an overall similarity in geochemistry, with the different morphology groups falling both within and outside the diamond indicator field (DIF) on the plots.
This suggests that all grains have a single, non-kimberlitic source.
Preliminary research involved commencement of a detailed study of results from the tenement area and immediate environment.
Copies of available reports on previous exploration were acquired to assist in this work.
In addition geological and structural data were examined.
Investigations were made as to what aerial photography and satellite imagery is available for the area, to assist in identification of geomorphic features of interest and structural studies.
The Lionel Project covers 24 blocks (approximately 72 square kilometres) making up two Exploration Licences, E 45/ 2437 & E 46/ 495.
The Project is being explored by Paramount for diamonds, with a principal focus on discovery and development of a hard rock source - kimberlite or lamproite.

The eastern Pilbara consists of several large granitic masses (batholiths) as well as small plutons and stocks intruded into the layered successions which have been deformed into complex upright fold structures.
The Lionel tenements fall within such a deformed intrabatholithic belt comprised of basalts, andesites and ultramafic sequences typical of the regional greenstone metamorphism.
This tectonic unit is known as the Kelley Belt, representing the western limb of a major syncline which is wedged between the Corunna Downs Batholith in the west and McPhees Dome in the east.
These rocks are Archaean in age.

LIONEL PROJECT E 45/ 2437 & E 46/ 495 ANNUAL REPORT FOR YEAR ENDING 5th OCTOBER 2006 Page 3 A kimberlite dyke system (the Brockman Creek kimberlite) with a strike length in excess of 20 km was located by De Beers in 1998 some 50 km to the northwest of the Lionel tenements (Wyatt et al, 2001).
Kimberlites generally occur in clusters, and groups of these in one region are known as fields or provinces.
As such the Brockman dyke system is of great significance, as it may herald the presence of many more kimberlites within this region.

The explanatory geological notes of the Nullagine 1:250,000 sheet report that in the period between 1895 and 1970 about 70 diamonds were recovered from Tertiary sandstones on the northern margin of Nullagine township.
These sediments are known as the Brooks Hill Beds which form elongated limonite-capped mesas consisting of fluviatile sands, gravels and basal conglomerates.
These deposits probably represent palaeochannels of the Nullagine River.
This is of significance as the Lionel South exploration licence falls with the Nullagine River catchment area.
Paramount Mining Corporation Limited (Paramount) conducted diamond exploration work on the property during the report period, under an option agreement with the tenement holder Vistarise Limited.
The initial work programme for the Project consisted of a geological review, air photograph and satellite imagery investigations.
Field work carried out within E 45/ 2437 & E 46/ 495 during the report period consisted of a heavy mineral sampling programme of rivers draining the project area.
A total of 6 stream sediment samples were collected.
The tenements are located in the Pilbara Region of Western Australia.
The southern margin of the project area is around 35 kilometres north of the town of Nullagine (Figure 1).
The project lies in an area where geological criteria are favourable for kimberlite or lamproite emplacement.
The proximity to the Nullagine Alluvial Diamond Field and the diamondiferous Brockman kimberlite dyke system serve to enhance the potential of this project (Figure 1).

The Exploration Licences fall within the eastern Pilbara Goldfield in the Pilbara Region of Western Australia.
They lie between 35 and 65 kilometres north of Nullagine, adjacent to the Marble Bar road.
This allows for easy ground access to the tenements along a network of station and mining tracks such as those to the Lionel Mining Centre and several other abandoned gold diggings (Figure 1).

Nullagine is a small mining centre, approximately 200 kilometres north-northeast of Perth, on the Great Northern Highway which leads to Port Hedland and beyond into the Kimberley Region of Western Australia.
The regional physiography consists of well-drained, hilly terrain.
The climate is semi-arid with occasional monsoonal rains during the summer months from November to March.
The main activities of the eastern Pilbara are cattle farming and mining.
The vegetation is typical open savannah parkland with spinifex grass covered terrain and eucalypt wooded areas along the creeks.
Though the region is prospective for kimberlites and lamproites, sample results from the Lionel tenements suggest their potential for diamondiferous host rocks is very low.
As a result it is concluded that no further investigations are warranted for diamonds.
In view of mining activities in the area, the tenements are prospective for gold and possibly for various other commodities.

U3O8 Limited 1 1.0 INTRODUCTION The Dawson-Hinkler Project is situated approximately 30 km south of Wiluna, starting a few kilometres west of the Leonora-Wiluna highway (Figure 1).
The Project comprises one granted exploration licence for a total area of 110.3km2.
The project is accessed from the Leonora to Wiluna highway, from the northern turnoff to the Yellirrie Station.
From then on, station tracks and fence lines provide access to most locations in the area.

The project area affects the Lake Way Pastoral Lease, which uses Dawson Well as a water source for its cattle.
