Prospecting Licence P77/3601 is situated approximately 63 km south-southeast of Southern Cross.
Access from Southern Cross is along the Forrestania Road (figure 1).
The Licence is prospective for gold and nickel mineralization.

The Licence was granted under section 56B of the Act and as such formed part of a sale of tenements from International Goldfields Ltd to Southern Cross Goldfields Ltd. Southern Cross Goldfields Ltd listed on the Australian Stock Exchange in March 2008 and P77/3601 forms a strategic part of SXGs Parker Dome Project.
An application for combined reporting over this project has recently been lodged with DoMP.
The British Hill gold deposit (on Ps77/3650/3651) forms the resource nucleus for exploration in the Project area.
SXG have recently reported a resource at British Hill of 1.6MT at 1.9 g/t gold based on historical drilling.
The Parker Range region has been explored and mined by the early prospectors since the first gold discovery in 1889.
Some nickel exploration was conducted during the 1960s and the area was extensively explored for gold beginning in the early 1980s.
Numerous companies have conducted exploration throughout the Parker Range region during the last 25 years.

The most significant of these were; Gepeko Pty Ltd: early 1980s CRA Exploration Pty Ltd: late 1980s Eclipse Ridge Pty Ltd/Scanfire Exploration Pty Ltd/ Southern Goldfields Limited: early 1990s Gasgoyne Gold Mines NL (Yilgarn Star discovery in 1989): 1985-1992 Orion Resources NL: early 1990s Abador Gold NL: 1992-1994 Sons of Gwalia Ltd: 1991-2002 Gondwana Resources Ltd: 2003 to present.

These companies conducted and documented a number of exploration activities, including but not limited to; Geochemistry: stream sediment sampling, auger and soil sampling, rock chip sampling, etc Remote Sensing: LandSat, radiometrics Geophysics: airborne and ground magnetics, electrical geophysics Drilling: auger, vacuum, RAB, aircore, RC and Diamond Past exploration activity on the area defined by P77/3601 included gridding, auger soil sampling and aeromagnetic/ air photo data acquisition by CRAE during the 1990s.
The CRAE auger sampling located the Dulcie West Prospect and soil sample coverage was subsequently extended by Abador Gold during the mid 1990s.
CRAE subsequently drilled Dulcie West.
The southwestern part of the licence area is mapped dominantly as sandplain (Bagas, 1994).
The central eastern parts of the Licence are underlain by ferricrete and Archaean sediments which trend northwesterly (figure 2).
Granite has been mapped approximately 900m west of the Licence however the granite contact is considered to lie along the Licence boundary immediately west of the Dulcie West soil anomaly.
Gold mineralisation along the Dulcie line occurs 2km across strike to the east and at British Hill 8km to the south east.
Gold anomalism in soils and drillholes at Dulcie West defines a target approximately 2km in strike that has been sparsely drilled.
Southern Cross Goldfields Ltd intends to further test this high priority target.
The Licence is explored in concert with surrounding tenements owned by SXG, including British Hill.
The British Hill gold deposit lies 8km to the southeast.
Consultants Hellman and Schofield were recently commissioned to assess the resource at British Hill and calculated 1.6MT at 1.9 g/t gold in the indicated and inferred categories.

The Licence lies within the Southern Cross Greenstone Belt, a tract of slightly- to strongly metamorphosed Archaean rocks that were initially widespread mafic and ultramafic volcanics, sedimentary rocks, and more restricted felsic volcanics.
The belt extends discontinuously for approximately 400 km, from north of Southern Cross south to Ravensthorpe near the southern coast of Western Australia.
The belt contains several large historical and current gold mines near Bullfinch, Southern Cross and Marvel Loch as well as abundant small gold showings.
The southern half of the belt is host to the recent nickel discoveries, Flying Fox and Spotted Quoll in the Forrestania area.

Many of the primary geological relationships have been obscured by subsequent deep weathering, the development of lateritic and calcrete duricrusts, and burial by surficial deposits (including colluvium, wind-blown sand, and unconsolidated deposits in ephemeral lakes and watercourses).
1 The margins of the greenstone belt are defined by outcrops of gneissic and granitoid igneous rocks.
The contacts between greenstone and granitoid/gneissic provinces are sheared.
Deformation of the belt is a consequence of craton wide east-west compression with synchronous granite intrusion.
The granitoid/gneissic terrains are now ovoid in plan and dome-shaped in three dimensions, with a concentric steeply-outward-dipping foliation.

The adjacent units in the greenstone belt display structures that are compatible with this; stratigraphic contacts and foliations dip moderately to steeply away from the margins of the neighbouring dome, and the stratigraphic units concordantly wrap the domes.
Post-tectonic (non-foliated) granitoids, discordant pegmatites and east-west striking mafic dykes have intruded the above-mentioned rocks.

Regional metamorphic grade increases southwards through the district, from the lowest of grades in the Marda Complex, to quite high grade in the vicinity of Marvel Loch, and falls to low grade at Ravensthorpe.
There is also a tendency for metamorphic grade to increase outwards towards the margins of the belt.
2 A consistent regional lithological layering, which is believed to have stratigraphic significance, is evident from the distribution of rock types around the granite domes.

In a few localities, at the lowermost stratigraphic level is a thin interval of quartz-muscovite schist and quartzite which occurs in sheared contact with the gneissic granitoid on the western side of the Ghooli Dome.
It is possible this is a basal sedimentation unit deposited on a stable basement; however this relationship has never been established.
This unit is overlain in a structural sense by a thick mafic unit.
Wherever unequivocal pillow facings have been documented in massive relatively undeformed tholeiitic basalt, they show facing away from the granite domes.
This supports the gross stratigraphic interpretation.
However, detailed mapping supported by detailed magnetics, has shown the presence of many isoclinal folds within the mafic unit, especially in the layer-parallel shear zones.

Detailed mapping shows that in the Southern Cross-Marvel Loch area there appears to be a general pattern of; Pillowed tholeiitic basalt with thin jaspilite layers at a lower stratigraphic level Komatiite, probably with interflow sedimentary units, which hosts at least one intrusive sill showing varied peridotite, pyroxenite and gabbro phases.
Overlying the mafic unit is a thick unit of pelitic metasediments presumably metamorphosed greywacke and shale.

Where not disturbed by faulting, the contact between the mafic and sedimentary unit is characterised by interlayered ferruginous chert and chlorite-garnet schist with sulphides.At Mt Caudan this horizon is massive sulphide.
This iron-rich layer is interpreted to be a volcanogenic transitional unit between the mafic and sedimentary sequence, with exhalative features.
The continuity of this same thick upper metasedimentary sequence well to the south into the Forrestania area is clearly established.
Gold mineralisation in the region usually occurs with sulphide bearing quartz, localised by both structural and stratigraphic controls (Bagas, 1994).
Host lithologies include mafic, ultramafic, BIF and sediment hosts.

Work completed on the Licence included: interrogation of the database inherited from Polaris and International Goldfields compilation of historical data, aeromagnetics and geology to select gold and nickel targets field visits to determine access and check regional geology Interpretation of geology and aeromagnetic images (figures 2 and 3) shows the licence is traversed by three magnetic units 400-700m apart.
The western magnetic unit correlates with Dulcie West, an auger soil anomaly identified by CRAE.
The Dulcie West Prospect, after infill sampling, returned a peak soil result of 3.58 g/t Au.
The anomaly extends over approximately 2km at the 32ppb level.
Subsequent RAB drilling by CRA (3 traverses, 800m apart) returned a best result of 6m@0.5g/t Au.
Follow up RC drilling on 400m spaced lines returned a maximum of 2m@1.17 g/t Au.
This drilling is considered to be too wide spaced to be an effective test and Dulcie West is considered a high priority drill target by Southern Cross Goldfields Ltd. 5 6 7
APPENDIX NUMBER TITLE 1 Vacuum Drill Hole Locations and Assays 1.0 SUMMARY E38/1585 "Adam Range" encloses a poorly-exposed greenstone belt situated 25 km northeast of Laverton, W.A.
Only about 1.0 km strike of the belt is exposed in lateritised subcrops in the northern part tenement, though it is magnetically interpreted to extend to the north under deep transported regolith.

The tenement was acquired for its potential to host gold mineralisation associated with structural targets derived from aeromagnetic interpretation, and Windarra-type nickel sulphide targets associated with ultramafic components of the greenstone belt.
Except for a single reconnaissance rock chip sample which assayed 9.4 gm/t Au, there is no known gold or other mineralisation within the tenement.
The structural targets were tested by a base-of-hardpan vacuum drilling programme.
Some of the holes did not reach bedrock due to transported regolith.
The vacuum drill geochemistry at the northern end of the tenement defined a linear 10-18 ppb Au anomaly, as well as several Cu-Ni-Pt-Pd anomalies associated with ultramafics.
Drill results showed the greenstone belt included a 250m-wide talccarbonate/serpentinite ultramafic between granites to the west and metabasalts to the east.

Surface gold anomalism is related to lateral dispersion along ferricrete horizons, and is interpreted to represent supergene dispersion around steep-dipping higher grade mineralisation in ultramafics which was not intersected by the reconnaissance drilling.
The gold anomalism occurs as two en echelon north-striking zones separated by offset along the east-west fault, and is open to the north.
Nickel, copper, platinum and palladium showed supergene effects in weathered and oxidised parts of the profile, their values diminishing in fresh rock.
No coincidence of these elements that might indicate sulphides could be unequivocally demonstrated in the assay results.

Although no nickel targets were specifically determined the limited drilling did not test the entire width of the main ultramafic body, and that further potential exists for exploration along internal discontinuities between sub-units.
A study is proposed combining ground magnetics with careful re-logging of drill cuttings to determine such discontinuities.
2.0 TENEMENT DETAILS E38/1585 "Adam Range" consisting of 11 graticular blocks was granted on 22nd March, 05 to Image Resources NL.
The year 1 work programme and expenditure were met by Troy Resources NL who have executed a JV agreement to earn a 60% interest in the tenement with Image Resources NL being the operators.

3.0 LOCATION AND ACCESS The tenement is situated 25 km north-east of Laverton, in the NE Yilgarn province of W.A., and is accessible via the formed gravel Laverton-Cosmo Newberry Road (now called the Great Central Road) which passes to the north of the tenement.
The principle area of interest is south of the main road.
Some secondary access is provided by a pastoral tracks though grid lines had to be cleared to provide access for drilling equipment.
The tenement lies within the Laverton Downs pastoral lease.
4.0 GEOLOGICAL SETTING Much of E38/1585 is covered by sandplain comprising indurated transported and residual regolith, mainly overlying Archaean granitoids which are traversed by major NW faults.
The majority of bedrock outcrops occur in the north of the tenement, comprising foliated to massive granites, variably weathered at surface, and capped by silcrete.
A 500m-wide north-striking greenstone belt is present in the northern part of the tenement, comprising talc-carbonate ultramafics, serpentinites, minor cherty BIF, and amphibolites to the east.
The belt is poorly exposed in lateritised subcrops along 1 km of strike to the south of the Great Central Road.
5.0 MINERALISATION Except for a single reconnaissance rock chip sample ARR-8 which assayed 9.4 gm/t Au there is no known mineralisation within E38/1585.
The nearest known gold occurrences are at Fairfield, some 5 km to the west; Cork Tree Well 16 km to the NW, and Black Label 11 km to the SSE.
All lie along separate but parallel greenstone belts to those which pass through the tenement.

6.0 RECENT EXPLORATION HISTORY Earlier exploration on E38/1585, probably for nickel during the 1960's, is evident from the ruins of an old camp site, a large overgrown airstrip, trenches in laterite, and several old vertical percussion holes in ultramafics.
No Open File exploration reports have been sighted to date.
An old surveyed corner bearing the numbers MC 4924 to 4927 may assist in locating such data.
Minor historic gold prospecting is evident from an old trench located at AMG 453880E/6853250N, across a BIF/sediment/ultramafic contact zone.
During 1993-1996 the tenement area was included in E38/553 held by CRA Exploration where minor patchy gold mineralisation was reported along a granite/greenstone contact.
7.0 EXPLORATION 2005-2006 Based on analysis of magnetic trends and intersections with inferred structural features, a total of 11 target areas were identified in the area.
These targets were tested by a shallow base-of-hardpan vacuum drill sampling by Davlyn Contracting, using a tractor-mounted vacuum drill rig, fitted with a front blade to clear its own access.
Davlyn were provided with a list of AMG-coordinated drill sites along east-west lines spaced at 200m to 400m with holes at 50m intervals.
Some of the drill lines meandered because of obstacles such as dense scrub belts, and a levee bank constructed for flood control purposes.
All samples were assayed for ppb-level gold, with selective follow-up assays for Cu, Ni, Pt and Pd where a potential for base metals was inferred.
This work did not have geological supervision, and a subsequent examination of drill spoils showed that a consistent hardpan layer was only in places a feature of the local terrain.
Some of the holes ended in identifiable bedrock, while many others, ended in deep transported regolith without having reached bedrock.
The Central Anomaly target corresponds to the 1.2 km-long belt of subcropping greenstones in the north-central part of the tenement, south of the main road.
A 1.0 km linear 10-18 ppb gold anomaly was indicated, as well as several Cu-Ni-Pt-Pd anomalies within a broad nickel zone which corresponds to identifiable ultramafic rocks in drill spoils.
8.0 GEOLOGY The geology as interpreted from vacuum drill and old RAB drill cuttings comprises a greenstone sequence striking slightly west of north, and bounded by granite to the west.
The greenstone sequence includes an ultramafic unit some 250 metres wide consisting of talc-carbonate rock and serpentinite sub-units, bounded by narrow (50m wide) metabasalt belts to east and west.
Thin BIFs occur along some internal contacts within the sequence, probably with some associated sediments.
The greenstone sequence is interpreted to be offset by about 100m along an east-west dextral fault situated to the south of line AMG 6854000mN, near the northern limit of bedrock exposure.
The greenstones are poorly exposed in shallow lateritised subcrops.
9.0 FIELD WORK CONDUCTED DURING 2005-2006 A program of vacuum drilling and geological reconnaissance was conducted to test the aeromagnetic targets generated earlier.
Results of this work are included in Appendix 1.

Previous RC drilling at Emull proved +1% Zn and +0.5% Cu lenses within a broader +0.1% Cu-Zn envelope was open at depths up to 150m vertical and remained open along strike.

The focus of this drill season was to determine if high grade Cu-Zn feeder zones exist at depth, define strike extent and improve the understanding of controls on mineralisation to assist in geological modelling with the ultimate aim of outlining a resource.
Ten RC drill holes for 2807m (08RBC091-100; 2807 samples) were completed on the Southern, Central and South Eastern zones and are the deepest drilled to date; up to 280m vertical.
Drill cuttings were collected at 1m intervals in a calico bag from a levelled static cone splitter which was operated correctly and cleaned at least every 6m.
Calicos were placed in green plastic bags and sent to Ultra Trace Pty Ltd in Perth for analysis.
Remaining drill cuttings were placed in numbered green plastic bags and stacked in rows then folded-over for protection from weather.
Drill collars were plugged on completion of drilling.
Samples were sorted, dried to 100oC, split where necessary and pulverised in a vibrating disc pulveriser.
Samples were then analysed for Au, Pt, Pd by firing a 40 gm portion of the sample and determined by ICP-OES.
Remainder were digested and refluxed with a mixture of acids including Hydrofluoric, Nitric, Hydrochloric and Perchloric.
This extended digest approaches a Total digest for many elements however some refractory minerals are not completely attacked.
Ag, Pb were determined by ICP-MS and Cu, Zn, Ni, Co, Cr by ICPOES.
Further results are shown in Table 5.
Anomalous Cu-Zn intercepts were returned from up to 250m vertical; remaining open at depth for all zones and open along strike to the west for the Southern and Central zones.
Unfortunately, the high grade zinc lenses previously intercepted at depths of 100-150m vertical were rarely encountered below this level, with Cu values also generally lower.
Controls on mineralisation are now better understood:

LIST OF APPENDICES Appendix 1 Drill Data Appendix 2 Surface Sample Data 1.0 SUMMARY Red Billabong project, Emull Prospect, consists of one exploration licence 80/2612 which totals 7 graticules and 22 km2.
This report details exploration activities completed by Northern Star Resources Ltd between 8th April 2008 7th April 2009 (2009 reporting period).
The tenement is 45km WSW of Halls Creek (district population, 3,300) which lies on the sealed Great Northern Highway between Broome (690km to the west) and Kununurra (370km to the north).
Most of the tenement area lies over the laterite and alluvium covered Nicholson Plain along the Margaret River.

Because of the poor exposure of basement rocks, the region has attracted very little exploration effort in the past, but has subcrop and geophysical signatures suggesting the occurrence of mafic-ultramafic intrusions with potential for base metal sulphide and platinum group metal (PGM) mineralisation.

Exploration activities for the 2009 reporting period were focused on determining if high grade Cu-Zn feeder zones exist at depth; define strike extent; and improve the understanding of controls on mineralisation to assist in geological modelling with the ultimate aim of outlining a resource.
Ten RC drill holes for 2807m (08RBC091-100; 2807 samples) were completed on the Southern, Central and South Eastern zones.
Significant Cu-Zn intercepts occurred in the first 150 vertical metres, but beneath this, mineralisation was severely depleted.
Strike extent of mineralisation was widened and remains open.
Re-assaying of 2008 RC drilling (345 samples) resulted in a correlation defined between Au and Cu-Zn-Ag-Pb in high grade Zn-Cu zones.
Available RC drill chips need to be re-logged to achieve lithological consistency and define structures, which will be used to aid interpretation.
QAQC data also needs to be collated and validated.
Once interpretation and validation is completed, a resource estimate needs to be calculated and information required (if any) to achieve the resource estimate needs to be gathered.
Further RC drilling is required at Emull to define strike extent of mineralisation to the west of the Southern and Central Zones.
Diamond drilling to assist in structural interpretation and orientation of mineralisation is also required.
Rock chip programs (20 samples) over the Emull and Lamboo Platinum prospects did not return any significant gold, base metal or PGM values.
Chromite values at Lamboo were high but horizons are too thin and discontinuous and are thus unlikely to be economic.
A number of field reconnaissance trips were completed to familiarise the new geological and corporate team with the project.
Assessment of the Eagle Hawk Crossing prospect did not define any areas of significance for gold, base metals and PGMs.
This area should be relinquished.
Evaluation of the region NW of Emull returned no exploration targets and it is recommended this portion of the tenement is also surrendered.

2.0 INTRODUCTION This report summarises exploration activities completed by Northern Star Resources Ltd (NST) on EL80/2612 (Red Billabong Project, Emull Prospect) for the annual reporting period 8th April 2008 to 7th April 2009 (2009 reporting period).

The tenement is centred approximately 45km WSW of Halls Creek (district population 3,300); a town which lies on the sealed Great Northern Highway between Broome (690km to the west) and Kununurra (370km to the north); Figure 1.
The Emull prospect consists of one exploration licence which underwent a voluntary partial surrender registered on 27/03/09.
Table 1 shows tenement details prior to surrender and Table 1.
Tenement details prior to voluntary surrender.

EL80/2612 was previously held by Biscay Resources Pty Ltd, a Western Australian unlisted private company with agreements dated 6 May 2002.
NST, having earned 100% and Biscay retaining a 1% net smelter return on all tenements, are managers and holders of all tenements, as at 18 November 2005.
Combined reporting status was granted for the project area (C 12/2004); however due to surrender of the other tenements, this was dissolved.

The tenement is subject to agreements between NST / Biscay Resources Pty Ltd and the Kimberley Land Council Aboriginal Corporation for and on behalf of the various Native Title Claimant Groups, as outlined in Table 3.

The agreements, dated 24 April 2002, and 4 June 2004, set out the agreed Heritage Protection and Work Clearance protocols for conducting exploration on the tenements and undertakings in regard to ongoing clearance and exploration work.
Native Title Claimant Groups covering E80/2612.
Claimant areas are shown in Figure 3.

During the first year of the project area a data base consisting of all published geological reports and maps and considerable unpublished material recording exploration work in the region from the 1960s to the present time has been compiled with much data digitised and available in interactive Geographical Information System format.
Summaries of relevant open file statutory reports have been made cross referenced with the Western Australian Mineral Exploration (WAMEX) database.
A detailed low level airborne magnetic survey was completed, covering nearly the entire tenement on NW-SE lines at approximately 100m spacing and 40m terrain clearance.
This is markedly better than the previously best survey of 1.5 km spacing and 150m terrain clearance.
Field reconnaissance of the area confirmed the poor exposure of basement lithologies and the anomalous base metal nature of the Emull stratigraphy.
The limited rock chip sampling at Emull did not generate any significant platinoid values.
Exploration activities for the second year of the project reporting period were dominated by the pursuit of base metal targets in the largely covered terrain.

To this goal, an airborne electromagnetic (AEM) survey (HoisTEM) over targets generated from the processing and evaluation of the detailed low level magnetic data acquired by the Company last year was completed.
The aim of the AEM survey was to identify conductors associated with base metal mineralisation.
The survey comprised three areas covering portions of the tenement; Red Billabong 3 - 246 line kms and Red Billabong 4 - 234 line kms.
The HoisTEM survey was completed on NW-SE lines at approximately 100m spacing and 35m terrain clearance.
A number of anomalous responses were generated and these targeted for evaluation.
Field reconnaissance of the area was undertaken to define base metal targets.
Soil traverses were completed to determine precious metal (gold-PGE) as well as base metal prospectively.
Anomalous gold and base metal results were returned.

Reconnaissance aircore / RAB drilling was undertaken over targets generated from the processing and evaluation of the magnetic and from the airborne electromagnetic (AEM) survey data to identify base metal and or precious metal mineralisation.
RC drilling (RBC001 to 005, 429m) tested the eastern end of the Emull Zinc mineralisation.
A single RC hole (RBC-007, 48m) also tested for platinum mineralisation at the bond prospect.
Anomalous base metal results were returned.

In addition a surface gradient Induced Polarisation (IP) survey was completed in order to define economic zinc mineralisation and also any sulphide mineralisation (Pt or Ni/Cu) that may be associated with mafic / ultramafic lithologies.
Field reconnaissance including geochemical sampling continued in order to define base metal and precious metal targets.
A number of anomalous responses were generated.
Aircore / RAB / RC drilling was undertaken to identify base metal and or precious metal mineralisation.
RC drilling (RBC023 to 025, 479m) also tested the eastern end of the Emull Zinc mineralisation.
A small programme of shallow auger drilling (27 holes for 91m) tested a line of quartz veining associated with the Springvale Fault to the east of Emull.
The mineralisation previously intersected at the Golden Eye was not replicated.
Some platinum mineralisation was intersected at Bond prospect but not of the same order seen previously.

Field reconnaissance and geochemical sampling (stream sediment sampling, including BLC, -80# and panned concentrates) of selected parts of the project area also continued in order to define base metal and or precious metal targets.
Areas targeted included the Emull Gabbro and Eaglehawk Gabbro to the south.
A number of anomalous responses were generated around the Emull Gabbro.
Rock chip and soil samples (-80#) were also taken to test for the surface expression of any mineralisation within the eastern margin of the Emull area and the Emull Gabbro.
Within the Emull area the Company is exploring for high grade zinc shoots within a broadly drilled mineralised zone which is some 500m long and 50m, hosted by the Emull gabbro.

A drill program at Emull consisting of 59 RC holes for 5418m (RBC026-037, 045-090) was completed with the aim of improving the understanding of structural / lithological controls on Zn-Cu-Pb-Ag-Au mineralisation; in particular the high grade plunging zinc shoots.
Significant intercepts are presented in Table 4.
The assay results also reveal a more complex nature to the south-eastern area.
Base metal mineralisation, including elevated copper values up to 2.95%, appear to occur within a number of sub-parallel lenses.

Elevated gold values associated with base metal values were returned from a structurally complex area within the south-eastern shoot, including 3m @ 3.3g/t Au (0.53% Zn, 0.83% Cu, 1.78% Pb, 75 g/t Ag).
Geology logs are currently not available in digital form.
These will be released in the 2010 Annual Report.
Further evaluation of platinum potential within the poorly outcropping Lamboo Ultramafics continued, with 6 RC drill holes (RBC039-044) for 493m completed over a strike length of 400m.
Geology logs are currently not available.
These will be released in the 2010 Annual Report.

Stream sediment sampling was carried out over the Eaglehawk Crossing area (south west portion of E80/2612) and covers the informally named Eaglehawk Crossing Gabbro where approximately 10km2 of outcrop are exposed and a further 4km2 probably subcrops beneath black soil and alluvium.
Outcrop is generally poor.
A total of 56 magnetic lag samples were collected (NSS306813-NSS306872) from stream tributaries largely flowing into the Margaret River.
No significant results were returned.
A total of 47 rock chip samples were collected (NSX601585-623, NSX601640-647); targeting gossanous outcrop at the Emull Zinc Prospect and also gabbro outcrop at the Eagle Hawk Prospect.
No significant results were returned from Eagle Hawk Crossing.
Rock chip assay results from Emull zinc helped define the extent of mineralisation and aided in RC drill planning.
7.0 WORK COMPLETED: 2009 Reporting Period The Exploration Index summarising activities over the tenements is shown in Figure 6.
RC drilling at Emull during the 2008 reporting period returned high grade gold values (up to 3m @ 3.3g/t Au) associated with higher grade Zn-Cu-Pb-Ag values.
These were returned from a structurally complex area within the south-eastern zone.
Given the majority of drill samples had not been assayed for gold, it was decided to re-assay high grade Cu-Zn zones to determine the distribution and significance of gold values.
Cu, Zn and Pb were also reassayed, to check original values.
Ni was assayed to aid in differentiating mafic and ultramafic units, which are difficult to distinguish apart in places.
Three to five kilograms of drill cuttings were collected from existing 1m interval green plastic sample bags using a spear and placed in a calico bag.
Care was taken to achieve a representative sample from top to bottom of the green bag.
Calicos were placed in green plastic bags and sent to Ultra Trace Pty Ltd in Perth for analysis.
A total of 345 samples were taken.
Samples were sorted, dried to 100oC, split where necessary and pulverised in a vibrating disc pulveriser.
Samples were then analysed for Au, Pt, Pd by firing a 40 gm portion of the sample and determined by ICP-OES.
Remainder were digested and refluxed with a mixture of acids including Hydrofluoric, Nitric, Hydrochloric and Perchloric.
This extended digest approaches a Total digest for many elements however some refractory minerals are not completely attacked.
Ag, Pb were determined by ICP-MS and Cu, Zn, Ni, Co, Cr by ICPOES.
There was a strong correlation between Au values and Cu-Zn values.
Cu-Zn-Pb-Ag values also correlated well with the original assays.
Assay results are located in Appendix 1.
The reader is referred to the 2008 annual report for drill hole information related to these assays.
Evaluation of the Eagle Hawk Crossing Prospect was completed, including collation of geochemical programs.
No areas of interest were defined.
Areas to the NW of Emull where aircore / RAB / RC drilling had occurred were also assessed.
Although some individual loworder anomalies were outlined, there were no areas of significance defined.
8.0 CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS Information from RC drilling this reporting period suggests that Zn-Cu mineralisation depletes at depth.
Therefore, resource estimation should be focused on the higher grade shallow mineralisation.
Available RC drill chips need to be re-logged to achieve lithological consistency and define structures, which will be used to aid interpretation.
QAQC data also needs to be collated and validated.
Once interpretation and validation is completed, a resource estimate needs to be calculated and information required (if any) to achieve a resource estimate needs to be gathered.
Further RC drilling is required at Emull to define strike extent of mineralisation to the west of the Southern and Central Zones.
Diamond drilling to assist in structural interpretation and orientation of mineralisation is also required.
Assessment of the Eagle Hawk Crossing prospect did not define any areas of significance for gold, base metals and PGMs.
This area should be relinquished.
Evaluation of the region NW of Emull returned no exploration targets and it is recommended this portion of the tenement is also surrendered.
RC geology logs from the 2008 reporting period still need entering digitally.
These need to be reported in the 2010 reporting period.

At least two significant mineral occurrences are known within or near Red Billabong.
The Emull base metal occurrence within the E80/2612 tenement area is hosted by altered and contact metamorphosed calc-silicate rocks, which have been partially assimilated by the Emull gabbro.
The deposit was recognised as a series of copper stained, siliceous gossans located adjacent to the contact between the Emull gabbro and felsic volcanic rocks of the Koongie Park Formation.
Thin semi-massive and disseminated mineralisation is confined to 4 discontinuous but apparently stratabound lenses, dominated by sphalerite, with subordinate chalcopyrite and galena.
The largest lens has a strike length of 500m and a maximum width of 50m.

The genesis of mineralisation at Emull is not certain, although models based on an origin as a volcanic hosted massive sulphide (VHMS) deposit partially assimilated during intrusion of gabbro, or as a skarn developed during intrusion of gabbro into carbonate units within the Koongie Park Formation, have been proposed.
A second prospect of similar character, Location 5, is located approximately 800m northwest of Emull.
Volcanogenic massive sulphide mineralisation is well documented within Koongie Park Formation sediments and volcanics northeast of Emull.
Base metal occurrences at Sandiego, Hanging Tree, Onedin, Gosford and Atlantis (referred to as the Koongie Park deposits) have been identified with 2 Mineral Resources estimated in 2009.
Primary sulphide zone: copper zone Cu >0.8%; mized zone, zinc zone Zn >3%).

Within these deposits, metal zonation within massive sulphide lenses characteristic of VHMS deposits is preserved at Sandiego and Onedin, where lead-zinc lenses overlie both massive and stringer copper mineralisation.
The ore occurs in massive, breccia, banded and stringer form, commonly in steeply plunging shoots aligned parallel to the axes of isoclinal folds.
The Emull program focused on weakly gossanous malachite azurite ferruginous outcrop with iron staining from oxidised sulphides.

The Lamboo Platinum program targeted thin moderately weathered and oxidised chromite rich zones in the segregated Lamboo Ultramafic sequence, near 2006 RC drilling which returned up to 3m @ 1.9 g/t (Au+Pt+Pd) from 38m (RBC042).
Rock chips were collected over a small unspecified area using a geo hammer, placed in calico bags and sent to Ultra Trace Pty Ltd in Perth for analysis.
Samples were sorted, dried to 100oC, split where necessary and pulverised in a vibrating disc pulveriser.
Samples were then analysed for Au, Pt, Pd by firing a 40 gm portion of the sample and determined by ICP-OES.
Remainder were digested and refluxed with a mixture of acids including Hydrofluoric, Nitric, Hydrochloric and Perchloric.
This extended digest approaches a total digest for many elements however some refractory minerals are not completely attacked.
Ag, Pb, As, Sb, Bi were determined by ICP-MS and Cu, Zn, Ni, Co, Cr, Mn, V, Ca, Fe by ICP-OES.
No significant results were returned from the Emull Program.
Seven samples from the Lamboo Platinum program returned +1% chromite, with a maximum of 17.3% Cr and 0.2% Zn (NSX601819).
Although this is high, the chromite-rich horizons are thin (<0.5m) and discontinuous both vertically and horizontally; therefore are unlikely to be economic.
Figure 8 shows rock chip location and Appendix 2 contains rock chip location, assay and description.

Chromium and platinum group metals in the Lamboo Ultramafics in the extreme south-eastern tenement area have been explored by surface prospecting and drilling and are shown to be confined principally to chromitite layers in the lower zone of the intrusive complex.
The chromitite layers which are thin, 5-150cm thick, are continuous along strike for up to 4 km and values of up to 0.3ppm Pt and 42ppm Pd have been obtained from drill core.
Approximately 1 km2 of the ultramafic intrusion lies within the tenement including recorded Mineral Occurrences 5116, 6162 and 5117 (Cr, PGE).

These occurrences and the layered ultramafic chromitite mineralisation model probably are not a high priority target at this time, but could take a higher priority should exploration provide significant new evidence of economic mineralisation in adjacent areas of the Lamboo Ultramafics or other similar East Kimberley intrusions.

Although no mining activity is currently in progress in the Red Billabong region, reasonably intensive past exploration has resulted in identification of a diverse range of mineralisation and sub-economic deposits.
Hassan (2000) reports more than 90 Mineral Occurrences (MOs) in the tenement region.
Those falling within the tenement mostly lie within a relatively confined area in the central and eastern area (Figure 5).
Known mineralisation within and around the tenement can be summarised as follows;

The Kimberley region has been prospected and explored since 1884 when Edward Hardman, Government geologist attached to the Kimberley Survey Expedition of 1884, found auriferous quartz reefs and alluvial gold over a large area of the East Kimberley (Hardman.

1885) In 1885, using Hardmans maps and report, the prospecting party of Charles Hall and John Slattery discovered payable gold near Old Halls Creek and precipitated a gold rush that led to the proclamation in May 1886 of the Kimberley as the first gold field in Western Australia.

It is generally considered that most of the historical gold production of the area was never recorded (official production to 1964 totalled 1056.8 kg), but none-the-less, rich auriferous alluvials and quartz reefs were rapidly worked out and miners turned progressively south to discover goldfields in the Pilbara, Murchison, Southern Cross, Coolgardie and Kalgoorlie districts.

Little mineral exploration or development took place in the Kimberley until the 1950s when the Bureau of Mineral Resources carried out an airborne radiometric survey over part of the region and prompted considerable activity by companies searching for uranium deposits.

Trend Exploration in the course of investigating a radiometric anomaly, discovered what has now become the Brockman specialty metal deposit, 16 km south-east of Halls Creek, containing economically significant niobium, tantalum, zirconium, yitrium and other REE.
Gold exploration over the past 20 years has defined potentially economic quartz stockwork mineralisation around old workings at Mt Bradley, Palm Springs and Nicholsons Find.
In 1995 Precious Metals Australia commenced operations at the Palm Springs Mine and Nicholsons Find and produced 2272 kg of gold before shutting down operations in 1997 due to falling gold prices.

Diamonds discovered in the northern Kimberley in 1973 was followed by intensive exploration that lead to the discovery of the Ellendale diamondiferous pipes in the west Kimberley in 1977 and Argyle in 1979.
The Argyle mine (Rio Tinto) continues to operate as the worlds largest single producer of diamonds and produced 90-95% of the worlds rare pink diamonds.
The Ellendale mine (Gem Diamonds) is currently operating and produces about 50% of the worlds rare fancy and vivid yellow diamonds.
Exploration for other commodities has been successful in defining resources of nickelcopper (Sally Malay), base metals (Koongie Park), and platinum group metals (Panton).

Geological mapping of the east Kimberley at 1:250,000 scale was first carried out between 1962 and 1977 as a joint program by the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) and the Bureau of Mineral Resources (BMR).
The BMR was renamed the Australian Geological Survey Organisation (AGSO) in 1993 and since 2001 is now known as Geoscience Australia.

A Bulletin on the geology of the east Kimberley and its mineral occurrences was compiled by Dow and Gemuts (1969) and Gemuts (1971) described the metamorphic and igneous rocks of the Lamboo Complex, the main mineralized geological unit of the East Kimberley.
During the period 1990-1995, part of the area was re-mapped at 1:100,000 and 1:250,000 scale by the GSWA and AGSO as part of the National Geoscience Mapping Accord, Kimberley-Arunta Project.

This work, which included whole-rock geochemical, petrological, geochronological, and remote-sensing studies resulted in a fundamental re-appraisal of the geological evolution of the region and vastly improved understanding of the geological setting and mode of occurrence of known and potential economic mineralisation.
Most of the tenement area lies over the alluvium covered Nicholson plain between the seasonally flowing Margaret and Laura river systems.
The region is gently undulating and relatively featureless.
Vegetation over much of the lateritic soil areas consists of low to medium density low scrub.
The remainder of the region is vegetated principally by low tree savannah with patches of spinifex and short grass.
Irregular patches and plains of black soil support only grass.
The climate is semi-arid monsoonal with rainfall between 350 and 400mm per annum occurring during the humid wet season between November and April.
Temperatures during the summer are hot (often greater than 40C) and accompanied by high humidity, while dry season temperatures are warm to hot with low humidity.
Because of extreme heat, unpredictable thunderstorms, and occasional cyclonic rainfall events, the months from December to April are essentially impractical for access and field work.

3.0 REGIONAL GEOLOGY Figure 4 shows the main tectonostratigraphic subdivisions of the of the East Kimberley region, and in particular, the outline of the Halls Creek Orogen, a major regional zone of deformation lying along the suture between the Kimberley Craton which underlies the Palaeoproterozoic Kimberley Basin to the northwest, and the North Australian Craton to the east.
Development of the Halls Creek Orogen began in the Palaeoproterozoic and tectonic activity continued intermittently into the Palaeozoic.

The Lamboo Complex lies at the core of the Halls Creek Orogen as a Palaeoproterozoic (1920-1780Ma) composite, linear belt consisting of variably deformed and metamorphosed sedimentary, volcanic and intrusive rocks.
The Lamboo Complex and onlapping Palaeoproterozoic sedimentary basins were deformed in the course of the 1835-1805 Ma Halls Creek Orogeny.
The Lamboo Complex as defined and described by Griffin and Tyler (1992) and Tyler et al, (1997) is subdivided into three roughly parallel, NNE trending zones; the Eastern, Central and Western zones.

Each has a distinct stratigraphy and history of deformation and metamorphism which leads to the interpretation that they are tectonostratigraphic terranes brought into their current locations by a combination of subduction and large-scale intrusion by masses of granitic and gabbroic magma.

Distinctly different geophysical signatures of the crust on either side of the Lamboo Complex and dating of deformation events has lead to an interpretation that the Central zone was a discrete crustal block accreted to the Kimberley Craton along the trace of the Springvale Fault at the time of the Hooper Orogeny (1865-1850 Ma).

Later collision with the North Australian Craton resulted in the Halls Creek Orogeny (1835-1805 Ma) and suturing of the Central zone and Eastern zone along the present-day trace of the Halls Creek Fault.
The Emull tenement falls within the Central zone.

4.0 LOCAL GEOLOGY The tenement area is virtually devoid of basement rock outcrop, the greater part of the region being a gently undulating plateau of Cainozoic laterite weakly dissected by the Margaret and Laura Rivers with thin alluvial deposits along shallow valleys.
Colluvial soils of sand silt and gravel overly the laterite, and mantle low angle escarpment-retreat slopes along broad valleys where erosion has destroyed the laterite hard-cap.
Small plains of black soils occur in areas of poor drainage relief and along the banks of the Margaret River, particularly where underlain by mafic parent rock.

Although much of the basement geology is obscured, interpretation of underlying basement lithology can be made in places where surface geological mapping can be integrated with soil and laterite characteristics distinguishable on aerial photographs.

The geology with major faults and lineaments are shown on Figure 5; most of the information is derived from the Angelo 1:100,000 map sheet (Griffin et al 1998) plus some interpretation based on magnetic data.
The oldest rocks exposed in the Western zone are metamorphosed turbiditic sandstone, siltstone and mudstone of the Marboo Formation deposited between 1870 Ma and 1858 Ma.
The Formation is interpreted to exist in subcrop north and north-west of the tenement.
The Western zone was subjected to the Hooper Orogeny (1865-1850Ma) which resulted in folding and greenschist facies regional metamorphism of the Marboo Formation.
Further to the west, metamorphism was stronger and gneisses were derived from Marboo Formation sediments and intrusive granodiorite.
The oldest rocks in the Central zone belong to the Koongie Park Formation which on the basis of recent zircon dating now includes rocks formerly mapped as Tickalara Metamorphics.

The formation is composed of metamorphosed mafic volcanic rocks, felsic volcanic and volcaniclastic rocks with turbiditic sandstone, laminated siltstone and mudstone, and thin chert layers interbedded with carbonate and iron-formation layers.
The Koongie Park Formation outcrops on parts of the tenement and is host to NSTs Emull prospect mineralisation.
(It should be noted that the Angelo 1:100,000 map sheet still uses the old Tickalara terminology).
The Lamboo Ultramafics form a NNE-trending elliptical intrusion about 6km long and 2-3km wide and a smaller intrusion (~1km2) some 3 km to the north in the extreme south-east area of E80/2612.
The intrusion has been the target of extensive exploration for Cr, PGE, Au, Ni and Cu mineralisation and is well summarized in Saunders (1999).
The Sally Downs supersuite consisting of extensive granitoid, massive gabbro and mingled gabbro-granitoid is believed to underlie much the area southeast of Margaret River.
Contacts between granitoid and gabbro are frequently complex and indicative of coeval mafic and felsic magmatism.

The Emull Gabbro is a NNE elongate intrusion approximately 15 km long by 7-8km wide occurring over a large potion of the tenement and its intrusion is probably associated with genesis of the Emull prospect base metal mineralisation.

Other areas of outcropping gabbro include the informally named Eaglehawk Crossing Gabbro in the extreme south of the tenement area where approximately 10km2 of outcrop are exposed and a further 4km2 probably subcrops beneath black soil and alluvium.
Immediately NW, the informally named Moola Bulla Complex and Amphitheatre Gabbro are possibly parts of a much larger intrusive complex.
Intrusion of the gabbro was possibly controlled by a major NNE trending fault along the Margaret River.

A large magnetic anomaly with no surface expression approximately 6km further north on the same fault may be sourced in a similar intrusion and a further 9km to the north on the same fault, patches of black soil either side of the Margaret River may be derived from underlying mafic intrusions.

The Halls Creek Orogeny commenced around 1835 Ma in the Eastern zone of the Lamboo complex, but in the Central zone and Western zones of the Lamboo Complex in the Red Billabong region only later phases are recorded as deformation and metamorphic overprints on the older rocks including intrusions of the Sally Downs supersuite.

Although sediments and mafic volcanics of the Palaeoproterozoic Kimberley Group are preserved both east and west of the tenement, they have probably been completely stripped by erosion within the tenement.

The Mesoproterozoic Yampi Orogeny is most strongly evident in the tenement area as a series of large scale, NNE trending series of sinistral strike-slip faults, initially developed in Palaeoproterozoic times along the Lamboo Complex zone boundaries and becoming more brittle in later re-activations.

Three phases of folding are evident in the Kimberley Group sediments and volcanics east of the tenement, but little evidence of the Orogeny is visible other than alignment of the Margaret and Laura Rivers and some of their larger tributaries along the major faults.
To the south, linear outcrops of Neoproterozoic Louisa Downs Group sediments butt against major faults.
The sediments include tillites and fluvioglacials becoming more marine in aspect higher in their succession.
Cambrian age conglomerate is conformably overlain by mafic extrusive flows of the Antrim Plateau Volcanics to the north / north west.
Cainozoic laterite occurs extensively throughout the tenement area, forming a plateau dissected by the Margaret River and its tributaries.
Erosion has reduced much of the laterite blanket into irregular remnants with low angle escarpments and stony surfaces.
Larger areas still retain a veneer of quartz sand and soil and shallow valleys contain thin colluvial deposits of reworked laterite gravel and sand.
Shallow alluvial sand and gravel occupies the valley of the Margaret River which closely follows the underlying trace of the Billabong and Margaret River Faults.
Patches of Black soil form small plains.

Some areas, such as those around the Emull Gabbro and the informally named Eaglehawk Crossing Gabbro and Mulla Bulla Complex, are clearly derived from the underlying mafic intrusions, but the origins of other occurrences is not so obvious.

5.0 EXPLORATION MODELS Locally, the most prospective search targets are considered to be; Polymetallic mineralisation (zinc, copper, lead, silver +/- gold) at Emull and Location 5 prospects hosted by sheared and faulted Koongie Park Formation in a contact zone with the Emull Gabbro intrusion.
High grade gold mineralisation similar to Nicholsons Find.
Potential exists within the eastern-most extension of EL80/2612 for further mineralisation at White Horse and Lamboo (Au1) and for discovery of additional occurrences.
Base metal and PGM/Au mineralisation associated with obscured mafic-ultramafic intrusions.
A primary selection criteria for the tenement application was the occurrence of geophysical anomalies indicative of the presence of mafic-ultramafic intrusions below alluvium and laterite.

Base and precious metal mineralisation associated with mafic-ultramafic intrusions may take several forms, but the major models considered by NST to hold most economic merit in the geographical and geological environment of the East Kimberley are; Sulphide segregation Ni-Cu-Co PGM deposits e.g.
: Voiseys Bay, Labrador, Canada : Norilsk Talnakh, Siberia : Sally Malay, East Kimberley, WA Structurally controlled hydrothermal polymetallic (PGM-Au) deposits e.g.

: Lac des Iles, Ontario, Canada : Coronation Hill, NT : Elizabeth Hill, Pilbara WA The term sulphide segregation Ni-Cu-CoPGM deposits is used here to encompass the range of genetic models described for numerous deposits, but all have in common the feature of sulphide melt separation from silica magma scavenging metals.

Models for specific deposits or groups of deposits discussed in the literature include; - Basal sulphide segregation Ni-Cu-CoPGM model - Feeder zone or magma conduit deposits - Deposits in mafic sills associated with flood basalts Structurally controlled hydrothermally-remobilised polymetallic deposits such as Lac des Iles in Ontario (Cu-Au-Ni-PGM), are not as well understood, but are probably derived by hydrothermal leaching of metals from large masses of brecciated mafic-ultramafic rock and deposition in breccias or structural dilation zones by mechanisms similar to the welldocumented Archaean gold deposits of WA.
They have not been a focus of past prospecting in the East Kimberley as the extent and variety of such deposits are only becoming apparent in recent years.

In addition, the routine geochemical detection of platinoids (and gold) at very low detection levels only became practical in the mid-1990s and associated gold mineralisation is usually very fine grained and not detectable by traditional prospecting.
For these reasons, such deposits are unlikely to have been identified in the past and remain a focus of exploration at Red Billabong.
6.0 EXPLORATION HISTORY AND MINERALISATION
Numerous field trips were completed to familiarise a new corporate and geological team with the Emull area.
Nickel-copper mineralisation in sulphide segregation deposits associated with maficultramafic intrusions is a principal target of the Red Billabong Project.

Geochemical anomalism is known in soils derived from dunites of the Lamboo Ultramafic intrusion which could be indicative of sulphide segregation mineralisation and MOs 2723 (Cu), and 5381 (Cu) occur in the same area.

Uranium-copper mineralisation at the Amphitheatre prospect west of the tenement is low grade, but meets some of the geological criteria for classification as Proterozoic sub-unconformity mineralisation, a model not likely to be applicable to E80/2612.
Exploration by NST is primarily targeted to explore for precious and base metal deposits associated with mafic-ultramafic intrusive complexes.
These include magmatic intrusive related sulphide segregation and structurally controlled hydrothermal polymetallic styles of deposits.
In addition, other base metal polymetallic resources, zinc, copper, lead and silver, as defined in the Emull and Location 5 areas of E80/2612 were targeted.
Other target types include high grade vein gold occurrences similar to the neighbouring Nicholsons Find.
The mine is currently on care and maintenance.
White Horse prospect (MO 6320) lies within the tenement 3km NE of Emull, where quartz reef outcrop has been assayed at 0.83 g/t Au and gossanous float at up to 3.29 g/t Au.
The gold mineralisation is interpreted to be fault-related in limonitic chlorite-carbonate-talc schist and not related to chromitite PGM mineralisation.
Gold is also known outside the tenement at Soda Springs some 20km WNW of Emull and at the Billabong prospect, some 4km SSE of Red Billabong Well.
Data gathering is underway for resource evaluation of the Emull Zn-Cu-Ag mineralisation.
The main aim of data gathering is to determine what further work is required to calculate a resource estimate.
Initial validation shows logging of lithology is not consistent and thus interpretation is difficult.

Swager, C.P., 1994, Geology of the Kurnalpi 1:100,000 Sheet an explanatory note: Western Australia Geological Survey, 1p.
This report details exploration undertaken on P28/1031 by Carrick Gold Limited for the period ending 12 July 2009.
The Kurnalpi Project is in the Eastern Goldfields of Western Australia, approximately 70 kilometres east northeast of Kalgoorlie.
Access to the tenements is via the sealed Yarri Road northeast from Kalgoorlie to the old Kanowna townsite, then east along the Kurnalpi-Pinjin Road.
This road is well maintained and cuts through much of the tenement group.

The Kurnalpi Property is located on the Norseman-Wiluna greenstone belt, an Archaean sequence of ultramafic, mafic, intermediate and acid intrusive and extrusive volcanic rocks with associated sediments.
The greenstone belt trends north northwest with komatiitic ultramafic unit approximately 100m wide within a sequence of metabasic units.
Flanking the belt are major Archaean intrusive granitic bodies.
A review of data identified that North Limited completed an auger drill programme on its Exploration Licences 28/434 and 28/435.
From analysis of Norths assay results and the accompanying diagrams, it was evident that the interpreted structures and gold anomalism appeared to be located on E28/434 which is due west of E28/435.
Most assays on E28/435 returned values of between 0ppm and 9ppm; with some assays as high as 20ppm.
No significant soil anomalies appeared to be present on E28/435.
Future exploration of the tenement area should include further geochemical sampling to identify possible targets after which an aircore programme could/should be designed.

P28/1031 200 Ha 13 July 2006 Bushwin Pty Ltd. 3.0 GEOLOGY 3.1 Project Geology The Kurnalpi Property is located on the Norseman-Wiluna greenstone belt, an Archaean sequence of ultramafic, mafic, intermediate and acid intrusive and extrusive volcanic rocks with associated sediments.
The greenstone belt trends north northwest with komatiitic ultramafic unit approximately 100m wide within a sequence of metabasic units.
Flanking the belt are major Archaean intrusive granitic bodies.
The major structural feature of the property area is the north northwest trending Avoca Shear Zone that dips to the west.
On the western side of the shear zone, the bedrock sequence comprises basalts, komatiites, sediments and minor felsic volcanics.
To the east of the Avoca Shear, the sequence is dominated by basalt, dolerite and sediments and in the easternmost portions of the Kurnalpi property by felsic volcanic rocks.
Other faults of the area are orientated approximately parallel to the Avoca Shear Zone.

Late stage northeast trending faults cross cut the Avoca Shear Zone and east to east southeast trending thrust faults are interpreted as being present in the north to the south of an intrusive granite.
Tertiary and Quaternary deposits of various origins cover the bedrock sequence and dominate much of the area where outcrops are generally sparse.
Bedrock gold mineralisation is associated with the major Avoca Shear Zone and with the northeast trending faults.
Gold derived from the bedrock structures has entered the alluvial sequences and was a major source of the gold produced during the active mining period at Kurnalpi.
The gold was noted as being coarse grained and nuggety in distribution.
Nickel mineralisation is present mainly in the west of the Kurnalpi property where it is present both in the laterite weathering profile overlying ultramafic sequences and also in the bedrock.
Outcrop is poor over the project area due to deep weathering profiles and thin soils covering the over 95% of the bedrock.
A plan of the local geology (GSWA mapping) of the project area is shown in Figure 1.

4.1 Review of historical data A review of data identified that North Limited completed an auger drill programme on its Exploration Licences 28/435 and 28/434 [both dead; formed part of a combined report].

The former EL28/435 is now made up of several tenements including P28/1031 (HOLDER: Bushwin Pty Ltd.; beneficially held by Carrick Gold Limited), P28/1032 and P28/1034 (both Shannon Resources Ltd.; beneficially held by Carrick Gold Limited).
The auger drilling programme was conducted over two exploration licences: E28/434 and E28/435.
It was conducted on a 400m x 50m grid pattern.
Regolith types that were encountered were reported to have varied from sandy quartz-rich transported soils, lateritic duricrust and minor areas of residual saprock.
A strong pedogenic carbonate horizon was also encountered ranging in depth from surface to 1 metre with an average depth of 0.7m.
Several areas of elevated gold soil anomalism (10-40ppm on E28/434; 10-20ppm on E28/435) were detected that were reported to be broadly coincident with interpreted structures.
From analysis of Norths assay results and the accompanying diagrams, it was evident that the interpreted structures and gold anomalism appeared to be located on E28/434 which is due west of E28/435.
Most assays on E28/435 returned values of between 0ppm and 9ppm; with some assays as high as 20ppm.
No significant soil anomalies appeared to be present on E28/435.

5.0 CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS Future exploration of the tenement area should include further geochemical sampling to identify possible targets after which an aircore programme could/should be designed.

The Munglinup graphite prospects lie within Exploration Licence 74/308, which is held in the name of Adelaide Prospecting Pty Ltd and was granted on 16 August 2006 for a period of 5 years.
The landscape in the Munglinup region is one of moderate relief with well developed drainage channels.

On the surface, graphitic zones appear as more resistant horizons, generally forming slight elevated ridges characterised by magnesite Adelaide Prospecting Pty Ltd - 2 - development and grey-black soils.
In contrast, red-brown loamy soil develops over granulitic gneisses, giving rise to abrupt changes in soil colouration.
The graphite occurs in layers of metamorphosed carbonaceous schists and gneisses now comprising clays, quartz, graphite and goethite.
All intersections of graphite were intensely weathered, with enhanced weathering of the graphitic horizons in comparison to wallrocks.
Individual graphite horizons vary in thickness up to a maximum of 14m.
Adelaide Prospecting Pty Ltd - 4 - 3.

WORK COMPLETED DURING THE REPORTING PERIOD Field reconnaissance of previous mapping was completed to try and identify any extension into the tenement area of the ultramafics units to the north, to ascertain if the tenement had any potential for nickel-copper-gold.
A small metamorphosed ultramafic outcrop was noted by previous mapping some kilometres to the north- west and outside the tenement boundary.
It was concluded that the tenement area has no potential for nickel-copper.
Tenement boundaries and grid lines were tied in by GPS.
The tenement area was prospected using a Toyota Landcruiser where possible, but due to the presence of very thick scrub most of the tenement area had to be traversed on foot.
A number of samples were collected, taken back to the campsite, dollied and panned.
No economic minerals were observed.
Some samples were bagged and transported back to Perth.
On further inspection it was decided not to submit them for analysis, and they were subsequently discarded.
Exploration planning for the next field season will be aimed at increasing the existing uneconomic graphite resource, estimated to be 1.47 million tonnes @ 18.2% fixed carbon.
Several other areas within the tenement show excellent potential for further high grade graphite resources.
These areas will initially need costeaning, sampling and assaying, followed by RC drilling if it is considered that they have the potential to substantially add to the existing resource.
Prospecting also identified several areas of nodular magnesite.
These occurrences will be targeted in the coming field season.

The Munglinup graphite deposit is located 4 kilometres north of the small settlement of Munglinup, 105 kilometres west of Esperance in Western Australia.
Access from Esperance is via 107 kilometres of sealed highway to Munglinup, then gravel road and bush tracks across the Munglinup River.
The prospect is readily accessible by road and cleared grid lines with cross country driving inhibited by dense scrub.
Alternat9ve access to avoid crossing the Munglinup River is possible via several kilometres of station tracks.
Access from Perth or Bunbury is also via sealed highways, distances of 640 kilometres and 580 kilometres respectively.
Esperance is served by daily scheduled passenger flights ex Perth.
A gravel strip suitable for light aircraft only exists at Munglinup, but is in need of upgrading.
The Port of Esperance can handle bulk grain and mineral exports, but has no container handling facilities.
Only ships with appropriate equipment are able to take containers on board at Esperance.
Fremantle (Perth) offers the nearest facilities for container handling.
Munglinup itself serves a rural community and comprises a primary school, road house, bottle shop, mechanical repair business, ambulance sub-branch, housing and sporting facilities.
Munglinup is on the SEC power grid and is services by land line STD telephone.
Town water is supplied from an asphalted Water Authority rain catchment area.
A postal service ex Esperance operates twice per week.
The Munglinup Graphite deposit is located in the Albany Fraser Province, a belt of granitic and metamorphic rocks characterised by gneisses and migmatite withan overall north-easterly trend.
The province is dated as Proterozoic, with deformation and metamorphism dated at 1100 to 1300my (Thom et al, 1977).
The succession of metamorphic rocks seen at Munglinup is considered to be entirely of metasedimentary origin.
Sofoulis (1957) suggests it may represent a "plutonically" metamorphosed equivalent of the "Whitestone" phase which forms the youngest member of the Archaean "Ravensthorpe System".
Sofoulis' mapping showed the sequence of rocks are tectonically folded into a major south-east plunging, overturned, tight syncline with a series of minor anticlinal and synclinal flexures.
All tectonic lineations recorded over the area show a constant plunge of 30 degrees towards the south-east.
The graphitic sequence at McCarthy's area has been structurally thickened by this folding.

Gunther SUMMARY This report describes the exploration activities undertaken by Atlas Iron Limited over a tenement of their Western Shaw Project, E45/2768.
The project area is located in the Pilbara region of Western Australia, approximately 190 km south south east of Port Hedland.
During the reporting period Atlas Iron Limited conducted exploration activities over the tenements E45/2768.
These activities included helicopter survey and an assessment of Atlas GIS coverage for the tenement.
Further exploration is proposed for these tenements during the next reporting period will include field reconnaissance, geological and geophysical interpretation, and target generation.

Atlas Operations Limited acquired the tenement from Buxton Resources Limited and South Boulder Mines Ltd. 2 3
Aerial photography was acquired over the northern two thirds of the tenement as part of the coverage for Atlas Western Shaw Project.
Photography was acquired from Landgate as digital imagery at 1.4m and 0.8m resolution and has been incorporated into Atlas GIS database.
The photography has been used for location and access information to assist exploration activities.
During the reporting period Atlas Iron Limited conducted initial exploration activities over the tenements E45/2768.
These activities included helicopter survey and an assessment of Atlas GIS coverage for the tenement.
Further exploration is proposed for these tenements during the next reporting period will include field reconnaissance, geological and geophysical interpretation, and target generation.
Buxton Resources conducted a review of previous exploration in the general area of the tenement E45/2768.
Exploration for gold and base metals was conducted by Sipa Resources Ltd and CRA Exploration Pty Ltd in 1991 1996.
Reconnaissance exploration for tantalum was undertaken by Sons of Gwalia Ltd along the margins of the greenstone belt in 2002 - 2003 (Smit 2007).
Buxtons review of data from these exploration activities highlighted two areas of interest, Target A and Target B.
Target A was determined from an anomalous BLEG sample (18.5 ppb gold) from stream draining Fortescue Group and in the headwaters banded iron formation.
It was considered the elevated gold response was related to auriferous conglomerates at the base of the Fortescue Group.
Target B was determined from rock chips collected by Sipa Resources that had highly elevated Ba > 0.2% with three samples returning > 1.5% Ba.
Sipa reported that some of the rock-chip samples also contain elevated base metals.
Buxton considered that the geochemical association of Ba, Cu and Zn may be indicative of a hydrothermal system and the district may have potential for volcanogenic massive sulphide mineralisation.
7 Exploration by Buxton further tested the Targets A and B identified from historic exploration.
Stream sediment sampling in the vicinity of identified Target A returned positive gold results from streams draining an old GML.
Buxton recommended further surface reconnaissance and sampling is recommended.
Buxton found no significant base metal results from rock-chip sampling of barium-rich gossans (Target B) (Smit 2008).
Buxton identified a further two exploration targets, the southern and northern iron targets (Targets C & D).
Limited rock-chip sampling of BIF returned iron values between 30 50% Fe.
Buxton recommended systematic rock-chip sampling is recommended to evaluate the potential for small high-grade (> 57% Fe) hematite ore bodies (Smit 2008).

E52/1707_A_2008/G:/GIR Technical Reports/GIR Projects SUMMARY During the year ending 19 July 2008 (the second year of grant of E52/1707) Giralia conducted preliminary iron ore exploration on the tenement subsequent to ministerial approval dated April 15, 2008 to explore for this commodity.
Historically the area occupying the current lease E52/1707 has only been lightly explored.
WAMEX Item 14427 documents gold exploration by BP Minerals/Nugold Hill Mines NL and Riomin Aust Gold Pty Ltd on the Neerambah Springs gold project immediately east of the tenement (1984-91).

The BP/Nugold/Riomin JV focussed on exploration of the Duck Creek Dolomite Formation, with discoveries at Amphitheatre (Xanadu) with a resource of 109,093 tonnes @ 3.67 g/t Au for Amphitheatre, 41,000 tonnes @ 2.67 g/t Au for Caesar and 57,400 tonnes @ 3.04 g/t Au for Claudius.
A heap leach mining operation was undertaken at Amphitheatre.

Further north-east, Sipa Resources and Lynas Corporation completed open pit mining of the Mt Olympus deposit after Sipa had outlined a resource at Mt Olympus of 10.85 million tonnes @ 2.3 g/t Au, of which 72% was refractory.
Mining was also completed at the Zeus and Waugh deposits.
Newcrest and Sipa continued exploration post mining.
To the east, the Angelo River uranium deposits lie at the unconformity between the overlying Bresnahan Group and Wyloo Group rocks.
Explored heavily, principally by Pancontinental and PNC, the Angelo A & B deposits have resource estimates of 643,000 tonnes @ 0.124% U3O8 and 515,142 tonnes @ 0.11% U3O8 respectively.
In 1990-1991 Aberfoyle Resources completed BLEG stream sediment sampling for gold at Kennedy and Kallenia Creeks well to the east.
Most directly applicable is work done by Firegold NL and Sipa Exploration NL in 1997-2003 (WAMEX Item 13778).
These companies explored the Mt Maguire area for gold with a tenement area very similar to E 52/1707.
Field activities were focussed on follow up of previously reported gold mineralised prospects with geological/regolith mapping traverses.
Giralia completed follow up of several unexplained BLEG stream sediment anomalies with prospecting activity and rock chip sampling, without success.
Prospecting focused on the Caffreys prospect, Murphys prospect, and the fault contact juxtaposing the Mt McGrath Formation against older sequences.
Previous rock samples from the Murphys prospect reportedly returned results up to 0.382g/t gold and elevated arsenic.
Geological reconnaissance traverses were carried out to confirm lithologies.
The Murphys Prospect is located within the Woongarra Rhyolite (Hamersley Group).
Soil sampling outlined an anomalous zone with a peak value of 106 ppb gold within an E52/1707_A_2008/G:/GIR Technical Reports/GIR Projects area with dimensions of 500x80 metres at +20ppb gold.
Geological reconnaissance failed to identify a significant mineralized system in outcrop as the cause of the gold values.
The Caffreys prospect is reportedly located on the contact between the Hamersley Group and the Duck Creek Dolomite at the base of Mt Maguire.
Locally the Duck Creek Dolomite is mapped as being composed mainly of sandstones with minor shales.
The Hamersley rocks form a scree slope that almost entirely obscure the contact zone which occurs about half way up Mt Maguire.
No evidence of alteration or mineralisation was detected.
Giralia has applied for iron ore exploration rights to the area of E52/1707, and intends to focus on exploration of the Hamersley Group iron formations.
Approval by the minister was granted to explore for iron on April 15, 2008.
The tenement covers sediments of the Palaeoproterozoic Ashburton Basin, which is located along the southern margin of the Hamersley Basin.
The Ashburton Basin sequence comprises around 12 kilometre thickness of sedimentary and volcanic rocks dated at around 1840 ma.
Rocks of the Ashburton Province unconformably overlie the < 2440 ma Hamersley Province.
The Ashburton Province rocks were affected by the 1820 ma to 1750 ma Capricorn Orogeny.
The Wyloo Group of the Ashburton Formation is interpreted to have been deposited in the foreland of the Pilbara Craton during the closure of the Yilgarn-Pilbara basin.
A major dextral transcurrent fault system (including the Nanjilgardy Fault) affects both Wyloo Group and older rocks.
The Ashburton Province comprises two major tectonostratigraphic depositional packages.

The lower package comprises Beasley River Quartzite, Cheela Springs Basalt (continental tholeiitic basalt), Mount McGrath Formation (fluvio-deltaic siliciclastics), Duck Creek Dolomite (reef and platform carbonates) and Ashburton Formation (turbidites).
The Upper package comprises back arc-related bimodal volcanics (June Hill and Mt Boggola basins), and turbiditic siliciclastic and carbonate rocks (upper parts of the Ashburton Formation).

Wyloo Group rocks are unconformably overlain by the Capricorn Formation (siliciclastics and minor volcaniclastics deposited in restricted basins) and younger Bresnahan Group (conglomerate, sandstone, siltstone).

(MT BRUCE SUPERGROUP) Turee Creek Group TU mudstone, siltstone, thin bedded sandstone Ho -Bolgeeda Iron Formation Hw -Woongarra Volcanics Hj -Weeli Wolli Formation Hamersley Group Hb -Brockman Iron Formation Hs -Mt McRae Shale, Mt Sylvia Fm Hd -Wittenoom Dolomite Hm -Marra Mamba Iron Formation Fortescue Group mafic volcanics, epiclastic sediments Locally within E52/1707, the western half of the small tenement is dominated by cover sequences associated with the current Turee Creek drainage.
The eastern half of the tenement comprises a wedge of Mount McGrath Formation sediments in fault contact with the Upper parts of the Hamersley Group and lower parts of the Wyloo Group.

During the current reporting period (the second year of grant of E52/1707) Giralia conducted preliminary iron ore exploration on the tenement with focus on exploration of the Hamersley Group iron formations.

Reconnaissance mapping and prospecting located iron formations in the Mt Maguire area that moderately to steeply dip to the SW. To date there is limited evidence of significant iron mineralisation GSWA mapping indicates that the iron formations exposed are related to upper members of the Hamersley Group probably Boolgeeda and Weeli Weeli Formations.
Further prospecting and mapping is proposed for the next period.
