The Pilbara region of Western Australia has been largely overlooked for base metals by modern explorers due to its remoteness away from better known gold and nickel sulphide deposits of the Archaean Yilgarn of WA.
Areas such as the Eastern Goldfields region received the bulk of Western Australias exploration expenditure for many years.

More recently, the Pilbara region has seen increasing interest for gold and base metal exploration due to higher commodity prices, the recognition of its mineral potential, developing infrastructure and historical inactivity.
Segue took control of the Pardoo Project from Westralian in October/ November 2006.
Work completed during the 2007 exploration year includes; 1 Geophysical modelling of Westralian electromagnetic data 2 Helicopter-based VTEM geophysical survey.
4 RC percussion drilling.

5 Density determinations 6 Aeromagnetic surveying 7 Ground TEM Surveying 8 Metallurgical Test Work 1 Geophysical Modelling of Westralian EM Data Ground geophysical data was collected by Westralian in two surveys up to the end of 2005.
Geophysical modelling of this data was completed by Southern Geoscience Consultants in late 2006 to determine the nature of the conductor responses and position drill holes to intersect them.
These locations listed in Table 3 formed the basis of drilling in 2007.

2 VTEM Geophysical Survey Upon acquisition of the project, current knowledge indicated significant potential for massive/ disseminated sulphide accumulations particularly in the annular rims of the interpreted mafic/ultramafic intrusion, particularly in the proximity of the dislocation zone, the Pardoo Fault.
Detailed, low-level aeromagnetic surveying completed in 2005, identified clearly defined geological stratigraphy and layering against the Pardoo Fault.
Work conducted up to the time the project was acquired only included detailed electromagnetic surveying in two areas of the project, Highway and Supply Well.

Given the success of earlier surveys in identifying conductors under cover associated with sulphide accumulations, a method was sort to provide rapid and cost effective assessment of the remaining area of the project.

Between 27th October and 1st November 2006 Geotech Airborne Ltd conducted a helicopter-borne time domain electromagnetic survey using Geotechs advanced versatile time domain electromagnetic system (VTEM) over the entire project area.
Figure 3 illustrates the coverage of the 100m (red) and 200m (green) line-spaced survey.
A total of 927 line kilometres were flown at 200m spacings and 382.5 line kilometres were in-filled at 100m line spacings to cover the entire 174km2 of the project.
Figure 3 illustrates the area of 100m spaced lines (red box) and 200m spaced lines (green box).
Southern Geoscience Consultants acted on behalf of Segue Resources Ltd during data acquisition phases of the project and managed all geophysical processing.
This section best represented both the geology and the mineralisation of the Highway resource.

In January 2007 MacroDrill, using a GK850 Rig, completed two HQ2/NQ2 sized diamond drill holes (DD07HW01- 233.2m and DD07HW02- 318.2m) at the Highway resource positioned equi-distant between these existing holes to test CRAs interpretation and potential lode extensions.
Holes were drilled initially as HQ2-sized core to bedrock and then reduced to NQ2 .
The Mesozoic-aged sediments overlying the Archaean bedrock provided difficult drilling.
Geologically, the overburden consisted mainly of poorly consolidated medium-grained sandstones with a base of matrix-supported pebble to cobble-sized, polymictic conglomerate.
The nature of this overburden, together with high water tables caused significant delays in hole collaring, conditioning and penetration.
HQ2-sized core, being largely Mesozoic-aged barren overburden, was not trayed and left at the drill site.
NQ2-sized core was trayed, orientated, metre marked, geologically logged and selectively assayed, generally at metre intervals as determined by the site Geologist.
Trayed core is stored at Pardoo Station.
In addition, gold (0.01ppm) was determined by an aqua regia digest and ICPMS finish.
A total of 376 core samples were submitted for analysis.
4 Reverse Circulation Drilling Between February and May 2007, a combined total of 32 holes for 4,172m were completed in two phases of RC drilling at the Highway tenement.
All reverse circulation samples were riffle split and bagged in 1m intervals for analysis.
The remaining 1m sample was laid on the ground, generally in lines of twenty.
Overburden was sampled separately using a sample scoop and submitted to the lab as 4m composites.
All samples in these programs were sent by road freight to the Kalassay Group in Perth.
In addition, Au/ Pt/ Pd (1ppb) was determined by aqua regia with an ICPMS finish (by method ICPMS_3).
Some of the later analyses for Au/Pt/Pd were completed via fire assay fusion with a ICPMS finish (process FAF1 MS03) to avoid significant delay in turn around.
A total of 2,582 reverse circulation samples (both programs of drilling) were submitted for analysis.

Kalgoolie-based TopDrill, commenced the initial drilling program on 22nd February 2007 and completed 5 holes (RC07HW001-002 & RC07SW001-003) for 522m before Cyclone George crossed the northern Pilbara coast on 8th March 2007 causing all work to be abandoned.
RC07HW001 was targeted to intersect mineralisation on one of the most conductive sections at Highway.
RC07HW002 and RC07HW018 were positioned to investigate the nature of a large palaeo-channel shaped conductor identified from the VTEM survey.
RC07SW01 03 were designed to intersect priority conductor targets at Supply Well determined from geophysical modelling of Westralian geophysical data.
Kalgoorlie-based MacKay Drilling, became available in mid April 2007 for the second drilling program.
RC07SW04 05 were designed to intersect priority conductor targets at Supply Well.

5 Specific Gravity Determinations A total of 62 mineralised reverse circulation sample pulps from the Highway resource were submitted to the Kalassay Group in Perth for specific gravity determinations (process SGPULP).

Unfortunately this corresponded to an area thought to represent an important and favourable geological feature, a layered mafic/ ultramafic intrusion.

VTEM surveying indicated that a number of the priority target conductors could be strongly conductive and may not necessarily be related to legitimate bedrock conductors.
The inloop TEM survey aimed to confirm and characterise selected high-priority VTEM conductors.

2007 MLEM Survey Location Plan This work would also allow drill hole planning to effectively test the refined targets if they were found to be clearly related to bedrock conductors in areas of geological interest.
The transmitter loop used during this inloop TEM survey was powered by a Zonge ZT-30 transmitter working at ~24-28A current (single turn loop).

The 100x100m inloop configuration utilised was aimed at coupling with bedrock conductors with any orientation (inloop omnidirectional EM technique) and provided significant depth of investigation (~150-200m).
All data was acquired using a SMARTem MkV instrument combined with a conventional receiver coil (dB/dt) working at a base frequency of 1-2Hz.

8 Metallurgical Test Work CRAE conducted sighter metallurgical test work on two samples of ore submitted to two different laboratories in 1993.
The first was from a single drill hole DD92GW034.

This indicated 89m of low grade nickel (0.37%) and copper (0.14%) as pentlandite and chalcopyrite potentially hosted in two rock Page 15 of 30 Date: 27/11/2008 types, a silica breccia and a chlorite-amphibolite schist.
This was conducted by Advanced Technical Development Pty Ltd in Melbourne.
It was later determined that the two composites behaved similarly in tests and were combined for further testing.
The second sample used RC chips composited from mineralisation in hole RC93GW40.
Tests were completed by AMMTEC in Perth.
The result of this historical work showed that the mineralisation produced low grade concentrates at good recoveries; or greater than 10% Ni concentrates with poor recoveries.
The best concentrate produced was 12.5% Ni & 5% Cu with only a 45% recovery.
Better recoveries of 69% had been achieved with a concentrate of 6.7% Ni.
All available historic sample pulps, namely all of Segues drilling sample pulps, were reassayed using Genalysis Laboratory Services for 38 individual elements including Co and PGEs.
The assay file is attached as Appendix 5.

The Pardoo Nickel Project (formerly known as the Highway and Supply Well Project) comprises two adjoining exploration licenses covering 174 km2 located on the Great Northern Highway, some 100km east-northeast of Port Hedland in the Pilbara region of Western Australia.
The project area lies on the sparsely vegetated coastal sand plain of spinifex grass and mainly scattered acacia bushes.
This coastal region has an arid to semi arid climate.
The average rainfall is approximately 250mm, with most rainfall related to tropical cyclones and thunderstorms occurring in the summer months from December to March.
Rainfall during the remainder of the year is light and irregular.
Drainage in the region forms a north to northwesterly network flowing toward the Indian Ocean.
The principal exploration target is nickel/ copper sulphide mineralization associated with the regional east-northeasterly trending De Grey Structural Zone, also known as the Pardoo Fault.
The project area contains 25km of effective strike of this zone.
Previous exploration has identified existing low-grade, JORC-code compliant resources of nickel and copper at the Highway prospect.
Additionally, the project is prospective for iron ore in the form of primary BIF, secondary enrichment and/or channel iron deposits.
Importantly the project area contains the same geological sequence that hosted the historic Goldsworthy iron ore mine and produced 157Mt of high grade hematite over 16 years until 1982.
Mithril Resources is in the possession of all historical CRA diamond drill core.
This core was left on site in the field for 15 years and is subsequently in poor condition.

The Dept of Industry and Resources retained two of the best historical core holes at the Carlisle Core Library in Perth (DD92GW034 and DD92GW031) as the deposit represents an unusual occurrence of the nickel mineralization.
Although these two holes have been re-trayed, most of the mineralized intervals have already been reduced to quarter core and metre marks are often of questionable accuracy.

A number of processing options to unlock the value of the inferred mineral resource of 130,000 tonnes of contained nickel in the Highway Deposit are being evaluated to determine the viability of the deposit as an open pit operation.
Preliminary results from biooxidation heap leaching amenability trials are positive and suggest recoveries of 92% for nickel and 91% for cobalt.
Westralian was first granted exploration licences at Highway and Supply Well in 2004.

In October 2004 the first round of ground moving loop transient electromagnetic surveying (MLTEM) was conducted on a 200m line spacing to locate and confirm discrete bedrock conductors associated with massive nickel sulphide mineralization.
This was completed Page 8 of 30 Date: 27/11/2008 along the historically identified nickel copper sulphide zones to supplement previous, but less effective airborne electromagnetic surveys.
In June 2005, a second, more detailed, round of MLTEM surveying (100m line spacing/ 50m stations using the same parameters) was completed, once again over previously identified EM anomalies.
The aim was to improve on target definition ahead of drilling.
MLTEM surveying over the Highway and Supply Well Prospects confirmed fourteen electromagnetic anomalies.
A heritage survey was completed and an 18 person camp was established on site in June 2005 broadly covering the historical CRAE grid.
This camp was maintained until May 2006 when it was sold and removed from site.
Again, in June 2005 an airborne geophysical survey was flown to collect magnetic, radiometric and elevation data over a large portion of the project area.

Historical diamond drill core from the Highway and Supply Well Prospects was reexamined in an attempt to relate higher grade nickel sulphide mineralization to host rock and adjacent lithological units.
Assay intervals by previous explorers were broad and appeared to crosscut geological boundaries effectively diluting nickel and copper concentrations in the sampled intervals.

Re-sampling revealed for the first time the presence of high grade nickel sulphide in the mineralised system grading 5.85% nickel over a 0.5m interval at the Supply Well Prospect and 2.11% nickel over a 1m interval at the Highway Prospect.
This has been important in establishing that high-tenor nickel sulphide intervals do exist (albeit narrow zones) within the lower-grade ore zones in the project area.
A review of the aeromagnetic/ radiometric survey completed in June 2005 highlighted a number of palaeochannel-shaped surface radiometric anomalies.
These anomalies were up to 1250m long and up to 250m wide with peak values greater than 100 counts per second.
Anomalies were field inspected and a strong correlation was found between the presence of surface pisolites, subtle changes in elevation and elevated radiometric counts.
No surface calcrete was observed.
A review of all geophysical data available on the project highlighted a strong gravity anomaly in the order of 8 x 5 km situated in the northern part of the Highway tenement.
The significance of this feature has not previously been appreciated.

It is believed to represent a large and classic target for nickel, copper and platinum group element (PGE) mineralisation in the form of a mafic to ultramafic intrusion with defining annular magnetic anomalies.
The Pardoo Nickel Project lies on the Port Hedland (SF 50-4) 1:250,000 and the Pardoo 1:100,000 scale geological mapping sheets.

Exposure throughout this area is primarily limited to a few regions where strike ranges rise abruptly out of the typically flat Quaternary aged floodplain and minor areas of low-lying granite hills The Pilbara Craton consists of two different tectonic components: older underlying Archaean granite-greenstone basement that was formed between 3600 and 2800 million years ago, and a younger, unconformably overlying Archaean- Proterozoic aged volcanosedimentary sequence called the Mt Bruce Supergroup occupying the Hamersley Basin that is believed to have been deposited between 2770 and 2400 million years ago.
Basement Archaean granite-greenstones are exposed in the Pilbara Craton and have been divided into five separate and distinct litho-tectonic units.
The Pardoo Nickel Project is located on the northern edge of the largest of these units called the East Pilbara Granite-Greenstone Terrane.
This northern portion of the Pilbara block incorporates the southern preserved margin of thin, on lapping Mesozoic aged Lambert Shelf and younger sediments of the Northern Carnarvon Basin.

Historical geophysical work has confirmed these on lapping sediments and windblown sands cover the basement Palaeoarchaean to Mesoarchaean aged (c.3500-2930Ma), East Pilbara Granite-Greenstone Terrane in the tenure that hosts the Pardoo mineralisation.
The De Grey Structural Zone is a large, regionally pervasive structure, trending east-northeasterly that becomes the Tabba Tabba Shear Zone further to the southwest.
It is believed Page 16 of 30 Date: 27/11/2008 that the De Grey Structural Zone is integral to the mineralisation at Highway and Supply Well prospects.

CRA Exploration Pty Ltd (now Rio Tinto Ltd) identified low-grade resources of nickel and copper mineralisation at the Highway Prospect in the northern Pilbara between 1989 and 1995 following extensive regional scale exploration.
Nickel resources were located in conjunction with similar mineralisation at the adjacent Supply Well Prospect.
Westralian Nickel Ltd (Westralian) was granted tenure over these projects in 2004 with the intention of developing resources through targeted exploration for the benefit of shareholders.
In June/ July of 2005, Westralian failed to raise the minimum required funds to complete an initial public offering (IPO) for listing on the Australian Stock Exchange.
In October 2006, Westralian shareholders voted to accept an offer from Segue Resources Ltd (Segue) to acquire 100% of the issued capital in Westralian.
In 2007 Westralian changed its name to Segue Pardoo Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary of Segue Resources Ltd.
In December 2007, Mithril Resources Ltd announced it had entered a Farm-in and Joint Venture Agreement with Segue (Pardoo) Limited, a wholly owned subsidiary of Segue Resources Limited.
Under the terms of the agreement Mithril has the right to earn a 65% interest in Segues 100% owned Pardoo Nickel Project through expenditure of $5,500,000 over 4 years.

Mithril conducted ground-based geophysics (figure 1), diamond drilling (4 holes-999.5 m), reassaying of historic sample pulps, specific gravity determinations and bio-oxidation heap leaching amenability trials in the 2007-2008 reporting year (table 1).

Previous historical drilling at both the Highway and Supply Well prospects has identified an unusual style of disseminated and semi-massive nickel-copper sulphide mineralization that appears stratabound and discordant within meta-sediments, cherts and possible ultramafic rocks.
Historical drilling at Highway has outlined an 800m long by 50-75m wide, disseminated and semi-massive nickel copper sulphide system containing 5-30% sulphide minerals.
The mineralized zone is stratabound and largely discordant to the lithology which dips 70-85o to the north, suggesting it is influenced by faulting or shearing.
The stratigraphic sequence consists of an integrated package of highly altered rocks, described by CRAE as schists, and multiple chert horizons.
It has been suggested that the schists represent fine grained quartz-feldspar-chlorite metasediments that seems well supported by independent petrographic work.
Grey, white or translucent chert lithologies, sometimes heavily brecciated, occur stratigraphically above and below the main mineralised host unit.
The hanging-wall and the footwall chert appear to merge along strike to become a single unit and the mineralised metasedimentary host appears to pinch out.
The main sulphide minerals are pyrite and pyrrhotite.

Variable quantities of chalcopyrite are visible in the drill core whereas pentlandite has only been clearly identified in a number Page 18 of 30 Date: 27/11/2008 of instances with violarite, chalcocite and covellite also in minor amounts probably representing localised enrichment.
Observations of existing diamond core samples confirm the presence of remobilized sulphides associated with major faulting and deformation.
Sulphide minerals form clots to wispy bands of remobilised mineralization, usually subparallel with cleavage.
Where chert bands occur within the host schist, the mineralisation is dominantly vein-type, usually at irregular orientations.
A historical inferred resource has been estimated from drilling at Highway, which is open along strike and at depth, of 37Mt of 0.3%Ni and 0.12% Cu using a 0.1% Ni cut-off.
A higher grade core of 5 million tonnes grading better than 0.5% nickel, 0.13% copper has also been delineated to 200m vertical depth on 100m and 200m spaced sections.
The Pardoo Nickel Project provides an excellent fit with the Companys exploration and development strategy.

Geographically, it is well positioned being 15 km from the coast and approximately 100km east of Port Hedland along the Great Northern Highway and in close proximity to power, rail and port facilities.
The Company believes there is significant potential to increase the size and value of the resource defined at Highway.
The deposit remains open at depth and the company notes that previous resource calculations did not incorporate the significant cobalt values.

A number of processing options to unlock the value of the inferred mineral resource of 130,000 tonnes of contained nickel in the Highway Deposit are being evaluated to determine the viability of the deposit as an open pit operation.
Preliminary results from biooxidation heap leaching amenability trials are positive and suggest recoveries of 92% for nickel and 91% for cobalt.
The leaching process is similar to that being implemented by Talvivaara Mining PLC on similar grade material at their namesake mine in Finland.

Mithril plans to recalculate the resource figure incorporating the recent drill results, the cobalt assays, a higher density (resulting from recent specific gravity measurements) and a new geological model in the next six months.
Nickel sulphides have been identified outside of the Highway resource area and exploration is planned to test targets with the potential to host high grade mineralisation on the Project.
A four drillhole program was completed in July 2008.
Of the four, two drillholes were targeted to test the continuity and depth potential of the Highway Resource and two targeted regional geophysical anomalies.
Collar, survey, lithology and assay files are attached as Appendices 2, 3, 4 and 5 respectively.
The first hole at the Highway Resource was drilled to a depth of 393m while the second, located 200m to the southwest, was drilled to a depth of 333m (Figure 7).
After passing through a thin (30m-50m) cover sequence the drillholes intersected basement lithologies including mafic schists, brecciated cherts and laminated metasediments.
Analytical results confirm the presence of wide zones of nickel sulphide mineralisation including higher grades of up to 1.8% nickel encountered over one metre intervals.
The sulphide content within these intervals typically averages 5-10%.
Both drillholes are inclined at 60 degrees (Figures 8 and 9).
This mineralisation appears to be associated with carbonate-sulphide veining within a metasediment.
DD08HW001, drilled 200m to the northeast also encountered gold and copper values at this horizon (1.37 g/t and 0.55% copper over 1m).
These results warrant further investigation.

The third drillhole (DD08HW003) targeted a strong ground electromagnetic conductor adjacent to a linear magnetic anomaly approximately 3km east-southeast of the Highway Resource and Page 23 of 30 Date: 27/11/2008 intersected 35m of graphitic shale from 84m which is the likely source of the conductor (Figure 10).
No further work is warranted on the target.
The fourth drillhole (DD08HW004) was targeted on a coincident magnetic and gravity anomaly 3km east and along strike from the Highway Resource.
The drillhole intersected a mafic unit containing approximately 30% magnetite from 32m downhole (25m vertical depth) to the end of the hole at a depth of 150m (Figure 10).
Drillhole summaries are attached as Appendix 6.
Specific gravity measurements were conducted every 4-5m on diamond drilled core.
Measurements through the ore zone average ten percent greater than previously Page 24 of 30 Date: 27/11/2008 recorded.
It is intended that a new average specific gravity measurement will be determined and incorporated into future resource calculations.
The survey comprised 2 areas consisting of the Highway central and Highway South survey areas.

The purpose of the ground EM surveys was to identify conductors indicative of massive sulphide mineralisation and in the case of Highway South, to follow up the targets generated from the VTEM survey conducted in 2007.
In all a total of 1013 EM soundings were collected along 47 NE oriented lines covering some 50.65 line km.
The Highway Central survey area joins the Highway and Supply Well South survey areas (figure 6).
A program of 1082 soundings or 54.1 line km was initially proposed and of this, 568 soundings were collected along 24 lines during this survey.
In all a total of 28.4 line km of slingram and in loop data were collected at the Highway Central Prospect.
The remaining unsurveyed lines will be surveyed at a later date.
Plan map of ground EM Lines.
The Highway South survey area is located 0.5 km to the south of the Highway Central survey area and all proposed work in this area was completed (figure 6).
A total of 445 slingram and inloop ground EM soundings were collected along 23 separate lines at the Highway South Prospect.
In all 22.25 line km data was collected at this prospect.
At Highway Central 2 targets of interest were defined, of which the southern most of these targets had been previously drill tested.
This southern most target is highly conductive and as the drill test finished in graphitic shale, there is potential for NiS mineralisation beneath.
The northern target was untested, however, is not as conductive as the target to the south.
It was suggested both of these targets should be drill tested.
At the Highway South Prospect 4 targets of interest were identified with only 1 target previously drill tested intersecting black shale however further testing of this target is recommended.
Of the four targets two had higher measured conductance and as such were higher priority targets.
The full Ground EM Report is attached as Appendix 1 and all data as Appendix 1A.

Work completed during the 2008 exploration year includes ; 1 Ground EM surveying 2 Diamond core drilling 3 Re-assaying of historic sample pulps 4 Specific Gravity Determinations 5 Bio-oxidation heap leaching amenability trials
Locally the project area lies on the northern, faulted limb of the Goldsworthy Syncline within the Goldsworthy Greenstone belt along the Pardoo Fault (figure 5).
The oldest rocks at the base of the Goldsworthy Syncline are volcano-clastic sandstones and cherts of the Warrawoona Group.
Above these are the rocks of the Gorge Creek Group.

These comprise sequences of fine to coarse grained clastic metasedimentary rocks of the basal Corboy Formation and fine grained and clastic sediments of the overlying Nimingarra Iron Formation, the host of the Goldsworthy iron deposit.
It is important to note that ultramafic schists are known to occur at the base of the Gorge Creek Group and elsewhere throughout the region.
The De Grey Group overlies the Gorge Creek Group and is comprised of medium to coarse grained metasediments with minor quantities of volcanic and volcanoclastic rocks.
Overlying the Archaean rocks of the greenstone belt are the Mesozoic-aged sediments of the Lambert Shelf.
Within the project area these sediments are generally 30- 40m in thickness and tend to thicken northward.
Mineralisation in the Highway and Supply Well prospects are within metasedimentary rocks and cherts of the Gorge Creek Group.
Intense metamorphism and alteration affects most rock types often making identification of primary lithologies very difficult.

The Pardoo Nickel Project is situated in the Northern Pilbara Region of Western Australia about 100kms east-northeast of Port Hedland with its significant infrastructure including roads, power, rail and a deep-sea port (figure 2).
Access is via the Great Northern Highway which passes through the project areas.
The Pardoo Roadhouse and the Pardoo Homestead are the only inhabited settlements in the region.
A number of station and exploration tracks provide access to the project off the Great Northern Highway.
The Pardoo Nickel Project currently consists of two granted exploration licenses E45/1866 & E45/2146 in the Pilbara Mineral Field.
The tenement blocks covers in all, a total of 176 km2.
The tenements are currently wholly owned by Segue Pardoo Limited with Mithril Resources reserving the option to earn a 65% stake through staged spending.
Segue also has two granted prospecting licenses, P45/2572 and P45/2573 with combined reporting status.
Minimum annual exploration expenditure is currently $63,000 as outlined in Table 2.
The region is largely covered by sediments and windblown sands and was not generally recognized as a prospective Archaean greenstone belt until the late 1980s.

Large areas of Page 7 of 30 Date: 27/11/2008 exploration licenses were taken up in 1988 by CRA Exploration (CRAE) targeting Witwatersrand style gold-uranium mineralization following the completion of regional aeromagnetic surveys which highlighted the areas magnetic characteristics.
Initial work in early 1989 by CRAE revealed the presence of base metals including nickel, zinc, lead and copper.
Early diamond drilling at the Supply Well Prospect identified nickel and copper sulphides in diamond drill core.

Consequently CRAEs exploration work in the area shifted to nickel, copper and some separate zones of sediment-hosted zinc mineralisation During 1988-1995, CRAE undertook detailed ground magnetic surveys, ground geophysical IP and EM surveys, broad regional airborne EM surveys and limited follow-up diamond, RC and RAB drilling over a large area known as the Worthy Project.
CRAE drilled 693 holes totalling 22,355m during their period of exploration.
The drilling included 632 RAB holes totalling 10,910m, 42 RC holes totalling 6,400m and 19 diamond drill holes totalling 5,045m.

Airborne magnetic and radiometric surveys were flown that enabled the detection and interpretation of the basement stratigraphy leading to the delineation of a major structural feature, the De Grey Structural zone largely hidden under sedimentary cover.
Ground follow-up of magnetics and IP along this zone identified several IP anomalies over 8km of strike.
Testing of the IP anomalies intersected some 50-100m widths of >10% pyrrhotite/pyrite mineralisation particularly in two holes at the Supply Well prospect.
Due to the presence of massive sulphides, a trial GEOTEM survey was flown in 1990, which was successful in outlining sulphide mineralisation beneath up to 70m of Mesozoicaged cover.
This subsequently led to a larger survey over the De Grey Structural Zone.
Several GEOTEM anomalies were identified from this airborne survey and were followed up with SIROTEM and ground magnetics.
Drilling of SIROTEM and IP targets at Supply Well intersected cherts that contained 10-15% pyrite/ pyrrhotite.
This intersection was considered stratabound, late-stage mineralisation associated with veins and fractures.
Significant investigation and drilling failed to replicate these results.
In 1992, further drill testing of identified GEOTEM anomalies, located several new areas of sulphides at the Highway prospect (14km to the south west of Supply Well).
SIROTEM was completed firstly over 400m then to 200m spaced lines.
Drilling one conductor intersected a pyrite/ pyrrhotite zone containing 113m at 0.31% Ni and 0.31%Cu.
Subsequent broad spaced drilling at the Highway prospect outlined an 800m long by 50- 75m wide, disseminated nickel-copper sulphide resource.

Tenement Airborne survey E80/3575 147.0 km2 / 1,552 line km 1 1.0 INTRODUCTION The Mad Gap Project is situated approximately 65 km northwest of Halls Creek (Figure 1).
The Project comprises one granted exploration licence for a total area of 110.3km2.
The project area alls within the Moola Bulla pastoral leases.
2.0 TENURE 2.1 Tenement Details The Mad Gap Project is operated and managed by U3O8 Limited (U3O8).
Following the spin-off of most of Giralias uranium assets into U3O8 Limited, the project was transferred to the later.
Figure 2 shows the current boundaries of the project (E80/3575).
U3O8 holds a 100% interest in this tenement, with a private group retaining rights to explore and develop diamond deposits on E 80/3575.

2.2 Native Title The Mad Gap South Project is totally covered by the Ngarrawanji claim, WC96/75, which was lodged and registered on the 25th June 1996 and is administered by the Kimberley Land Council.

2 3.0 GEOLOGY 3.1 Regional Geology The Mad Gap South project, in the Kimberley region of Western Australia is located immediately south of the Mad Gap anticline, which hosts extensive uranium anomalism in a basal sandstone unit, unconformably overlying Lower Proterozoic metamorphic rocks.
Most of E80/3575 is underlain by phyllites of the Olympio Fm.
in direct contact with a large batholith of the Bow River Granite, and overlain to the west by units of the Kimberley Group, including some thin sections of the Carlson Volcanics.
At the Mad Gap prospect, the basal Brown Sandstone unit of the O'Donnell Formation, unconformably overlies older metamorphic rocks and volcanics of the Whitewater Volcanics and Olympio Formation.

Regionally, strongly uranium anomalous outcrop samples containing secondary uranium minerals on joints and fractures were discovered in the late 1960s over many kilometres at a well defined stratigraphic position.
The mineralisation appears clearly stratabound and related to the unconformity.
Highest radioactivity is observed on the eastern limb of the Carola Syncline, where a NNW-SSE reverse fault causes the repetition of a conglomerate unit.

Uranium mineralisation is exposed for over 20 kilometres around the Mad Gap Anticline, hosted by the Brown Sandstone unit of the O'Donnell Formation, the basal member of a Palaeoproterozoic sediment sequence unconformably overlying older rocks of the Halls Creek Orogen.

Similar visible secondary uranium is exposed on nearby EL80/3398 at the Anomaly One and Diana prospects, also clearly stratabound along a sandstone/siltstone contact within the O'Donnell Formation immediately above the unconformity.
3 4.0 PREVIOUS EXPLORATION A summary of previous exploration on E80/3575 is provided below.

Rock chip sampling in the 1970s on U3O8 Ltd nearby E80/3574 returned assays including 4.65% U3O8, 4.42% U3O8 and 1.69% U3O8 from pits on outcropping secondary uranium mineralisation located along joints and cracks and within porous, 4 highly weathered sandstones, exposed for over 20 kilometres around the Mad Gap Anticline.

Widely spaced shallow vertical drilling (average 60 metres depth) beneath the outcropping uranium mineralisation returned consistently anomalous radioactivity associated with the Brown Sandstone unit.

Of 23 shallow holes testing the 20 kilometres of strike at Mad Gap, 8 holes returned assays in excess of 0.05% U3O8, and two holes reported intersections of 0.2% U3O8 or higher over narrow intervals, with better intersections including 3 feet @ 0.208% U3O8, within 9 feet @ 0.086% U3O8.
Table 2 is a summary of the previous exploration campaigns.

Details of the eastern sequence, from east to west (i.e.

up sequence), are as follows: The upper Bulong Complex is composed of serpentinised olivine orthocumulate that becomes finer grained upward (to the west) from coarse to medium to fine to very fine grained with a corresponding decrease in the amount of original olivine within the rocks.
In the upper very fine grained zoned olivine spinifex- P25P25_1705_2007A Page 4 of 22 textured layers are present indicating that this upper zone is composed of thin komatiitic flows.

The sedimentary/felsic volcanic sequence is 5-10m wide and composed of shale, including sulphidic black shale, chert, felsic tuff and dacitic breccia with angular fragments up to several centimetres in size within a tuff-ash matrix.
In places this sequence contains highly anomalous Cu and other elements, e.g.
(copper gossan).

The fractionated ultramafic/gabbro sill is composed of a ~5m pryroxenitic basal marginal zone (as seen in the percussion hole just west of Cu gossan), a ~250m wide, serpentinised, medium grained olivine and olivine-pyroxene cumulate, a ~150m wide, strongly layered pyroxene zone, rich in orthopyroxene and with some melagabbro/norite layers, a strongly layered gabbro/norite zone with marker variations in grain size and cumulate mineralogy and an upper pyroxene spinifex-textured upper zone that fines upwards into doleritic rocks.
The top contact of the sill is not exposed although sediment rock scree is present west of the upper most outcrop of the sill.
In the area of the Cu gossan there appears to be a structural disruption of the sill.

The presence of relatively abundant orthopyroxene seen in the pyroxenite and gabbro/norite zones strongly suggests that the magma from which the sill crystallized was contaminated by crustal material.
It appears that the sill was emplaced into a sedimentary/felsic volcanic sequence that immediately overlies the Bulong Complex.
Outer-Rim Exploration have been contracted through Southern Geoscience to complete a SQUID TEM survey along the basal contact zone of the ultramafic-gabbro sill.
Planning for this has been completed and work should commence in February 2008.
Western Nickel Western Nickel completed soil geochemistry dating from 1973.
They assayed for only 3 elements Ni, Cu, and Zn.
It was clear from their results that samples with a high Ni result had a corresponding low Cu assay and samples with low Cu had a high Ni assay.
Only a few assays had corresponding high Ni and high Cu results.
Samples with high Ni only are probably lateritic ultramafic saprolite that is commonly developed over high MgO rocks .
High Cu only samples are probably related to the sedimentary sequence though there was insufficient data to prove this.
PacMin The Pacmin soil geochemistry was derived from 2 sampling programs.
In the first Mt Eden Gold Mines collected 205 samples during 1993/94 on ten 600 to 1000m spaced lines with samples 100 metres apart.
The <2mm size fraction was sampled and they were assayed for only Au and Ni.
Without corresponding Cu, Co or PGE assays the nickel values could not be assessed.
The second program consisted of 705 samples taken in 1994 along 300 400m spaced lines with samples taken every 50 metres but composited to 100m.
These samples were assayed for Au, As, Cu, and a few samples were also assayed for Co.
These results also needed to be treated with suspicion as the effect of compositing the samples.
A single very high Cu value taken over the highly sulphidic basal zone would be reduced by half.
Also the effect of compositing would produce coincident anomalies where none exist.

This mapping was completed to ascertain the stratigraphy of the area in order to plan follow up geochemical and geophysical programs to identify possible nickel sulphide targets.

The Clinker Hill Project is comprised of 17 tenements totalling 25.4km2.
The project is located some 35km east south-east of Kalgoorlie along the Transline Access Road.
It is 20km south of the Bulong Nickel Project and 20km north of Carnilya Hill.
Kalgoorlie Boulder Resources Limited (KBRL) is the operator and beneficial owner of the tenement.
A total of 1154 soil samples were taken throughout the Clinker Hill project area during the reporting period.
Two main techniques were used: In areas of little alluvium and colluviums (the eastern side of the project area along the mapped basal contact) soil samples were taken with a spade.
A 10 20cm deep hole was dug to remove surface material and the 2mm size fraction was collected and sent to Amdel Laboratories soil lab in Perth for analyses.
In areas of alluvial and colluvial cover auger samples were taken at a depth of 0.5 to 1 metre, depending on the penetration.
Both techniques were used to attempt to assay bedrock particles in the soil profile.

Upon submission to Amdel laboratories to samples were first dried to a core temperature of 1000 C. The sample was then milled in an LM5 pulveriser to 90% passing 106 m. An analytical sub sample of 250 g was taken from the bulk and the residue retained.

The Clinker Hill project is located on the Kurnalpi Terrane in the Eastern Goldfields Superterrane.
The Kurnalpi Terrane is the central terrane in the Eastern Goldfields and is bounded to the east by the Burtville Terrane and to the west by the Kalgoorlie Terrane.
The bounding faults are the Hootanui (to the west) and the Ockerburry (to the east).
Other major faults include the Mertondale, Emu, Celia and Keith-Kilkenny fault systems.
A deep weathered lateritic profile is developed over MgO-rich ultramafic rocks both over the Bulong Complex and over the ultramafic zone of the ultramafic/gabbro sill.
Some of the lower MgO-rich ultramafic rocks, those containing higher Al2O3 contents, outcrop as weathered bedrock.
Soils from over these rocks should strongly reflect the bedrock although over the very MgO-rich rocks regolith processes (such as Mn scavenging) may produce spurious geochemical anomalies.
Much of the project area in the south, north and along the western side is covered by recent alluvium and colluvium and soil geochemistry probably will not reflect the bedrock.
Outer-Rim Exploration have been contracted through Southern Geoscience to complete a SQID TEM survey along t he basal contact zone of the ultramafic-gabbro sill.
Planning for this has been completed and work should commence in February 2008.

On the east side the tenements cover the upper-most part of the west facing ultra-mafic Bulong Complex, an overlying thin sedimentary/felsic volcanic sequence and then a ~1.3km wide differentiated ultra-mafic/gabbro sill.

Further to the west and perhaps separated by a major fault (as shown on the 100 000 scale Kanowna geology map) are poorly outcropping sediments, felsic volcanic, gabbro and Spinifex-textured komatiites.
The relationship of these western rocks to the eastern sequence is not known.
It is possibly that they represent lateral equivalents, although, if so there, must be significant facies change in the ultra-mafic sequence.

Polished hand specimen show an attractive translucent pattern of very fine grained, apple green coloured, chert transected by milky-white to blackish quartz veins and veinlets.

Allowing for wastage, variation of colour and quality it is prudent to assume that only a small fraction of the prase is marketable but even this will represent a potential value in excess of several million dollars.
The success of this project will also depend on the marketing endeavours as there is strong demand for attractive specimen especially from China.
The prase is thought to be fresher and less fractured at shallow depth.

In order to properly assess the quality and quantity of the prase it is recommended to carry out large diameter triple tube diamond drilling underneath the principal outcrop to a vertical depth of at least 30 metres.
Diamond core will also be valuable for marketing purposes.

The geological and structural setting of the area is also very favourable for copper/gold and other mineralisation with numerous workings of the Carlow Castle mining centre only a few hundreds of metres away.
The prospectivity and underexplored nature of the area has been recently emphasized with the discovery of a rich shallow and blind gold lode at Carlow South.
The mineralisation is shear related.
An indicated and inferred resource was calculated as 91,000 tonnes grading 10 g/t gold and 1.40% copper to a depth of 100 metres.
The presence of similar sized mineralized pods underneath the extensive chert covered part of the project area should not be excluded.
_ APPENDIX 1 ANALYTICAL RESULTS
A large portion of the lease is covered by thick chert scree shedding of the prominent ridges.
The Mining Lease covers several chert ridges which are bright-green at two main locations.
The principal rock types are strongly sheared and brecciated steeply south dipping cherts, metasediments and ultramafic schists.
These schists are interpreted as komatiitic lava flows which extruded over sediments at very high temperatures.
The green color of the chert is due to chromium and/or nickeliferous oxide impurities absorbed by the chert.
The prase outcrops within massive to thickly bedded cherty ridges separated by poorly outcropping schists.

The prominent ridges are cut by numerous northeast trending faults (see also Figure 3).This narrow zone between the large Andover Intrusive Complex to the south and a major regional trust to the north (the recently recognized Regal Trust) is characterized by intense shearing and brecciation.
This tectonised zone of greenstones hosts several deposits of gold/copper, nickel (at Ruth Well) and also base metals.
Principal gold (+copper) occurrences are found at Weerianna, Carlow, No.6 Well, Sing Well and Nickol River gold mining centre.
The total strike length of the outcropping prase is approximately 500 metres and has a width of some 50 metres.
The depth of the coloured chert is unknown but could be well in excess of 100 metres.

ANNUAL REPORT CARLOW CASTLE PRASE (M47/385) For the period 13 August 2005 to 12 August 2006 WEST PILBARA MINERAL FIELD WESTERN AUSTRALIA DATE: OCTOBER 2006 Voermans Geological Services Pty Ltd FIGURE 2 TENEMENT PLAN 1.
The property is located about 9km west-southwest of Roebourne a few hundred metres north of the well-maintained Cherratta gravel road.

The lease lies immediately to the northwest of the copper/gold workings at Carlow Castle and is centered over an outcropping sequence of attractive, translucent pale green cherts or chrysoprase or prase
Mining Lease 47/385 was granted on the 13th of August 1996 for a period of 21 years to Kongoni Nominees Ltd.
The size is 46 hectares and the minimum annual expenditure is $10,000.00.
The lease is surrounded by P47/944 and 945 held by Legend Mining Ltd.
These prospecting licences cover the Carlow Castle copper/gold mining centre.
A tenement plan of the area is shown in Figure 2.

The Archaean Pilbara Craton can be divided into two components: a granitegreenstone terrain which was formed between c. 3600 and 2800 Ma (Million years) and an unconformably overlying volcano-sedimentary sequence of the c. 2770 to 2400 MA Hamersley Basin.

Within the granite-greenstone 2. terrain five lithotectonic elements are distinguished of which the most northwesterly, the c. 3280-2920 Ma West Pilbara Granite-Greenstone Terrain (WPGGT) is present in the project area.
The WPGGT is characterized by a number of east-northeast striking greenstone sequences that envelop elongate to ovoid granitoid complexes.
In the West Pilbara both greenstones and granitoid complexes were intruded by a number of layered mafic to ultramafic intrusions.
The northern edge of the Andover Complex, the largest intrusion in the West Pilbara, outcrops immediately south of the main Carlow Castle workings and also the project area.
The oldest greenstone sequence, the c. 3270-3250 Ma Roebourne Group, is present in the project area.
The succession comprises a basal volcanic unit, the Ruth Well Formation, which gradually grades into a dominantly sedimentary unit, the Nickol River Formation.
Main lithologies of the Ruth Well Formation include basalts, serpentinized peridotitic komatiite with local spinifex texture and thin bands of grey and white banded cherts and black chert.

The largely felsic Nickol River Formation contains grey and white-banded chert, ferruginous chert, BIF (Banded Iron Formation), clastic and carbonate sedimentary rocks, quartzite, felsic volcanics, conglomerate and serpentinized peridotite with local spinifex texture.
The boundary between the Ruth Well and Nickol River Formation lies between the basalts at Carlow and the main chert horizon hosting the prase.
In the West Pilbara most major structures such as thrusts, strike-slip faults and folds have northeast-southwest trends.
These features resulted from several phases of northwest-southeast compressive and extensional events during the long tectonic evolution of the WPGGT.
The most common mineral associations present in the West Pilbara are gold and copper/gold (Carlow Castle), nickel-copper (Radio Hill), PGE (Munni Munni) and copper-lead-zinc (Whundo area).

Carlow Castle and surrounding districts, originally known as Glenroebourne, have been copper-gold producers since discovery in the 1860s and enjoyed a peak of mining activities from the late 1889 to about 1910.
Only limited mining has occurred since then.
Carlow Castle itself was last mined in 1957 when 105 tonnes of copper=rich ore was produced as fertilizer material.

Exploration activities completed during the reporting period included the following: 142 underground ore definition diamond drillholes for a total of 34415.1m 68 RC grade control drillholes in East Pit for a total of 2827m 5 RC void probe holes in East Pit for a total of 298m 3.0 INTRODUCTION This annual report summarises all exploration undertaken on the tenement between 24 October 2006 and 23 October 2007.
4.0 LOCATION AND ACCESS The Wiluna Project is located approximately 180km east of Meekatharra in central Western Australia.
The Wiluna town ship and Wiluna Gold Mine are located within the project area.
Access from Meekatharra is via the Gunbarrel Highway.

Access within the project is via unsealed roads and station tracks (Figure 1) 5.0 TENURE On 20 June 2007 Apex Minerals entered into an agreement with Oxiana Limited to acquire 100% ownership of the Wiluna gold mining and processing operation.
The acquisition includes the plant and infrastructure, existing gold resources and additional exploration potential.
The project is now managed by Apex Minerals.
The Wiluna Greenstone Belt can be divided into two metamorphic domains, the Wiluna domain in the east and the Matilda domain in the west.
The major north west trending Perseverance Fault (also known as the Erawalla Fault) separates the domains.

The Wiluna domain is a low grade, prehnite-pumpellyite facies, metamorphic terrain comprising mafic to ultramafic lavas with intercalated sedimentary units, felsic volcanics and dolerite sills overlain by a thick pile of felsic volcanics, tuffaceous sediments, and sedimentary rocks, interrupted by extrusion of a large volume of komatiitic lava.
Primary igneous textures and structures are well preserved, and deformation is predominantly brittle.
The Matilda domain is a medium to high grade, greenschist to lower amphibolite facies, metamorphic terrain with predominantly ductile deformation.
It consists of a volcano sedimentary sequence in an interpreted major north west trending synclinal structure, with the axis close to the Perseverance Fault.
The sequence comprises basal banded iron formation in the west, overlain by komatiitic volcanics with limited basal peridotite members.
These grade upwards into high magnesium basalt and basalt with interflow chert and graphitic sediments.
Metabasalt predominates in the project area.
Felsic volcanic rocks and sediments are interpreted to form the core of the syncline.
A number of granite plutons intruded both domains during the very latest stages of volcanism, or the earliest stages of subsequent compressional deformation and regional metamorphism.
Emplacement was essentially along the contact between the greenstones and the unknown substrate.

6.1 Local Geology Wiluna Mine At the Wiluna Gold Mine, the stratigraphy is dominated by a series of tholeiitic and high-magnesium basalts and generally strikes north north westerly, facing and dipping steeply to the south west.

Gold mineralisation, hosted by all major lithologic units, is controlled by the Wiluna Fault System (WFS), which consists of north- and northeast-trending, steeply east- and west-dipping sets of dextral strike-slip faults that disrupt the stratigraphy.
The ore shoots generally plunge moderately to steeply to the south.
Mineralisation is localised along faults at dilational bends or jogs, fault intersection, horsetail splays and in subsidiary overstepping faults.
Wall rock alteration, as well as the structural deformation and mineralisation, is asymmetrical in relation to the main fault planes, and is best developed in the hanging wall.
It forms distinct mappable colour zonation related to sequential wall-rock alterations around the faults.

Although alteration assemblages vary in detail depending on host rock, two major alteration zones can be defined in general: a distal chloritecalcite and a proximal sericite-silica-albite-dolomite/ankerite-arsenopyrite-pyrite zone.
Stibnite is present in a few deposits: Moonlight, West Lode and Happy Jack.
Gold is associated with sulphides, and shows positive correlation with the abundance of arsenopyrite.
In limited instances free gold has been observed in chalcedonic quartz veins.
See Figure 2 for the regional geology.

Exploration activities completed during the reporting period included the following: 142 underground ore definition diamond drillholes for a total of 34415.1m 68 RC grade control drillholes in East Pit for a total of 2827m 5 RC void probe holes in East Pit for a total of 298m 7.1 Drilling and Sampling Procedures Diamond drilling was completed using NQ sized core, the sampling and assaying was carried out using half core with sampling constrained by lithological boundaries.
Sampling of core is generally continuous with sampling being consistently on the same side of the core.
The maximum sample length in core was restricted to 1.2m.
Prior to July 2007 all analysis was carried out on site.

The historic Hogans Find Gold Mine, which is immediately to the east of the Project area, has a recorded production of 314.5 tonnes of ore, at an average grade of 27.35g/t gold up to 1904, together with 909 ounces of alluvial gold.
Previous work by Terrain Minerals has focused on the Coogee Gold deposit, to the east of the Aztec Dome, and various geophysical targets to the west of the Aztec Dome.

This report documents all exploration activity on those tenements that comprise the combined reporting group C148/2001 that was approved by the Department of Industry and Resources on 16/01/2001 and amended to include E26/97 on 30/01/2006.
On 01/102008 two of the then four Project leases, namely M26/478 and M26/485, were removed from the combined reporting group.

Fifty percent of E26/97 was compulsorily surrendered in April 2008 and previous project leases, M26/478 and M26/485, were surrendered on 20/09/2008 and have been reported separately as individual surrender reports.

Exploration activities during 2008 concentrated on the Aztec Dome portion of E26/97 and included a geophysical data review, acquisition of historic ground IP data, a ground gravity survey, a combined ground EM / IP survey, geological mapping and drafting, and geophysical interpretation of all available ground and airborne data along with small programs of petrography and whole rock and minor element analyses.
2.0 LOCATION AND ACCESS The Coogee Project is located 20km northeast of Kambalda, and 55km south of Kalgoorlie, on the north side of Lake Lefroy.
E26/97 straddles the boundary between the Woolibar and Mt Monger pastoral stations.
The Coogee (East Kambalda) Project, comprising M26/477 and E26/97, covers an area of 49.6km2 (previously 103km2) in the East Coolgardie District of the Coolgardie Mineral Field of Western Australia.

Access to the Project is via the well formed Carnilyia Hill to Kambalda unsealed haul road (to the north) and a series of four wheel drive station and exploration tracks, and several old abandoned woodline rail tracks.
Alternative access from Kalgoorlie is via the Mt.
Monger road to Mount Monger Homestead, and thence south to the Carnilya Hill mine site.
The southern part of the Project area straddles Lake Lefroy.
The historic Hogans Find Gold Mine is located to the immediate east of the Project area and is accessed by way of a series of tracks from the north.
Most of the area is impassable in wet weather as it is traversed by a series of drainage channels and flood plains which feed in to Lake Lefroy.
3.0 TENURE The Coogee (East Kambalda) Project comprises one Mining Lease and one Exploration Licence (Figure 2) covering 49.6km2.
Transfer to Terrain Minerals Ltd was completed on 05/02/2009.
A 50% compulsory surrender was completed in April 2008.
4.0 REGIONAL GEOLOGY The Project area lies within the Kalgoorlie Terrane in the southern part of the Eastern Goldfields Province of the Archaean Yilgarn Craton.

Separated from other greenstones in adjacent terranes by either major faults or granitoid intrusions, the Kalgoorlie Terrane is conventionally divided into four major and two smaller domains which despite being separated by shear zones and structural breaks have common deformation histories and similar regional litho-stratigraphic successions.
The Project falls within the northern confines of one of these smaller divisions, the Parker Domain.
The Parker Domain is bounded in the east and west respectively by two major regional north trending structures, the Mount Monger and Lefroy Faults.

To the north, the domain limits terminate south of the Carnilya Anticline at the east trending Talcum Fault, a major thrust that separates the Parker Domain from its northern neighbour, the Boorara Domain.
One hundred and twenty kilometres to the south-southeast granitoids of the Norseman Terrane close out the Parker Domains southward continuation.

Regional mapping of the domain, combined with interpretation of aeromagnetic data, indicates the presence of quite extensive areas of metamorphosed tholeiitic and high-Mg basalts, ultramafic rocks, sediments, felsic volcanics, and volcaniclastic rocks intruded by granitoid plutons.
The outcropping greenstones of the Parker Domain appear to relate regionally with the upper basalt unit and felsic volcanic-sedimentary unit of the adjacent Kambalda Domain.
However in the east, the sedimentary rocks contain magnetite-rich BIF horizons which may be more closely associated with the adjacent BIFbearing sedimentary rocks of the Kurnalpi Terrane.
Any comparisons drawn are tenuous as much of the Parker Domain, to date, has been only lightly explored and cursorily mapped.
The structural trend is northwest.
Northwest trending isoclinal folds, with some overturning of the east limbs, are cross folded into a series of elongate domes, the largest of which is the Aztec Dome.
These folds are dislocated by north trending faults that are truncated by major regional shears sub-parallel to the geological strike.
Late north-northeast trending faults affect all earlier structures.
3 CGC1482001A2008 Coogee Project 2008 Annual Report The weathering profile is a truncated laterite profile where upper saprolite is overlain by thin (<10m) of Cainozoic transported cover.
Rocks are relatively fresh in the areas of outcrop.
Lithologies and structure are largely concealed beneath the shallow Cainozoic cover north of Lake Lefroy.
The saline clays and muds of Lake Lefroy are of unknown depth as all exploration to date has been limited to the onshore area of the exploration licence.
5.0 DATA ACQUISITION AND PROCESSING All available relevant BHP data were sourced from historic exploration report open file item number 2014.

These data included geological and geochemical maps and accompanying reports, drill logs and assay data from drill holes R34 and R35, the detailed IP survey along the north edge of Lake Lefroy conducted by McPhar Geophysics in 1969 and a report on the geology and structure of the Carnilya Hill nickel deposit.
The collars of R34 and R35, on the regional imperial BHP grid, were picked up as GDA 94 and AMG 84 zone 51 co-ordinates.
The collar, downhole, sampling and assay data for historic holes R34 and R35 were digitally entered and forwarded to the database consultants for validation and entry into the database.
The BHP ground IP survey data was digitised from archived reports.
The data were then modeled using the Zonge 2D inversion program, firstly with no weighting and then for solutions with a vertical bias.

Two cross-sections of historic BHP holes R34 and R35, plus historic Sovereign Resources diamond core hole ASD001, in the southeastern outcropping portion of the Aztec Dome, are included as Figures 3 & 4.
6.0 GEOLOGICAL MAPPING Fourteen square klometres of outcrop, within the Aztec Dome portion of E26/97, were mapped at a scale of 1:5,000 (Appendix 1).
Bedrock geology and regolith was mapped onto transparent overlays over laminated 1:5,000 photo-enlargements of WA State colour vertical photography.
Digital photo images were purchased from the Central Map Agency of the Department of Land Information.
Selected points were marked on the overlays and recorded as MGA94, Zone 51 co-ordinates to scale control the field copies during drafting.
The northwest trending Aztec Dome is breached axially by a shear / fault occupied by the Parkeston Dyke.
The base of this hole intersected carbonate veined, spinifex textured komatiitic basalt (up to 17% MgO) this lithology does not outcrop.
The eastern side of the Dome is intruded by four, small quartz-syenite plugs that are oriented northwest.
The western side of the Dome has no felsic intrusives, no mapped interflow sediments, but the basalts have higher magnetic susceptibilities that can be used to map the individual basalt flows.
Three dimensional modeling of the gravity data provides a shape of the upper surface of the underlying denser rocks that fits well with the mapped geology and appears to be stratigraphic in nature.
The eastern side of the Dome appears to be down faulted with only the lower part of the basalt sequence exposed in the western half.
The depth to the top of the dense underlying rocks is much shallower on the western side of the Aztec Dome.
In a broad sense the geology of the Aztec Dome is comparable to the Kambalda Dome, 12km to the southwest.
Both Domes lie within the Late Archaean Kalgoorlie Terrane, which comprises a number of domains that share similar deformation histories and lithostratigraphic successions.
The Aztec (Dome) Basalt appears to correlate with the upper part of the Devon Consols Basalt at Kambalda, as it has a similar MgO content (6.8%), and rare pillows and fewer variolites.
Equivalents of the Kapai Slate and the Paringa Basalt are absent.
The underlying denser rocks (basal spinifex textured lithology in hole ASD001) are correlated with the Kambalda Komatiite.

Petrology shows that the basalts from hole ASD001 are metasomatically silica-carbonatepotash-sulphide altered with all primary textures largely obliterated by amphibolite grade metamorphism and metasomatism.
This metasomatic alteration is associated with the intrusion of a quartz syenite plug.
Anomalous base metal chemistry has been introduced into the basalts from a deeper, probable ultramafic source.
Values up to 3,500ppm Ni, 5,400ppm Cr, 430ppm Cu and 3.9% S occur in basalts (not the basal ultramafics) with anomalous values occurring over tens of metres down hole (Figures 3 & 4).
The high nickel values are attributed to the presence of nickeliferous pyrrhotite and the elevated copper values with trace chalcopyrite present as occluded particles in both pyrrhotite and pyrite.

The geological setting setting of the Aztec Dome, supported by geophysical interpretation and drill hole petrology and geochemistry, indicate that the mapped area is prospective for blind Kambalda-style komatiite hosted nickel deposits and for structurally controlled gold deposits.
The outcrop geology maps of the Aztec Dome at 1:5,000 scale are included as Figures 5 & 6.
The report on the geological mapping of the Aztec Dome is included as Appendix 1.
Information on the Parkeston Dyke, a prominent regionally extensive structure which cuts the Aztec Dome in half, is presented in Appendix 2.

Three samples were of metabasalts from the stratigraphically lowermost, the middle and close to the top of the basalt.
The fourth sample was of felsic intrusive.
Sample numbers and locations are shown in Table 2 below.
Clay silt, sand and gravel in channels and on floodplains.
Two are microporphyritic and aphyric basalts and the stratigaphically lowest is a high magnesian (komatiitic) basalt.
The intrusive is a late alkali quartz syenite with no metamorphic overprint.
The Mason Geoscience petrography report is shown in Appendix 3 (also as an appendix in the Appendix 1 geological mapping report).
8.0 WHOLE ROCK ANALYSES Eight rock chip outcrop samples were collected for whole rock analyses and a suite of minor elements.
Details of the samples collected and results are shown in Table 3.
Assaying was performed by the Kalgoorlie Assay Laboratory of the Kalassay Group.
Samples were oven dried at 120C before crushing to minus 3mm in a Fixed Jaw and Boyd-Type crushers.
Post crushing, the samples were pulverized in an LM5 Ring Mill to 90% passing 75 microns.
Pulverising bowls were cleaned by a high-suction vacuum system between samples and at the end of each batch of samples the bowls and pucks were cleaned by pulverizing barren silica sand.
For whole rock analysis by pressed powder, an accurately weighed 10 gram sub-sample is taken from the 200 grams homogenized pulp.
A binding agent is added, the mixture homogenized, placed in a die and formed into a hard disc in a 25 tonne hydraulic press.
Whole rock analyses comprised the nine main oxides of MgO, MnO, FeO, Al2O3, Na2O, SiO2, CaO, K2O, TiO2, by the XRF9 technique on a Bruker S4-X-ray spectrometer with LOI determined by fusion.

For base metal determination a 40g sub-sample of the homogenized pulp is placed in a disposable container and digested in a four acid mixture where the acids were added to the sample in the set order of nitric, perchloric, hydrochloric and finally hydrofluoric acid.

This acid digest commences at room temperature for thirty minutes before being transferred to a heated water bath bringing the temperature to 80C for a further one and a half hours after which the solution is allowed to cool.
A flocculant is then added, the sample homogenized, and the solution is rested until a clear supernatant solution develops.
The clear solution is pipetted off and diluted to a pre-set volume before being subjected to ICPMS analysis.
In-house and commercially available standards are digested and analysed with the sample batch along with blanks and duplicates.

Whole rock comparisons with Kambalda lithologies (Table 4) indicate that the Aztec Dome mafics and syenite intrusives have similar geochemistry to the Devon Consols Basalt and syenite bodies in the cover sequence at Kambalda.
This provides further encouragement for a similar geological setting between the Aztec Dome and the Kambalda Dome.

10.0 GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS 10.1 GENERAL All ground geophysical surveys and imaging, modeling, reviewing and interpretations of historic and new geophysical data sets were designed to better define the subsurface geology of the Aztec Dome, and in particular, to define the extent of high density lithologies (Kambalda-style komatiites below the base of historic hole ASD001) and major structures, with a view to highlighting prospective nickel and gold drill targets.
These geophysical data sets and reports are shown in Appendices 4 -10.
10.2 GROUND GRAVITY SURVEY Atlas Geophysics, of Morley, Western Australia, undertook a two man ground gravity survey over the Aztec Dome between 26/06/2008 05/07/2008.
Data from 1,070 ground stations were acquired on a nominal spacing of 100m X 250m, with some infill at 100m X 125m.
Gravity data were acquired concurrently with GPS-Glonass data using a Scintrex CG5 Autograv Gravity Meter.
A single loop was completed for each shift worked with each loop containing a minimum of two repeated readings such that an interlocking network of closed loops was formed.
A total of five per cent repeats were acquired for quality control purposes.
Gravity control was established via an ABA and ABABA loop on multiple days to the Kalgoorlie Aeroclub AFGN 1964910114.
Expected accuracy is better than 0.01mGals.
GPS control was established using AUSPOS.
Three separate 10 hour sessions were submitted to AOAPOSs online processing systems where returned co-ordinates were accurate to better than 0.01m.
The field control station is a plaqued geodetic point GRVGPS0039.
Final data were received in both digital and hardcopy format.
The Atlas Geophysics gravity survey acquisition report is included in Appendix 4 and the digital data accompanies this report.

7 CGC1482001A2008 Coogee Project 2008 Annual Report 10.3 GROUND EM and IP SURVEY A three man geophysical crew from Zonge Engineering and Research Organisation (Australia) Pty Ltd (Zonge), South Australia, completed surveying on the cleared historic BHP grid lines 13000NW and 15000NW, covering a portion of the southern Aztec Dome, between 03/11/2008 -15/11/2008.
The survey was terminated because of bad weather (rain and thunderstorms), slow production, and lack of time.
The remainder of this survey is planned for completion during the 2009 field season.
A total of 3.65 line kilometres of complex resistivity induced polarisation (IP) data were collected on historic BHP line 13000NW.
A further 6.20 line kilometres of coincident moving loop time domain electromagnetic (EM) data were collected on historic BHP lines 13000NW and 15000NW.
This EM data was collected at 200m stations on both lines, with minor 100m station infill on line 13000NW.

The EM and IP surveys were designed to locate small volumes of massive sulphide mineralisation surrounded by appreciable volumes of disseminated sulphide mineralisation of the Kambalda style of nickel mineralisation.
Also, the IP survey would allow for the evaluation of the quality of the 1969 BHP IP survey.

However, it is unclear how deep these surveys can see through the outcropping basalt cover sequence, and how thick the underlying ultramafic sequence is, and the depth to the prospective contact at the base of the potential host ultramafic sequence.
IP and EM data were initially collected on historic BHP line 130000NW to determine which method would be best suited to exploring for nickel mineralisation in the Aztec Dome area.
On the basis of this initial line only EM was collected on line 15000NW before the issues described above resulted in termination of the survey.
The location of the survey lines is shown in Figure 7.
The Zonge survey logistics report is shown in Appendix 5.
11.0 GEOPHYSICAL INTERPRETATION 11.1 REVIEW OF HISTORIC BHP IP DATA Value Adding Resources reviewed the 1969 BHP IP survey data over the southern onshore part of the Aztec Dome (Appendix 6).
The data were re-modeled after the data were digitized from archived reports to provide a clearer picture of chargeable and/or conductivity sources that may be related to sulphide mineralization.
This proved to be a useful exercise as twelve targets were identified.
The strong IP response from Target A is complex, multi-sourced and is of a disseminated style of mineralisation, located on the south-east margin of a syenite plug.
This could be a hydrothermal gold / copper target or may be associated with disseminated copper / nickel adjacent reflecting the anomalous geochemistry in historic hole ASD001?
Targets B and K coincide with the Parkeston Dyke and are considered to be moderate gold targets.
Targets C, D, F, G, H, I, J and L are located in the western portion of the Aztec Dome and are rated low order anomalies for nickel.

These targets are percentage frequency effect (PFE) and/ / or 8 CGC1482001A2008 Coogee Project 2008 Annual Report conductive responses associated with lithological contacts of which Targets J, G, and D are the most interesting for nickel mineralisation.
Target locations are shown in Figure 8 and the geophysical review report is shown in Appendix 6.
11.2 INTERPRETATION OF GRAVITY & AEROMAGNETIC DATA Imaging and modeling of the Atlas Geophysics gravity data and the UTS 1996 aeromagnetic data were performed by Fathom Geophysics.
Preliminary imaging of the geophysical data sets is shown in Appendix 7.

This was effective in defining the major lithological and structural units within the Aztec Dome, and served as a base for more detailed interpretation and subsequent planning for ground EM and IP surveying.

3D gravity inversion modeling of the gravity data was isosurfaced to determine the shape of the top of the denser rock unit interpreted to be ultramafics - top of the nickel prospective Kambalda komatiite sequence?.
This surface was visualised using FracSIS and is estimated to be 250-300m below the current land surface?
A series of geophysical images were produced and are included in the Fathom Geophysics Appendix 8 report.
One image example is shown in Figure 9.
Of note is the distinct hole in this high density isosurface which relates to the presence of a low density lithology in the southeastern portion of the Aztec Dome.
Historic diamond core hole ASD001 is located on the edge of this feature a likely felsic intrusive.
This high density isosurface also has a very sharp, steep dipping western edge.
Also of note is the presence a more magnetically susceptible zone which may reflect interlayered and folded high and low magnetic response (?)
mafics / ultramafics beneath the western portion of the Aztec Dome.
This work led to a simplified interpretation of the Aztec Dome, and a comparison with the Kambalda Dome, as shown in Figure 10.
A manual interpretation of the Sovereign Resouces 1996 UTS aeromagnetics and the Atlas Geophysics 2008 gravity data over the Aztec Dome was completed by Fathom Geophysics (Appendix 9).
Geological mapping was supplied by Terrain Minerals.
The Dome has two distinct sides; the western half contains some highly magnetic basalt units, while the eastern half has moderately magnetic basalts with thin interflow sediments.
The Dome is surrounded by sediments and intermediate to felsic tuffs.
The eastern half has five possible felsic intrusives; one is apparent on the gravity while the others are apparent on the magnetics.
The western edge of the Dome shows rapid changes in both the gravity and magnetic data interpreted as a steeply west dipping shear while the eastern half is more shallow dipping and stratigraphic.
The highly magnetic portions of the basalts are restricted mostly to the core of the Dome, indicating a deeper level of exposure of the western half.
A prominent northwest tending shear zone, occupied by a Parkeston Dyke, separates the two halves of the Dome.
A large west-northwest trending shear zone, occupied by a Proterozoic dyke, terminates the Dome to the north.
Several gravity anomalies are evident in the Aztec Dome, some associated with coincident magnetic anomalies, including a zone of high density rocks (ultramafics at shallowmoderate depth?)
on the western edge of the Aztec Dome and a low density "hole" (likely !
