Two prospective folded ultramafic zones have been defined in the western portion of the Aztec Dome whilst the rim of the syenite intrusion (near anomalous historic hole ASD001) in the eastern portion of the Aztec Dome continues to be firmed up as a geophysically interesting region.

A string of gold targets were defined in the eastern and northern Aztec Dome, mostly associated with the faulted margins of outcropping and interpreted syenite intrusive plugs, and two gold targets were defined in the folded core of the western Aztec Dome.
The best nickel targets were defined in the interpreted ultramafic units below the western Aztec Dome.
Figure 11 is a geophysical interpretation map of the Aztec Dome refer to Appendix 9 for more detail.
11.3 INTERPRETATION OF EM & IP DATA The Kambalda komatiite hosted nickel ore bodies are small in size but are high grade.
The nickel mineralisation occurs at the contact between the host serpentinised komatiites (Kambalda Komatiite unit) and footwall basalts (Lunnon Basalt unit).
The sulphide ore zones are usually less than 6m true width.
Some of the mineralisation is massive, but there are larger volumes of disseminated mineralisation.
The mineralisation can be traced for kilometres and is of variable width.
The economic ore zones have dimensions of 100m to 150m.
These ore zones have small geophysical footprints and therefore are difficult geophysical targets.

In the Aztec Dome the thickness of the outcropping basalt cover sequence - equivalent to the hangingwall Devon Consols Basalt and the thickness of the potential host ultramafic sequence equivalent to the Kambalda Komatiite are not accurately known.
Therefore, the depth to the base of the potential host ultramafic sequence will be a limiting factor in the effectiveness of any geophysical survey for nickel sulphide ore bodies.
The footprint of the nickel mineralisation for IP and TEM are different.
It is expected that the IP footprint will be larger due to disseminated halo surrounding the massive mineralisation (which will have an EM footprint).
The expected IP signature is of a phase anomaly with an associated conductive zone.
The EM expected signature is of a discrete conductive anomaly.
Figure 12 (from Appendix 10) is a depth slice at 175m depth from the inverted IP survey data .
Several phase anomalies are shown - labeled A to E. Anomalies B, C and D are rated the higher anomalies.
Anomaly B is located on the Parkeston Dyke and is most likely composed of multiple bodies.
Anomaly B coincides with a resistive zone and is a potential gold target.
Anomalies C and D are complex responses and are associated with a very weak conductor at station 2100E.
These two anomalies are potential gold and nickel targets.
Anomalies A and E are located to the east of the Parkeston Dyke.
The phase anomalies are located on the flanks of weak conductive response.
The EM plate model is located between these phase anomalies.
Figure 13 (from Appendix 10) shows the amplitude profile plot of the EM data on line 13000NW (200m loop).
The data are dominated by polarisation effects.
The polarisation effect is not an EM response and makes the data unreliable to interpret.
The negative decay is clearly the result of polarisation effects.
It is difficult to ascertain more subtle polarisation effects that may be affecting other stations.
There is a possible bedrock feature centred about station 3600mE (387971E / 6556636N) that may be the response associated with a near vertical conductor.
The feature has the classic M shaped response (moving loop) associated with vertical conductors.
Anomaly peaks at stations 3400E and 3700E have times constants of about 3.1 and 4.4 ms respectively.
This must be treated with caution as the response is probably at the resolution of the Zonge TEM-3 coil and factors such as a windy day can produce such a response with this coil.
On line 15000NW the EM data are dominated by polarisation effects.
The polarisation effect is not an EM response and makes the data unreliable to interpret.
No bedrock conductors are evident, although there is a weak conductive zone centred about station 3200N.
More survey work on lines further north is required before a proper evaluation of the effectiveness of the IP and EM geophysical techniques can be made planned for 2009.

12.0 DISCUSSION & CONCLUSIONS Petrology shows that the basalts from historic diamond core hole ASD001 are metasomatically silica-carbonate-potash-sulphide altered with all primary textures largely obliterated by amphibolite grade metamorphism and metasomatism.
This metasomatic alteration is associated with the intrusion of a quartz syenite plug.
Anomalous base metal chemistry has been introduced into the basalts from a deeper, probable ultramafic source.

Values up to 3,500ppm Ni, 5,400ppm Cr, 430ppm Cu and 3.9% S occur in basalts (not the basal ultramafics) with anomalous values occurring over tens of metres down hole this is unexpected and highly anomalous.
The high nickel values are attributed to the presence of nickeliferous pyrrhotite and the elevated copper values with trace chalcopyrite present as occluded particles in both pyrrhotite and pyrite.

The geological setting setting of the Aztec Dome, supported by geophysical interpretation and drill hole petrology and geochemistry indicate that the mapped area is prospective for blind Kambalda-style komatiite hosted nickel deposits and for structurally controlled gold deposits.

In the Aztec Dome the thickness of the outcropping basalt cover sequence (Devon Consols Basalt equivalent) and the thickness of the potential host ultramafic sequence (Kambalda Komatiite equivalent) are not accurately known.
Therefore, the depth to the base of the potential host ultramafic sequence will be a limiting factor in the effectiveness of any geophysical survey for Kambalda-style nickel sulphide ore bodies.

A series of IP and EM anomalies were defined on two lines across the southern portion of the outcropping Aztec Dome, however, this survey is incomplete and more geophysical data must be collected prior to a full evaluation of the subsurface anomalism of prospective areas.

To date IP has been more effective than EM in defining geophysical anomalies, several of which - especially around the margins of the syenite intrusive plug near hole ASD001, and the Figure 13: EM Line 13000N 200m Loop Amplitude Profiles Station 3600mE 11 Parkeston Dyke are prospective for gold.
The potential for hydrothermal disseminated sulphide gold deposits has been largely ignored to date.

Nevertheless, Ni, Cr, Cu, and S anomalism in hole ASD001 remains unexplained and must be a focus for future nickel exploration, along with geophysical anomalies under the western portion of the Aztec Dome.
The prize for discovering another Kambalda-style nickel camp will be huge.
This expenditure has amounted to approximately $203,000 (against an annual tenement commitment of $30,000).
Full expenditure details will be provided in the Form 5 expenditure report for the year ending 12/04/2009 in the next few months.

It is anticipated than an expenditure of between $70,000 - $100,000 will be required in the 2009 tenure year of E26/97 to complete the EM / IP geophysical surveying, interpretation, and drill target selection of the Aztec Dome.

REFERENCES .1 4 Kambalda East Project Aztec Dome Geological Mapping 2008 ii List of Figures Figure 1 Aztec Dome Location Plan 1:50,000 Figure 2 Aztec Dome Outcrop Geology 1:10,000 Figure 3 ASD 001 Stratigraphic Column Figure 4 Aztec Dome Poster List of Appendices Appendix 1 Mapping Control Points Appendix 2 Photographs Appendix 3 Petrology Reports Kambalda East Project Aztec Dome Geological Mapping 2008 1 SUMMARY Fourteen square kilometers of outcrop, within E26/97, were mapped at a scale of 1:5,000.
Integration of the geological mapping with low level aeromagnetic data and ground gravity data has delineated the outline of the Aztec Dome, its major shears and felsic intrusions.
The northwest trending Aztec Dome is breached axially by a shear occupied by the Parkeston Dyke.

A diamond drill hole on the eastern half of the Dome indicates that the basalts have a stratigraphic thickness of around three hundred meters and that thin interflow sediments are concentrated near the top of the basalt sequence.
The eastern side of the Dome is intruded by four, small quartz-syenite plugs that are oriented northwest.
The western side of the Dome has no felsic intrusives, no mapped interflow sediments, but the basalts have higher magnetic susceptibilities that can be used to map the individual basalt flows.
Three dimensional modelling of the gravity data provides a shape of the upper surface of the underlying denser rocks that fits well with the mapped geology and appears to be stratigraphic in nature.
The eastern side of the Dome appears to be down faulted with only the lower part of the basalt sequence exposed in the western half.
The depth to the top of the dense underlying rocks is much shallower on the western side of the Aztec Dome.
In a broad sense the geology of the Aztec Dome is comparable to the Kambalda Dome, twelve kilometers to the southwest.
Both Domes lie within the Late Archaean Kalgoorlie Terrane, which comprises a number of domains that share similar deformation histories and litho-stratigraphic successions.
INTRODUCTION Fourteen square kilometers of outcrop, within E26/97, were mapped at a scale of 1:5,000 between 9th - 23rd August 2008.
The outcrop pattern of the basalts was mapped to provide the shape of the Aztec Dome.
These data were integrated with the Sovereign Resources 1996 UTS low level aeromagnetic data and the 2008 Atlas Geophysics ground gravity data to produce an interpretation of the Aztec Dome.
During mapping four samples were collected for petrographic descriptions and digital photographs of interesting geology were taken.
LOCATION and PHYSIOGRAPHY The Aztec Dome, part of the Terrain Minerals Ltd Kambalda East Project, is located 15 kilometres northeast of Kambalda on the north side of Lake Lefroy (Figure 1).
It lies on the Widgiemooltha (SH51-14) 1:250,000 and Lake Lefroy (3235) 1:100,000 map sheets, in the East Coolgardie District of the Coolgardie Mineral Field of Western Australia.
The Dome straddles the boundary between the Woolibar and Mt Monger pastoral leases.

Kambalda East Project Aztec Dome Geological Mapping 2008 M26/477 LEGEND Nickel Mine Major Shear Gold deposit Gold prospect 380000mE370000mE 6560000mN 6550000mN Lake Lefroy Kambalda Dome Hunt Lunnon Fisher Juan McMahon Long Victor Durkin Coogee Au deposit Boulder - Lefroy Fault M t M onger Fault 390000mE Carnilya Hill Cutters Luck (Au) E26/97 Hogans Find (Au) N 250m0 Parkeston Dyke Aztec Dome 2 Access is via the well formed Kambalda to Carnilyia Hill unsealed haul road or alternatively from Kalgoorlie via the Mt.
Monger road to Mount Monger Homestead, and thence south to the Carnilya Hill mine site and thence by a series of four wheel drive station and exploration tracks.
Most of the area is impassable in wet weather as it is traversed by a series of drainage channels and flood plains which feed in to Lake Lefroy.
The surface of the generally dry, saline, Lake Lefroy at approximately 290 meters above Australian height datum, dominates the area.
The highest hills are on the north shore of the lake rising to 336 meters, and the best rock exposures occur where steep slopes are close to the lake shore.
Despite the steep hills the slopes and gullies are generally scree covered and do not provide the best outcrop.
Aprons of rock dominated colluvium extend laterally 150 meters outwards from the hill outcrop areas, grading into alluvium or gently undulating loam with pedogenic carbonate developed over subcrop.
Dune sand extends east and west of the hill masses along the north shore of the lake.
REGIONAL GEOLOGICAL SETTING The East Kambalda Project lies within the Kalgoorlie Terrane in the southern part of the Eastern Goldfields Province of the Yilgarn Craton.

Separated from other greenstones in adjacent terranes by either major faults or granitoid intrusions, the Kalgoorlie Terrane is conventionally divided into four major and two smaller domains which despite being separated by shear zones and structural breaks have common deformation histories and similar regional litho-stratigraphic successions.
The Kambalda East Project falls within the northern confines of one of these smaller divisions, the Parker Domain.
The Parker Domain is bounded in the east and west respectively by two major regional north trending structures, the Mount Monger and Lefroy Faults.

To the north, the domain limits terminate south of the Carnilya Anticline at the east trending Talcum Fault, a major thrust that separates the Parker Domain from its northern neighbour, the Boorara Domain.
One hundred and twenty kilometres to the south-southeast granitoids of the Norseman Terrane close out the Parker Domains southward continuation.

Regional mapping of the domain, combined with interpretation of aeromagnetic data, indicates the presence of quite extensive areas of metamorphosed tholeiitic and highMg basalts, ultramafic rocks, sediments, felsic volcanics, and volcaniclastic rocks intruded by granitoid plutons.
The outcropping greenstones of the Parker Domain appear to relate regionally with the upper basalt unit and felsic volcanic-sedimentary unit of the adjacent Kambalda Domain.
However in the east, the sedimentary rocks contain magnetite-rich BIF horizons which may be more closely associated with the adjacent BIFbearing sedimentary rocks of the Kurnalpi Terrane (Swager et.
Any comparisons drawn are tenuous as much of the Parker Domain, to date, has been only lightly explored and cursorily mapped.

PREVIOUS MAPPING INVESTIGATIONS The first edition geological mapping, by the GSWA, with explanatory notes of the Widgiemooltha (SH51-14) 1:250,000 sheet in 1966, was superseded in 1989 by the second edition by Griffin (1989).
Griffin (1990) also produced the GWSA Report 32 entitled Geology of the Granite-Greenstone terrane of the Lake Lefroy and Cowan 1:100,000 Sheets, Western Australia.
In the late 1960s and early 1970s the area was held in a Temporary Reserve by BHP for several years as part of its extensive exploration programme for nickel in the Mount Monger district.
In 1985 CRA commissioned Jack Hallberg to map its tenements at 1:25,000 scale.
His resulting Mt Monger series, however, only extends westwards to cover Hogans Find.
In August 1990, David Isles of World Geoscience Consultants, completed an interpretation of high resolution aeromagnetic data of Croesuss Hogans Find / Cutters Luck area.
In 1991 N Archibald included 1:25,000 reconnaissance mapping by Aztec Exploration in his regional interpretation.
During 1999 Ralph Bourn incorporated all previous mapping and interpreted the regional geology on behalf of Sovereign Resources (Bourn, 1999).
GEOLOGICAL MAPPING 5.1 Methodology, Control and Accuracy Fourteen square kilometers of outcrop, within E26/97, were mapped at a scale of 1:5,000.
Bedrock geology and regolith were mapped onto transparent overlays over laminated 1:5,000 photo-enlargements of WA State colour vertical photography.
The Atlas Geophysics station, GRVGPS0039, has a positional accuracy of better than 0.01 meter for latitude and longitude, GDA 94, AMG 84 and AHD.
These control point data are included in Appendix 1.
The BHP cut grid lines (1965) and the Aztec Exploration grid (1987) were recorded on overlays and their survey details were sourced from archived company reports.
These data were then used as additional scale control and positional accuracy of the mapping which is three meters.

Kambalda East Project Aztec Dome Geological Mapping 2008 4 The gravity height data (AHD) from 1,070 gravity stations collected by Atlas Geophysics in June-July 2008, were converted to a topographic contour file with contours at two meter intervals.
The geo-reference system for geological mapping is MGA 94, zone 51.
Geological drafting was performed by Ellis Drafting and Graphics, West Perth, using Mapinfo.
Final plots were coloured north and south sheets at 1:5,000 with legend and inset of the stratigraphy of historic hole, ASD 001, and a 1:10,000 coloured plot with contours (Figure 2).

The Mapinfo layers are:- Geology_polygons Polygon_text contacts structure structure_text aztec_grid bhp_grid tenement rab drill holes contours drainage fences railway tracks labels Legend Legend_fill 5.2 Legend and Rock Codes The rock codes used were those documented in the GSWA Record 2004/13 entitled East Yilgarn Geoscience Database-Updated Rock Codes by Riganti & Groenewald (2004).
MAPPED LITHOLOGIES The supracrustal rocks have been metamorphosed to upper greenschist to lower amphibolite facies regional metamorphism, based on mineral assemblages.
There are still enough original textures preserved to use protolith nomenclature.
The prefix meta, therefore, has been omitted from the lithological name and units are discussed in terms of their protoliths.
The felsic intrusive rocks show no regional metamorphic overprint.
The IUGS classification (Le Bas and Streckeisen, 1991) is used for igneous rocks.
Clay silt, sand and gravel in channels and on floodplains.
They are brecciated to crudely pillowed with abundant millimeter scale variolites and sheeves of millimeter scale actinolite-tremolite needles that are often slightly plumose.

These basalts crop out along the lake shore in the embayment in the core of the Dome and underlie areas of scree covered subdued relief near the drainage that feeds into Lake Lefroy (refer to Appendix 2 photos).
Basalt (Abb) These basalts are grey-green, fine-grained to coarse-grained rocks that are almost gabbroic in appearance when coarse-grained.
Individual flows vary in thickness from meters to tens of meters.
The thicker flows tend to be coarse-grained, have subophitic texture, and are sometimes porphyritic, with plagioclase phenocrysts up to five millimeters.
The majority of the basalts are aphanitic, massive rocks that are commonly, hyaloclastites.
Pillow basalts are locally common and more easily seen along the shores of Lake Lefroy.
Porphyritic varieties are relatively common, with plagioclase occurring as scattered small millimeter scale phenocrysts.
Glomeroporphyritic varieties are rare, as are variolites.
Vesicles and quartz amygdales, however, are more common.
Millimeter scale magnetite octahedra are present in some outcrops and float and these basalts respond to the hand magnet.
Basalt, mapped as magnesian tholeiite, forms the majority of the outcrop and the feldspars are invariably epidotised to varying intensities(refer to Appendix 2 photos).

Mafic Pyroclastic (Abx) One band of subrounded lapilli tuff with lapilli up to three centimeters in diameter crops out in the central portion of the eastern half of the Dome (refer to Appendix 2 photos).
Interflow Sediments (As) Interflow sediments crop out poorly and are thin, discontinuous, banded to brecciated, carbonaceous or siliceous, sulphidic rocks.
The main outcrop area is along the BHP cut line between historic holes R34 and ASD 001, on the eastern side of the Dome.
Intermediate Tuffs (Ait) These are fine-grained to medium-grained crystal tuffs of latite to quartz latite composition, composed of feldspar, hornblende, biotite and quartz.
Individual outcrops are quite variable and can be mixed with thin siliceous volcaniclastics, thin cherty sediments and the occasional black shale and quartz granule-conglomerate mudstone.
Sandstone (Ass) Outcrop of these rocks is restricted to hill to the east of the historic Draggoon workings.

The quartz sandstones are planar bedded, laminated, with rare ripple marks and Kambalda East Project Aztec Dome Geological Mapping 2008 6 centimeter scale trough cross bedding which indicate the beds are inverted (refer to Appendix 2 photos).
Conglomerate (Asc) and carbonaceous Black Shale (Aslb) form a minor component of the mapping.
6.2 Mafic Intrusives Dolerite / gabbro (Abd / Abg) Dolerite and gabbro are present as thin, lenticular bodies no more than a few hundred meters long that are contemporaneous with the basalts.
They are neither differentiated nor layered.

6.3 Granitoids Quartz Syenite (Ags) These are pink-grey coloured, massive equigranular, or more commonly, porphyritic felsic intrusives occurring as subcircular plugs up to nine hundred meters in diameter and confined to the eastern half of the Dome.
Feldspar phenocrysts are abundant as stubby euhedral to subhedral square to oblong shaped, concentrically zoned crystals up to ten millimeters in size.
Rare mafic xenoliths occur as centimeter scale, subrounded, partly absorbed bodies.
Dyke swarms on a centimeter thick to meter thick scale are peripheral to the main plug north of historic hole ASD 001.
The dykes have a variety of trends and occasionally bifurcate.
An irregular reticulated pattern of white quartz veins occurs in the center of the main plug (refer to Appendix 2 photos).
6.4 Regolith Apart from skeletal soils over areas of outcrop and subcrop the regolith is depositional.
Alluvium (CA) Clay, silt, sand and gravel in channels and on flood plains.

Colluvium (CCl) Proximal colluvium dominated by rock fragments, occur as aprons to hill masses and scree in valleys within the hill masses Colluvium (CCq) Proximal colluvium dominated by vein quartz fragments, is closely associated with subcrop of felsic intrusives.

Kambalda East Project Aztec Dome Geological Mapping 2008 7 Colluvium (CCf) Proximal colluvium dominated by weakly magnetic pisolite gravel and re-worked ferruginous duricrust and mega-mottles, forms around areas of ferruginised saprolite near Stans Dam.
Colluvium (Cck) Calcrete dominated thin colluviun as nodules and crusts on basalt and high-Mg basalt around the margin of Lake Lefroy.
Lacustrine (Ld) Active aeolian dunes and lake deposits are marginal to Lake Lefroy.
PETROLOGY Four drill chip and outcrop samples were submitted to Mason Geoscience, Adelaide, for preparation of thin sections and petrographic description.
Three samples were of basalts from the lower, the middle and close to the top of the outcropping basalt sequence.
The fourth sample was a syenite intrusive.
Primary textures are partially preserved.

The two chip samples from historic Aztec Exploration reverse circulation drill holes on its Southern Anomaly are micro-porphyritic and aphyric basalts, from the middle and top of the basalt pile, and the stratigaphically lowest sample, from the shore of Lake Lefroy, is a high magnesian (komatiitic) basalt, with preserved (expyroxene) spinifex textures in centimeter sized ovoids.
The intrusive is a late aegerine bearing quartz syenite with no regional metamorphic overprint.
Sample 101092, from the historic Aztec Exploration Draggoon Anomaly, shows a hydrothermal overprint of silica + carbonate + potash + sulphide overprint, associated with weak gold mineralization.
The Mason Geoscience petrology report (Mason, 2008) is included as Appendix 3.
Selected Mintek Services petrology reports (Borner, 1998), prepared for Sovereign Resources, are also included in Appendix 3.
Kambalda East Project Aztec Dome Geological Mapping 2008 8 8.
STRATIGRAPHY Current geochronology information indicates a late Archaean stratigraphic succession deposited over 55 Ma within the Kalgoorlie Terrane from 2715 Ma to 2660 Ma.
The Kalgoorlie Terrane has the best defined litho-stratigraphic sequences in the Eastern Goldfields Superterrane.
The Kambalda Sequence of mafic and ultramafic rocks, that hosts nickel mineralization, was deposited between 2715 Ma and 2690 Ma.
The maficultramafic sequence typically has a lower basalt unit, the Lunnon basalt, overlain by a komatiite dominated ultramafic unit, the Kambalda Komatiite, and an upper basalt unit.
The upper basalt unit is subdivided into the Devon Consols Basalt that is separated from the overlying Paringa Basalt by the Kapai Slate.
The Kambalda Komatiite has been dated at 2707 Ma and the Kapai Slate has an age of 2692 4 Ma.
The Kalgoorlie Sequence was deposited between 2690 Ma and 2660 Ma and unconformably overlies the Kambalda Sequence.
Within the Kalgoorlie Sequence four unconformity based sequences of andesitic, dacitic and rhyolitic volcaniclastics and derived sediments (Black Flag Beds) are currently recognized.

The late Archaean syenites pre-date the Proterozoic Parkeston Dyke and are probably similar in age to seriate sodic syenite / quartz syenite in the northern parts of the Eastern Goldfields that have been age dated as 2500 Ma (2489 82) by Rb-Sr isochron (Libby and de Laeter, 1981).
Undeformed Proterozoic dykes were intruded at 2400 Ma.
8.1 Diamond Drill Hole ASD 001 Diamond core hole ASD 001 was drilled in December 1997 by Sovereign Resources to test a coincident gravity and magnetic anomaly.
Unfortunately the core has been discarded and no core photography is available.
Ralph Bourn, now retired, logged the core and personal communication with him confirmed the fate of the core.
The following lithological descriptions, drill hole summary and drill hole stratigraphy have been taken from his accounts in Sovereign Resource reports.
Core samples were dispatched to Mintek Services (Perth) for petrographic descriptions (Borner, 1998 see Appendix 3).
Bourn (1999) subdivided the basalts as follows :- Amphibolite-1 Dark grey, fine-grained, strongly metasomatised orthoamphibolite having the appearance of an aphanitic silicified metabasalt.

Microscopically the diagnostic igneous textures have been obliterated by varying degrees of silicic, epidotitic, potassic, sulphidic and carbonate alteration with hornblende of amphibolite facies grade metamorphic origin variably replaced by metasomatic quartz and biotite with later quartz carbonate veining.
The paragenesis of pyrite and pyrrhotite is more complex with evidence for both early and late stage sulphidisation processes occurring.
Amphibolite-2 Dark grey, fine-grained, strongly metasomatised orthoamphibolite having the appearance of a slightly microphyric, spotted metabasalt.
The spots are white and microscopically in one instance have been determined as relic amygdaloidal quartz infillings.
Darker green ones are saussuritised plagioclase grains and clusters.
Visually most of the spots appear to be feldspar laths or varioles usually less than one millimeter in length or diameter.

As with Amphibolite-1 type, primary diagnostic igneous Kambalda East Project Aztec Dome Geological Mapping 2008 9 features are invariably lacking due to the destructive intense silicic, potassic, carbonate and sulphidic alteration.
Amphibolite-3 Dark green, fine-grained, silicified, carbonatised and epidotised orthoamphibolite.
Microscopically the green colouration is due to metamorphic actinolite which constitutes almost 40% of the rock.
Quartz, carbonate and epidote are replacing the amphibole.

Komatiitic basalt or high magnesium basalt Petrographically this rock type has been described as a greyish-green, carbonate veined, amphibole-chlorite, spinifex textured high magnesium basalt or komatiitic basalt.
Normalised geochemical plotting of Al2O3, CaO and MgO, position this rock unit in the theoretical fractionation path of a komatiitic basalt which supports the petrological observations.
Volcanic breccia Grey to dark grey, fine-grained strongly metasomatically altered fragmental.
Invariably the support matrix to the fragments is lighter grey in colour.
Most of the breccia appears to be of a flow-top origin except where intensely veined by carbonate and obviously tectonic.
Fragments range in size from a few millimeters to over three centimeters.
Throughout the core either the fragments or the matrix is sulphidised, but never both together.
In the stricter sense the breccias are not entirely homogeneous or monolithic as exotic sulphide, Amphibolite types 1 and 2, as well as fibrous spinifex textured fragments, co-exist side by side.
Tuffaceous sediment or tuff Dark brown, very fine-grained, moderately foliated tuff or tuffaceous sediment that has been silicified, biotitised, and carbonatised.
Though distinctly laminated in appearance because of of biotite and carbonate segregation, microscopic examination provides no evidence of primary relic clastic or pyroclastic textures.

The drill hole stratigraphy is a sequence of orthoamphibolites (metabasalts) with intercalations of slumped tuffaceous and chemically derived sediments (cherts, jaspers).
The orthoamphibolites exhibit considerable fragmentation which can mostly be attributed to the brecciation of individual lava flow tops though some tectonic brecciation is also evident.
Towards the bottom of the hole the composition changes from magnesian basalt to komatiitic basalt or high-Mg basalts.
Most diagnostic igneous textures have been obliterated by silica, epidotite, potash, sulphide and carbonate metasomatism.
This has resulted in sections of the core exhibiting classic quartz-carbonate stockwork structures.
Other intervals have considerable pyrite and pyrrhotite mineralisation which generally occur as disseminations and veinlets.
Some of the orthoamphibolites show variolitic, micro-amygdaloidal and coalescing patchy textures which enables a crude differentiation to be made between lithotypes Amphibolite 1 and 2.
Also evident, though less common, are occasional fibrous spinifex textures within the orthoamphibolites.
Amphibolite 3 is quite distinct from the other two amphibolites and appears to be a slightly later intrusive into the sequence.
The lithology of most interest in the diamond core is the platy spinifex textured, heavily carbonate-veined amphibole chlorite rock intersected near the base of the hole.

Whilst the texture is extraordinarily similar to ultramafic spinifex rock identified elsewhere in the Yilgarn, microscopic and geochemical studies indicates the unit to most likely be komatiitic or high-Mg basalt.
Bourn (1999) considered the succession to dip to the southeast at between 40o and 70o as evidenced from the ?
angles of tuffaceous meta-sediments which occur at 55.73m, 62.63m, 68.0m and the thin, occasionally laminated, siliceous intraformational cherty tuffs logged at 98.42m,102.45m and 236.48m.
The orthoamphibolites are usually too brecciated and tectonically disturbed to derive younging directions.
Correlating the thin interflow sediments cropping out between the collars of R34 and ASD 001 with the interflow sediments logged in the diamond drill hole gives a 45o dip eastwards.
This gives an interpreted stratigraphic thickness of 290 meters for the basalt with overlying felsic tuffs and sediments and underlying komatiitic basalts (Figure 3).
Variolitic high-Mg basalts crop out on the lake shore of the embayment.
These rocks would appear to represent the lowermost exposed part of the Dome stratigraphy.

STRUCTURE The Aztec Dome is manifested as a range of hills of basalt and dolerite intruded by coarse-grained porphyritic syenite.
The domal structure is indicated by magnetic trends as there are few dip indicators or stratigraphic markers in the area of outcrop.
The outcrop pattern correlates broadly with a pronounced magnetic and gravity high.
The Dome has dimensions of six kilometers northwest by three kilometers northeast.
The outcropping onshore part has a strike length of four kilometers with the remainder of the Dome continuing underneath the lacustrine sediments of Lake Lefroy.
The Dome trends to 320o with an unknown plunge to the northwest and southeast.
A steeply west dipping axial planar foliation is developed.
The northern edge is a major shear zone that terminates north plunging isoclinal folds.
It is the only locality in the mapped area where the rocks are both flattened and stretched.
The east side is moderately dipping and appears to be stratigraphic in nature.

At BHP line 13000 NW, a northwest trending, steep shear zone a few meters wide, juxtaposes basalt and sediments along the eastern edge but this shear cannot be traced to the north very far and may possibly curve into a west-northwest trend (refer photos).
The west side shows a linear edge to mapped outcrop implying a steep dip, or truncation by faulting / shearing.
The most commonly mapped shear trend is to 300o, the shears being a few meters thick and dipping moderately to the south.
A single seven meter wide shear trending to 345o and dipping at 45o to southwest is exposed on the north shore of the lake.
The Dome is transected centrally by the narrow, but persistent, north-northwest trending shear occupied by the non-outcropping Parkeston Dyke.
SOLID GEOLOGY INTERPRETATION The Aztec Dome is defined by surface geological mapping, detailed UTS airborne magnetic data interpretation and detailed ground gravity data interpretation.
Independent modelling of the gravity data, the magnetic data and the outcrop geology all show the basic shape (Figure 4).
The geophysics and geology are complementary.
Imaging of the Atlas Geophysics 2008 gravity data and the Sovereign Resources 1996 UTS magnetic data was performed by Fathom Geophysics (Buckingham, 2008).
Three dimensional inversion modelling of the gravity data was iso-surfaced to determine the shape of the top of the denser rocks interpreted to be ultramafic rocks.
This surface was visualized using FracSIS software.

A manual interpretation of the UTS magnetics and the Atlas Geophysics gravity data, over the Aztec Dome, was completed by Fathom Geophysics (Core, 2008), incorporating geological mapping supplied by Terrain Minerals.
Gravity imaging shows a rapid change in the gravity on the west side that is probably a steeply dipping shear zone.
D Isles interpreted the regional scale Stans Dam Shear, a kilometer wide shear zone trending to 315o, to terminate the Dome on its western flank.
The east side is shallowly dipping and is possibly stratigraphic, whilst there is a gradual drop off to the north.

Imaging of the magnetic data indicates that the highly magnetic part of the basalt is restricted mostly to the core of the Dome and appears to indicate a deeper level of exposure on the western side where most of the highly magnetic basalt is exposed.
As with the gravity, the western edge in the Kambalda East Project Aztec Dome Geological Mapping 2008 12 magnetics is much steeper than the eastern edge.
East-northeast and northwest trending faults were picked as edges to the gravity or magnetics using the Fathom Geophysics structural detection filter.
These detected faults have no obvious offsets but there is a dramatic change in the amplitude of magnetic anomalies across them.
The structural detection filter did, however, miss the west-northwest trending shears mapped in the field.
Five likely felsic intrusives were interpreted.
One is apparent on the gravity the others are apparent on the magnetics (Figure 4).
The Dome is split axially into a western and eastern half by the non-outcropping, negatively polarised Parkeston Dyke occupying an earlier structural break trending northwest.
The eastern half has no shallow marker magnetic stratagraphic basaltic units.
It has a thicker basalt sequence that has thin banded carbonaceous, siliceous and sulphidic sediments in the upper part of the basalt stratigraphy.
The inferred syenite plugs interpreted from magnetic and gravity data that are oriented parallel to the Dome axis are confined to the eastern half.

The western half has neither syenite plugs, nor mapped interflow sediments - no interflow sediments were encountered in nineteen historic Aztec Exploration reverse circulation holes drilled into the southern gold in soil anomaly.
A magnetic basalt stratigraphy identifies one or more units that define fold shapes that the gravity data defines as south plunging anticlines.

The 3D inversion modelling of the gravity data indicates that the depth to the top of the high density layer is shallower in the western half compared to the eastern half and may be as shallow as 150 meters below surface.
The western half is structurally higher than the eastern half.
The Dome is faulted with the east side down.
DISCUSSION In a broad sense the Aztec Dome is comparable to the Kambalda Dome, twelve kilometers to the southwest.
The Aztec (Dome) Basalt appears to correlate with the upper part of the Devon Consols Basalt at Kambalda, as it has a similar MgO content (6.8%), and rare pillows and fewer variolites.
Equivalents of the Kapai Slate and the Paringa Basalt are absent.
The underlying denser rocks are correlated with the Kambalda Komatiite.

Petrology shows that the basalts from hole ASD 001 are metasomatically silicacarbonate-potash-sulphide altered with all primary textures largely obliterated by amphibolite grade metamorphism and metasomatism.
This metasomatic alteration is associated with the intrusion of the quartz syenite plug.
Anomalous base metal chemistry has been introduced into the basalts from a deeper, probable ultramafic source.

Despite the occurrence of classic stockwork carbonate and quartz / carbonate veining with pyrite and pyrrhotite in equal abundance over extensive intervals down hole, much of the core recorded nil or barely detectable gold.
Values for platinum and palladium, likewise, were insignificant.

CONCLUSIONS The Kambalda East Project, of which the Aztec Dome is part, lies within the Late Archaean Kalgoorlie Terrane that is divided into four main and two smaller domains that are separated by major structural breaks.
These domains have common deformation histories and similar regional litho-stratigraphic successions.
In a broad sense the geology of the Aztec Dome is comparable to the Kambalda Dome, twelve kilometers to the southwest.
In the Aztec Dome an outcropping basalt sequence is underlain by dense non-outcropping rocks, thought to be ultramafic lithologies, and overlain by tuffs and sediments.
The mafic-ultramafic lithologies equate to the Kambalda Sequence and the tuffs and sediments equate to the Kalgoorlie Sequence.
The Kapai Slate and the Paringa Basalt of the Kambalda Dome are not present in the Aztec Dome.
The Aztec Dome is defined by surface geological mapping, detailed UTS airborne magnetic data interpretation and detailed ground gravity data interpretation.
The geological and geophysical data combine well in defining the geological architecture of the Dome.
These data are complimented by the stratigraphy, petrology and geochemical data from historic diamond drill hole ASD 001.

TM 00065 CONTACT Mr Bob Jeffery REPORT BY Dr Douglas R Mason SIGNED for Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd DATE 2 October 2008 Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3462 2 October 2008 -2- Terrain Minerals Ltd Petrographic Descriptions for Four Rock Samples from the Kambalda East Project (Aztec Dome, Yilgarn Craton, Western Australia) SUMMARY 1.

Rock Samples A collection of 4 drill chip and outcrop rock samples from the Kambalda East Project (Aztec Dome, Yilgarn Craton, Western Australia) has been studied using routine optical petrographic methods.
Brief Results A summary of rock names and mineralogy is provided in TABLE 1.

Primary rock types Basic to ultrabasic igneous rocks are considered to be represented by microporphyritic quenched basalt and aphyric holocrystalline basalt (101089, possibly quenched top and holocrystalline middle of a lava flow), and spinifex-textured quenched high-Mg basaltic lava (101091) of inferred komatiitic magmatic association.
Aphyric holocrystalline basaltic rock is also thought to represent the primary rock of sample 101092.
Alkali quartz syenite (101090) contains phenocrysts of K-feldspar in a finer-grained groundmass of K-feldspar, plagioclase, quartz and Na-clinopyroxene (aegerine).
Weak selective replacement of plagioclase by albite is the only alteration effect.
The absence of metamorphic effects (see next) confirms that the syenitic intrusion was emplaced with post-metamorphic timing.

Metamorphism and alteration Regional metamorphism in the upper greenschist to lower amphibolite facies has affected the basic to ultrabasic igneous rocks, producing new assemblages of plagioclase + hornblende + biotite garnet zoisite opaques (?magnetite, ?ilmenite).
Primary textures were partly preserved.
Veining and hydrothermal alteration (101092) has locally affected meta-basic rocks.
Veins were filled by quartz + calcite + minor opaques (?sulphide), accompanied by high-intensity proximal alteration of potassic type (plagioclase + biotite + calcite + minor ?sulphide).
The veining and associated alteration are typical of lode-gold systems at this moderate metamorphic grade.
*: Only primary minerals currently present in the rock are listed.
Others may have been present, but are altered.
*: Earlier parageneses are separated from later parageneses by a semicolon.

Mineral abbreviations Act = actinolitic amphibole; aeg = aegerine (Na-clinopyroxene); alb = albite; bio = biotite; cal = calcite; car = carbonate minerals; cla = clay minerals; cpx = clinopyroxene; gar = garnet (almandine-rich); hem = hematite; hbl = hornblendic amphibole; ilm = ilmenite; Kf = K-feldspar; mt = magnetite; opq = opaque minerals; pla = plagioclase; qtz = quartz; sulp = sulphide minerals; zoi = zoisite; ?min = uncertain mineral identification.

Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3462 2 October 2008 -4- Terrain Minerals Ltd 1 INTRODUCTION A collection of 4 rock samples was received from Mr Bob Jeffery (Terrain Minerals Ltd, West Perth, Western Australia) on 2 September 2008.
Background information was provided, indicating the samples originate from the Kambalda East Project of Terrain Minerals, located in the Aztec Dome approximately 15 km NE of Kambalda.
The samples represent surface grab rock samples and drill chip samples.
Field comments were provided for the samples, and a spreadsheet indicated specific sample details.
Particular requests were: i) To prepare a thin section and petrographic description for each sample ii) To provide photomicrographs of relevant features.
Excerpts from this report were provided by email to Mr Jeffery on 1 October 2008.
This report contains the full results of this work.
2 METHODS At Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd the samples were examined in hand specimen and marked for section preparation.
Standard thin sections were obtained from an external commercial laboratory.
Conventional transmitted polarised light microscopy was used to prepare the routine petrographic descriptions.

Paragenetic stages of development of each rock are indicated in the mineral modal list, where each mineral is assigned to a numerical paragenesis (paragenesis 1 is earliest; paragenesis 2 overprints 1; paragenesis 3 overprints both 2 and 1; etc).

The paragenetic stages display relative timing insofar as they can be determined within each sample, and are not meant to be directly equated between samples although this may be correct for some samples.
3 PETROGRAPHIC DESCRIPTIONS The petrographic descriptions are provided in the following pages.
: 101089 HAND SPECIMEN : The drill chip fragments represent fine-grained massive dark green rock.
Some chips respond strongly to the hand magnet, suggesting they contain a significant amount of magnetite.

ROCK NAME : Hornblende-biotite-zoisite-magnetite meta-basalt PETROGRAPHY : A visual estimate of the modal mineral abundances gives the following: Mineral Vol % Origin Hornblende 47 Metamorphic 2 (after precursor 1) Plagioclase 31 Metamorphic 2 Biotite 10 (3-20) Metamorphic alteration 2 Zoisite 10 Metamorphic 2 Opaques (mainly ?magnetite) 2 (1-3) Metamorphic 2 In thin section, this sample displays pervasive metamorphic alteration textures, with partly-preserved primary basaltic igneous textures of both massive aphyric type and quench microporphyritic type.
Hornblende is moderately abundant, forming pleochroic green subhedral grains that pervade the rock.
It is much more abundant in the aphyric rock than in the quenched microporphyritic type.
Plagioclase is moderately abundant, occurring as indistinct prismatic microphenocrysts in the quenched variant, and abundant randomly oriented subhedral small prisms in the aphyric type.
Biotite is abundant in the quenched type, where it forms tiny randomly oriented ragged flecks that pervade the groundmass plagioclase.
This biotite displays a drab green pleochroism.
In contrast, somewhat larger biotite plates in the aphyric type display a more normal brown to pale yellow pleochroism.
Opaques occur in minor amount as small blocky crystals (magnetite as supported by positive response to the hand sample).
In the aphyric type, tiny magnetite grains are sparsely disseminated through the rock, and local larger crystals ~0.4 mm in size also are present.
In the quenched variant, minute equant magnetite crystals are sprinkled throughout the rock and locally form denser ragged aggregates.
Zoisite occurs in the quenched type as small euhedral stumpy prismatic crystals that are scattered throughout the rock.
In the aphyric variant, small granules of zoisite tend to form small ragged alteration aggregates in the plagioclase prisms.
INTERPRETATION : This sample represents a meta-basaltic igneous rock.

Two textural types are captured: finer-grained quenched microporphyritic type which contained minor small plagioclase phenocrysts in very fine-grained groundmass, and a coarser-grained aphyric type inferred to have been composed of plagioclase laths and Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3462 2 October 2008 -6- Terrain Minerals Ltd ferromagnesian grains.
The two rock types possibly represent the quenched top and better-crystallised central part of a lava flow.

Regional metamorphism in the upper greenschist to lower amphibolite facies caused recrystallisation to produce the new assemblage of hornblende + plagioclase + biotite + zoisite + minor opaques (magnetite).
The primary textures were only partly preserved.
1: SAMPLE 101089 (Transmitted light, crossed polarisers, Obj.

x10, Image PA013732) This view of meta-basalt illustrates the massive metamorphic assemblage of hornblende (green bladed crystals), plagioclase (colourless), minor zoisite (indistinct turbid microgranular aggregates in plagioclase), and minor biotite (small brown flakes) and opaques (black magnetite grains).
2: SAMPLE 101089 (Transmitted light, crossed polarisers, condenser in, Obj.
x10, Image PA013731) This view of meta-basalt illustrates the faintly preserved primary plagioclase laths (twinned, white to grey) now replaced by metamorphic plagioclase.
Other ferromagnesian minerals have been completely destroyed, generating new amphibole (bladed crystal aggregates), small biotite flakes, and opaque crystals (magnetite).

: 101090 HAND SPECIMEN : The surface grab rock sample represents a massive medium-grained pale grey to white crystalline rock, composed of slightly larger darker grey feldspar crystals (phenocrysts) in a finer-grained groundmass which contains small pale reddish brown grains (?ferruginised ferromagnesian grains).

ROCK NAME : Weakly weathered porphyritic alkali quartz syenite PETROGRAPHY : A visual estimate of the modal mineral abundances gives the following: Mineral Vol % Origin K-feldspar 25 Igneous phenocrysts 1 Quartz 15 Igneous groundmass 1 K-feldspar 29 Igneous groundmass 1 Clinopyroxene (aegerine) 5 Igneous groundmass 1 Albite 25 Alteration 2 (after plagioclase 1) Hematite 1 Weathering 3 Clays Tr Weathering 3 In thin section, this sample displays a massive porphyritic igneous texture, modified by selective alteration effects and subsequent weak weathering effects.
K-feldspar is abundant.
Some forms large blocky crystals (phenocrysts) ~3-5 mm in size, and a significant amount also occurs in the groundmass as smaller subhedral grains.
Albite occurs as optically continuous twinned replacements of twinned plagioclase prisms of variable size, ~0.2-1.5 mm long.
They occur in the groundmass, but some plagioclase has overgrown the margins of the K-feldspar phenocrysts.
Quartz occurs in the groundmass as small equant to angular anhedral clear grains.
Some display suturing of recrystallisation origin.
Clinopyroxene is present in moderate amount as stumpy subhedral prisms in the groundmass.
They display the characteristic weakly pleochroic deep green colour of this mineral.
Most have suffered partial staining by very fine-grained deep red hematite, and some hematite also forms small interstitial patches with intergrown fibrous clays.
INTERPRETATION : This sample crystallised from silica-oversaturated alkaline magma, producing the porphyritic massive assemblage of K-feldspar + plagioclase + quartz + aegerine.
Selective alteration generated albite after plagioclase.
This possibly occurred during final crystallisation.

Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3462 2 October 2008 -9- Terrain Minerals Ltd At a much later time after uplift and erosion, circulation of a small amount of meteoric water generated finegrained hematite and clays: some hematite formed as small replacement patches in the aegerine, and some hematite formed as small interstitial patches with intergrown clays.
Client note: .outcrop sample from a subcircular felsic plug that I have called a porphyritic quartz syenite (Ags).
Response: Yes, the rock is readily termed quartz syenite, and its alkaline nature is confirmed by the presence of Na-clinopyroxene (aegerine).
3: SAMPLE 101090 (Transmitted light, crossed polarisers, Obj.

x4, Image PA013735) This view of porphyritic quartz syenite captures K-feldspar phenocrysts (grey, far right, top left) and finer-grained groundmass of twinned albite (after plagioclase prisms) and interstitial quartz (small clear pale yellow to grey grains).
4: SAMPLE 101090 (Transmitted plane polarised light, Obj.
x10, Image PA013736) This view captures grains of primary aegerine (Na-clinopyroxene, green) which have suffered partial oxidation in response to weak weathering.
The presence of the Na-clinopyroxene confirms that the magma was peralkaline (molecular Na2O+K2O>Al2O3).
: 101091 HAND SPECIMEN : The grab rock sample represents a fine-grained massive dark green rock composed of centimetre-sized globular structures.

ROCK NAME : Actinolite-plagioclase meta-quench high-Mg basalt PETROGRAPHY : A visual estimate of the modal mineral abundances gives the following: Mineral Vol % Origin Actinolite 78 Metamorphic 2 (after precursor 1) Plagioclase 20 Metamorphic 2 Opaques (mainly ?magnetite) <1 Metamorphic 2 Biotite 1 Metamorphic alteration 2 In thin section, this sample displays a spinifex-type quenched basaltic igneous texture, modified by metamorphic replacement.

Actinolitic amphibole is abundant, and occurs in two forms: i) Most actinolite occurs as acicular crystals ~2 mm long which form variably oriented bladed aggregates (spinifex texture) occupying large ovoid bodies many millimetres in size.
These are the large globular structures observed in the hand sample.
ii) A lesser amount of actinolite occurs as denser massive matted aggregates between some of the spinifex-textured ovoids.
Plagioclase is the other principal mineral.
Some occurs as fine-grained aggregates that fill the interstices between the actinolite blades in the spinifex-textured ovoids.
Some plagioclase also occurs as granular interstitial aggregates within the ovoids.
Opaques are present in minor amount as small blocky (cubic) crystals that are sparsely and irregularly scattered through the rock.
They are inferred to be magnetite.
Biotite is present in minor amount as small randomly oriented pleochroic brown to pale yellow flakes, located in the small plagioclase aggregates.
INTERPRETATION : This sample is considered to have formed as a quenched lava of high-Mg basaltic composition, most likely of komatiitic magmatic association.
Rapid quenching of the magma at the time of extrusion produced centimetre-sized ovoids composed of spinifex-textured acicular ?pyroxene and minor interstitial plagioclase.
Subsequent regional metamorphism caused selective replacement by the metamorphic assemblage of actinolite + plagioclase + minor opaques (magnetite) + biotite.

In more detail, the acicular pyroxene crystals Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3462 2 October 2008 -12- Terrain Minerals Ltd were completely replaced by actinolite minor magnetite, and interstitial plagioclase suffered recrystallisation and replacement by plagioclase + minor biotite + opaques (?magnetite).
5: SAMPLE 101091 (Transmitted plane polarised light, Obj.
x4, Image PA013738) This view of meta-high-Mg basalt displays the preserved primary spinifex-type quench texture.
Metamorphic actinolitic amphibole (green) has replaced the primary acicular pyroxene crystals.
Colourless metamorphic plagioclase now occupies interstices.
: 101092 HAND SPECIMEN: The drill chip sample represents a fine-grained dark greenish grey rock with weak foliation.
The chips effervesce strongly in reaction with dilute HCl, confirming calcite is present in significant amount.
Plagioclase is moderately abundant in all chips.
In least-altered chips, its occurs as faintly distinguishable randomly oriented prismatic crystals whose forms are clearly of igneous origin.
In more altered chips, the plagioclase forms a uniformly very fine-grained microgranular alteration mosaic.
Hornblende occurs in the least-altered chips as randomly oriented subhedral prismatic crystals up to ~2 mm long.
Their green pleochroism suggests they have a genuine hornblendic composition.
Hornblende is absent from the more strongly altered chips.
Garnet is present as subhedral equant crystals in the least-altered chips.
It is absent from the most altered chips.

Opaques of two types are distinguished: small lath-like crystals (probably ?ilmenite) are sparsely scattered through the least-altered chips, and minor small ragged grains (sulphide, possibly ?pyrrhotite) are disseminated irregularly through the most-altered chips.

Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3462 2 October 2008 -14- Terrain Minerals Ltd Carbonate (calcite) forms moderately abundant small ragged grains that are irregularly distributed through the most-altered chips.
It is absent from least-altered chips.
Biotite is moderately abundant, occurring in all chips.
In least-altered chips, the biotite forms small randomly oriented flakes that are pleochroic from dark tan brown to pale yellow.
In most-altered chips, it forms small ragged flakes with reddish brown to almost colourless pleochroism.
The different pleochroic schemes are considered to reflect compositional differences between distal and proximal alteration biotite.
Quartz-carbonate-sulphide vein cuts the most-altered chip.
It is non-planar in form, possibly with a bifurcating shape, but contacts with host rock are quite sharp.
It is filled mostly by small equant anhedral quartz grains that form an equigranular granoblastic mosaic throughout the vein.
Carbonate (calcite) occurs in minor amount as ragged small grains.
Opaques (?sulphide, possibly ?pyrrhotite) occurs in minor amount as small ragged grains.
INTERPRETATION : This sample is considered to have initially formed as a basaltic igneous rock composed of plagioclase and ferromagnesian grains.

All primary minerals and most primary textures have been destroyed by subsequent metamorphic effects which may have occurred in two stages: i) Initial metamorphism in the upper greenschist to lower amphibolite facies generated the new metamorphic assemblage of plagioclase + hornblende + garnet + minor opaques (?ilmenite).

ii) Fracturing and invasion by mineralising hydrothermal fluid resulted in filling of the veins by quartz + minor calcite + opaques (?sulphide), accompanied by alteration of wallrock by plagioclase + biotite + carbonate (calcite) + opaques (?sulphide).
Distal from the vein, alteration generated new brown biotite, with partial preservation of the precursor metamorphic hornblende, plagioclase, garnet and ?ilmenite.
Proximal to the vein, strong alteration generated new microgranular plagioclase + biotite + carbonate (calcite) + trace opaques (?sulphide).
This alteration involved metasomatic introduction of CO2, K and possibly S: the CO2 is hosted by calcite, the K is hosted by biotite, and S is hosted by ?sulphide.
It is possible that Au was introduced in this event, in which case native gold might occur in the veins and/or in the altered host rock.

7: SAMPLE 101092 (Transmitted light, crossed polarisers, Obj.

x4, Image PA013747) This view captures the contact between granular quartz-rich vein (lower right) and strongly altered meta-basic host rock (upper left) now composed mostly of alteration albite (grey) and biotite (small reddish brown flakes).

x10, Image PA013748) This view illustrates the presence of opaques (black, centre, most likely sulphide such as ?pyrrhotite) which formed as part of the proximal alteration assemblage with plagioclase (grey) and biotite (reddish flakes) in strongly altered meta-basic host rock adjacent to quartz-rich vein (bottom).

APPENDIX 2 PARKESTON DYKE DATA CGC1482001A2008 Coogee Project 2008 Annual Report PARKESTON DYKE The regionally extensive Parkeston Dyke is a narrow, north-northwest trending crustal structure subparallel to the Boulder Lefroy and Mount Monger Faults, which are major structures within the Kalgoorlie Terrane of the Archaean Eastern Goldfields Supergroup.

The Parkeston Dyke is a poorly documented and poorly outcropping structure which extends for over 100km from the Golden Mile area of Kalgoorlie (and probably further to the northwest) to the southeast of Lake Cowan on the Yardina map sheet (1:100,000 reference 3334), where it is probably terminated against the Albany - Fraser Orogen.
Its age is unknown, but it is probably a reactivated Archaean structure which is now locally occupied by dolerite.

This dolerite could be Archaean, but if the dolerite is a correlative of the Widgiemooltha Dyke Suite, then its age is approximately 2420 Ma - the extensive east-northeast trending Binneringie Dyke and Jimberlana Dyke have been dated at 2418Ma and 2411Ma respectively.
If the dolerite is a later feature associated with the notheasterly trending Albany - Fraser Orogen then its age is approximately 1210 +/- 10 Ma.

The Parkeston Dyke forms a prominent north-northwest trending structure, easily identifiable on aeromagnetic and gravity images (Figure A) which transects the Aztec Dome and separates it in to distinct western and eastern portions (Appendix 1).
Its projected trace is marked on the geology maps in Figures 5 & 6 in the main report text.

Preliminary reconnaissance of the projected location of the Parkeston Dyke in the southern portion of the Aztec Dome located two areas of fine-medium grained, weathered, undeformed, felsic dolerite, which are totally different in appearance to the common basalt and rare dolerite/gabbro outcrops which form the hills of the Aztec Dome.

Preliminary discussions with geoscientists of the Geological Survey of WA in December 2008 indicate that this felsic dolerite is almost certainly the Parkeston Dyke, and the outcrops described below are amongst the first to be recorded for this rare geological feature.

Brief descriptions of the two outcrop localities are given below - 387353E 6555379N MGA Location just south of old BHP line 12000NW on a small embayment in the outcropping basalt on the edge of Lake Lefroy (Figure B) 5m wide outcrop of massive green brown medium grained dolerite (Figure C).
Contacts are scree covered so strike and dip are unknown.
This dolerite looks different and is more weathered and more green brown coloured compared to the main fresher dark grey to green grey basalt outcrops nearby (Figures D & E).
A hand specimen has been collected and passed on to geoscientists of the Geological Survey of WA in December 2008.
A crust of magnesite is developed on the edge of this dolerite this may be a (?)
local weathering feature but magnesite is also observed in the other locality described below.
Blocky massive to jointed fine-medium grained onion skin weathered dolerite (Figures F - I), similar in appearance to dolerite exposure on edge of Lake Lefroy described above.
Prominent joint set strikes 3100 and dips 850 southwest.

Magnesite occurs with the dolerite as a weathering product and, despite the lack of dolerite outcrop away from the creek, magnesite nodules and chips can be traced along the scree and colluvium for several hundreds of metres to the north possibly forming a linear trend - related to the Parkeston Dyke trend?
Both outcrops described are all of limited extent and poorly exposed, and away from the edge of Lake Lefroy and several creeks, the strike extensions are totally scree and colluvium covered.
Weathered magnesite appears to be associated with the weathered dolerite and projected trend of the Parkeston Dyke in several localities.
