TM 00065 CONTACT Mr Bob Jeffery REPORT BY Dr Douglas R Mason SIGNED for Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd DATE 2 October 2008 Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3462 2 October 2008 -2- Terrain Minerals Ltd Petrographic Descriptions for Four Rock Samples from the Kambalda East Project (Aztec Dome, Yilgarn Craton, Western Australia) SUMMARY 1.

Rock Samples A collection of 4 drill chip and outcrop rock samples from the Kambalda East Project (Aztec Dome, Yilgarn Craton, Western Australia) has been studied using routine optical petrographic methods.
Brief Results A summary of rock names and mineralogy is provided in TABLE 1.

Primary rock types Basic to ultrabasic igneous rocks are considered to be represented by microporphyritic quenched basalt and aphyric holocrystalline basalt (101089, possibly quenched top and holocrystalline middle of a lava flow), and spinifex-textured quenched high-Mg basaltic lava (101091) of inferred komatiitic magmatic association.
Aphyric holocrystalline basaltic rock is also thought to represent the primary rock of sample 101092.
Alkali quartz syenite (101090) contains phenocrysts of K-feldspar in a finer-grained groundmass of K-feldspar, plagioclase, quartz and Na-clinopyroxene (aegerine).
Weak selective replacement of plagioclase by albite is the only alteration effect.
The absence of metamorphic effects (see next) confirms that the syenitic intrusion was emplaced with post-metamorphic timing.

Metamorphism and alteration Regional metamorphism in the upper greenschist to lower amphibolite facies has affected the basic to ultrabasic igneous rocks, producing new assemblages of plagioclase + hornblende + biotite garnet zoisite opaques (?magnetite, ?ilmenite).
Primary textures were partly preserved.
Veining and hydrothermal alteration (101092) has locally affected meta-basic rocks.
Veins were filled by quartz + calcite + minor opaques (?sulphide), accompanied by high-intensity proximal alteration of potassic type (plagioclase + biotite + calcite + minor ?sulphide).
The veining and associated alteration are typical of lode-gold systems at this moderate metamorphic grade.
*: Only primary minerals currently present in the rock are listed.
Others may have been present, but are altered.
*: Earlier parageneses are separated from later parageneses by a semicolon.

Mineral abbreviations Act = actinolitic amphibole; aeg = aegerine (Na-clinopyroxene); alb = albite; bio = biotite; cal = calcite; car = carbonate minerals; cla = clay minerals; cpx = clinopyroxene; gar = garnet (almandine-rich); hem = hematite; hbl = hornblendic amphibole; ilm = ilmenite; Kf = K-feldspar; mt = magnetite; opq = opaque minerals; pla = plagioclase; qtz = quartz; sulp = sulphide minerals; zoi = zoisite; ?min = uncertain mineral identification.

Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3462 2 October 2008 -4- Terrain Minerals Ltd 1 INTRODUCTION A collection of 4 rock samples was received from Mr Bob Jeffery (Terrain Minerals Ltd, West Perth, Western Australia) on 2 September 2008.
Background information was provided, indicating the samples originate from the Kambalda East Project of Terrain Minerals, located in the Aztec Dome approximately 15 km NE of Kambalda.
The samples represent surface grab rock samples and drill chip samples.
Field comments were provided for the samples, and a spreadsheet indicated specific sample details.
Particular requests were: i) To prepare a thin section and petrographic description for each sample ii) To provide photomicrographs of relevant features.
Excerpts from this report were provided by email to Mr Jeffery on 1 October 2008.
This report contains the full results of this work.
2 METHODS At Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd the samples were examined in hand specimen and marked for section preparation.
Standard thin sections were obtained from an external commercial laboratory.
Conventional transmitted polarised light microscopy was used to prepare the routine petrographic descriptions.

Paragenetic stages of development of each rock are indicated in the mineral modal list, where each mineral is assigned to a numerical paragenesis (paragenesis 1 is earliest; paragenesis 2 overprints 1; paragenesis 3 overprints both 2 and 1; etc).

The paragenetic stages display relative timing insofar as they can be determined within each sample, and are not meant to be directly equated between samples although this may be correct for some samples.
3 PETROGRAPHIC DESCRIPTIONS The petrographic descriptions are provided in the following pages.
: 101089 HAND SPECIMEN : The drill chip fragments represent fine-grained massive dark green rock.
Some chips respond strongly to the hand magnet, suggesting they contain a significant amount of magnetite.

ROCK NAME : Hornblende-biotite-zoisite-magnetite meta-basalt PETROGRAPHY : A visual estimate of the modal mineral abundances gives the following: Mineral Vol % Origin Hornblende 47 Metamorphic 2 (after precursor 1) Plagioclase 31 Metamorphic 2 Biotite 10 (3-20) Metamorphic alteration 2 Zoisite 10 Metamorphic 2 Opaques (mainly ?magnetite) 2 (1-3) Metamorphic 2 In thin section, this sample displays pervasive metamorphic alteration textures, with partly-preserved primary basaltic igneous textures of both massive aphyric type and quench microporphyritic type.
Hornblende is moderately abundant, forming pleochroic green subhedral grains that pervade the rock.
It is much more abundant in the aphyric rock than in the quenched microporphyritic type.
Plagioclase is moderately abundant, occurring as indistinct prismatic microphenocrysts in the quenched variant, and abundant randomly oriented subhedral small prisms in the aphyric type.
Biotite is abundant in the quenched type, where it forms tiny randomly oriented ragged flecks that pervade the groundmass plagioclase.
This biotite displays a drab green pleochroism.
In contrast, somewhat larger biotite plates in the aphyric type display a more normal brown to pale yellow pleochroism.
Opaques occur in minor amount as small blocky crystals (magnetite as supported by positive response to the hand sample).
In the aphyric type, tiny magnetite grains are sparsely disseminated through the rock, and local larger crystals ~0.4 mm in size also are present.
In the quenched variant, minute equant magnetite crystals are sprinkled throughout the rock and locally form denser ragged aggregates.
Zoisite occurs in the quenched type as small euhedral stumpy prismatic crystals that are scattered throughout the rock.
In the aphyric variant, small granules of zoisite tend to form small ragged alteration aggregates in the plagioclase prisms.
INTERPRETATION : This sample represents a meta-basaltic igneous rock.

Two textural types are captured: finer-grained quenched microporphyritic type which contained minor small plagioclase phenocrysts in very fine-grained groundmass, and a coarser-grained aphyric type inferred to have been composed of plagioclase laths and Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3462 2 October 2008 -6- Terrain Minerals Ltd ferromagnesian grains.
The two rock types possibly represent the quenched top and better-crystallised central part of a lava flow.

Regional metamorphism in the upper greenschist to lower amphibolite facies caused recrystallisation to produce the new assemblage of hornblende + plagioclase + biotite + zoisite + minor opaques (magnetite).
The primary textures were only partly preserved.
1: SAMPLE 101089 (Transmitted light, crossed polarisers, Obj.

x10, Image PA013732) This view of meta-basalt illustrates the massive metamorphic assemblage of hornblende (green bladed crystals), plagioclase (colourless), minor zoisite (indistinct turbid microgranular aggregates in plagioclase), and minor biotite (small brown flakes) and opaques (black magnetite grains).
2: SAMPLE 101089 (Transmitted light, crossed polarisers, condenser in, Obj.
x10, Image PA013731) This view of meta-basalt illustrates the faintly preserved primary plagioclase laths (twinned, white to grey) now replaced by metamorphic plagioclase.
Other ferromagnesian minerals have been completely destroyed, generating new amphibole (bladed crystal aggregates), small biotite flakes, and opaque crystals (magnetite).

: 101090 HAND SPECIMEN : The surface grab rock sample represents a massive medium-grained pale grey to white crystalline rock, composed of slightly larger darker grey feldspar crystals (phenocrysts) in a finer-grained groundmass which contains small pale reddish brown grains (?ferruginised ferromagnesian grains).

ROCK NAME : Weakly weathered porphyritic alkali quartz syenite PETROGRAPHY : A visual estimate of the modal mineral abundances gives the following: Mineral Vol % Origin K-feldspar 25 Igneous phenocrysts 1 Quartz 15 Igneous groundmass 1 K-feldspar 29 Igneous groundmass 1 Clinopyroxene (aegerine) 5 Igneous groundmass 1 Albite 25 Alteration 2 (after plagioclase 1) Hematite 1 Weathering 3 Clays Tr Weathering 3 In thin section, this sample displays a massive porphyritic igneous texture, modified by selective alteration effects and subsequent weak weathering effects.
K-feldspar is abundant.
Some forms large blocky crystals (phenocrysts) ~3-5 mm in size, and a significant amount also occurs in the groundmass as smaller subhedral grains.
Albite occurs as optically continuous twinned replacements of twinned plagioclase prisms of variable size, ~0.2-1.5 mm long.
They occur in the groundmass, but some plagioclase has overgrown the margins of the K-feldspar phenocrysts.
Quartz occurs in the groundmass as small equant to angular anhedral clear grains.
Some display suturing of recrystallisation origin.
Clinopyroxene is present in moderate amount as stumpy subhedral prisms in the groundmass.
They display the characteristic weakly pleochroic deep green colour of this mineral.
Most have suffered partial staining by very fine-grained deep red hematite, and some hematite also forms small interstitial patches with intergrown fibrous clays.
INTERPRETATION : This sample crystallised from silica-oversaturated alkaline magma, producing the porphyritic massive assemblage of K-feldspar + plagioclase + quartz + aegerine.
Selective alteration generated albite after plagioclase.
This possibly occurred during final crystallisation.

Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3462 2 October 2008 -9- Terrain Minerals Ltd At a much later time after uplift and erosion, circulation of a small amount of meteoric water generated finegrained hematite and clays: some hematite formed as small replacement patches in the aegerine, and some hematite formed as small interstitial patches with intergrown clays.
Client note: .outcrop sample from a subcircular felsic plug that I have called a porphyritic quartz syenite (Ags).
Response: Yes, the rock is readily termed quartz syenite, and its alkaline nature is confirmed by the presence of Na-clinopyroxene (aegerine).
3: SAMPLE 101090 (Transmitted light, crossed polarisers, Obj.

x4, Image PA013735) This view of porphyritic quartz syenite captures K-feldspar phenocrysts (grey, far right, top left) and finer-grained groundmass of twinned albite (after plagioclase prisms) and interstitial quartz (small clear pale yellow to grey grains).
4: SAMPLE 101090 (Transmitted plane polarised light, Obj.
x10, Image PA013736) This view captures grains of primary aegerine (Na-clinopyroxene, green) which have suffered partial oxidation in response to weak weathering.
The presence of the Na-clinopyroxene confirms that the magma was peralkaline (molecular Na2O+K2O>Al2O3).
: 101091 HAND SPECIMEN : The grab rock sample represents a fine-grained massive dark green rock composed of centimetre-sized globular structures.

ROCK NAME : Actinolite-plagioclase meta-quench high-Mg basalt PETROGRAPHY : A visual estimate of the modal mineral abundances gives the following: Mineral Vol % Origin Actinolite 78 Metamorphic 2 (after precursor 1) Plagioclase 20 Metamorphic 2 Opaques (mainly ?magnetite) <1 Metamorphic 2 Biotite 1 Metamorphic alteration 2 In thin section, this sample displays a spinifex-type quenched basaltic igneous texture, modified by metamorphic replacement.

Actinolitic amphibole is abundant, and occurs in two forms: i) Most actinolite occurs as acicular crystals ~2 mm long which form variably oriented bladed aggregates (spinifex texture) occupying large ovoid bodies many millimetres in size.
These are the large globular structures observed in the hand sample.
ii) A lesser amount of actinolite occurs as denser massive matted aggregates between some of the spinifex-textured ovoids.
Plagioclase is the other principal mineral.
Some occurs as fine-grained aggregates that fill the interstices between the actinolite blades in the spinifex-textured ovoids.
Some plagioclase also occurs as granular interstitial aggregates within the ovoids.
Opaques are present in minor amount as small blocky (cubic) crystals that are sparsely and irregularly scattered through the rock.
They are inferred to be magnetite.
Biotite is present in minor amount as small randomly oriented pleochroic brown to pale yellow flakes, located in the small plagioclase aggregates.
INTERPRETATION : This sample is considered to have formed as a quenched lava of high-Mg basaltic composition, most likely of komatiitic magmatic association.
Rapid quenching of the magma at the time of extrusion produced centimetre-sized ovoids composed of spinifex-textured acicular ?pyroxene and minor interstitial plagioclase.
Subsequent regional metamorphism caused selective replacement by the metamorphic assemblage of actinolite + plagioclase + minor opaques (magnetite) + biotite.

In more detail, the acicular pyroxene crystals Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3462 2 October 2008 -12- Terrain Minerals Ltd were completely replaced by actinolite minor magnetite, and interstitial plagioclase suffered recrystallisation and replacement by plagioclase + minor biotite + opaques (?magnetite).
5: SAMPLE 101091 (Transmitted plane polarised light, Obj.
x4, Image PA013738) This view of meta-high-Mg basalt displays the preserved primary spinifex-type quench texture.
Metamorphic actinolitic amphibole (green) has replaced the primary acicular pyroxene crystals.
Colourless metamorphic plagioclase now occupies interstices.
: 101092 HAND SPECIMEN: The drill chip sample represents a fine-grained dark greenish grey rock with weak foliation.
The chips effervesce strongly in reaction with dilute HCl, confirming calcite is present in significant amount.
Plagioclase is moderately abundant in all chips.
In least-altered chips, its occurs as faintly distinguishable randomly oriented prismatic crystals whose forms are clearly of igneous origin.
In more altered chips, the plagioclase forms a uniformly very fine-grained microgranular alteration mosaic.
Hornblende occurs in the least-altered chips as randomly oriented subhedral prismatic crystals up to ~2 mm long.
Their green pleochroism suggests they have a genuine hornblendic composition.
Hornblende is absent from the more strongly altered chips.
Garnet is present as subhedral equant crystals in the least-altered chips.
It is absent from the most altered chips.

Opaques of two types are distinguished: small lath-like crystals (probably ?ilmenite) are sparsely scattered through the least-altered chips, and minor small ragged grains (sulphide, possibly ?pyrrhotite) are disseminated irregularly through the most-altered chips.

Mason Geoscience Pty Ltd Report #3462 2 October 2008 -14- Terrain Minerals Ltd Carbonate (calcite) forms moderately abundant small ragged grains that are irregularly distributed through the most-altered chips.
It is absent from least-altered chips.
Biotite is moderately abundant, occurring in all chips.
In least-altered chips, the biotite forms small randomly oriented flakes that are pleochroic from dark tan brown to pale yellow.
In most-altered chips, it forms small ragged flakes with reddish brown to almost colourless pleochroism.
The different pleochroic schemes are considered to reflect compositional differences between distal and proximal alteration biotite.
Quartz-carbonate-sulphide vein cuts the most-altered chip.
It is non-planar in form, possibly with a bifurcating shape, but contacts with host rock are quite sharp.
It is filled mostly by small equant anhedral quartz grains that form an equigranular granoblastic mosaic throughout the vein.
Carbonate (calcite) occurs in minor amount as ragged small grains.
Opaques (?sulphide, possibly ?pyrrhotite) occurs in minor amount as small ragged grains.
INTERPRETATION : This sample is considered to have initially formed as a basaltic igneous rock composed of plagioclase and ferromagnesian grains.

All primary minerals and most primary textures have been destroyed by subsequent metamorphic effects which may have occurred in two stages: i) Initial metamorphism in the upper greenschist to lower amphibolite facies generated the new metamorphic assemblage of plagioclase + hornblende + garnet + minor opaques (?ilmenite).

ii) Fracturing and invasion by mineralising hydrothermal fluid resulted in filling of the veins by quartz + minor calcite + opaques (?sulphide), accompanied by alteration of wallrock by plagioclase + biotite + carbonate (calcite) + opaques (?sulphide).
Distal from the vein, alteration generated new brown biotite, with partial preservation of the precursor metamorphic hornblende, plagioclase, garnet and ?ilmenite.
Proximal to the vein, strong alteration generated new microgranular plagioclase + biotite + carbonate (calcite) + trace opaques (?sulphide).
This alteration involved metasomatic introduction of CO2, K and possibly S: the CO2 is hosted by calcite, the K is hosted by biotite, and S is hosted by ?sulphide.
It is possible that Au was introduced in this event, in which case native gold might occur in the veins and/or in the altered host rock.
6: SAMPLE 101092 (Transmitted plane polarised light, Obj.

x4, Image PA013742) This view of least-altered meta-basalt displays the metamorphic assemblage of plagioclase (colourless), hornblende (olive green to dark green ragged grains), garnet (equant subhedral pale buff brown crystal, centre right), and alteration biotite (small dark brown flakes).
7: SAMPLE 101092 (Transmitted light, crossed polarisers, Obj.

x4, Image PA013747) This view captures the contact between granular quartz-rich vein (lower right) and strongly altered meta-basic host rock (upper left) now composed mostly of alteration albite (grey) and biotite (small reddish brown flakes).
8: SAMPLE 101092 (Transmitted light, crossed polarisers, Obj.

x10, Image PA013748) This view illustrates the presence of opaques (black, centre, most likely sulphide such as ?pyrrhotite) which formed as part of the proximal alteration assemblage with plagioclase (grey) and biotite (reddish flakes) in strongly altered meta-basic host rock adjacent to quartz-rich vein (bottom).

APPENDIX 4 ATLAS GEOPHYSICS KAMBALDA GRAVITY SURVEY MEMO CGC1482001A2008 Coogee Project 2008 Annual Report P2008009 Atlas Geophysics Memo Number M2008009 Kambalda Gravity Survey TERRAIN MINERALS Attention: Mr Bob Jeffery Memo completed by: Mark J Jecks Geophysicist/Director T 08 9471 1575 F 08 9471 1079 PO BOX 1049 MORLEY WA 6943 AUSTRALIA info@atlasgeo.com.au ABN 68 123 110 243 11 September 2008 ATLAS GEOPHYSICS PTY LTD Page|1 P2008009 1.0 Project Brief Project P2008009 required the acquisition and processing of 1070 new gravity stations located on tenements held by TERRAIN MINERALS.
The survey area was located to the north east of the township of Kambalda in Western Australia.
Atlas Geophysics Pty Ltd completed the acquisition of the dataset using foot-borne gravity methods.
A single two man walking crew was utilised to carry out the acquisition.
The survey commenced on the 26th June 2008.
Acquisition was completed on the 5th of July 2008.
ATLAS GEOPHYSICS PTY LTD Page|2 P2008009 2.0 Equipment and Instrumentation One Scintrex CG5 Autograv Gravity Meter Serial Number - 40240 Two Leica System 1200 GPS receivers.

Two HP Laptop computers for data download and processing One Magellan FX324 autonomous GPS receivers for navigation One Iridium satellite phones for long distance communications Personal Protective Equipment for all personnel Batteries, battery chargers, solar cells, UPS System Survey consumables Tools, engineering and maintenance equipment for vehicle servicing First aid and survival kits Tyres and recovery equipment Two hydraulic jacks 3.0 Acquisition of the Gravity Data Gravity data were acquired concurrently with GPS-Glonass data using Scintrex CG5 gravity meters (Photo 1).
Data were acquired in a single shift of 10 hours duration, with each shift consisting of a single loop controlled by observations at the gravity control stations.
Each loop contained a minimum of two repeated readings so that an interlocking network of closed loops was formed.
A total of 5% repeats were acquired for quality control purposes.
Repeat readings were evenly distributed on a time-basis throughout each of the gravity loops.

Photo 1: Gravity observation on foot ATLAS GEOPHYSICS PTY LTD Page|3 P2008009 3.1 Formulae used in Processing The following corrections were applied to the dataset to produce Bouguer Anomalies for each of the gravity stations.
All formulae produce values in milliGals.
To convert values to SI gravity units (gu) or ms-2, simply multiply by a factor of 10.
Instrument scale factor: This correction is used to correct a gravity reading (in dial units) to a relative gravity unit value based on the meter calibration.
corrected reading in milliGals ?
gravity meter reading in dial units ?(?)
scale factor (dial units/milliGal) Earth Tide Correction: As the earth is not a homogeneous sphere, it is subject to variations in gravity due to the gravitational attraction of the Sun and Moon.
These background variations can be corrected for using a predictive formula which utilises the gravity observation position and time of observation.
The Scintrex CG5 gravity meter automatically calculates ETC but uses only an approximate position for the gravity observation so is not entirely accurate.
For this reason, the Scintrex ETC is subtracted from the reading and a new correction calculated within AGRIS software.
The full formula is too complex to list here.
tide corrected reading in milliGals ?
scale factor corrected reading in milliGals ?
Earth Tide Correction (ETC) in milliGals Instrument Drift Correction: Since all gravity meters are mechanical they are all prone to instrument drift.
Drift can be caused by mechanical stresses and strains in the spring mechanism as the meter is moved, knocked, reset, subjected to temperature extremes, subjected to vibration, unclamped etc.
The most common cause of instrument drift is due to extension of the sensor spring with changes in temperature (obeying Hookes law).
To calculate and correct for daily instrument drift, the difference between the gravity control station readings (closure error) is used to assume the drift and a linear correction is applied.

Instrument Drift in milliGals/hour ?2 control station 2nd reading in milliGals ?1 control station 1st reading in milliGals ?2 control station 2 time ?1 control station 1 time ATLAS GEOPHYSICS PTY LTD Page|4 P2008009 Observed Gravity: The preceding corrections are applied to the raw gravity reading to calculate the earths absolute gravitational attraction at each of the GSLs.
Observed Gravity in milliGals ?1 control station 1 known observed gravity in milliGals ?
tide corrected reading in milliGals ?1 control station 1 reading in milliGals ?
reading time ?1 control station 1 time ?
instrument drift in milliGals/hour Theoretical Gravity: The theoretical gravity value at each GSL is calculated based on the assumption that the Earth is a homogeneous ellipsoid.
The 1967 variant of the International Gravity Formula is used to approximate the theoretical gravity at each station location and essentially produce a latitude correction.
Gravity values vary with latitude as the earth is not a perfect sphere and the polar radius is much smaller than the equatorial radius.
The effect of centrifugal acceleration is also different at the poles versus the equator.
Theoretical Gravity in milliGals ?

GDA94 latitude at the GSL in decimal degrees Free Air Correction: Since the gravity field varies inversely with the square of distance, it is necessary to correct for elevation changes from the reference geoid (AHD).
Gravitational attraction decreases as the elevation above the reference geoid increases.
Free Air Correction in milliGals ?
GDA94 latitude at the GSL in decimal degrees ?

elevation above the reference geoid (AHD) in m Bouguer Correction: If a gravity observation is made above the geoid, the effect of rock material between the observation and the geoid need to be taken into account.
The slab of rock makes a positive contribution to the gravity value.
A rock density of 2.67 gm/cc was used in the correction.
Bouguer Correction in milliGals ?
rock density (gm/cc) ?

elevation above the reference geoid (AHD) in m ATLAS GEOPHYSICS PTY LTD Page|5 P2008009 Free Air Anomaly: The free air anomaly is the difference between the observed gravity and theoretical gravity that has been computed for latitude and corrected for the elevation of the GSL above or below the geoid.
Free Air Anomaly in milliGals ?
Observed Gravity in milliGals ?
Theoretical Gravity in milliGals ?
Free Air Correction in milliGals Bouguer Anomaly: The Bouguer anomaly is computed from the free air anomaly above by removing the attraction of the slab calculated by the Bouguer correction.

The Bouguer anomaly is the most interpretable value derived from a gravity survey (in areas of low relief) as changes in the anomaly can be directly attributed to lateral density contrasts within the geology below the observation point.

Final data have been delivered to a technically excellent standard and are presented both digitally and hardcopy as Appendices to this report.
4.1 Data Formats Final reduced ASCII data for the project has been delivered in standard Atlas format.
Table 2 overleaf details the format of the final gravity database supplied.
All fields are comma delimited.
Raw GPS-GNSS and gravity data in their respective native formats have been included on the data DVD as Appendix B.
The table (1) below summarises the deliverables.
The gravity control point consists of a small concrete slab set into the ground, opposite the GPS control point.
The control station is witnessed by an Atlas Geophysics survey plaque attached to a 1.5 metre steel picket placed within 0.5m of the both control points.
Gravity Control was established via an ABA and ABABA loop on multiple days to the Kalgoorlie Aeroclub AFGN 1964910114.
The gravity tie was completed with the project gravity meter on 30/6/08 and 01/07/08.
Expected accuracy is better than 0.01mGals.
GPS Control was established using AUSPOS.
Three separate 10 hour sessions were submitted to AUSPOSs online processing systems where returned coordinates were accurate to better than 0.01m.
The station is located on the northern side of a prominent hill in the southern extents of the survey area, north of Lake Lefroy.
The station can be accessed via historic drill lines trending NE-SW connected via station tracks running off the Carnily Hill Haul Road.

SUMMARY During November 2008, Zonge Engineering and Research Organization (Zonge) mobilised a three-person geophysical field crew to the Aztec Dome prospect near Kambalda Western Australia to conduct Dipole-Dipole Induced Polarisation (DDIP) and Moving Loop EM (MLEM) surveys for Terrain Minerals Ltd.
The surveys commenced on the 2 nd November and were completed on the 18 th November.
In this time DDIP data were collected along a single line using a 100 metre station and a- spacing.
MLEM data were acquired along two lines at 100 metre station intervals, a portion of one of these lines was in-filled with 21 MLEM soundings acquired at 50 metre station intervals.
This produced 270 IP data points to n=8 over 3.65 line kilometres and MLEM soundings at 85 locations over 6.2 line kilometres.
Data quality and repeatability were monitored throughout the course of the survey.
Strict acquisition procedures were adhered to, which ensured that high quality data were collected.
Logistics Summary Zonge Job 825 Page 2 2.
INSTRUMENTATION A Zonge multipurpose GDP-32ii receiver was used to record all of the IP and EM data for this project.
The raw data from each day was downloaded every evening from the receiver to laptop computer and emailed to Zonges Adelaide office.
Preliminary processing and plotting were completed in the field.
Final processing and plotting were completed in Zonge Engineering's Adelaide office.
All transmitted fields were generated with a Zonge GGT-30 geophysical transmitter which was powered by a ZMG-30 generator system.
Signal frequency and synchronisation were controlled directly by an XMT-32 controller.
Porous ceramic pots filled with a saturated copper sulphate solution were used as non- polarisable receiver electrodes.
Receiver electrodes were connected to the receiver using 2.5mm 2 insulated copper wire.
Transmitter electrodes were constructed using multiple galvanised star pickets prepared before reading and wetted with salt water to aid conduction and electrode stability.
Transmitted EM fields were produced using a 200 x 200 metre square single turn loop of 2.5mm 2 insulated copper wire.
Initially data were sensed using both a single component Zonge TEM-3 coil with an effective area of 10000m 2 and an EMIT three component magnetometer positioned at the centre of each loop.

Whilst reading the first line of MLEM (13000N) the magnetometer data deteriorated due to poor signal strength in more resistive conditions, at this point the magnetometer reading was abandoned and the remainder of the survey was completed using the coil only.
SURVEY PARAMETERS All DDIP data during this survey was taken using Zonge's CR, frequency domain IP program using a fundamental frequency of 0.125 Hertz.

Both signal magnitude and phase information were recorded for the 1 st , 3 rd , 5 th , 7 th and 9 th harmonics of the fundamental with the 1 st , 3 rd and 5 th used in the 3-point decoupling calculation.
Dipole length and station spacing was 100 metres and data were recorded using a roll-along configuration from west to east.
This provided n-spacings up to 8 for most transmitter positions along line.

Data for MLEM were recorded during this survey was taken using Zonge's TEM program using a frequency of 4 Hertz.
As GDP time windows vary with frequency, reading frequency is selected in the field such that late time data decays well into noise.
Window time information can be found in the .chn files on the accompanying disc.
Transmitter ramp time was measured in the field using an oscilloscope and was set in the receiver at 220?s.
Transmitter loops were constructed using a single turn, 200 x 200 metre wire loop energised at 15 Amps with station intervals at 100 metres.
Infill data were acquired on line 13000N using a single turn 100 x 100 metre transmitter loop with 50 metre station intervals and transmitter ramp time of 180 ?s.

DATA PROCESSING The quality of each block of raw TEM and IP data were examined before being averaged to create a single record for each receiving station.
Blocks or channels that were considered of poor quality were skipped before averaging each stations data.
All raw data taken during this survey are included on the accompanying disc so that this data may be edited and re-averaged if necessary.
The EMIT magnetometer outputs signal such that 1 mV/A = 350 pT/A.
MLEM data as recorded by the GDP receiver reflects mV/A, corrected data to reflect actual pT/A B-field magnitudes is presented in AMIRA format .tem files contained on the accompanying disc.
The edited and averaged MLEM data were used to produce 1D inversion smooth models using Zonges STEMINV modelling program.
Edited, averaged and decoupled IP data were then used for plotting and modelling.
The 3- point decoupled phase is a DC or zero frequency phase interpolation using the 1 st , 3 rd and 5 th harmonic phase data to remove coupling effects often seen in raw phase data.
Preliminary smooth 2D inversion models of IP data were created using Zonges TS2DIP software.
Inversion results for the IP and EM surveys may be found within the Processed_Data directory on the accompanying disc.
Plots of the inversion models are presented in Appendices I.

Preliminary or rough plots of modelled of data is provided by Zonge at no cost however no attempt has been made to alter default modelling constraints to account for topography, geological information or data fit.
Should this be desired, Zonge endeavour to retain a copy of this data and will be able to perform refined modelling as requested at a later date.

BHP undertook the survey to locate small volumes of massive sulphide mineralisation surrounded by appreciable volumes of disseminated sulphide mineralisation.
The Kambalda nickel ore bodies are small in size but are high grade.
The nickel mineralisation occurs at the contact between serpentenised ultra basic rocks and greenstones.
The sulphide zones are usually less than 6m true width.
Some of the mineralisation is massive, but there are larger volumes of disseminated mineralisation.
The mineralisation can be traced for kilometres and is of variable width.
The economic ore zones have dimensions of 100m to 150m.
These ore zones are small and therefore are difficult geophysical targets.
The BHP rationale was to detect to larger disseminated mineralisation footprint using IP.
The location of The BHP IP survey is shown in figure 1.
A summary of the lines is shown in Table 1.

Aztec Dome IP Survey Traverses A review of the BHP IP in 2008 indicated that the data could be re-modelled to provide a clearer location of chargeable and/or conductivity sources that may be related to sulphide mineralisation.
The IP data was digitised from archived reports.
The data was then modelled with the Zonge 2D inversion program.
The data was modelled with no weighting and then for solutions with a vertical bias.
The resulting data was imported into Oasis Montaj to produce plans.
Only the vertical model bias data is presented in this report.
The IP targets identified from this review are shown in Figure 2.
Twelve targets (A to J) have been identified.

Target E is a weak PFE response observed within a felsic intrusive.
Targets C, D, F, G, H, I, J and L are located on the western margin and are rated low order anomalies.
These targets are PFE and /or conductive responses associated with lithological contacts.
No targets were selected from line 10000 as this line is dominated by the conductive sediments of Lake Lefroy.
The lake sediments are highly conductive (approx.
25m thick) and the PFE anomalies are likely to be affected by EM coupling (see figure 4).
There are two conductive features near target E (see figure 2), on lines 14000 and 15000, which coincide with drainage into Lake Lefroy.

AOI: A097 Survey RTP 1VD, 2008 detailed gravity stations A097 AOI: RTP NE illumination Purpose TMI data are reduced to the pole to shift anomalies directly over their source and produce symmetric anomalies.
The location of sources, particularly source edges, can more readily be determined when the magnetic data has been reduced to the pole.

Filtering The result of the reduction to the pole operation is a field which would be observed if the given field had been observed with vertical polarization, that is, as though observed at the Earths magnetic pole.
If strong remnant magnetization is present in directions other than that of the Earths ambient field, the transformed field will be in error.

A097 AOI: RTP Tilt Angle RTP Tilt Angle Filter Filtering The tilt angle filter is defined as the arctangent of the ratio of the vertical derivative to the horizontal gradient magnitude, of the field.
For isolated sources, the tilt angle is positive over the source, crosses through zero at or near the edge of a vertical sided source, and is negative outside the source region.
Purpose The tilt angle filter is excellent for highlighting structure in magnetic data.
It responds equally well to shallow and deep sources.

Positive tilt angle Negative tilt angle A097 AOI: RTP Ternary CMY RTP Ternary Representation Filtering This representation of the magnetic field combines three of the best known approaches to highlighting source edges and structure.

Cyan = First vertical derivative Magenta = tilt angle filter Yellow = horizontal gradient magnitude Purpose To highlight pertinent structures, emphasize breaks in continuity and enhance the textural character of units.

Notes on TMX Interpretation Very broad interp This is the gravity with a linear color stretch.
The obvious thing to note here is the difference in gradient between the southwest and northeast.

The high gravity drops off much faster to the southwest so a very generalized cross section of the dome should look something like (ignoring the syenite): Mafic package Sediments/felsic and intermediate volcanics Sediments/felsic and intermediate volcanics A A AA The gravity is going to be almost useless for determining the distribution of units within the mafic package because the mapping indicates that it is all basalt.
Basalts tend to have very similar density but can have significant magnetic contrast due to the form of the Fe-oxide (magnetite/ilmenite).
From the mag along with the field mapping it appears as though there is a lower magnetic signature basalt overlying a high magnetic signature basalt.
It appears as though there are a couple of interlayered high mag/low mag units that have been folded.
Here again you can see a rapid increase in magnetics on the southwest side and then a gradual drop off to the northeast also indicating an asymmetric broad geometry to the dome.
There is also a significant change in the geometry across the shear zone that cuts through the middle of the dome.
This change in geometry possibly indicates some normal or thrusting motion on the fault with the northeast side lowered relative to the southwest.
Intrusive units There are a few dikes and felsic intrusions in the interpretation area.
These are rough interpretations of where they go: The main dike along the shear zone appears larger in the south but I think this is probably due to a shallower dip to the dike.
I am guessing the dip is to the southwest and that the dike is remnant magnetized making it the low rather than the parallel high.
Not sure how to explain things if it is the parallel high.
The round bodies are most likely syenites though the one along the dike may not be.
Structurally complex zones around these bodies would make good gold targets.
Units within the dome The bulk of the dome appears to be made up of low magnetic basalt.
There are some higher magnetic units within the basalt.
In the east there also appears to be some interlayered sediments with the basalt.
It is not clear if this is folding causing alternating basalt and the surrounding sedimentary unit or if it is sediments within the basalt package.
I went ahead with folding as that appears to be the preferred model in the geology interp provided.

Director: Dr Amanda Buckingham Office: Perth, WA, Australia amanda@fathomgeophysics.com ABN: 75 128 894 673 Modelling of Potential Field Data The interpretation of potential field (magnetic & gravity) data is complicated because of the inherent non-uniqueness of the problem.
There are many distributions of sub-surface susceptibility & density that can give rise to the magnetic & gravity response measured at or above the surface.
Geological knowledge (from outcrop mapping, drilling etc) can be used to constrain the interpretation of such data.
Forward modelling and inversion routines can be used to test geological models and provide a range of valid solutions where the dip, depth, geometry and character of units are unknown.
x y z Observed Gravity Data Fathom Geophysics has prepared this memorandum/report based upon information believed to be accurate at the time of completion.

Fathom Geophysics makes no warranty as to the accuracy, reliability or completeness of the information contained in this memorandum/report and will not accept liability to any person for any errors or omissions or for direct or indirect losses or damages claimed as a result, including for items discussed, opinions rendered or recommendations made in this memorandum/report, except for statutory liability which may not be excluded.

Using a 3D inversion routine, the subsurface is discretised into a large number of cells (in the x, y and z directions) each having a constant physical property, and distributions of magnetic susceptibility or density are obtained by minimizing a model objective function subject to adequately fitting the observed data (Jones and Oldenburg, 1998).
The problem of estimating a reasonable earth model based on observed data is known as the geophysical inverse problem.

Ideally, the physical property model generated has features which correlate with various interpreted geologic boundaries and rock units, and can be used to refine the geological model in areas of limited outcrop or poor geological control.
A valid solution The Aztec Dome Bouguer Gravity data were input into the 3D gravity inversion routines.
Inversion parameters were iteratively refined to produce a model that is both a valid response in terms of error, and geologically feasible.

Terrain undertook the surveys to locate small volumes of massive sulphide mineralisation surrounded by appreciable volumes of disseminated sulphide mineralisation (Kambalda nickel style mineralisation).
IP and TEM data were collected on line 130000mN to determine which method would be best suited to exploring for nickel mineralisation in the Aztec Dome Project area.

During November 2008, Zonge Engineering and Research Organization (Zonge) mobilised a three-person geophysical field crew to the Aztec Dome Project area in Western Australia, to conduct dipole-dipole complex resistivity induced polarisation (CR-IP) and coincident moving loop TEM (MLEM).
A total of 3.65 line kilometres (1 line) of CR-IP, 6.20 line kilometres (two lines) of MLEM data were collected.
Data quality and repeatability were monitored throughout the course of the survey.
The survey logistics, instrumentation, survey parameters and specifications are detailed in the logistic summary report produced by Zonge.
The location of the IP and TEM surveys are shown in Figure 1.
A summary of the lines is shown in Table 1 and 2.
2008 IP and MLEM Survey Traverses Survey Rationale The Kambalda nickel ore bodies are small in size but are high grade.
The nickel mineralisation occurs at the contact between serpentenised ultra basic rocks and greenstones.
The sulphide zones are usually less than 6m true width.
Some of the mineralisation is massive, but there are larger volumes of disseminated mineralisation.
The mineralisation can be traced for kilometres and is of variable width.
The economic ore zones have dimensions of 100m to 150m.
These ore zones are small and therefore are difficult geophysical targets.

Terrain Minerals Aztec Dome Project 2008 Value Adding Resources Value Adding Resources Pty Ltd wroberst@bigpond.net.au ABN 7312 6236 520 billr@austgold.com.au The footprint of the nickel mineralisation for IP and TEM are different.
It is expected that the IP footprint will be larger due to disseminated halo surrounding the massive mineralisation (TEM footprint).
The expected IP signature is of a phase anomaly with an associated conductive zone.
The TEM expected signature is of a discrete conductive anomaly.
Terrain Minerals decide to undertake both IP and TEM on a trail line to evaluate which technique would be most suitable to provide a first pass coverage over the Aztec Dome Project Area.
Also the IP would allow for the evaluation of the quality of the 1969 BHP IP survey.
For the IP, 100m dipole-dipole spacing was chosen to provide good depth coverage (400m approx.)
and cost effective coverage of the project area.
Detailed 50m dipole-dipole could be done selectively over anomalous zones if warranted.
For the TEM, 200m by 200m moving loop array was chosen.
The moving loop array was selected to maximise the coupling with a buried conductor.
The 200m loop size was chosen to allow for cost effective coverage of the target area.
The signature of a Kambalda style ore body with such a large loop is expected to be subtle.
Thus follow-up of subtle conductive zones with 100m loops and/or fixed loops would be required.
IP Survey The 2008 IP survey was chosen to coincide with the BHP 1969 IP line 13000mN.
A review of the 1969 BHP IP in 2008 identified a number of targets within the Aztec Dome Project area (see Report 1969 BHP Induced Polarisation Survey Review by VAR October 2008).
In Figure 2 a chargeability depth slice at 175m depth shows the anomalous IP responses from the BHP survey (red colours are high chargeability and blue colours are low).
The IP anomalies on BHP line 13000mN are labelled A to D (see Figure 3).
Target A is a strong PFE anomaly associated with higher resistivity.
Target A is located on the south- east margin of a felsic intrusive.
The IP response, high PFE/resistivity, is of disseminated style of mineralisation (Au/Cu).
Target A is a complex response and is multi-sources (3 or more sources).
Target B coincides with the Parkston Dyke.
Targets C and D are located on the western margin and are rated low order anomalies for nickel.
These targets are PFE and /or conductive responses associated with lithological contacts.
Figure 3 shows the inversion models for the BHP data.
For the chargeability modelled data red colours are high and blue colours are low.
For the resistivity model the blue colours are more resistive and the reds more conductive.

Terrain Minerals Aztec Dome Project 2008 Value Adding Resources Value Adding Resources Pty Ltd wroberst@bigpond.net.au ABN 7312 6236 520 billr@austgold.com.au The 2008 IP was collected with 100m dipole-dipole array, using Zonges Complex Resistivity frequency domain methodology.
The IP data is shown in Figures 4, 5, 6 and 7.
Shown in Figures 4 and 5 the observed data is displayed with the 2D inversions.
The 2D inversions have been weighted to produce moderately biased vertical solutions.
In Figures 6 and 7 the 2D inversions of the BHP and Zonge data are shown.
In Figure 6 the chargeability anomalies are similar.
The variations observed are mostly likely due to EM coupling in the BHP data.
The Zonge data has had any EM coupling removed.

In Figure 7 Terrain Minerals Aztec Dome Project 2008 Value Adding Resources Value Adding Resources Pty Ltd wroberst@bigpond.net.au ABN 7312 6236 520 billr@austgold.com.au the apparent resistivity inversions show similar patterns.
On both figures drill-hole ASD0001 with Ni assay profiles is shown.
A plate model derived from the MLEM data (purple line) is shown.
The Ni mineralisation is associated with a very weak phase anomaly and a very weak conductive lies to the east.
In Figure 8 a depth slice at 175m depth from the inverted dated is shown in plan.
The phase anomalies are labelled A through to E. Anomalies B, C and D are rated the higher anomalies.
Anomaly B is located on the Parkston Dyke and is most likely composed of multiple bodies.
Anomaly B coincides with a resistive zone and is a potential Au target.
Anomalies C and D are complex responses and are associated with a very weak conductor at station 2100E (see Figure 9).
These two anomalies are potential Au and Ni targets.
Anomalies A and E are located to the east of the Parkston Dyke.
The phase anomalies are located on the flanks of weak conductive response (see Figure 9).
The MLEM plate model is located between these phase anomalies.

Terrain Minerals Aztec Dome Project 2008 Value Adding Resources Value Adding Resources Pty Ltd wroberst@bigpond.net.au ABN 7312 6236 520 billr@austgold.com.au Terrain Minerals Aztec Dome Project 2008 Value Adding Resources MLEM Survey The 2008 MLEM survey collected 200m loop data with 100m station moves on two lines (13000N and 15000N).
Line 13000N was in-filled with a 100m loop at 50m station intervals.
Initially the data was collected with the Zonge TEM-3 coil and an Emit three component magnetometer.
Data for the magnetometer was collected only on line 13000N .
The magnetometer data was noisy and slow to collect was it was decided not collect any further data.
The magnetometer is not reviewed in this report.

MLEM Line 13000N 100m Loop Amplitude Profiles The bedrock feature was followed up with 100m moving loop data (50m station moves).
A weak response was observed but the polarisations effects make it difficult to interpret this data.
A plate model was generated using the 200m loop data (see Figure 14).
The model is of a thin plate dipping to the east at about 75 degrees.
The depth to the top of the body is 150m.
The plate has a weak conductivity-thickness product of 400s (a weak to moderate conductor).
The plate dimensions and strike length cannot be determined from the data collected.
Due to the polarisation effects it is recommend that a fixed loop EM survey be done to validate this feature prior to drill testing.

Encounter Resources Ltd Pingandy Creek Project is located in the Shire of Upper Gascoyne, some 84kms south of Paraburdoo in Western Australia and approximately 900km north of Perth (Figure 1).

The project is situated on the northern margin of the Bangemall Supergroup in a geological setting that is considered prospective for unconformity style uranium mineralisation and for stratabound and fault related base metals deposits.
The Pingandy Creek project was targeted utilising the geochemical mapping and sampling completed by the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) and Uranium Channel Radiometrics (Figure 2).
Figure 1: Pingandy Creek Project Location Plan
The backdoor Formation is approximately 1500m thick and is intruded by dolerite sills.
It consists mostly of siltstone and mudstone that varies in colour from greenmaroon and cream.
It is interbedded with fine to very coarse-grained sandstone, oolitic dolostone and minor chert.
The depositional environment for the siltstones is interpreted to be deposited below the storm wave-base and records a progradation from distal shelf to proximal shelf environment.
There is also a distal delta-front depositional environment (Martin et al, 2006).
The Blue Billy Formation is generally less than 200m thick and comprises a distinctive parallel-planar laminated, black, carbonaceous siltstone that weathers to a blue-grey colour.
Lenticular bodies of thick medium-coarse grained sandstone with interbedded siltstone and minor dolostone exist within this formation.
This formation resulted from an upward shallowing distal shelf succession (report).
The Cheyne Springs Formation ranges from 50-300m thick but rarely exceeds 200m.
It consists of interbedded dololutite, dolomitic siltstone, and siltstone with minor finemedium dolomitic sandstone and quartz sandstone.
This formation marks a slight shallowing of the Edmund basin and represents shelf and pelagic dolostones (report).
The Yilgatherra Formation has a total thickness of 350m and consists of pebble to cobble conglomerate fining upward though very coarse-grained sandstone to finegrained sandstone and then siltstone.
Marine transgression was the depositional environment ranging from fluvial to shallow marine (report).
During the reporting period Encounter applied for combined report status on the 17th September 2008.
The Geological Survey of Australia corefarm was visited to view the historical HD1 diamond drill hole completed by Pasminco in 1994.
Resampling was completed and samples sent away for assaying of Uranium and Vanadium.
The results for these samples are reported in Table 1 below.
Specific samples were analysed with a handheld Niton XRF machine and results are in Table 2.
Significant anomalous results are highlighted in yellow and a copy of the geology legend is in the Appendix.
Conversion of the historical drill data into the Encounter Resources Legend was commenced.
Further historical drilling in the most recently granted tenements was also reviewed.
Figure 6 below shows the location of HD1 with GSWA geology in the background.
Figure 3: Pingandy Creek HD1 on GSWA Geology
Interpretation of old data and hyperspectral work in the area did not identify any anomalism requiring followup work.
The Gooragoora Formation is mostly medium to thick-bedded, trough cross stratified, fine to very coarse grained sandstone with smaller amounts of conglomerate, laminated siltstone and dolostone.
The depositional environment is interpreted to be a progradational deltaic environment (report).
The Discovery Formation has a thickness between 50-70m in the north and 280m in the south and is used as a marker horizon.
It consists predominantly of planarlaminated, pyritic, silicified carbonaceous siltstone.
Local silicified beds of medium grained sandstone, pebble conglomerate and sedimentary breccias occur.
The depositional environment of this formation is controversial and both primary and secondary origins have been suggested.
Pingandy Creek Project is situated in the central northern part of the Bangemall Supergroup.
The Bangemall Supergroup comprises an up to 6km thick sequence of late paleoproterozoic to mesoproterozoic clastic and carbonate sediments.
It forms a broad syncline and is bound to the north and south by the Pilbara and Yilgarn Cratons.
The Bangemall Supergroup is subdivided into the Edmund (lower) and Collier (upper) Groups.
Edmund The Edmund group exceeds 4000m in thickness and the main lithologies include siltstone, sandstone, conglomerate, dolomite, stromatalitic dolomite, carbonaceous siltstone, and chert.
Dolerites commonly intrude these units.

There are 11 units from bottom to top (after martin et al, 1999a), Yilgatherra, Irregully, Gooragoora, Blue Billy, Cheyne Springs, Kiangi Creek, Muntharra, Discovery, Devil Creek, Ullawarra, and Coodardoo Formations.
FINAL SURRENDER REPORT 2008 - 2009 3 The project sits partially within the bounds of the Nharnuwangga Wajarri Ngarlawangga (NWN) Native Title Claim.
The area of the NWN claim is covered by an Indigenous Land Use Agreement (ILUA) between the claimants and the State of Western Australia, dated 5 July 2001.
FINAL SURRENDER REPORT 2008 - 2009 4 In 1995 Pasminco reviewed the 1994 airborne magnetics and radiometrics, completed soil geochemistry, regolith mapping and ground geophysics.
One diamond hole HD1 was drilled into the Hughes magnetic anomaly to a depth of 616.5m and a downhole gyroscopic and magnetic survey was done.
A highly magnetic unit was intersected between 470-510m which was determined to be partially responsible for the Hughes magnetic anomaly.
No significant mineralisation was intersected.
A metre above the base of the black shales of the Jillawarra Formation is a 0.8m wide black pyritic calcarenite layer with 1410ppm Zn.
FINAL SURRENDER REPORT 2008 - 2009 9 Table 2: Niton Results on Pasminco Diamond Hole HD1.
The Muntharra Formation is generally 30-50m thick and is restricted to an area immediately adjacent to the Talga Fault.
It is made up of thinly bedded siltstone, dolomitic siltstone, and dolostone with interbedded dolomitic sandstone and quartz sandstone.
Deposition is interpreted as mostly below storm wave-base (report).
The Devil Creek Formation is generally 85-200m thick but can range up to 450m thick in places.
It comprises thin-thick bedded dolostone, dolomitic siltstone, siltstone, dolostone breccia, dolomitic sandstone, stromatalitic dolostone and minor chert.
North of Talga Fault the depositional environment was platform carbonate environment and south was basinal mudstones (report).
Based on results to date not identifying any areas of significant interest it was recommended tenement E08/1794 be surrendered.
As part of a regional reconnaissance diamond exploration program, De Beers of Australia collected large hyperspectral datasets over the Pilbara and Ashburton provinces of WA.
One of these surveys, the Turee Creek South Survey, was flown during the period between October and December 1999 and covers the area of E08/1578, E08/1779 and E08/1794.
The data from this survey is available through AGARSS who have a licence with De Beers to sell the hyperspectral data.
The hyperspectral data is a multi-channel remote sensing dataset that can be used to map minerals and alteration assemblages at surface.
Encounter purchased a series of hyperspectral images over the tenement area in the last reporting period.
The data was interpreted by Brian Bennett of Australian Geological and Remote Sensing Services (AGARSS).
His report was included in the 2007-2008 Combined Annual Report (C051/2008) and has not been reported here as the majority of the report still remains confidential to Encounter Resources Ltd.
It was found that the hyperspectral mapping delineated a zone of potential alteration of a known black pyritic shale horizon which is known to contain base-metal mineralisation.
The hyperspectral data may also be used in the future to better define geology and structure of the area and highlight the best areas for geochemical sampling.
The Ilgarari Formation is approximately 680m thick and has numerous intruding dolerite sills.
It consists mainly of greenish-grey, laminated pyritic and carbonaceous siltstone.
The depositional environment is interpreted as a transgressive, deepmarine shelf (Martin et al, 2006).
The Calyie Formation consists of sandstone and is 190m thick.
The sandstone is mostly medium to very thick bedded and consists of medium to coarse-grained quartz sandstone.
There is minor interbedded siltstone.
This formation is interpreted as being deposited in a shallow marine to fluvial depositional environment (Martin et al, 2006).
Target Commodities: U, Pb-Zn-Ag
Exploration License E08/1794 is located approximately 84km south of Paraburdoo on the Turee Creek 1:250,000 Sheet.
The area covers part of the Pingandy Creek and along with leases E08/1779 and E08/1578 forms Combined Report C51/2008.
Access to the tenement from the south is via the Pingandy Road from Mt Augustus or from the north via the Ashburton Meekatharra Road from Paraburdoo.
The region is typified by a series of low lying, undulating hills interrupted by a network of broad, seasonal rivers.
Occasional steep ridges are found in the region where the lower members of the Edmund Group outcrop.
Minor flat lying mounts of calcrete can be seen within the broader drainage systems in the southwest of the project.
Flora in the region is limited to low scrubs and grasses with larger bushes and trees restricted to the bound of the major drainages.
The Exploration Licences were applied for on 1 September 2005, 27 March 2006 and 11 May 2007 respectively.

The Coodardoo Formation is the youngest in the Edmund Group and ranges in maximum thickness from 150-370m.
It consists of thick to very thick-bedded fine to very coarse-grained quartz sandstone and pebbly sandstone, interbedded with siltstone.
The depositional environment of this formation is thought to be turbidite fan deposits (report).

Collier The Collier group has an estimated thickness of about 2000-2500m and the main lithologies include predominantly siltstone, fine-very coarse-grained sandstone, pebbly sandstone, dolostone and minor chert and conglomerate.
Thick dolerite sills intrude these units.
The Collier group is subdivided into the Backdoor, Calyie and Ilgarari Formations (Martin and Thorne, 2002).
Austramin Holdings., 1990; Mt Boggola Prospect, Ashburton Province, WA,
The Kiangi Creek Formation ranges from about 200-550m in thickness and consists of interbedded siltstone, sandstone with minor conglomerate and local dolostone.
The formation is interpreted as a deep water depositional environment with some deposition occurring above storm wave-base (report).
The Ullawarra Formation varies in thickness from 100m north of the Talga Fault to 650m south of the fault.
It consists of thin-bedded siltstone and mudstone with lesser fine-medium grained sandstone and minor chert and dolostone.
The depositional environment for this unit is interpreted to be a deep marine shelf environment (report).
The Irregully Formation consists of laminated and stromatalitic dolostone and dolorudite, minor sandstone and dolomitic sandstone.
Some rare conglomerate also exists.
Thickness of this formation ranges from 350m to over 2000m.
The depositional environment ranges from peritidal platform environments to mostly slope and deep-marine environments with minimal shallow-marine facies (report).
Previous exploration within this area includes lease holdings by Anaconda Australia (1966-67), CRA Exploration (1981-82) and Newcrest Mining from 1989-1993.
Pasminco entered into a joint venture with Newcrest Mining in March 1993.
In 1965 Anaconda was granted three temporary reserves to the west of Pingandy Creek.
They completed a helicopter-borne regional mapping and sampling program during which 6435 stream sediment samples and rock chip samples were collected and analysed for Cu, Pb and Zn.
Three locations of geochemical anomalism were identified but not followed up.
CRA Exploration targeted shale-hosted Pb-An-Cu within either the clastic Ashburton Formation in the Ashburton basin or in the Irregully formation of the Bangemall Basin.
CRA Exploration obtained colour aerial photographs (1:25,000), airborne magnetics and radiometric and INPUT surveys.
They completed drainage and rock geochemistry, geological interpretation and SIROTEM was used to follow up the INPUT anomalies noted.
The SIROTEM surveys indicated a number of extremely conductive sediments existed near the base of the Bangemall succession which was interpreted as black shales from the Jillawarra Formation.
There was also a nearvertical source thought to be a target within the Ashburton Formation below the Bangemall Group located south west of CRA Explorations tenements.
There was no follow-up of these targets.
Examination of radiometric data by CRA Exploration identified six uranium anomalies of possible interest; however no work was completed on them.
Newcrest began exploration of the area in 1989 and acquired 13 contiguous ELs.

They reviewed the previous exploration and acquired colour aerial photographs (1:25,000), BMR aeromagnetics and radiometrics along with airborne EM and magnetic data from CRA Exploration which was processed and re-interpreted.
They also re-interpreted the SIROTEM data and completed geochemical reconnaissance and geological mapping of the areas.
A ground magnetic survey over part of the Hughes anomaly was completed.
Newcrest discovered the Peebeezee zincanomalous ironstone.
Pasminco Exploration entered into a JV with Newcrest in March 1993.
During that year mapping and rock chip sampling was completed which highlighted a number of cross structures which are believed to have controlled sedimentation.
A total of 1072m of RC drilling (15 holes) were completed along 30km strike length of the Peebeezee horizon.
A weak sphalerite and chalcopyrite mineralised sequence at the base of the Jillawarra Formation was located.
In the second year these holes were gamma logged and there was further rock chip sampling and geological mapping completed.
An Aeromagnetic survey was flown over the tenement at 200m line spacing highlighting the intense magnetic feature of the Hughes anomaly.
Eight RC drill holes totalling 777m were drilled with the best result being 8m @ 0.53% in hole PBZ20.
Encounter Resources Ltds Pingandy Creek project (E08/1578, E081779 and E08/1794) is located approximately 84kms south of Paraburdoo W.A.
The Exploration Licences were applied for on 1 September 2005, 27 March 2006 and 11 May 2007 respectively.
This report covers the surrendered lease E08/1794.
The south eastern half of the project sits within the bounds of the Nharnuwangga Wajarri Ngarlawangga (NWN) Native Title Claim.
The area of the NWN claim is covered by an Indigenous Land Use Agreement (ILUA) between the State and the claimants, dated 5 July 2001.

Activities conducted by Encounter during the tenure held included the collation of historical data, the acquisition and interpretation of a series of hyperspectral images over the tenement area, field reconnaissance visits to the project and a review of historical drill hole HD1.
Interpretation of old data and hyperspectral work in the area did not identify any anomalism requiring followup work.
Based on results to date not identifying any areas of significant interest, it was recommended tenement E08/1794 be surrendered.

Tenement E09/1247 is part of a the Ti Tree and Goldlaw Project which comprises four contiguous Exploration Licences which, in aggregate, cover an area of 670 square kilometres of the Gascoyne Mineral Field.
The project geology comprises Palaeoproterozoic Gascoyne Complex granitoid intrusives and Morrisey Metamorphic Suite metasediments, overlain by remnants of the Bangemall Basin succession.
The granitic rocks are themselves, subdivisible into early, gneissic intrusives and later, non-foliated granites of the Minnie Creek Batholith.
The Project tenements consist of E9/1167, 1200, 1201 and 1247, all of which have potential, sometimes proven, to host porphyry style copper-molybdenum deposits.
Mineralisation of this model have been shown to exist within the tenements, the most advanced of which was drilled to shallow depths in 1980.
The drilling intersected lowlevel copper molybdenum mineralisation associated with significant sulphide-rich potassic alteration.
As a result of work completed in 1995, confirmation of large size alteration systems and IP anomalism provided specific, but as yet untested drill targets.
Tenement E9/1247 consists of no less than three discrete segments separated by tenement E9/1201.

The most prospective ground lies in the northern segment which contains several large geochemical anomalies and weakly magnetically anomalous granites including target T19 and portions of T23A and T24.
These targets are associated with gold anomalism to 25 ppb on target T19, molybdenum anomalism on target T23A and molybdenum-copper on target T24.
A review of the data base indicates that none of these targets are currently sufficiently well defined to allow drilling.
A programme of I.P.
surveying, geological mapping and soil sampling is therefore recommended to evaluate their potential.
The Rum Well anomaly is weakly anomalous in molybdenum and a second molybdenum area of mineralisation is noted along the regional trend north west of Rum Well.
All these require mapping and sampling to bring them to a drill-testing stage.
DoIR E09-1247 MER 19Dec07.doc 19/12/2007 In addition the weakly magnetic granitoid target in the south east corner of the main tenement block contains a portion of target T24.
This is shown to be molybdenummineralised within adjacent E9/1201 and is another area with porphyry potential.
However, to commence the programme it is recommended that an Induced Polarisation survey be carried out to cover T19 and T23A.

The geophysical company Fugro have been contacted as to information on costs and system availability to test the tenement and indicate that there are some delays as the geophysical crew will not be able to operate until October-November.
The method has an effective penetrative depth of around 200 metres and costs are in the order of $3000 per day, with the average rate of coverage being one to two kilometres per day.
Thus the funding allows for around 15 kilometres of IP survey and this is translated into six lines from 1.2km to almost 3 km in length.
The following programme should be implemented to evaluate these targets: 1.
Dipole dipole I.P.
testing of four of the targeted granitoids.
Geological and evaluations of identified lithocap and other targets, including reconnaissance soil and other geochemical surveys.
Geophysical (IP) testing of geological and geochemical targets.
4 RAB and/or RC drilling of IP anomalies and geochemical targets, including deep drilling beneath lithocap targets.
5 Result evaluations, data base compilation and reporting.
TITLE: E09/1247 Proposed Exploration Program 2007 Geophysical Survey

REPORT PERIOD: Goldlaw Pty Ltd and WR Richmond Goldlaw Pty Ltd and WR Richmond Annual E09/1247 Annual Mineral Exploration Report 23 October 2006 22 October 2007 AUTHOR/S: H Davies Anderson's Tenement Management DATE: 1:1,000,000map sheet:
The following programme was designed to cover three of the four Exploration Licences held at the Ti Tree project.

The tenements have been subjected to various degrees of exploration, with tenement E09/1167 being the most advanced in that there has been some drilling, including three quite deep RC holes completed in areas exhibiting porphyry copper molybdenum mineralisation.
The other two are less well explored and much of this work concentrated on evaluation the base metal massive sulphide potential of the tenements.
The search for porphyry-related mineralisation is still at an embryonic stage.
The problem of testing the three tenements while staying within the budgetary constraints of a one year, Department of Industry and Resources expenditure requirement, is a logistical one.

The evaluation of E09/1167 is sufficiently advanced to allow limited deep drilling, probably on an existing drill pad, thus perhaps negating the need for the time-consuming and expensive Aboriginal and Mines Department site clearance requirements.
However the budget for this drilling is probably inadequate to support the drilling of even one deep hole.
Also such drilling would require proportionally high mobilisation costs, and specialised drill equipment as the depth would be below that normally achievable by an RC rig.
Deep drilling means high ground-water pressures, slow drilling rates and time consuming delays.
In the current overheated market, the basic need of locating a rig owner prepared to take on this small amount of work would be a problem in itself.
Drilling therefore has to be delayed until the programme is more substantial and a suitable rig with a powerful compressor is available.
This in turn would require higher organisational levels to deal with the DoIR.
The other tenements presented an even greater problem.
The data base for the Ti Tree project is the largest of all the Far West and Kangaroo Creek data bases.
Much of it also pre-dates the routine use of computers.
Much time was spent reviewing this information and scanning and grid-co-ordinating maps in an attempt to generate tightly constrained drill targets.
This was an impossible task and had to be abandoned.
The solution eventually came down to geophysical surveying, a process which would yield useful indirect information which, in itself, would provide drill targets.
Pricing on an airborne EM survey was obtained and plans drawn up to cover a part of each of the three tenements, costed to meet DoIR expenditure requirements.

After some consideration this was abandoned as, while the EM system provides blanket coverage, and includes magnetic imagery, over an area delineated by the client, it does not detect disseminated sulphide mineralisation of the kind present within porphyry copper-molybdenum deposits.
It was therefore decided to utilise a ground Induced Polarisation survey.
This method has a depth penetration of up to 200 metres so would easily penetrate any lithocap or lateritic cover along the line of the survey.

It is specifically designed to detect disseminated sulphides and in addition, if the offset dipole dipole method is used, it DoIR E09-1247 MER 19Dec07.doc 19/12/2007 provides a form of three dimensional imaging of anomalous targets.
Its disadvantages are in its expense, slow rate of progress and limited lateral coverage.

This aside, by using an IP survey, the dimensions of which are constrained to fall within budget limits, the cost of mobilisation are apportioned to each tenement and their IP evaluation is carried out in one session.

Using the data base set up in MapInfo, scanned maps showing the location of copper-molybdenum samples and the magnetically anomalous granitoids were used to precisely define the locations of the IP survey lines.
With a GPS the line length and position could be used to control the survey and that data could be pressed into service at any time.

However, the IP crew of Fugro, who were asked to quote on the work, would not be available until October, which allows some time for a field evaluation and any adjustment of the survey can be vectored in before the work is undertaken.

ABSTRACT: 19 December 2007 Meekatharra Gold, Molybdenum, Copper and Base Metals Location: The Goldlaw Project lies immediately north west of the Ti Tree prospect and straddles the Minnie Springs shear system between Minnie Springs and Camp Well, on the Meekatharra 1:1,000,000 map 350km north east of Carnarvon.
Geology: LANDSAT studies, aeromagnetic and radiometric surveys, sediment sampling, soil and rock chip sampling and petrology defined several anomalies, particularly copper and molybdenum.
Work to Be Done: Geological mapping and sampling, 16km IP survey and 1,000m drilling.
Conclusions: Previous work on the tenement suggests the presence of potentially mineralised targets all of which are believed to warrant further evaluation via the above activities.
The budget for this programme is therefore as follows, with the Fugro survey taking precedent over the tenement ground evaluations.
