2008 ANNUAL TECHNICAL REPORT E27/310 Balagundi 3 1 SUMMARY Work completed on Exploration Licence 27/310 included 218 auger geochemical samples collected and analysed for a multi-element suite, and six (6) rock chip samples taken as part of a regional geological interpretation and targeting exercise undertaken by consulting geologist John McIntyre of Lithos-X Mineral Exploration Consultants.
2 INTRODUCTION Exploration Licence 27/310 forms part of Pioneer Nickel Limiteds Balagundi Project.
The tenement was acquired from original title-holder Plasia Pty.
The Balagundi Project comprises eleven contiguous tenements either granted or under application, totalling approximately 135 square kilometres.
The companys primary objective in the project is to explore for volcanogenic massive sulphide deposits (VMS) within bimodal volcanic sequences in the Gindalbie Terrane.
This report details exploration work undertaken on the tenement during the period May 2007 to May 2008.
The principal commodities sought are copper, zinc, lead, nickel and gold.

2.1 LOCATION AND ACCESS The tenement is located on the Hampton Plains Station, approximately 30 kilometres east of Kalgoorlie, south of the abandoned townsite of Kanowna, and approximately 10 kilometres northeast of the historic Balagundi Gold Camp.
Access to the tenement is via the sealed Kalgoorlie to Bulong road, turning due north along station tracks just before the Hampton Plains homestead.
Access within the tenement is via fence lines and 4WD tracks.
2.2 PHYSIOGRAPHY The landscape of the project area is flat to gently undulating, and broken by low scarps and strike ridges.
Lakes, which are predominantly saline, occupy low lying areas.
Climate is semi-arid with an annual rainfall of around 250mm which generally occurs in the summer to autumn period; occasional cyclonic events can also cause local flooding.
Vegetation consists of open eucalyptus woodland including salmon gum, gimlet and mallee interspersed with salt bush and blue bush which cover the flat and undulating country.
2008 ANNUAL TECHNICAL REPORT E27/310 Balagundi 4 2.3 TENEMENT STATUS The tenement is located on Hampton Plains Pastoral Lease.

Details of the tenement are provided in Table 1 below: Prospect Tenement Area blocks Status Holder Grant Expire Balagundi E27/310 6 Live Western Copper Limited 05/05/2005 04/05/2010 Table 1 - Tenement Details

2008 ANNUAL TECHNICAL REPORT E27/310 Balagundi 5 3 GEOLOGY 3.1 Regional Geology Exploration licence 27/310 occurs within the Gindalbie Terrane of the NorsemanWiluna Belt which is located in the Eastern Goldfield Province of the southeast Yilgarn Craton.
The Gindalbie Terrane is bound to the west by the Mt Monger Fault and to the east by the Emu Fault, and consists of three recognisable greenstone sequences separated by low angle thrust faults.

The lower most sequence comprises a calc-alkaline complex overlain by fine-grained sedimentary rocks characterised by a bi-modal volcanic sequence including basalt, andesite and dacitic lavas interbedded with siltstones and tuffs and intruded by mafic intrusives.
The lower-most succession is structurally overlain by komatiite from the Bulong Volcanic Complex, with intercalated felsic tuff horizons that may represent Kalgoorlie Terrane sequences.
The whole package has been folded into a broad north-south plunging anticline known as the Bulong anticline, located about 20 kilometres east of Balagundi.
2008 ANNUAL TECHNICAL REPORT E27/310 Balagundi 6 3.2 Local Geology In the northern part of the tenement, limited outcrop of Archaean bedrock is exposed.
Predominant rock types are gabbro (Aog) and sediments, predominately shales and siltstones (As).
Immediately east of the tenement boundary, komatiitic ultramafic rocks belonging to the Bulong Complex can be seen in outcrop.
The remaining surface area of the tenement is covered by laterite (Clz) and laterite derived products (Czc).
A north east trending seasonal creek system drains the area to a salt lake immediately north of the tenement area.
2008 ANNUAL TECHNICAL REPORT E27/310 Balagundi 7 4 PREVIOUS EXPLORATION ACTIVITIES The tenement area has had a long history of gold and base metal exploration.

There is evidence of early gold-mining activity at the Western Lights and Northern Workings prospects in the central part of the tenement; no production records exist, but workings look to be of a minor nature.
Modern exploration commenced in the late 1960s with base metal exploration on the eastern side of the tenement within the Bulong Complex, predominantly for nickel-sulphides.
Companies including Ada Exploration Pty, Western Mining Corporation and Australian Selection Trust have all explored parts of the current tenement area.
Work consisted of field mapping, rock chip sampling and auger geochemistry.
Extensive lateritised peridotite sequences were mapped, but no gossans were recognised within the tenement area.
Australian Selection intersected anomalous copper results within a gabbro unit immediately south west of the tenement but did not follow these up.

Pioneer have previously acquired multi-client aerial photography and aeromagnetic data over the Balagundi project area, compiled open-file data into a digital database, completed reconnaissance geological mapping, and carried out a 674-hole auger geochemical program over the southern half of the tenement as part of a regional auger program.

5 EXPLORATION DURING THE REPORTING PERIOD Exploration completed by Pioneer during the reporting period comprised multi-element auger geochemistry over the northern portion of the tenement, rock-chip sampling, and engaging LithosX Mineral Exploration Consultants to complete a study into the solid geology, aeromagnetics, surface geochemistry and regolith types to delineate a series of targets for gold, nickel and VHMS zinc-copper mineralisation.
An exploration index map showing the location of work completed within the tenement is presented as Figure 4 below.
Total exploration expenditure on the tenement during the report period was $81,962.

2008 ANNUAL TECHNICAL REPORT E27/310 Balagundi 8 5.1 Multi-element Auger Geochemistry An auger-sampling program comprising 224 samples was undertaken over the project area which was part of a regional program collecting some 1815 samples.
A hydraulic auger rig, mounted on a 4WD Land-cruiser was used to collect the samples, which were collected on a 400m X 40m pattern using GDA94_51 datum.
Sample location was determined by a DGPS unit fitted to the rig.
Average hole depth was 1m.
The samples were collected in pre-numbered geochemical bags.
Analytical standards were inserted into the numbering sequence at a ratio of 3 per 100 samples.
2008 ANNUAL TECHNICAL REPORT E27/310 Balagundi 9 completed a brief log of the sample material.
All location and drilling data were digitally captured by the operator.
A plan of the sample locations and sample numbers is presented as Plan 1.
The samples were dispatched to Acme Laboratory Services in Canada for analysis.
The samples were dried at 60C then pulverised to 85% passing 150 mesh and digested using a standard four acid attack.

5.2 Solid Geology Study Lithos-X Mineral Exploration Consultants were contracted to complete a solid geology and regolith interpretation and target generation over the Balagundi Project Area, including E27/310, with the aim of delineating a series of targets for VMS style mineralisation as well as targeting gold and nickel.

In addition, an outcrop geology interpretation was completed so that surface geochemistry could be domained and analysed by regolith type (e.g., outcrop, upper saprolite, lateritic duricrust, soils developed above buried laterites, and transported sediments).
Six rock-chip samples were taken from E27/310 as part of a wider sampling program for a total of 32 samples over the entire project area.
These were prepared at Genalysis Laboratories in Perth and the pulps sent to ACME Laboratories in Canada for assaying.

They were analysed for the following elements by the 1EX (4 acid-digestion) ICP-MS technique: Ag, Al, As, Au, Bi, Ca, Cd, Ce, Co, Cr, Cu, Fe, K, Li, Mg, Mn, Mo, Na, Nb, Ni, P, Pb, Rb, S, Sb, Sn, Sr, Ta, Ti, V, Y, Zn and Zr.
As a result of this study, the project area has been divided into four domains with common lithostratigraphic and structural properties.

They are, from the west: Kambalda Domain of the Kalgoorlie Terrane, bounded to the east by the Boorara Shear, here defined as the contact between the Golden Ridge- Corsair ultramafic and sediments (possibly Black Flag equivalents) to the east; Boorara Domain of the Kalgoorlie Terrane, comprising sediments and ultramafic units in the Nimbus through to Kanowna area.
Bounded to the west by the Boorara Shear and to the east by the Mt Monger Fault.

The Domain is here interpreted to include the Perkollili Felsic Fragmental Complex; Balagundi Subdomain of the Kurnalpi Terrane, comprising bimodal tholeiitic and felsic volcanics and sediments bounded to the west by the Mt Monger Fault and to the east by the Victory Dam Fault.

The domain is characterised by the absence of ultramafic volcanic rocks; and Bulong Subdomain of the Kurnalpi Terrane, comprising principally ultramafic volcanics interbedded with mafic rocks, sediments and felsic volcanics.

The bulk of the tenements in the project area are located within the Balagundi subdomain, and are interpreted to comprise a series of thrust repeats of a sequence comprising basal high magnesian basalt, basalt, volcaniclastic sediments and felsic volcanics at the top, intruded by gabbroic rocks
2008 ANNUAL TECHNICAL REPORT E27/310 Balagundi 10 at several levels, and then locally folded and overturned.
Regional work indicates this subdomain has a HFSE enriched geochemical signature, and is bimodal in character.
Several base metal anomalous targets are developed, generally within the volcaniclastic sequence located between the mafic volcanics and the uppermost felsic volcanic package.
This stratigraphic package is considered to be the most prospective for VHMS targets at this stage.
Four generations of fault are distinguished in the interpretation: 1.
D1 Layer parallel shears producing repetition of layering; 2.
Det Probable D2 tear faults, or possibly post D1 extensional fault; 3.
D2 Major domain bounding thrusts, e.g., the Boorara, Mt Monger and Victory Dam faults and/or shears; and 4.
D3 Late cross faults and fracture patterns- principally either NW or NE trending.
A regolith interpretation has been produced, outlining the following broad regolith units: 1.
Outcrop, either fresh or Lower Saprolite.
Amenable to geochemical sampling for gold, and possibly base metals; 2.
Upper saprolite after Archaean outcrop.
Locally mapped, but potentially more exists than mapped.
Probable depleted geochemical signature in gold and base metals; 3.
Tertiary lateritic duricrust, and soil and colluvium developed over this.
Not amenable to traditional soil sampling, but possibly responsive for elements that can be transported up through the laterite (e.g., by tree roots?
Modern alluvium and colluvium possibly developed over buried laterite, or potentially over buried Tertiary units that are precursors to the lateritic duricrust.
Potentially deep cover and not amenable to traditional soil sampling.

The aim of this interpretation is to look at any existing or new surface geochemical work with an eye to understanding the signature of ore, pathfinder and lithogeochemical indicators above a deposit in the various regolith types so ongoing exploration will be regolith specific.
As a result of the report, a series of targets for gold, nickel and VMS style deposits have been ranked ready for ongoing exploration.
Three styles of mineralisation have been targeted: 1.
Gold mineralisation, in classical structurally controlled Archaean lode style deposits; 2.
VHMS style Cu- Zn- (Pb) mineralisation; and 3.
Ni sulphide systems hosted in komatiites.
Only the western edge of a komatiite unit is located on the eastern edge of the tenements, and appears (based on the existing geochem) to have low potential for Ni mineralisation.
See Appendix 3 for a solid geology and structure map over E27/310.

The gold mineralisation is associated with a number of features, the main ones being shearing, quartz veining, ferruginisation and pyritisation.
In the central portion of the tenements, there are three major mineralised shoots - Parrot Feathers, Lindsay's Find and Neves structures.
Drilling has intersected high grade mineralised structures at depths of 450m.
The mineralisation envelope exhibits good down dip continuity within the west dipping shear system although the individual shoots may vary in length along strike.
Gold mineralisation has also been suggested to be associated with porphyry dykes and the sheared margin of the Archaean intrusive granite stock.
In the Lindsay's Trial Pit area, the base of the weathering is very shallow, while at Parrot Feathers it extends down to 20m or more with probable leaching of gold in the oxidised zone.
Work Programme M27/169: RC Drilling & Assaying: A drill programme of 352 holes was completed over this tenement and targeted two main identified structures: Eastern Structure and Central Structure.
Drilling at Parrot Feathers was designed to infill and target high grade shoots for 3D modelling purposes.
Samples were assayed for Au, As & Cu at 1 metre intervals by Leonora Laverton Assay Group, Kalgoorlie by a fire assay technique FA40 and ICP or MS finish.
Assays greater than 1g/t were repeat-tested.
M27/34: Mapping, Logging, Gridding and Surveying: A 100x50 metre grid using 1.2 metre stakes was established over a previously defined gold geochemical anomaly.
The grid was based on the Lindsays new local grid with a north azimuth of 315 degrees.

According to geological reports of the regional geology, the regional magnetic feature is a major NNW trending fault (Hampton Fault) or shear zone extending over a strike length of 50kms.
This links the mining centres of Hayes New Find, Gindalbie and Lindsays Find and other major mining centres to the south.
The project area is overlain by a generally shallow regolith and Lindsays Find mine is located within a steep south plunging antiform containing secondary isoclinal folds.

The mine sequence comprises magnesium enriched porphyritic basalt in contact with epiclastic sedimentary rocks (shales to fine sandstones) and an andesite porphyry stock intruding this sequence along a NNE trending corridor, hosting the bulk of the gold mineralisation.
The gold mineralisation in the areas surrounding the mine occurs in meta-volcanics and metasediments on the limbs of a complex fold structure.

The gold is generally contained within small flat-lying shear zones that dip to the west, however, it has been reported that mineralised shears occurring within the Lindsays Find Trial Pit dip up to 65 degrees west or east.

The status of geological mapping and general structural knowledge of the area is incomplete however an improved understanding of lithological and structural controls of gold mineralisation has made exploration drilling and resource definition a success.

Introduction The Lindsays Find Project is situated 56kms north northeast of the city of Kalgoorlie-Boulder in the Eastern Goldfields of Western Australia (see Figure 1).
The project tenure comprises two mining leases, eighteen prospecting licenses and two exploration licences over a total area of approximately 150 sq km.

The main route to the project passes through the township of Kanowna on a sealed road, and then heads toward the mining centre of Gindalbie bypassing roads to the mining centres of Kurnalpi, Black Swan and Carosue Dam.
A northwest track six hundred metres north from the turnoff to Carosue Dam leads to the Lindsays Find area located 4.5kms from the main road.
Generally the topography is subdued and characterised by low rounded hills of mafic outcrop which grade into wide alluvial valleys.
Gold was first discovered in the region at Kanowna in 1893 and soon after at Gindalbie and Lindsays Find.
It was not long before shallow mining commenced and substantial quantities of gold were being produced.
During that early period of mining, Kanowna yielded approximately 1.0M oz and Gindalbie around 40,000oz at grades of the order of 1.0oz/ton.
Lindsay's Find was reported to have produced 4,237t at 19g/t.
The ground was picked over by small scale operators during the 1930s with only 100 oz (950t at 3.0g/t) extracted.
There was long period pre- and post-World War II when conditions were not favourable for gold mining in Australia and records at Carrick Vale reflected this.
It was not until the early 1980s that interest reemerged.
In the early 1990s another 4,000t of material was removed from the Trial Pit at a grade of 4.0g/t.

Throughout the Carrick Vale prospecting and exploration licences there is evidence of small scale surface mining, involving trenching and shallow shafts, most of which is unrecorded and of uncertain timing.
The climate is semi-arid with an annual rainfall of about 250mm and annual evaporation of about 2300mm.
Rainfall in the area varies from light falls during winter to heavier, patchy falls in summer and autumn.

In some instances this region can become flooded due to very heavy rains brought about by tropical cyclones which move in from the northwest (Ahmat, 1995) The area has moderate dense vegetation and so access to other parts of the property can be achieved by travelling cross country using a four wheel drive vehicle (Refer: Figure 1).
Geological Setting Carrick Vale Geology The Carrick Vale property area is located on the central part of the NNW trending Archaean greenstone belt that runs between Norseman and Wiluna.
In the area of the property, the bedrock comprises a sequence of metamorphosed Archaean basic and felsic volcanic rocks.
The basic rocks range from basalt to gabbro while the felsic rocks include volcaniclastics and porphyritic felsic rocks.
This sequence has been intruded by a porphyritic granitoid stock in the west of the tenements area and by NNE trending porphyritic felsic dykes in other parts.
Much of the Archaean bedrock sequence is overlaid by Cainozoic sediments and rocks that include detrital deposits and laterite.
The main structure in the tenement area is a NNW trending antiform that runs through the Trial Pit and extends to the north and south.
The antiform plunges to the SSE so that there is a southern closure on the surface trace of rock units.
Westerly dipping shear zones that host gold mineralisation are known in the vicinity of the antiform axis and there are also northeast trending structures.
These two structural orientations are associated with the fold mineralisation.

A post folded porphyritic biotite-granite intrusion is located in the central portion of the Lindsays Find project which may have been the mechanism for the development of structural sites for the deposition of significant gold mineralization.
Gold mineralisation probably developed initially in north-northwest trending shear zones during strikeslip deformation parallel to fold planar foliations.
The probable presence of ultramafic rocks low in the stratigraphic sequence, below the Lindsays Find project, suggests the most likely reservoirs for ore fluids.
It should be noted that as well as gold fluids, highgrade nickel sulphide ore is mined at Silver Swan located in an adjoining tenement south west of the project.

Regionally the geology of the Edjudina 1:100,000 sheet is characterised by granites intruding or in fault contact with Archaean rocks which include sediments, felsic and mafic volcanics.
The region falls within the Edjudina Terrane (Swager et al., 1990) of the Eastern Goldfields Province and is bound by the Claypan fault to the west and the Pinjin fault to the east.

This region differs from the domains to the west with minor volumes of metabasalt and metakomatiite and more prolific calc-alkaline andesitic complexes with associated clastic rocks as well as BIF, chert and metasedimentary sequences intruded by metadolerite (Swager,1995a,1997).
The region has undergone greenschist metamorphism although high grades upto amphibolite can occur close to granite margins.
Locally the geology consists of intermediate schists and sediments with BIF forming prominent north west trending ridges.
The basaltic schists tend to form more flat to gently undulating landforms and shallow surficial sediments cover most of the region and outcrop is limited.
The most common granitiod variety is monzogranite with biotite and includes the Galvalley and Yarri Monzogranites which are located to the southeast.

The Galvalley Monzogranite forms a large ovoid structure having been intruded post regional folding while granites intruded prior to regional folding are interpreted as sheets conformable with the greenstone layering.
Zones of shales and undifferentiated mafic intrusives occur as sporadic outcrops in between zone of thick salt lake cover and possibly residual soils.

EXPLORATION Exploration carried out during 2007 /08 has been dominated by a combined soil sampling and reconnaissance regolith mapping program.
Throughout the tenement large zones are deemed unsuitable following mapping for conventional soil sampling as the alluvium and are poor sampling media and also obscure the underlying geology.

The soil sampling program consisted of the collection of 500 grammes of -80# material collected from the B soil horizon if identified (where seen 15-20 cm depth) or from within the a zone 10 cm into the thick pedogenic calcrete zone intersected throughout sampled areas in close proximity to interpreted perched salt lake sediments.
A total of 130 samples were collected on a 400 x 50 metre grid.
Several coherent results of greater than 15 ppb Au were identified.
A short ground validation program is planned.
Gold deposits within the district are a mixture of low tonnage high grade underground ore and moderate grade, moderate tonnage open pit developments.
Recent successes in exploration in the area have defined broad low grade gold Hawthorn Resources Limited A.C.N.
009 157 439 P31/1730 Triumph 2007-2008 Annual Report 2 resources within sheared granite and also within andesitic volcanics associated with intrusive granite bodies.

Gold mineralisation occurs in a variety of host rocks and structural settings in the vicinity of the Edjudina line of workings, approximately 3.7 km west of the tenement which extends over 15 kilometres between the Glengarry Mine and Clymies Well.
Gold production from this area is recorded as approximately 1363 kg from 43,043 tonnes at an average grade of 31.67g/t Au.
The gold is associated with boudinaged quartz veins with anastomosing shear zones hosted within pyritic sericite chlorite schists with felspar porphyry dykes occurring within the shear zones.
Recent resource upgrades by Jackson Gold Limited at their Wallbrook Hill prospect, 10 kilometres south of Porphyry, are 7.1M tonnes@ 2.14 g/t Au for 488,400 ounces of gold.

In the northern area of Savannah gold is hosted within the Mt Hornet Shear Zone with 8 deposits and prospects located in a complex mix of metamorphosed mafics, intermediate volcaniclastics, sediments and intrusive syenite.

Komatiites of the UG form a compositional continuum from spinifex-textured flows to olivine adcumulates.
The latter are interpreted to have formed from a continuous channelized flow (Hill et al., 1995), which is a regime conducive to the formation of Ni sulphide deposits.

Nickel-Cr data from Yackabindie (Naldrett and Turner, 1977), Mt Keith (Dowling and Hill, 1990), Kingston and Hooneymoon Well (Hill and Gole, 1989) cluster on, or close to, an olivine-liquid mixing trend and extend along the Ni-rich leg, indicating a mineralised komatiite sequence (Barnes and Brand, 1996).
The Sinclair NiS deposit (33,000t of contained Ni) and the mineralisation at Stirling, Skye and Schmitz Well all lies on this trend.
Limited data from Fly Bore, Marshall Pool and Mt Clifford (Donaldson, 1983) are Cr-rich, indicating cumulus chromite.
Within the Mt Clifford region there is known NiS mineralization present at Marriott Prospect (8,000 Ni tones) and Babylon (107 Prospect).
However, there is no known mineralization within the Thooto Pool lease.

Granite outcrops are generally more subdued, as flat sheets or boulder style outcrops.

Drainage is generally north to south, in wide, mulga-covered alluvial plains.

The Thooto Pool Region is situated within the Agnew-Wiluna Greenstone Belt.
This belt is characterised by NNW-trending komatiites, mafic volcanic rocks, and felsic volcanic and volcano-clastic sedimentary rocks, bounded by intrusive granitoids.
The regional geology is described by Bunting and Williams (1979), and a more detailed description of the komatiite sequences given by Naldrett and Turner (1977) and Hill et al.
Naldrett and Turner (1977) divided the Agnew-Wiluna Belt into two greenstone units separated by a major unconformity.
These include the Lower western Greenstone sequence, host to the barren Lawlers Ultramafic unit and the Upper eastern Greenstone sequence (UG), host to NiS mineralised komatiitic sequences.

The stratigraphy for the UG is poorly understood, comprising of volcanic and volcano-clastic rocks (acid, felsic & mafic), sedimentary rocks (pelites, shales and cherts), basalts (pillowed, tholeiitic and high Mg) and komatiite sequences (olivine ad-meso-orthocumulates and thin spinifex textured flows).

The conclusions derived from survey are to relinquish the entire Tjukayirla tenement package for the following reasons: Major magnetic anomaly interpreted to be a BIF unit Extreme depth of possible ultramafic stratigraphy rendering exploration prohibitive Little target focus within possible ultramafic Other issues: The remoteness and lack of infrastructure around project Difficult native title issues with multiple claimants Clearly the key points are the depth of possible ultramafic at ~600m and the lack of focus within this ultramafic for drill targeting.
Despite the relinquishment of the ground it is acknowledged that the stratigraphy does indeed still hold NiS tier 1 potential though at this time further exploration is not warranted.

Fugro Airborne Surveys was contracted to fly an airborne magnetic survey over the entire group of tenements to test the depth of Palaeozoic cover and provide a targeting tool for testing the inferred mafic/ultramafic basement.
The area of the survey is approximately 1200 km2.
This work was carried out during October 2006.
2.1 Location and Physiography The Tjukayirla Project is located approximately 220km east of Wiluna and 240km northeast of Laverton.
The main access route to the leases is via the Great Central Road from Laverton (Figure 1).
The topographic highs reflect the multiple belts of covered N/NNE trending sedimentary rocks.
Sand ridges of the order 10m are prevalent in the NE portion of the project area.
The highest point of the tenement group reaches 571m a.s.l.
Topographic lows are underlain by basalt and covered by colluvium or sheetwash alluvium.
The predominant drainage is to the north where Lake Jeffries and Banjo Creek form regional depressions.

Regional Geology From work carried out by the Bureau of Mineral Resources (BMR) and the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) in 1971 and oil exploration companies during the early 1960s, the following is the existing geological interpretation.
Seismic data shows a Proterozoic basement in excess of 12,000 metres in thickness which was subdivided into upper and lower units based on seismic velocities.
The lower older unit does not crop out in the survey area but to the west the outcrop is described as gently folded shallow marine sediments that are intruded by dolerite dykes.
The younger upper unit is known from oil exploration holes drilled to the east of the project area and is described as sandstones, siltstones, shale and dolomite.
The Proterozoic basement is overlain largely by Palaeozoic sediments with a flat lying tholeiitic basalt at its base.
This is the Table Hill Volcanics and has been dated from oil exploration holes at 575 40 Ma.
Thin Mesozoic and Cainozoic sediments overlie these units and form most of the present day land forms.

The reported overall thickness of the Palaeozoic sediments is within the thickness range of the modelling carried out from the data collected from the recent detailed aeromagnetic survey (see section 3.2).

The survey also shows that the basement Proterozoic units in the project area are likely to be a mafic/ultramafic stratigraphy with possible intercalated BIF units rather than the shallow marine sediments as reported by the BMR/GSWA work.

Previous Exploration The Hunt Oil company and its partner Placid Oil explored for hydrocarbons in the early to mid 1960s and the work consisted of photo interpretation, a reconnaissance aeromagnetic survey , a detailed gravity survey, a reflection seismic survey and an exploratory drill hole (Yowlaga 2) which intersected only 845 metres of Phanerozoic sediments.
This poor volume of sediments resulted in hydrocarbon exploration being abandoned here.
The BMR and GSWA mapped the area during 1971 as part of a reconnaissance geological survey of the Officer Basin.
This work included seismic traverses, detailed gravity surveys and the completion of stratigraphic drill holes.
This work was integrated with the work carried out by Hunt Oil/Placid Oil program to produce the applicable published 1:250,000 geological map series.

An aeromagnetic survey was flown as a targeting tool for testing the inferred mafic/ultramafic stratigraphy below the Palaeozoic sediments.

Due to the limited detail available within the existing widely spaced GSWA/BMR dataset, a high resolution airborne magnetic survey was undertaken to increase the capabilities of interpretation and give confidence in depth modelling.

3.1 Introduction and Background The Tjukayirla project is one of the few remaining unexplored regions of WA which still holds potential for a tier 1 high MgO NiS discovery with over 80km of prospective strike.

Existing magnetic coverage over the Tjukayirla package was collected in 1976 at 3000m altitude; this survey identified a strong North-South magnetic feature with approximately 80km of strike flanked by weaker magnetic anomalies in what appears to be a classic BIF, mafic, ultramafic stratigraphy.

Given that the presence of deep Proterozoic cover in the Eraheedy basin is well known, (300-600m over area of interest) it becomes necessary to establish depth to basement for explorable potential of this stratigraphy very early in the life of project.

The quality of the government dataset though of reasonable standard for the time of acquisition was clearly sub-optimal compared with currently available acquisition systems and after some preliminary modelling the decision to carry out a new high resolution survey over the tenement package was made, with the intent of increasing confidence in depth modelling and structural information.
The survey was awarded to Fugro Airborne Surveys and flown in October 2006 over a period of 11 days with final processed data received in early December 2006.
An extensive process of magnetic modelling in both 2.5D and 3D coupled with image processing was then carried out to maximise the value of the dataset and draw out any subtle features.
Results of the modelling are discussed in 3.3.

The entire tenement package was initially flown at 400m spacing to with in-field modelling carried out to determine areas of relatively shallow cover, with these areas identified 200m infill lines were flown to enhance structural information over these units.
Figure 2 shows the final coverage over the Tjukayirla project.

A member of the BHP Billiton Group, which is headquartered in Australia Registered Office: 180 Lonsdale Street, Melbourne, Victoria 3000, Australia ABN 49 004 028 077 A member of the BHP Billiton Group, which is headquartered in Australia Registered Office: 180 Lonsdale Street, Melbourne, Victoria 3000, Australia ABN 49 004 028 077 3.3 Results and Interpretation Using current state of the art modelling software several key findings were made in regards to the potential for High MgO deposits in the area and there explorability.

Firstly it became clear that the magnetic survey had shown signifcantly more geological complexity in the area with significant changes in magnetic intensity along strike and signs of shallow cover weathering in the West of survey area.
The large central trend of the survey was confirmed as Banded Iron Formation with a depth in the order of 400m to top.
The units flanking this to the North East are potentially ultramafic stratigraphy though modelling confirms depths betwenn 600 -700m though exact depth difficult to model due to subtlty of signal.

There also appears to be a deepening trend to the North-East consistent with previous interpretations, an excepition ot this being the apparent increase in cover depth over E38/1704 indicative of a possible graben structure present.

Proterozoic rocks are fairly exposed on the Project area and are differentiated into the following units (in ascending age order).

4.1.1 Wyloo Group: The Ashburton Formation (~2000Ma) is the uppermost formation of the Wyloo Group and predominates in the eastern part of the project comprising of wacke, mudstone, arenite, lithic conglomerate, BIF and lesser felsic to mafic volcanics.

The Wyloo Group lies unconformably on the Proterozoic Hamersley Group and is proposed to have formed in a shallow to deep evolving foreland basin on the rifted passive southern margin of the Pilbara Craton.
It consists of shallow marine and deltaic sandstones and conglomerates transitioning into vesicular basalts, shallow marine/shelf carbonates, and further deltaic sandstones.
Overlying the lower section of the Wyloo is the mafic to felsic June Hill Volcanics which then moves into the 5-10km thick Ashburton Formation at the top of the group.
Maximum ages for the Wyloo Group is 2470 30Ma taken from U-Pb ageing of Hamersley Group clasts in a lower conglomerate of the Wyloo.
Rb-Sr zircon age from the June Hill Volcanics was 1843Ma.
Minimum age is constrained by the 1680Ma Boolaloo Granodiorite which intrudes the Ashburton Formation.
4.1.2 Bangemall Supergroup Sediments of the Bangemall Supergroup are exposed on the tenement.

These are the Wongida Dolomite member composed of well bedded dolomite to sandy dolomite with common stromatilite textures, and the Gooragoora Sandstone Member comprising thinly bedded and cross laminated brown arenite.
These are attributed to the Edmund Group of the Bangemall Supergroup.
Rocks of the Edmund Group strike N-S in the area and exhibit varying levels of folding along n-s fold axes.
Preservation of primary features including bedding is excellent.
All exploration conducted by Shaw River Resources Limited and Ram Resources over the tenements during the reporting period are detailed below.

5.1 GEOPHYSICS 5.1.1 Aerial Photography and Landsat Information Shaw River Resources has previously acquired Air Photo coverage from Landgate covering the area of the Mt Minnie and Parry Range Project.
In addition Landsat imagery has been purchased by the company and additional data acquired with the exploration data from RAM Resources.
Both Landsat and Air Photo data has been used for preliminary interpretation of Fe-Mn occurrences.

SRRE08_1707_Parry Range DOIR annual report 2008-2009 13 5.1.2 HyMap Survey In the course of acquiring the tenements from RAM Resources, Shaw River discovered that the HyMap hyperspectral survey data over the Parry Range tenements in 2007 had not been collected or analysed by RAM geologists.
Shaw River has since acquired the data and will incorporate the analysis in the coming period with the remainder of its geological and geophysical information.

The 2008 HyMap Survey and Processing Report focuses on tenements E08/1595 and E08/1597 but the data compiled will be used for analysis and review of the Parry Range project area and therefore has been included in this report and can be found in Appendix II.

This report describes the work undertaken and exploration results obtained by Shaw River Resources Limited and Ram Resources Limited (the companies), on the tenement E08/1707 (the tenement) on the Parry Range Project, during the 19/09/08 -18/09/09.
The Parry Range Project area is located in the West Pilbara region of Western Australia, 250km South of Karratha, and 100km east of Onslow.

The tenements are registered in the name of Ram Resources Limited and operated by Shaw River Resources Ltd under the terms of a sale and joint venture agreement with Ram Resources dated 9 February 2009.
During the reporting period available aerial photography over E08/1707 was reviewed along with Landsat imagery.
A preliminary review of HyMap Hyperspectral data over the Parry Range project area was commenced.

During the 2008/2009 period an agreement was reached with the holders, Ram Resources Limited, previously Contact Resources and Contact Uranium, whereby Shaw River Resources would obtain an 85% interest in the tenement.
Shaw River plans to conduct exploration for iron and manganese on E08/1707.
Earlier exploration over the tenement E08/1707 and surrounding tenements has focused on base metal anomalism.
Field visits during 2006 and 2007 confirmed the existence soil covered plains within the project area.
In 2007 Airborne HyVista surveying was carried out due to the lack of exposure of any rock.

The exploration model for base metals is similar to that used further east on E08/1183 where groupings of copper occurrences are categorised into two main groups, the Kin occurrences and the Mount Murray occurrences, and a third group in an area of previously noted high grade silver occurrences.

All occurrences at Mt Parry occur along a NNW striking package of chlorite rich schists believed to be derived from mafic volcanics and associated sediments, within the middle Proterozoic Morrisey Metamorphics.
This package of lithologies is believed to continue from NNW of the Kin occurrences to SSE of the Mount Murray occurrences and on up to the lease boundary.
Lithologies encountered at the magnetic anomalies were gossans and iron rich rocks containing up to 4% manganese.
The Mount Murray occurrences occur as 2 separate systems, both striking NNW and separated by approximately 60m.
The Eastern occurrence, MME, has lithologies, noted from shaft spoils, virtually identical to those of Kin1 and Kin2.
MME is traced along strike between 2 previously dug shafts and dozer scrapes for a distance of 150m.
The Western Occurrence, MMW, has copper carbonates noted in the later Pegmatite intrusion, and is traced along blasted surface workings and dozer scrapes for approximately 150m.
Common to all the occurrences are quartz veins with visible high percentages of copper carbonates.
Significant drilling results were: Mount Murray: PRC2 3m @ 0.1% Cu from 60m.

Further work to be conducted on E08/1707 as part of the greater exploration search on adjacent tenements for Stratabound and hydrothermal manganese-iron bodies will include; Potential sampling and prospect scale identification of manganese iron occurrences Project area Hyperspectral data review The area is recommended for further work, some of which will be conducted in the 2009/2010 calender years.

Appendix I - Exploration Maps Appendix II - Hyperspectral Survey INTRODUCTION The Parry Range Project area is located on the south-western margins of the Pilbara region of Western Australia, and is centred 1000km east of Onslow, and 250km southwest of the town of Karratha on the Pilbara coast.
The project area is located on the Yanrey (SF 50-9) and Wyloo (SF 50-10) map sheets.
Main access to the tenements is via the sealed Nanutarra-Paraburdoo Road that runs west through the tenement.
Station tracks provide reasonable access to the majority of the area.
Ownership of the tenement will be transferred from RAM Resources Ltd to Shaw River Resources Ltd during the following reporting period.
RAM Resources will retain a 15% free carried interest in the tenement until the completion of a bankable feasibility study.
The Parry Range Project area covers Proterozoic rocks in the Gascoyne Province of the Capricorn Orogen.
Other broadly defined provinces of the Capricorn Orogen include the Ashburton Basin in the north and the Nabberu Basin in the South.
The Proterozoic Capricorn Orogen is situated between the Archaean Pilbara and Yilgarn cratons and is interpreted as a deformed rift basin.

The project area is situated in the western area of the Gascoyne province and comprises variably metamorphosed sedimentary rocks, and lesser volcanics that have been intruded by a range of granitoids.

Regional geological maps refer to the area underlying the tenement as including the Wyloo Group of the Tectonic Ashburton Basin and the younger Edmund Group of the Edmund Basin (Bangemall Supergroup) of the Proterozoic.

Stratigraphic and structural targets should be followed-up by field investigations including soil sampling.
RAB and/or RC drilling should be conducted to test interpretation and anomalies if required.

Cazaly Resources Limited 2008 Annual Report E25/0337 Bare Hill Project Cazaly Resources Limited July 2008 2 CONTENTS Page 1.0 SUMMARY 3 2.0 INTRODUCTION 4 3.0 TENURE 4 4.0 GEOLOGY 6

The Bare Hill Project is located on the eastern flank of the Bulong Anticline, within the Gindalbie Terrane of the Archaean Norseman-Wiluna Greenstone belt in the Eastern Goldfields province of the Yilgarn Craton.
The Archaean rocks are dominated by mafic and ultramafic volcanics although minor interflow sediments are present.
The mafic rocks include fine, medium and coarse grained varieties, which loosely translate to basalt, dolerite and gabbro (Smith, 1997).
Structurally the region is dominated by the Bulong Anticline (Yindargooda Dome), a major upright D2 fold plunging approximately 40 to 60 degrees to the south-southeast (Hickman, 1986).
The Bulong Anticline is fault bounded to the west by the Mt Monger Fault, to the east by the Randfall fault, and is intruded by granite in its core.
The moderately westward dipping Gindalbie Terrane consists of a lower mafic to felsic volcanic sequence overlain by a thick ultramafic to mafic succession known as the Bulong Complex.
These rocks have been folded into a broad structural dome known as the Yindarlgooda Dome (Swager 1995).

5555 kilometresil trkilo etresil tril trkilo etresil trkilo etresil tr 2008 Annual Report E25/0337 Bare Hill Project Cazaly Resources Limited July 2008 6 4.0 GEOLOGY
Gold mineralization within the region is associated with several different host lithologies and mineral assemblages.
High-Mg basalts, dolerites, quartz dolerites and minor quartzfeldspar porphyries contained within the Boorara-Menzies Shear Zone host gold mineralization at the Corsair and Boorara Mining Centres.
At Corsair, the regional chloritecarbonate alteration has been overprinted by a silica-sericite-pyrite assemblage along with chalcopyrite and gold mineralization.
Gold mineralization at Boorara is associated with silica-sericite-pyrite and arsenopyrite assemblages.
At Golden Ridge the sheared basalts and sediments are intruded by quartz-albite porphyry.
Gold mineralization is associated with albite-silica-sericite-pyrite alteration and minor carbonate-pyrite-galena-sphalerite and rutile assemblages in quartz-albite veining.
At the Balagundi Mining Centre the mafic rocks contain pyrite-quartz-albite-carbonate-chlorite alteration assemblages.

Gold mineralization at Balagundi is associated with narrow, high-grade quartz veins; veined brittle-ductile shears at the contact between basalt and dolerite units and with northeast striking cross-faults which displace the lithological contacts particularly where close spaced faulting has isolated basalt units within sedimentary rocks (Roberts et al.
2008 Annual Report E25/0337 Bare Hill Project Cazaly Resources Limited July 2008 7 To the north the Kanowna Felsic Volcanic Complex hosts the Kanowna Group of deposits.
Gold mineralization in the area is generally aligned along two trends, the Kanowna and White Feather trends.
Deposits in these areas are associated with felsic porphyry dykes which have intruded localised shear zones.
The host rocks are primarily felsic volcanoclastic derived sediments and polymictic conglomerates.
Gold mineralization is associated with sericite-carbonate and quartz-albite-pyrite alteration with additional fuchsite alteration being associated with the White Feather trend.
At the Kanowna Bell Gold Mine gold mineralization is hosted by granodiorite porphyry, which is emplaced along the Fitzroy Shear Zone (Hamill, 2003).
In addition to primary gold mineralization, there are numerous palaeochannel deposits localised within buried Tertiary drainage systems around the Kanowna area.
5.0 PREVIOUS EXPLORATION The nearby Balagundi Mining Centre produced a total of 120 kg of gold between 1900 and 1916.
The largest producers were the Mount Bellow and Balagundi Consolidated Gold Mines (Kelly 1954).

More recent exploration activities in the region commenced during the nickel boom of the 1960s when the region was explored by Western Mining Corporation, Carpentaria Exploration and Australian Selection (Seltrust) from the late 1960s to early 1970s.
6.0 EXPLORATION ACTIVITIES During the reporting period Cazaly collected and analysed 40 surface rock samples (RG03871RG03910).
Samples were submitted to Kalassay Laboratories in Kalgoorlie for gold analysis by fire assay while other elements were analysed by four-acid digest with ICP finish.
The best result returned was 0.084 g/t gold from quartz outcrop.
Refer to Figure 2 for the sample location plan and to Appendix 1 for the sample descriptions and assay results.
Nevertheless the assay results of rockchips have still to be assessed to plan further works.
The potential for deep mineralization has not been thoroughly investigated.
Additional drilling in selected areas has been considered.

SUMMARY This report covers the work completed by Nickelore Limited (Nickelore) formerly Halcyon Group Limited (Halcyon) on the BTZ Bardoc Project in the 12 months to 31 December, 2007.
The BTZ Bardoc Project comprises of 10 Mining Licences and 1 Prospecting License between the old Bardoc and Broad Arrow Gold Mine sites.
The tenure was acquired by Halcyon after purchasing the Bardoc South Project from Placer Dome Asia Pacific Limited (PDAP) in 2004.

Work undertaken in the reporting period involved drilling campaigns in six tenements targeting extensions of known gold deposits or previously untested geochemical anomalies, limited down hole surveying of some of the drill holes and some rehabilitation.
Reviews by Nickel consultant Sarah Dowling on drilling conducted on nickel targets within the tenure adjacent to P24/2495 highlighted several untested nickel targets.
Further exploration including drilling is required at many of the targets tested.
The original area held is shown on the map on this page.
The Escape Creek Project area is considered to be prospective for diamonds, and has been explored previously.
This earlier work has generated diamonds and indicator mineral trails in certain small catchments within the area, but to date the diamond host rock, kimberlite, has not been discovered.
Paramount Mining Corporation Ltd commenced its investigations by collating all historical data and studying the distribution of indicator trails within the project area.
This was followed up by field work in September and October 2007.
As a result of field observations and the historical data study it was decided that certain portions of Escape Creek could be surrendered.
The Company has therefore relinquished 24 of the original 56 blocks held for E 80/ 3491.
The relinquished areas are highlighted on the map on page 3.

Photos of core C:\yaringa\E9_1443_Annual_09.docx SUMMARY A search for potash mineralisation within evaporite basins in Australia resulted in a detailed geological study of the South Carnarvon Basin being initiated.
Several suitable target areas were identified with the areas applied for as Exploration Licences.
This report details the work completed on one of these target areas, E9/1443, during its first year.
INTRODUCTION The Company has identified the on-shore section of the Gascoyne Platform in the South Carnarvon Basin as the most prospective part of the Carnarvon Basin for potash mineralisation.
The Gascoyne Platform is a diamond shaped area that covers about 86,000km 2 and contains up to 5,000m of sediments.
It is located approximately 600km to 1200km north of Perth.
Parts of the adjacent Coolcalalaya Rift are also deemed to be prospective for potash mineralisation and have been included in the Gascoyne Project.
The tenement area was chosen on the basis of interpreted seismic data indicating areas that are possible hosts for evaporite deposits.
TENURE (Figure 1) E9/1443 was granted on 27 February 2008 in the name of Holocene Pty Ltd.
The tenement consists of 70 graticular blocks.
LOCATION AND ACCESS The project area is located approximately 100 km east north east of Carnarvon in the Gascoyne Mineral Field.
Access is the main Gascoyne Junction road commencing from 25km south of Carnarvon.
GEOLOGY The Gascoyne project area contains a sequence of Ordovician to Permian sediments that overlie Precambrian basement rocks.
The main target is the Yaringa Member of the 750mthick, Dirk Hartog Formation of Silurian age.
The features of this formation are known from seven exploration wells in the immediate area (Figure 4).
The 100m-thick Yaringa Member is composed of dolostone, halite and anhydrite beds.
Typically, halite beds are less than 10m thick but such beds occur in sequences aggregating 40m in thickness.
Bromine levels in the halite are high (up to 330ppm), suggesting precipitation from highly concentrated halite- and bittern-field brines.
Traces of sylvite (KCl) were reported in the Yaringa No 1 well.
A recent detailed analysis of drilling, seismic, gravity and other geological data has resulted in the identification of several areas that are prospective for potash mineralisation.

The selection criteria for the targets include local thickening of the target Dirk Hartog Formation (Figure 2) at basin edges and locations in the distal parts of the basin where high-order evaporite brines were generated and salts precipitated.

Figure 2 is a schematic diagram illustrating the features and genesis of the Woolarry prospects where thick sections of the evaporite-formation target are indicated by geophysical and stratigraphic data.
These deposits are a basinal facies in a rift environment linked to the distal parts of the Silurian basin.
Palaeogeographic reconstructions suggest that this rift was separated from the main basin by a shallow channel.
There is a high probability that any highorder evaporite brines generated in the main basin could have decanted into the deeper rift basin and further evaporated thus precipitating potash-rich salts.
PREVIOUS EXPLORATION C:\yaringa\E9_1443_Annual_09.docx Figure 3 displays the location of drillholes previously completed over the Yalbalgo area.
All available drillhole data from the above holes is summarized in Table 1.
A combination of gravity, magnetic, seismic profile and shotline data were used to identify suitable depositional targets (See Figure 3).
Figure 2 illustrates the model used to determine targets for potash development.
The target is the Silurian Dirk Hartog Formation, a sequence of dolomite, shale, sandstone, anhydrite, limestone and evaporite, with the evaporite beds being the primary target.
This formation lies immediately over the Tumblagooda Sandstone (see Figure 4).
EXPLORATION COMPLETED Following examination of the gravity and previous drillhole data, an 1176 metre diamond drill hole was completed.
The target was evaporitic horizons within the Silurian Dirk Hartog Formation.
The hole ended in Tumblagooda Sandstone, having passed through the Dirk Hartog Formation but with no evaporites encountered.

These tenements are in the North Eastern margin of the of the Yilgarn block.
Eolian sand plains dominate the tenement areas, with patchy longitudal dunes derived from the granitoid outcrops, breakaways, colluvial and erosional planes.
Due to the extensive cover much of the geological knowledge has been derived from aeromagnetic data.
Interpretation reveals apparent remnant greenstone belts between granitoid batholiths (Smith.
A small outcrop mapped by the AGSO (Urarey 1:100,000 map sheet) tends to provide some evidence of the existence of greenstone.
Regionally the greenstones include a typical suite of mafic, ultramafic and sedimentary rocks of middle greenschist facies to transitional lower amphibolite facies.
A major structure lies in the eastern area where a sinistral fault offsets the Deleta Greenstone belt by 15 to 20 km horizontally.
Analysis by AGSO suggest that the maximum compressive strength in this area was oriented WNW and may correlate to other mineralising events elsewhere in the Yilgarn.
The greenstones, interpreted in the tenement areas, have a favourable orientation to be dilated by the abovedescribed tectonism with the potential to produce dilatational/breccia type deposits.
To the north these greenstones trend north and northeast and possible shear hosted deposits become likely.
Contact intends to follow up these untested greenstones.
The current tenement holdings cover areas that for many years were held by companies that focussed mainly on the Kingston area ultramafics.
The area remains virtually unexplored with only minor exceptions.
Previous explorers targeted only diamonds and gold.
None of the north eastern areas have been systematically investigated for the occurrences of greenstone, and this area remains open.
Encouraging magnetics in the north east outlining a potential volcanic pile in previously designated granitic rock are examples of the potential for new ore bodies.
The newly mapped eastern area greenstone belts are further examples of the unexplored nature of the area.
As the Collurabbie Tenements cover areas prospective to base metals and gold.

Contacts approach to the exploration focused on initially on acquiring higher resolution air borne magnetics, radiometrics and HyVista airborne spectrographic data with the view to follow up all anomalies with ground MMI geochemistry geophysics, including EM and magnetics, coupled with geo-chem and follow up drilling.

Report A 053684 Work completed on the Bermuda Project, E38/589, during 1997 to 1998 involved aeromagnetic and IP surveys, soil sampling, auger and RC drilling and petrology studies.

Significant Au anomalism, > 50 ppb was encountered in several holes, including 4m of 200 ppb from 72 in KRC266 and 6m of 160 ppb from 28 in KRC173.

Trial Aircore drilling through little Proterozoic cover proved to be unsuccessful.
Auger drilling over areas of previously outlined mineralization proved to be ineffective.

Report A 059641 Work completed on the Nassau Project, 38/1004, in 1998 to 1999 included geological interpretation, an induced polarisation survey, percussion drilling and down-hole geophysical (IP) logging.

The aeromagnetics and RC drilling indicated that the northeastern area is dominated by strongly sheared metasediments with minor mafic lithologies and in the southwest that the majority of the area consisted of a granitic basement.

Report A 060808 E38/589, Bermuda was part of the larger Kingston/North Laverton gold project and was located 190 km north northwest of Laverton.
The Kingston Project area covered the interpreted continuation of the Gerry Well Greenstone Belt under flat lying sediments of the Proterozoic Earaheedy Basin.
Small outliers of outcropping BIF are the only evidence of near surface Archaean geology, however past BHP drilling intersected greenstone lithologies at depths of less than 70 metres.
The tenement was considered prospective for Archaean greenstone hosted gold mineralization which was concealed by a variable thickness of Proterozoic cover.

Work completed in 1999 to 2000, comprised infill RC drilling and the best results recorded were 2 m of 1.55g/t Au from 80 m and 2 m of 1.00 g/t Au from 156 m. Moderate gold anomalism was located within the tenement and it was noted that there was a close spatial association between this anomalism, the major through-going structures and significant alteration.
Arsenic and antimony also showed good correlation with major structures and gold anomalism.
However the significant gold intersections recorded were all over narrow width and it was considered that no further drilling was required.

Group Elements Project FCN 30% WMR 70% (Western Mining Resources Ltd) Source: http:/www.falconminerals.com.au/projects/collurabbie_w_a_.phtmlIn October 2003 Falcon announced the identification of Ni, Cu, PGE anomalism from the first air core drilling program on the Falcon-Western Mining Resources Ltd joint venture ground at Collurabbie.
This followed soon after WMR announced the discovery of combined nickel, copper and PGE sulphides in their adjacent ground to the north, over a strike length of seven kilometers.

On 17th August 2004, Falcon confirmed that nickel, copper and platinum group elements in sulphides were intersected in the initial round of RC and diamond drilling along the Olympia zone in the first deep drilling program on the joint venture ground as earlier anticipated.

Intersections along the Olympia zone included: 8m @ 1.23% nickel, 1.62% copper and 3.84 g/t of PGEs (including 1.64 g/t platinum, 2 g/t palladium) from 57m depth in disseminated sulphides, and 8m @ 2.93% Ni, 2.23 g/t PGE's (including 0.71 g/trhodium and 0.9 g/t ruthenium) plus other PGEs in a narrow zone of massive to matrix sulphides.
Collurabbie is interpreted to have the characteristics indicative of a new nickel-sulphide camp in Western Australia.
The mineralization style and metal association is regarded as unique in Western Australia and appears to have no geological equivalent globally.
The Collurabbie style mineralization appears from shallow air core drilling to extend over several kilometers of strike between the joint venture ground and WMR ground to the north.
Air core drilling indicates parallel zones also exist under a thin layer of transported sand that has effectively impeded exploration for nickel sulphides in this area for 3 decades.

The attached plan shows the known extent of nickel, copper and PGEs anomalism to mid June 2004 based on air core drilling in the weathered zone and supported by polished sections of drill samples indicating the presence of nickel sulphides, reported on June 8th 2004.

A selection of drill holes that returned assay results indicative of nickel, platinum and palladium sulphides, were examined for more direct evidence of sulphides from the50m spaced shallow air core drilling.

Being within the weathered and oxidized zone, the air core drilling intersected the geochemical dispersion halos interpreted to be derived from nickel sulphides either between these holes or in fresher rock beneath at depth.

Examination of drill chips in the field at hole CLAC 196 that previously reported 10m from 30m at 0.95 g/t PGEs, 0.9% Nickel and 0.88% Copper, showed strong indications of oxidized nickel sulphides and gossanous textures indicating that this hole drilled into part of the sulphide system but still within the weathered zone.
Subsequent deep drilling of hole CLD 125 confirmed the presence of significant nickel-PGE sulphides beneath this zone.
Air core drill chips from 30-32m depth were collected and submitted for independent microscopic optical examination using cut and polished chips mounted in resin.
A second examination of the polished chips was conducted using a Scanning Electron Microscope analysis.

Results of optical mineragraphic polished chips examination of sample 30-32m showed iron oxide (goethite) interpreted to be derived from pyrrhotite (iron sulphide) hosting pentlandite (nickel iron sulphide).

Results of a Scanning Electron Microscope and x-ray diffraction (XRD) examination that can provide quantitative percentages of elements within goethite grains, confirmed the presence of nickel oxide from 2.1% to 2.4%, copper oxide from 3.2% to 4.9% along with iron oxide.
Another goethite grain analysed 4.4% nickel oxide.

The Scanning Electron Microscope and XRD were not able to quantify sub percentage levels of PGEs although normal assays recorded them in air core drilling and subsequent deeper drilling confirmed them at depth.
The overall chemical analysis for the interval 30-32m was 2m @ 1.17% nickel, 1.35% copper, 1.34 g/t PGEs in a weathered zone which is consistent with the results above.

Hole CLAC 196 from where these chips were located is from the southern most line of drilling in a geochemical nickel, copper and PGE trend that spans over 400m air core drilled gridlines for a total of 2.5 km in strike length and is open to the south.
The joint venture completed 231 holes of shallow drilling to March 2004 to define zones of anomalous geochemistry.
That work has defined a number of these zones extending for over 1km to 2.5km in length.
The June 2004 microscopic work strongly supports the interpretation of sulphides of nickel, copper and PGEs at depth in fresher rock.
In August 2004 the first part of an extensive drilling campaign to test in several defined areas commenced along part of Olympia.
It intersected significant PGE's and nickel sulphides over the 600m of strike at 200m drill line intervals.
To obtain such intersections in what appears to be an extensive nickel system is considered to be very significant at such an early stage of exploration.
Two horizons of interpreted sulphide Ni, Cu and PGE anomalism exist on the western side of the tenement.

The western most air core drill lines along Argos and Agora indicated this to extend over strike lengths up to about 1.5km however there are some significant on-strike, un-drilled areas that may extend these horizons further.
This zone has three target areas designated for deep drilling with 2,500m of RC percussion that commenced in late June 2004.

The next ultramafic unit to the east Olympia, alongholes CLAC 61 to 196 (CLAC 196 returned 10m @ 0.95 g/t PGEs, 0.9% Ni and 0.9%Cu), was geologically interpreted to have potential for medium to high grade nickel,copper and PGEs sulphides and was the subject of the drilling reported on 17th August 2004.
The currently known anomalous strike length with two fault breaks observable on the plan, is 2.5km and open to the south.
3,000m of RC percussion with diamond tails commenced in June 2004 resulting in the first release of 17th August 2004.
A trial programme was determined but with vehicle breakdown and tyre punctures being extreme only two lines on E38/1778 were completed.
Anomalous nickel and gold demonstrate the effectiveness of the technique and further sampling is in progress and will be reported in the 30 June combined report.

The greenstone occurrences in the southern areas east of the faulted igneous contact with the domal external granite are interpreted as an amphibolite sequence of mafic origin, probably part of the Duketon Greenstone Belt.
The dominant structural trend over the western tenements is NNW/SSE with a minor ENE/WSW, evident from the aeromagnetic images, the latter confirmed by quartz vein orientations.

SUMMARY OF EXPLORATION ACTIVITY This report describes exploration carried out on E 27/232, which forms a part of the Whiteheads project, between 13 September 2005 and 12 September 2006 (Figure 1).
An onsite review was undertaken as part of a Whiteheads tenement rationalisation process.
TENEMENT STATUS Exploration Licence E 27/232 was granted to Great Gold Mines NL (subsequently renamed Hawthorn Resources Limited) on the 13th of September 2004.
Quantum Resources Limited manages the licences by virtue of a Farm-in and Joint Venture agreement with Hawthorn Resources Limited.
On the 30th June 2008, Quantum Resources Limited earned the right to an eighty percent interest in this and other licences in the area.
An application for a partial surrender was lodged on the 11th of August 2008 and a second partial surrender application was lodged on the 27th August 2008.
Both applications are still pending.
LOCATION AND ACCESS The Whiteheads project area is situated on the Gindalbie 1:100,000 geology sheet (SH 51-10- 3237) and forms part of the larger Whiteheads Project.
E27/232 is located 70 kilometres north east of Kalgoorlie within the Eastern Goldfields Province in the Yilgarn Craton.
Access is via the unsealed Yarri road which services the Kanowna Belle and Black Swan minesites and is also the main thoroughfare to Edjudina and beyond.
Numerous fencelines and farm tracks cross cut the tenement.

GEOLOGY 4.1 Target The region is highly prospective for mineralisation.
The Gindalbie Mining centre has historically produced 45,240 ounces of gold from 52,321 tons at average grade of 27 g/t gold.
Gold mineralisation is related to extensive shearing and quartz veining along lithological contacts and in the fine grained clastic and pyroclastic rocks of the Gindalbie Formation.
The main gold targets are small underground targets of medium to high gold grades exploitable by underground mining methods.
There is also the potential for VMS style of mineralisation as several gossans were uncovered in the 1970s but no significant base metal mineralisation has been discovered.
4.2 Regional geology The following summary of the regional geology is drawn from Chin and Smith, 1983; Riganti and Chen, 2002 and Chen and Wyche, 2003.

The Yilgarn Craton consists of 3.0 to 2.6 Ga granitioid-greenstone terranes of the Eastern Goldfields, Southern Cross and Murchison Provinces and 3.3 to 2.6 Ga high grade gneiss complexes and greenstones of the South Western Gneiss Terrane (Ho et al., 1990).
All of these terranes became stable at the conclusion of late Archaean (2.7-2.6 Ga) orogenic event to form the present day Yilgarn Craton.
The Eastern Goldfields Province forms the eastern part of the Yilgarn Craton and is separated from its western neighbor, the Southern Cross Province, by the regional NNW trending Ida Fault.
The Eastern Goldfields Province has been further subdivided into structuralstratigraphic terranes bounded by regional NNW oriented faults (Swager, 1997).

All of the terranes contain volcanosedimentary assemblages of a similar age deposited in separate but possibly adjoining basins and share the same history of granitic magmatism and tectonism (Swager, 1997).
Tenement P27/1612 is located within the Gindalbie Terrane in the southern portion of the Eastern Goldfields Province.
The western border of the Gindalbie Terrane abuts with the Kalgoorlie Terrane and is marked by the poorly exposed Mount Monger Fault.
On the eastern side the shallow west-dipping Emu Fault separates the Gindalbie Terrane from the Kurnalpi Terrane.
The Gindabie Terrane consists of three greenstone assemblages; 2.67-2.7 Ga old calc-alkaline assemblage, komatiite-tholeiite assemblage and bimodal felsic-mafic volcanic assemblage.
The calc-alkaline and structurally overlying komatiite-tholeiite assemblages are exposed in the southern half of the terrane forming the doubly plunging Bulong Anticline.
The northern half of the terrane comprises a bimodal felsic-mafic volcanic succession.
The lower part of bimodal volcanic sequence is dominated by rhyolite and the upper part is dominated by tholeiitic basalt.
Granitoid bodies occupy large areas around and within the greenstone succession and are predominantly monzogranitic in composition.
Traditionally, granitoids exposed between major greenstone belts are termed external and those that are within, or adjacent to, greenstone Quantum Resources Limited.
Many gold deposits in the Yilgarn Craton are either hosted by the granitic bodies or have been influenced by their emplacement.
Therefore their presence must be regarded as an integral part of any regional model for gold mineralization (Cassidy et al., 1990).

At least three principal compressional deformation episodes have been identified within the greenstone and granitoid rocks of the Yilgarn Craton although the magnitude and style of deformation in the greenstone sequences varies significantly.
Several extensional events that either preceded or followed the compression deformation contributed to the cratons regional deformation history (Swager, 1997).
D1: An early north-south compression produced low angle thrust faults, bedding-parallel foliation and tight to isoclinals folds in the lower greenstone sequence.
The D2 and D3 deformation events are the result of a single protracted period of regional eastwest compression.
D2: During the first stage of compression, referred to as the D2 event, deformation produced large scale north-trending upright folds and local development of gneissic banding.

D3: During the second stage, referred to as the D3 event, regional scale northeasterly and northwesterly trending ductile shear zones such as the Koolyanobbing and Mount Dimer Shear Zones were formed.

Post D3 deformation includes the formation of north-northeasterly trending faults and fractures and emplacement of mafic and ultramafic dykes during the Proterozoic along the easterly to north-easterly trending fractures.
Metamorphism in the greenstones ranges from prehnite-pumpellyite to mid-amphibolite facies.
The high grade metamorphic zones are in areas adjacent to the granite-greenstone contacts.
The cause of metamorphism has been linked to the intrusive plutonism and is evident from the occurrence of low pressure metamorphic mineral assemblages.
The peak metamorphic conditions prevailed during the main D2 compressional event; granites intruded during D2 are deformed by the D3 shear zones.
It is possible that the timing of peak metamorphism varied across the region because of differences in emplacement ages of various granitoid bodies.
Both gold and iron deposits are considered as potential exploration targets in the area.
The timing of gold mineralization remained unresolved.

However it is considered to be related to the late phase of deformation, accompanying or outlasting peak metamorphism, and postdating the intrusion of most internal granitoids and other intrusive phases (Ho et al., 1990).
4.3 Local Geology Tenement E27/232 is located in the northern part the Gindalbie Greenstone Terrane of the Eastern Goldfields Province.
The Gindalbie Greenstone Terrane is part of the Eastern Quantum Resources Limited.
The tenement is situated just south of the Gindalbie gold field.
The inferred NNW tending Hamton Fault lies adjacent to its southern boundary.
Nearly all of the project area is covered by the Cainozoic sediments, however, small outcrops of Archean felsic volcanics crop out in its northeast corner and along the southwestern boundary.
These felsic volcanics are the lower part of the bimodal volcanic succession.
The upper part of this succession consists of tholeiitic basalt.
The following description of local geology has been derived from Swager (1994).
A large part of the tenement is covered by Cainozoic sediments including laterite and silcrete regolith and colluvium.
The felsic volcanics that are exposed in the tenement can be catergorised into two main types: felsic volcanic and volcaniclastic (Afv) and feldspar-quartz porphyry (Afp).
Felsic volcanic and volcaniclastic rocks (Afv) are characterized by feldspar phenocysts, with or without quartz phenocrysts in a very fine-grained quartzofeldspathic matrix.
Fine biotite is scattered throughout the matrix or in small aggregates where it is partly replaced by chlorite.
The rocks are mostly weakly foliated.
Layering is defined by different amounts, ratios and grain sizes of phenocryst phases and by interleaved, thin, fragmental, tuffaceous or biotite-rich beds.

The feldspar-quartz porphyry (Afp) units contain large, irregular, zoned plagioclase phenocrysts and scattered, small bluish quartz phenocrysts in a fine- to medium-grained matrix of feldspar, quartz and biotite with minor opaques, apatite, zircon and secondary muscovite and epidote.
In some parts of the porphyry, both plagioclase and rounded quartz pheocrysts occur within a matrix of perthitic and granophyric feldspars, quartz and biotite.

EXPLORATION Exploration activity undertaken on this tenement during the reporting period included a field review of the Whiteheads tenements as part of a tenement rationalisation process and prioritisation of existing and potential exploration targets.

WANLs Mt Holland-Bear gold and nickel project is located about 16km west southwest of the closed Bounty Gold Mine within the Archaean Forrestania Greenstone Belt, Western Australia.
Western Areas NL is exploring the Mt Holland-Bear project area for komatiitehosted nickel sulphides deposits and mesothermal gold deposits.

2 Introduction This is the final surrender report for P77/3571 for the period 5th May 2008 to 8th June 2009.
The five tenements are owned 100% by Western Areas NL (WANL).

The five project tenements form two small tenement blocks with; 1) the contiguous E77/1309, P77/3570 and P77/3571 comprising the Bent Bear tenement block in the northwest covering the Bent Bear prospect; and 2) the contiguous P77/3569 and P77/3572 comprising the Sleeping Bear tenement block in the southeast covering the Sleeping Bear prospect.
The two small tenement blocks are about 3.5km apart.
P77/3571 is located about 16km west southwest of the closed Bounty Gold Mine within the Archaean Forrestania Greenstone Belt, Western Australia (Plan file 09047_P773571_Loc.pdf).
Access to the project area is excellent via the Forrestania-Southern Cross Road turning west (near King Ingram Road) onto mine infrastructure roads and numerous cleared grid line tracks.
Pre-existing cleared grid lines provide good access around the Mt Holland-Bear tenement areas.
Western Areas NL is exploring the Mt Holland-Bear project area for komatiite-hosted nickel sulphides deposits and mesothermal gold deposits.
3 Tenement The status of the WANLs tenements of the Mt Holland-Bear nickel and gold project area are presented in Table 1.
4 Previous Exploration The Mt Holland-Bear project area and its surrounds have a comprehensive history of previous mineral exploration beginning with Amax searching for nickel in the early 1970s.
For the period 1981 to 2001 the area was held under tenement and explored mainly for gold as part of the regional exploration tenement package surrounding the Bounty Gold Mine.

The last available public domain mineral exploration report detailing previous exploration activities in the area was by Viceroy Australia in 2001 around the time it went into voluntary administration.

The previous exploration tenements covering WANLs Bent Bear project tenement areas were relinquished in November 2005 and WANL made its Mt Holland-Bear tenement applications shortly thereafter in December 2005.

The previous work has identified low grade Cu-Mo-Au sulphide mineralisation hosted by the Bent Bear Schist that dips shallowly towards the east and extends outside of the tenement block at shallow depths.
An overlying tremolitic ultramafic unit, exposed along the eastern margin of the tenement block, also dips towards the east and outside of the tenement block at shallow depths.
This ultramafic has been previously tested for nickel without success.
5 Geology The Mt Holland-Bear Nickel-Gold Project is located on the western margin of the northern Forrestania Greenstone Belt.
The Bounty Gold mine is about 16km to the east northeast.

The regolith of the Mt Holland-Bear project tenement area and its surrounds is dominated by a deeply weathered Tertiary laterite profile and Recent-Tertiary transported alluvial, aeolian and colluvial sediments.
The depth of lateritic weathering in the region is highly variable depending on rock type but is generally around 40-60m.
Outcrops of Archaean rocks within the tenements and surrounding region are small, sporadic and generally deeply weathered.
Knowledge of the basement geology is based mostly on the results of a large number of RAB, aircore and RC drill holes combined with interpretation of aeromagnetic data.
The surface geology of WANLs Bent Bear tenement block is dominated by sand plains and laterite duricrusts.
There are also small outcrops of BIF/chert, quartzite, felsic schist and mafic schist that dip at 30-40o towards the NE.
This area covers the Bent Bear Schist Cu-MoAu prospect.

The low grade Cu-Mo-Au sulphide mineralisation hosted by the Bent Bear Schist outcrops along the eastern margin of WANLs Bent Bear tenement block and dips shallowly towards the east outside of the tenement block area, ie, only the shallowest portions of the mineralisation are contained within WANLs tenement block.
The Bent Bear Schist is a distinctive metasedimentary or metavolcanic unit sandwiched between underlying (basal) tholeiitic mafic schists and overlying tremolite-rich rocks (ultramafics).
Its western contact with the underlying mafic schists is not well defined and is thought to be transitional.

The tremolitic ultramafic body overlying the Bent Bear Schist outcrops along the eastern margin of the WANLs Bent Bear tenement block and dips shallowly towards the east outside of the tenement block.
Only the shallowest portions of this ultramafic unit and its basal contact lie within WANLs tenement boundary.
6 Work Completed Exploration activities completed within the tenement block for the annual exploration period ending 4th May 2009 consisted of a review of previous exploration activities and results.
The results of this work are summarised in Section 4 and contributed to Section 5 of this report.

7 Conclusions and Recommendations A review of previous exploration data indicated that; i) the Bent Bear tenement block (P77/3570, P77/3571 and E77/1309) has been comprehensively explored for both nickel and gold by previous explorers; and ii) there is very low residual exploration potential for the discovery of economic nickel sulphide and gold deposits within this tenement block.

Gold A significant amount of gold (est.
~480 kg) has been recovered from the Ashburton Basin, primarily from alluvial workings in the central part of the province (Thorne and Seymour, 1991).
Minor amounts of primary gold mineralisation have been found in ferruginous/gossanous (after pyrite?)
