The nearest recorded occurrence of a gold bearing quartz vein is at Prismoid Hill (526993 mE / 7395395 mN), located approximately 5 km to the west of the tenement boundary of E08/1513-I.
Base metals Numerous minor vein/shear hosted copper deposits occur within sediments of the Ashburton Formation in the central Ashburton Basin (Thorne and Seymour, 1991).
Supergene enriched ore from this style of mineralisation was historically mined from deposits at Windy Creek and Goobaroo Pool, located between 3 and 10 km to the northeast of E08/1513-I.

Uranium Past exploration for sandstone-hosted uranium mineralisation within sandstone intervals of the Ashburton and Capricorn Formations have proven largely unsuccessful, with most radiometric anomalies found to be largely due to thorium-rich heavy mineral layers within the sediments (Thorne and Seymour, 1991).

Occurrences of the secondary uranium mineral carnotite [K2(UO2) 2(VO4)23H2O] are noted filling voids within Tertiary calcrete (Thorne and Seymour, 1991), suggesting there might be some potential for calcrete-hosted mineralisation along the Seven Mile and Turee Creek drainage systems.
Gold A significant amount of gold (est.
~480kg) has been recovered from the Ashburton Basin, primarily from alluvial workings in the central part of the province (Thorne and Seymour, 1991).
Minor amounts of primary gold mineralisation have been found in ferruginous / gossanous (after pyrite?)
quartz veins within the Ashburton Formation, which may also contain a trace of galena.
The nearest recorded occurrence of a gold bearing quartz vein is at Prismoid Hill (526993mE, 7395395mN), located approximately 5km to the west of the tenement boundary of E08/1513.
Base metals Numerous minor vein / shear hosted copper deposits occur within sediments of the Ashburton Formation in the central Ashburton Basin (Thorne and Seymour, 1991).
Supergene enriched ore from this style of mineralisation was historically mined from deposits at Windy Creek and Goobaroo Pool, located between 3 and 10km to the northeast of E08/1513.
Similar lode mineralisation has been described by past workers around the Mt Elephant area (563300mE, 7395200mN), near the boundary between E08/1511 and E08/1513.
This is discussed further in the Past Work section of this report.

Occurrences of the secondary uranium mineral carnotite [K2(UO2) 2(VO4)23H2O] are noted filling voids within Tertiary calcrete (Thorne and Seymour, 1991), suggesting there might be some potential for calcrete-hosted mineralisation along the Seven Mile and Turee Creek drainage systems.
A search for historic tenements in the Ashburton Project area identified a number of past exploration licenses searching for a variety of commodities including gold, base metals, uranium and iron.
These are summarised in Table 2.

Ashburton Project Partial Surrender Report 2008 Polaris Metals NL Page 3 A brief review could not locate open file records for all of these tenements, however a summary of those reports that could be found is given below: TR70/5749, largely covered the Capricorn Formation within the Elephant Hill area (E47/1511-I, E47/1513-I).
It was explored for sandstone hosted uranium mineralisation by Pechney Australia.
The source of radiometric survey anomalies was found to be due to thin layers of thoriumbearing zircons and monazite within the basement sediments.
TR70/7079 was held over the Capricorn Formation immediately to the west of E08/1511-I and was explored for base metal mineralisation by Open Pit Mining and Exploration (OPMX).
Exploration focussed on a 500 m long, northwest-trending copper-bearing (haematite/quartz) gossan containing trace amounts of gold, silver and cobalt.
Surface sampling of the gossan returned assays ranging between 0.1 and 45% Cu.
The best result of three (earlier) diamond drill holes into the deposit returned 5 m @ 1.3% Cu.
A follow-up VLF-EM survey failed to identify a continuation of the gossan to the east, but may have been too shallow penetrating to detect the target.
E08/790, 969, 993 were held by Intension NL searching for additional (vein / shear hosted) copper mineralisation within the Ashburton Formation surrounding Elephant Hill.
Numerous orientation soil and rock chip geochemical surveys were completed returning peak values ranging up to 10.24% Cu and 2.17 g/t Au at the Elephant North prospect (within E08/1511-I).
E47/1086, mostly located to the northeast of E47/1523, and was held by Sipa Resources for gold exploration within the Mt McGrath Formation c.f.
No work was done on ground within the Ashburton Project area.
Dampier Mining also searched for detrital iron in outwash fans of the Seven Mile Creek (north of the Ashburton Project) during 1977-78.

This work failed to identify any haematite conglomerate shed from the Paraburdoo deposit and it was concluded that any haematite scree deposits in the area would probably be small and difficult to find (concealed).
Work completed during 2007 aimed primarily at assessing the detrital iron potential within the Seven Mile and Turee Creek systems cross cutting the tenement areas.
Ochre Resources and Polaris focussed on the iron potential of the project area, as described in the most recent annual statutory report for the Project area (Rafty, 2007).
This report discussed geochemical (rock chip) sampling studies from areas mapped as by the GSWA as Tertiary alluvial fans (Cza).
However, the descriptions of the chip samples suggest they are likely to represent hematite lag from small fault systems / gossans within the Ashburton Formation.
Some of the samples returned elevated base metal and manganese values which is consistent with a gossanous / fault hosted origin of the iron.
Five iron rich samples were sent for metallurgical test work to determine whether they could produce a saleable product.
Average head grade of the samples was ~20% Fe.
Heavy medium separation of a coarse fraction of the samples returned a concentrate grading 57-61% Fe with a 21% recovery.
Recommendations were made for a more thorough sampling of the alluvial material, including channel sampling and shallow percussion drilling.

Prodemas (2007) also considered the project to be prospective for both channel iron deposits and detrital scree deposits, commenting on the known outcrop of CID mapped to the north of Paraburdoo and the fact that the creeks drain from the hematite deposits of the Paraburdoo Ranges.

Prodemas proposed a mining model to extract hematite from the alluvial gravels within the Seven Mile and Turee Creek systems, and postulate a potential resource of one billion tonnes by multiplying the surface extent of mapped alluvium by a nominal thickness of 5m.
GEOPHYSICAL DATA REVIEW Open file magnetic, radiometric and gravity data were acquired and imaged.
Magnetic and radiometric data were windowed from the 2007 Ashburton survey.
This survey was flown by UTS Geophysics for the GSWA / Geoscience Australia (Job A781).
Data were collected at a 400m line spacing and nominal 60m flying height.
Within the Project area only regional gravity data sampled on an approximately 5km grid is available.
Images of the compiled geophysical data are shown in Figure 2.
The top panel shows an RGB composite (ternary) radiometric image from the radiometric data, where red is assigned to the potassium channel, green is thorium and blue is uranium.
The areas of relatively high radiometric response (pale coloured areas) generally correspond with outcropping Ashburton Formation.
Duck Creek Dolomite is characterised by a subdued thorium response (dark green) while the Mt McGrath Formation is characterised by a moderately strong potassium response (red).
Within the Project Area, transported alluvial material generally forms a darkish coloured smear concealing the Ashburton Formation response.

Examination of the uranium channel data yields peak anomalies of approximately 5 ppm eU which can be generally be related to northeast trending lineaments, suggesting the uranium anomalies may be due to weak hydrothermal alteration.
7 Figure 2: Geophysical images for the Ashburton project area - ternary radiometrics (top) first vertical derivative of magnetics (middle) and first vertical derivative of gravity (bottom).

8 While the Ashburton Formation is generally magnetically bland, it contains several small magnetic markers which are mapped as trend lines and probably reflect heavy mineral layers within the sediments.
Several narrow, moderate amplitude magnetic anomalies are interpreted as thin BIF units, although field checking is required to validate these.
Subtle magnetic markers are present at the top and base of the Mt McGrath Formation.
The main magnetic units observed to the northeast of the Ashburton Porject area are due to BIFs within the Hamersley Group as well as the Cheela Springs Basalt.
The main gravity anomalies shown in Figure 2 are due to dense BIF layers within the Hamersley Group as well as the Cheela Springs Basalt.
A single point high is identified in the Mt Elephant area, which may reflect a station coincidently located on a dense BIF / gossan or bad data.
A basement solid geology interpretation using the available geophysical imagery along with the regional 1:250k geological mapping is shown in Figure 3.
Stratigraphic contacts were interpreted using the magnetic and radiometric markers described above.
A number of structural elements were also mapped, including a dominantly NE trending fault set and several dolerite dykes interpreted from distinctive negative magnetic lineaments.

The Ashburton Project was acquired by Polaris for its iron ore potential, specifically to explore for concealed detrital (alluvial haematite sourced from the Paraburdoo Ranges) or channel iron deposits.
The exploration work completed to date has failed to successfully define either of these deposit types within the portions of the project tenements subject to this report.
Ochre/Polaris has focussed largely on evaluating the abundant alluvial material for potential upgrade to an iron concentrate.

However several limitations in this assessment are noted; The limited sampling completed so far is clustered and it does not appear that any attempt has been made to collect a sample representative of the full width of the alluvial channels.
Furthermore, descriptions of many of the rock chips samples collected by Ochre suggest many of these were taken (as lag?)
from gossans or haematitic basement shales, and hence possibly do not represent alluvial material at all.

There is no evidence to support an average thickness of 5 m or density of 2 t/m3 for the alluvial material mapped by the GSWA to yield the total potential tonnage of one billion tonnes estimated by Prodemas (2007).

It is considered unlikely that a detrital scree deposit of any substantial size will be preserved so far from the source (Paraburdoo Ranges) and the potential for a CID is considered remote in the graticular sub-blocks surrendered.
Past exploration in the Mt Elephant area has indicated widespread copper and gold anomalism.
This may be attributable to a number of small shear/fault hosted lode occurrences of sub-economic size and grade.
These BIFs have only very limited potential for hydrothermal haematite and are therefore considered uneconomic for this style of iron mineralisation.

REGIONAL GEOLOGICAL SETTING 2.1 Tenement Geology 1 2
Exploration Licences E08/1511-I to E08/1513-I and E47/1528-I form a group of tenements collectively referred to as the Ashburton Project.
The tenement E47/1528-I was added to the project group on 12 September 2008, but is not due for partial surrender until 19 February 2010.
Table 1 summarises the tenement details.
The project area is located approximately 18 km and 75 km southwest Paraburdoo and Tom Price respectively (Figure 1) and covers over 660 km2.
The tenements were granted on 20 February 2006 with authorisation for iron being granted on 6 April 2007.
Until 14 July 2006 Ochre Resources Ltd (Ochre) owned 100% of these tenements.
Polaris Metals NL (Polaris) purchased through Asset Sale Deed on the 14 July 2006.
Shareholder approval was obtained on 15 September 2006.
The subject tenements were officially transferred to Polaris on 4 May 2007.

Ochre signed and registered a Heritage Agreement with the Innowonga (W98/069) Claim Group; Gobawarrah Mindurarra Yinhawanga (WC97/043) Claim Group; and the Jurruru (WC00/008) Claim Group through the Yamatji Marlpa Barna Baba Maaja Aboriginal Corporation (YMBBMAC).

REGIONAL GEOLOGICAL SETTING (after Thorne et al, 1991) The Ashburton Project tenements are situated in the central to northern section of the Ashburton Basin (a NW-SE trending elongate sedimentary depositional zone approximately 330 km long by 70 km wide) containing poorly exposed middle Proterozoic Wyloo Group sediments (Figure 2).
A widespread blanket of Quaternary alluvium and colluvium forms a wide floodplain to the northwest flowing Ashburton River and tributaries including the southwest flowing Turee ad Seven Mile Creeks.

An extensive, but discontinuous Cainozoic cover of silcrete, calcrete, laterite, colluvium, alluvium, and pisolite unconformably overlies the Wyloo Group which is intruded by late Proterozoic Phanerozoic dolerite dykes & sills.

The upper Wyloo Group unit is the Ashburton Formation comprising a metapelite psammite sequence with interbedded basic volcanics, banded iron formation (BIF), chert, ferruginous pelite and local metaconglomerate.
Conformably underlying the Ashburton Formation is the Duck Creek Dolomite (thinthick bedded, locally stromatolitic metadolomite; metadolorudite, minor chert, and pelite).
The underlying unit is the conformable Mount McGrath Formation (ferruginous metasandstone and metaconglomerate; pelite and metadolomite).
The Cheela Springs Basalt (vesicular & amygdaloidal metabasalt, metatuff, and metasandstone) unconformably underlies the Mount McGrath Formation.
The basal unit is the Beasley River Quartzite (fine- to coarse-grained quartzitic metasandstone and pelite; minor metadolerite sills) which conformably underlies the Cheela Springs Basalt.

In a regional context the Wyloo Group defines the NW-SE trending Ashburton Basin which has been subject to several deformation phases producing a series of NW-SE striking synforms and Figure 2a: Turee Creek 1:250,000 Geological Map Sheet Legend Ashburton Project Partial Surrender Report 2008 Polaris Metals NL Page 2 antiforms with reverse plunges common along strike.

Limited sinistral strike (southwest steep shallow arcuate) dipping slip faulting occurs towards the basin margins producing graben blocks exposing the lower Wyloo Group; particularly on the northern margin abutting the older Hamersley basin sediments.

Towards the centre of the Ashburton Basin strike slip faulting has exposed thin slithers of the Capricorn Formation (ferruginous and quartzitic sandstone, mudstone, siltstone, conglomerate, dolomite, and felsic volcanic rock) restricted to the overlying Blair Basin unconformably overlying the Ashburton Formation.

Outcrop over the tenements is patchy and restricted to topographic elevated areas with large tracts of Quaternary and Cainozoic cover in the low lying alluvial flood plain zones.
Over E08/1513-I significant pods of Cainozoic alluvium occur as relict zones within the Quaternary alluvium covered flood plain associated with the braiding of Turee Creek.
Approximately 10% of the area occurs as outcrop of undifferentiated Ashburton Formation.

Minor zones of thin-thick bedded E-W striking 60-70N dipping metasandstone, pelite, local metaconglomerate, and metadolomite as basal Ashburton Formation in the central section of the tenement from the east to the western boundary.
In the far northeastern sector in the Mt Elephant area, Capricorn Formation occurs as fault bounded outcrop.
In this area an arcuate N-S concealed fault off setting Ashburton Formation appear to have an association with the faulted bounded Capricorn Formation.
Minor late Proterozoic NE-SW striking dolerite dyke orthogonally intrudes the Ashburton Formation in the southwestern sector of the tenement.

Exploration Licence E08/1511-I, which adjoins E08/1513-I, similarly has approximately 10% outcrop of folded steeply dipping undifferentiated Ashburton Formation with a minor zone of metasandstone, pelite, local metaconglomerate, and metadolomite as basal Ashburton Formation.

The outcrop zones are restricted to the western and eastern boundary zones as the tenement is bifurcated by the southwest flowing Turee Creek which has developed an extensive flood plain zone containing relict pods of Cainozoic alluvium amongst Quaternary alluvium.
The outcrop over E08/1512-I is mostly restricted to the northwest sector of the tenement where it is mostly the basal metasandstone, pelite, local metaconglomerate, and dolomite.
Undifferentiated steeply southwest dipping Ashburton Formation outcrops sporadically near the southern, western and northwestern boundaries.

The tenement is bifurcated by the southwest flowing Seven Mile Creek developing an extensive flood plain of Quaternary alluvium and colluvium (restricted to hill slopes) with minor relict pods of Cainozoic alluvium.
Minor late Proterozoic NE-SW striking dolerite dyke orthogonally intrudes the Ashburton Formation on the central southern boundary.
The project area covers approximately 600 km2 of the Ashburton Basin.
Polaris Metal NL acquired these tenements from Ochre Resources Ltd through an asset sale on 14 July 2007.

Target generation through the reinterpretation of available multi-client aeromagnetic, radiometric, and gravity data failed to delineate possible concealed detrital (alluvial haematite sourced from the Paraburdoo Ranges) or channel iron deposits.
The exploration work completed to date has failed to successfully explore for either of these deposit types.
It is considered unlikely that a detrital scree or channel iron deposits of any substantial size will be preserved so far from the source (Paraburdoo Ranges) within portions of the subject tenements.

SUMMARY An open file report review and solid geology interpretation of available government geophysical surveys over the tenements of the Ashburton Project is discussed in this report.
The Ashburton Project consists of four tenements covering a total area of 670.6 km2 located approximately 15-20km south of the township of Paraburdoo, WA.

Basement geology within the Project area almost entirely consists of Proterozoic sediments of the Ashburton Formation, with a narrow keel of Capricorn Formation preserved within a WNW trending synclinal axis.

The Project area is extensively covered by alluvial deposits along the outflow of the Seven Mile and Turee Creek systems, which drain from iron mineralisation in the Paraburdoo Range, approximately 7km to the north.
The Ashburton Project tenements were acquired by Polaris from Ochre Resources / Heron Resources for the potential to host detrital and channel iron deposits.
Previous work by Ochre / Polaris has focussed on trying to upgrade the alluvial fan material into a saleable product.
Processing testwork suggested that iron-rich material taken from the Project could be upgraded to a 60% Fe product.
However, further bulk sample testwork of alluvial material is required to verify this result to support a mining proposal.
Past workers have also identified the potential for fault hosted copper-gold mineralisation around Mt Elephant in the southern part of the Project area.
Best results from orientation geochemical surveys include assays of up to 10.24% Cu and 2.17 g/t Au at the Elephant North prospect.
Three holes drilled into the Mt Elephant prospect yielded a best intersection of 5m @ 1.3% Cu within a gossan also containing trace amounts of gold, silver and cobalt.

Gossans similar to Mt Elephant would also have the potential to host a small resource of DSO hematite ore. Further exploration for channel iron deposits and DSO hematite within the minor Ashburton Formation BIFs is considered warranted, along with further review of the copper-gold potential of the Project area.

The following recommendations for further work are made: A helicopter EM survey flown over the entire project area to help map the thickness of alluvial material and directly target for concealed channel iron deposits.
Representative bulk sampling of the alluvial fan material to validate the conceptual resource and feasibility of mining and upgrading this material.
A detailed, low level magnetic and radiometric survey to refine the interpretation of the Ashburton BIFs and possible structures hosting copper-gold mineralisation.
Review and further evaluation of the copper gold potential of the project area.
The potential for DSO hematite from the associated gossanous material should be evaluated at the same time.
Detailed mapping and sampling of BIF layers interpreted at the base of the Ashburton Formation for potential DSO hematite.

Hawke Geophysics was invited to review the prospectivity of the Project, particularly in terms of the exploration potential for iron mineralisation.
GEOLOGY The Ashburton Project tenements cover the central to northern sections of the Ashburton Basin.

The Project area is located approximately 10km south of the giant Brockman Iron Formation hosted (Hamersley Group) hematite deposits of Paraburdoo and the Western Ranges and a few kilometres south of known gold (Mt Olympus) and secondary iron deposits within the Mt McGrath Formation of the Wyloo Group.
Outcrop geology for the project area is shown in Figure 1.
3 The geology of the project area is described after Thorne and Seymour, 1991.

Basement geology within the Project area almost entirely consists of Proterozoic sediments of the Ashburton Formation (Wa) of the Wyloo Group, with a narrow keel of the overlying Capricorn Formation preserved within a WNW trending synclinal fold axis.
Outcrops of older Wyloo Group stratigraphy, Mt McGrath Formation (Wm) and Duck Creek Dolomite (Wd), occur to the northeast of the Project area.
The Ashburton Formation is the uppermost unit of the Wyloo Group.

It is a 5-12 km thick, low-metamorphic grade metasedimentary sequence consisting of (Was) sandstones (psammites) and (Wam) mudstone (pelites), with minor intervals of mafic and felsic volcanics, conglomerate, chert and iron-formation.
Banded-iron formations occur as thin beds (0.01 to 0.5 m thick) and are estimated to represent <1% of the entire Formation.
The Capricorn Formation (R) is an 800m thick sequence of metasedimentary rocks which unconformably overlies the Wyloo Group.
The Project area is extensively covered by colluvial and alluvial deposits particularly along the outflow of the Seven Mile and Turee Creek systems.
Tertiary age deposits of silcrete, calcrete and laterite are also found throughout the Project area.
Polaris constructed GIS datasets of the Ochre rock chip sampling and obtained public domain aeromagnetic, geology, and mineral occurrence data in MapInfo format.

Spatial analysis revealed possible palaeodrainages originating from the Brockman Iron Formation to the north along weak linear magnetic features associated with Turee Creek (E08/1511-I and E08/1513-I) and Seven Mile Creek (E08/1512-I).
A NW-SE trending linear magnetic low zone bifurcating E08/1511-I corresponds to an outcropping Late Proterozoic dolerite dyke mapped by the GSWA to the west of E45/1511I.

The fault bounded NW-SE trending Capricorn Formation on the southeast boundary of E08/1511-I appears to have been a physical barrier affecting Cainozoic and Quaternary deposition in the southward flowing fluvial systems.
Evidence of sediment accumulation north of the Capricorn Formation in Turee Creek is provided by development of large aerial dispersed Cainozoic alluvium gravel bars over E08/1511-I.

The interpretation for the dolerite dyke and Capricorn Formation to provide trapping mechanisms developing coarse ferruginous gravel bars and pisolite deposits have defined the exploration focus on E08/1511-I.
On E08/1513-I the linear nature of the Cainozoic alluvium bars and apparent development origin suggests secondary ferruginous detritus being derived from the Capricorn Formation.

The weaker magnetic linear and small fragmented zones of Cainozoic alluvium suggest there is no obvious physical barrier except in the northeast sector where wider Cainozoic alluvial and colluvium bars are banked up against outcropping Ashburton Formation.

The potential for four different styles of iron mineralisation which were considered for the partial surrendered areas: Detrital Iron Deposits (DID): (eg Brockman 2 detritals) refers to partial- to un-consolidated haematite gravels (mature detritals) that are deposited as colluvial scree adjacent to iron formation escarpments (McKenna and Harmsworth, 1998).
As the Ashburton Project area lies more than 7 km from the nearest mineralised BIF escarpment (Paraburdoo Range), the formation of this style of mineralisation is considered highly unlikely.
Channel Iron Deposits (CID): (eg Robe Pisolite) refers to a detrital iron ore consisting of small haematite/goethite ooids cemented within a goethite matrix (Ramanaidou et al, 2003).
They are generally considered to have formed during the Tertiary within the channels of ancient river systems.
Numerous occurrences of CID are found within the Pilbara/Hamersley/Ashburton geological province, and do not require close proximity to a BIF.
The nearest outcrop of CID is mapped by the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) approximately 15 km north of the Ashburton Project, on the eastern flank of Bellary Creek.
There is potential for concealed CID mineralisation associated with the drainage systems within the Ashburton Project tenements.
Alluvial deposits: Past work by Ochre aimed at upgrading the laterally extensive alluvial outwash deposits located within the Seven Mile/Bellary and Turee Creek systems (Prodemas, 2007; Rafty, 2007).
A number of areas within the project area have the A number of thickened alluvial iron gravel deposits have been defined within the project area (Figure 6a and 6b).
However, the surrendered areas have only very limited chance of containing alluvial deposits of economic significance.
BIF derived ore: The Ashburton Project area does not contain any BIF of the Hamersley Group.
Thin, local BIF units were deposited in the Ashburton Formation.
A small haematite occurrence is noted within a thin BIF near the base of the Ashburton Formation on the Wyloo 1:250,000 sheet by the GSWA (Thorne and Seymour, 1991 p122).
This occurs in a similar stratigraphic position to rocks within the Ashburton Project.
It is unlikely that a thin Ashburton Formation BIF band will contain a sufficient volume of material/tonnage to form a stand-alone magnetite project.

Alluvial deposits: Past work by Ochre Resources / Heron Resources aimed at upgrading the laterally extensive alluvial outwash deposits located within the Seven Mile / Bellary and Turee Creek systems (Prodemas, 2007; Rafty, 2007).

In additional to the alluvial iron gravel targets identified within the Seven Mile and Turee Creek drainage systems, the following target areas for basement mineralisation were defined (Figure 7): 1.
Ashburton BIFs (Fe): a series of higher amplitude magnetic anomalies at the base of the Ashburton Formation may be due to BIF layers.
There is potential for these to host DSO haematite mineralisation, however any potential resource of this type will be small.

Mt Elephant North, Green Elephant (CuAu): these prospects are defined by the piecemeal soil and rock chip geochemical surveys completed by Intension, with peak assay values grading up to 10.24% Cu and 2.17 g/t Au.
These prospects appear to be associated with the northeast trending faults, and there is potential for repetition of similar mineralisation in parallel structures.

In additional to the detrital and channel iron targets identified within the Seven Mile and Turee Creek drainage systems, the following target areas for basement mineralisation are proposed (refer Figure 3): 9 Mt Elephant (Fe, Cu) A 500m long, 5m wide gossan near the contact between the Ashburton Formation and Capricorn Formation is host to the known copper mineralisation at this prospect.
The magnetic data suggest possible extension of this trend to the west and east.

In addition to the copper mineralisation, this trend may also be a realistic target for DSO hematite ore. Mt Elephant North, Green Elephant (CuAu) these prospects are defined by the piecemeal soil and rock chip geochemical surveys completed by Intension, with peak assay values grading up to 10.24% Cu and 2.17 g/t Au.
These prospects appear to be associated with the NE trending faults, and there is potential for repetition of similar mineralisation in parallel structures.
Ashburton BIFs (Fe) a series of higher amplitude magnetic anomalies at the base of the Ashburton Formation may be due to BIF layers.
There is potential for these to host DSO hematite mineralisation, however any potential resource of this type will be small.

DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS The Ashburton Project was acquired by Polaris for its iron ore potential, specifically to explore for concealed detrital (alluvial hematite sourced from the Paraburdoo Ranges) or channel iron deposits.
The exploration work completed to date has failed to successfully explore for either of these deposit types.
Ochre Resources / Polaris has focussed largely on evaluating the abundant alluvial material for potential upgrade to an iron concentrate.

However several limitations in this assessment are noted; The limited sampling completed so far is clustered and it does not appear that any attempt has been made to collect a sample representative of the full width of the alluvial channels.
Furthermore, descriptions of many of the rock chips samples collected by Ochre suggest many of these were taken (as lag?)
from gossans or hematitic basement shales, and hence possibly do not represent alluvial material at all.

There is no evidence to support an average thickness of 5m or density of 2 t/m3 for the alluvial material mapped by the GSWA to yield the total potential tonnage of one billion tonnes estimated by Prodemas (2007).
It is considered unlikely that a detrital scree deposit of any substantial size will be preserved so far from the source (Paraburdoo Ranges).

However, there is reasonable potential for a channel iron deposit to be present within the tenement area, concealed beneath a thin layer of alluvium or calcrete within either the Seven Mile or Turee Creek systems.
While likely to only yield small tonnages, the potential for thin BIF units within the Ashburton and Capricorn Formations to produce a DSO hematite resource should be further investigated.
The largest reported of these (coinciding with a weak-moderate magnetic anomaly) is the 5-10m thick gossan hosting the Mt Elephant Cu mineralisation (E08/1511, E08/1513).
Several moderate amplitude magnetic trends near the lower contact of the Ashburton Formation with the Duck Creek Dolomite (E08/1512) may also represent a reasonable BIF host.
Past exploration in the Mt Elephant area has indicated widespread copper and gold anomalism occurs in this area.

While this may be attributed to a number of small shear / fault hosted lode occurrences of sub-economic size and grade, further review and possible investigation of these deposit types is considered warranted.
This could be conducted at the same time as evaluation of the gossans for their DSO hematite potential.

RECOMMENDATIONS The following recommendations are made: 1) Helicopter EM survey A helicopter EM survey is recommended for the Ashburton project to help map the thickness of alluvial material and target for concealed channel iron deposits (expected CID response is shallow resistor within conductive alluvium).
Of the current HEM systems in the market, the SkyTEM system operated by Geoforce (of Perth) is recommended as it offers the shallowest sampling / mapping capability.
A 500m line spacing should be adequate to screen the Project areas for any CIDs of substantial size.
An indicative survey cost for the four tenements is estimated to be around $260,000.
2) Channel / drill sampling of alluvial material Representative bulk sampling of the alluvial fan material by channel sampling or shallow drilling, as previously recommended by Rafty (2007).
This is required to validate the conceptual resource and feasibility of the mining and concentrating project proposed by Prodemas (2007).
Geochemical assay of both head grade and a coarse (+1mm sieve) fraction may give an early indication of the upgradability of the alluvial material.

3) Detailed magnetic survey - A detailed, low-level magnetic and radiometric survey is recommended to refine the interpretation of the Ashburton BIFs and the interpretation of possible structures prospective for Cu / Au mineralisation.
An indicative cost to fly the four tenements at a 100m line spacing and 25-30m flying height is around $140,000.
Images of the compiled geophysical data are shown in Figure 4.
The top panel shows an RGB composite (ternary) radiometric image from the radiometric data, where red is assigned to the potassium channel, green is thorium, and blue is uranium.
The areas of relatively high radiometric response (pale coloured areas) generally correspond with outcropping Ashburton Formation.
Duck Creek Dolomite is characterised by a subdued thorium response (dark green) while the Mt McGrath Formation is characterised by a moderately strong potassium response (red).
Within the project area, transported alluvial material generally forms a darkish coloured smear concealing the Ashburton Formation response.

Examination of the uranium channel data yields peak anomalies of approximately 5 ppm eU and can be generally be related to northeast trending lineaments, suggesting the uranium anomalies may be due to weak hydrothermal alteration.

While the Ashburton Formation is generally magnetically bland, it contains several small magnetic markers which are mapped as trend lines and probably reflect heavy mineral layers within the sediments.
Several narrow, moderate amplitude magnetic anomalies are interpreted as thin BIF units, although field checking is required to validate these.
Subtle magnetic markers are present at the top and base of the Mt McGrath Formation.
The main magnetic units observed to the northeast of the Ashburton Project area are due to BIFs within the Hamersley Group as well as the Cheela Springs Basalt.
The main gravity anomalies shown in Figure 4 are due to dense BIF layers within the Hamersley Group as well as the Cheela Springs Basalt.
A single point high is identified in the Mt Elephant area, which may reflect a station coincidently located on a dense BIF/gossan or bad data.
A basement solid geology interpretation using the available geophysical imagery along with the regional 1:250,000 geological mapping is shown in Figure 5.

A number of structural elements were also mapped, including a dominantly northeast trending fault set and several dolerite dykes interpreted from distinctive negative magnetic lineaments.

104 114 132 Page 2 3 LOCATION AND ACCESS The Mt Thirsty project area (Figure 2) is centred approximately 10km north-west of Norseman.
Access is via the unpaved Hyden-Norseman road.
Old grid lines, station tracks and four wheel drive tracks can be used for access within the tenements.

4 GEOLOGY The tenements predominantly overlie Archaean rocks of the Mt Kirk Formation, which comprises an 8km thick, approximately north-south striking sequence of metamorphosed peridotite, pyroxenite, sediments and mafic-acid volcanics.

The formation is bounded to the west by Archaean granites and to the east is juxtaposed by the Mission Fault against the underlying mafic volcanics with minor sediments of the Archaean Woolyeenyer Formation.
The sequence is interpreted to dip steeply to the east.
The Mt Kirk Formation is intruded by two major mafic-ultramafic differentiated sills, the Mt Thirsty Sill to the west and the Mission Sill to the east.
The Proterozoic Jimberlana Dyke, a 1km thick differentiated ultramafic-mafic intrusive truncates the Mt Kirk Formation within E63/654, and pegmatite dyke swarms occur locally.
Tertiary laterite and Quaternary colluvial deposits cover much of the area.
The Mission Sill is up to 2000 metres thick and forms a tightly folded, southerly plunging syncline.
E63/654 is located on the western limb of this syncline.
Cook (2000) refers to petrological work by Jack Hallberg that concludes that the sill is a composite body formed from 2 separate pulses of intrusion.
Hallbergs stratigraphic sequence from the base of the sill is thin peridotite, overlain by altered pyroxenite, then a repeat of this sequence grading up into norite and gabbro.
Outcrop is relatively sparse, and the area is covered by alluvium and colluvium derived from the erosion of the ferricrete duricrust, or lag derived from ultramafic rocks.
This cover is generally less than 3 m thick in the east and gradually thickens westwards.
5 PREVIOUS WORK The Mt Kirk Formation has been explored for gold and base metals, notably copper-nickel sulphides, from the late 1960s to the present.
Between 1966 and 1972, WMC and Central Norseman Gold explored the Jimberlana Dyke and its surrounding areas south of Mt Thirsty for nickel, copper, platinum and chrome.
Copper-PGE mineralisation was found at the Spinifex East prospect, but no economic mineralisation was found on E63/654.
Between 1968 and1974, Barrier Exploration and Jimberlana Minerals undertook a program of Induced Polarisation (IP) and ground magnetic surveys, soil and auger sampling and diamond drilling.

A number of IP anomalies were defined, and two diamond holes were drilled to test the coincident nickel-copper-IP anomalism.
Between 1993 and 1996, Resolute Ltd and Great Southern Mines NL and Dundas Mining Pty Ltd undertook regional gold exploration, using predominantly soil sampling techniques.
Several minor gold anomalies were identified on what is now E63/654, but these were not thought to be significant enough to warrant follow-up.
In late 2000, Anaconda Nickel Ltd (ANL) carried out shallow RC drilling over the Mission Sill ultramafic intrusion, targeting nickel laterite deposits in a joint venture with AGR.
However anomalous Au-Pt-Pd results were obtained, with a best result of 5.7 ppm combined Au-Pt-Pd over 2 metres.

AGR obtained and reprocessed the detailed aeromagnetic and radiometric data over the tenement area from the Kinross Gold, Abbotshall (Accession No: 60108), WGC, Yilgarn and Geoscience Australia, Norseman surveys.
Geochemical data collected by Resolute Mining Ltd and over the area covered by E63/654 was obtained from DOIR Open File reports and re-processed.
Soil sampling in the period 2003 to 2005 focussed on the Mission Sill.
The best soil sample results were returned from line 6436557mN, where a 175 metre wide zone of precious metal was detected.
This location is coincident with a discrete copper in soil and IP anomaly identified by Barrier Exploration and Jimberlana Minerals.
RC drilling by PlatX in 2004 confirmed the shallow PGE anomalism known from the ANL drilling, with a best result of 1m at 2.04 g/t combined Pd and Pt in MTRC38 (at the surface).
Fresh rock mineralisation was intersected on both traverses, close to the eastern margin of the Mission Sill.
In holes MTRC36 and MTRC 42, PGE anomalism is coincident with Cu, and trace amounts of chalcopyrite were recognised in the drill chips.
Petrographic studies on 15 samples of RC chips suggest that the mineralisation is hosted by sulphide alteration that overprints the original ultramafic lithology.
Revealed textures were also indicative of primary magmatic sulphide, similar to textures within the Munni Munni Sill.
PGE minerals were not identified.

In 2006, a further nine RC holes were drilled for a total of 1,487 metres over the Mission Sill to identify the fresh bedrock source of coincident Au-Cu-PGE and IP anomalism encountered through previous geophysical surveys, soil sampling and RC drilling intercepts.
Results were reported in 2006, although they were not received until after the reporting anniversary.
Significant results are shown below (Table 2).
The best results were obtained from MTRC55 on the previously drilled section 6436160N, where mineralisation generally appears restricted to the oxide zone.

latitude S. In all 65 rock samples were collected, of which 14 were selected for petrological studies, and 4 were sent to be subjected to a multi-element geochemical scan (Table 3).
At the time of writing this report, the results are still awaited and the geological map is to be finalised on receipt of formal rock identifications.

It appears that the sill is made up of a succession of layers from a microgabbro to the east overlain by medium grained pyroxenites, followed by a fine grained peridotite which passes onto a fine grained dolerite (Figure 3).
The western part of the area mapped is underlain by a younger leucocratic granite which has intruded into the sill.
All the sills units are cut by pegmatite, aplite and quartz dykes.
PlatX Limited Mt Thirsty 2007 A.C.N.
104 114 132 Page 5 The sills layers trend NE-SW with a shallow dip to the NW.
In the NW corner of the area mapped, an outcrop of fine grained gabbro in enclave within the granite could be equivalent of the lower microgabbro layer or represent part of another intrusive cycle.
The formations plunge to the SW and disappear under soil cover.
The pyroxenite layers of the Mission Sill and particularly the lower part of them seem to be the most likely host for PGE mineralization.
The structural interpretation based on earlier drilling results and mapping postulate a rather flat lying disposition of the various layers in the sill.
The next drilling phase should verify this interpretation and target the pyroxenites at the contact zone with the microgabbro.

104 114 132 Page 6 hydrothermal events could have concentrated sulphides, gold and PGE in structural traps or at chemical barriers.

The Company has identified the on-shore section of the Gascoyne Platform in the South Carnarvon Basin as the most prospective part of the Carnarvon Basin for potash mineralisation.
The Gascoyne Platform is a diamond shaped area that covers about 86,000km 2 and contains up to 5,000m of sediments.
It is located approximately 600km to 1200km north of Perth.
Parts of the adjacent Coolcalalaya Rift are also deemed to be prospective for potash mineralisation and have been included in the Gascoyne Project.
The tenement area was chosen on the basis of interpreted seismic data indicating areas that are possible hosts for evaporite deposits.
TENURE (Figure 1) E9/1155 was granted on 3 April 2006 in the name of Tyson Resources Pty Ltd.
The tenement consists of 70 graticular blocks.
The tenement was acquired by Reward Minerals in November 2005.
The area was selected on the basis that brine rich fluids flowed from the west , slowly evaporating and enriching in salts.
It is postulated that that enriched brines collected at the western side of the fault zone, evaporating to dryness with the potash settling out last.

Mineral Drillholes data C:\yaringa\E9_1155_Annual_08.docx SUMMARY A search for potash mineralisation within evaporite basins in Australia resulted in a detailed geological study of the South Carnarvon Basin being initiated.
Several suitable target areas were identified with the areas applied for as Exploration Licences.
This report details the work completed on one of these target areas, E9/1155, during its second year.
The project area is located approximately 100 km east north east of the Overlander Roadhouse in the Gascoyne Mineral Field.
Access is via station and oilrig access tracks leading off from the main gravel road from the Overlander Roadhouse to Byro Station.
GEOLOGY The Gascoyne project area contains a sequence of Ordovician to Permian sediments that overlie Precambrian basement rocks.
The main target is the Yaringa Member of the 750mthick, Dirk Hartog Formation of Silurian age.
The features of this formation are known from seven exploration wells in the immediate area (Figure 4).
The 100m-thick Yaringa Member is composed of dolostone, halite and anhydrite beds.
Typically, halite beds are less than 10m thick but such beds occur in sequences aggregating 40m in thickness.
Bromine levels in the halite are high (up to 330ppm), suggesting precipitation from highly concentrated halite- and bittern-field brines.
Traces of sylvite (KCl) were reported in the Yaringa No 1 well.
A recent detailed analysis of drilling, seismic, gravity and other geological data has resulted in the identification of several areas that are prospective for potash mineralisation.

The selection criteria for the targets include local thickening of the target Dirk Hartog Formation (Figure 2) at basin edges and locations in the distal parts of the basin where high-order evaporite brines were generated and salts precipitated.

Figure 2 is a schematic diagram illustrating the features and genesis of the Woolarry prospects where thick sections of the evaporite-formation target are indicated by geophysical and stratigraphic data.
These deposits are a basinal facies in a rift environment linked to the distal parts of the Silurian basin.
Palaeogeographic reconstructions suggest that this rift was separated from the main basin by a shallow channel.
There is a high probability that any highorder evaporite brines generated in the main basin could have decanted into the deeper rift basin and further evaporated thus precipitating potash-rich salts.
Historical Exploration Previous exploration work carried out over the Randall Hills tenements was conducted by Mt Martin Gold Mines from 1987 to 1998.
Exploration conducted on E25/29 included soil sampling and RAB drilling.
Regional soil sampling delineated 15 anomalous areas with Au values > 30 ppb Au.
Extensive follow-up RAB and some RC drilling (outside E25/212) were completed.
At the Slack anomaly, situated on E25/212, five RAB holes (SB1-5) for 292 metres were drilled.
The exploration work included considerable RAB drilling which was completed in 1994 / 1995 with 130 RAB holes for 2033 metres on E25/98 testing the Slack anomaly.
The Lady Eileen workings were briefly mapped and sampled in 1987 on behalf of the then tenement holder [Wamex item 3775].

Previous Exploration Randall Hills Project Westex Resources Limited carried out exploration on E25/212 prior to the Option agreement with Integra Mining, included metal detecting and loaming in the first two years of tenure and a study of previous exploration.
Work conducted by Integra during the 2005/2006 reporting period on E25/212, E25/300 and P25/1808 included sourcing and compilation of all previous exploration data.
Data sources included WAMEX Open File Data, Hampton Hill Mining (previous holders of tenement E25/98), Mount Monger Gold and Solomon Australia databases.
A significant amount of data was located for these tenements, and a detailed review was undertaken and remains in progress.
This report details exploration carried out on Randall Hills Project tenements E25/212, E25/300 and P25/1808 during the reporting period 20th December 2006 to 19th December 2007.
The Randall Hills tenements are explored by Integra Mining Limited under an option agreement with Westex Resources Limited, the current registered holder.
The Randall Hill project is located approximately 70 kilometres east southeast of Kalgoorlie, in the Bulong District of the East Coolgardie Mineral Field (Figure 1).
The project is situated on the Mt Monger and Cowarna Downs Stations and partially falls within the Randalls Timber Reserve.
Access to the tenements is provided either via the Trans Australia Railway access road or via the Mt Monger Road and then on station tracks.
The project area is considered prospective for high-grade gold mineralisation and Kambalda-style nickel sulphide mineralisation.
Work carried out by Integra Mining Limited during the work period included an RC drilling program and planning of regional soil sampling.
The exploration index plan is presented in Figure 2.

The tenements lie predominately within the Juglah Domain which is located in the southeast of the Gindalbie Terrane.
The Juglah Domain lies on the eastern limb of the upright, regional Bulong Anticline.
The tenements lie to the west of the Randall Fault zone, which forms the boundary between the Mt.
Belches Formation and the Gindalbie Terrane to the west.

The geology consists of a sequence of tholeiitic and high-Mg basalts interlayered with minor komatiite units and differentiated mafic-ultramafic intrusives that have been thrust over younger felsic volcanic and volcaniclastic rocks with ultramafic schist lenses in the south.
The mafic unit can be traced southwards around the anticline to Mount Monger.
At Mount Monger the mafic unit comprises high-Mg basalt characterised by pyroxenespinifex textures on various scales and several major ultramafic-mafic lenses, interpreted as intrusive sills.

Generally as the mafic unit is traced northwards it becomes thinner and contains progressively less ultramafic rocks and shows a change in basalt composition from high-Mg (pyroxene spinifex) to more tholeiitic (feldspar-phyric).
The eastern limb of the Bulong Anticline is relatively poorly endowed with gold mineralisation in comparison to the western limb.
The Goddard Fault, a folded D1 thrust, is recognised as an important control on the mineralisation on the southern part of the western limb (Roberts, 2004).
This structure has not been identified on the eastern limb and is either wedged out or otherwise unrecognised on the eastern limb.
Gold mineralisation in the Mt.
Belches Formation is mainly associated with tight D2 fold closures within the BIF units.

However mineralisation is believed to post-date D2 folding and on a local scale is influenced by the position of offsetting oblique faulting that has juxtaposed BIF against the enclosing thick, less competent psammite.
The gold mineralisation is a late event (syn - post D4) related to the formation of shallowly southdipping arrays of extensional quartz veining preferentially in the competent BIF units (Newton et.

An RC drilling program was conducted by Kennedy Drilling on tenement E25/300 during the current reporting period to test the continuity and geometry of the gold mineralisation encountered in RAB drilling during the previous work year in the vicinity of the Lady Eileen Prospect.
The Lady Eileen workings are located in an amphitheatre of outcropping basalt (Hawk Hill) and eroded duricrust.
Pits and shafts have been developed on narrow lenticular quartz reefs in the outcrop areas around Lady Eileen.
Individual quartz veins attain a maximum width of 0.5m and have a consistent westerly dip and northwest strike.
The main workings extend over a strike length of 200m and have been developed on a massive laminated quartz reef which attains a maximum width of only 30cm but has been stoped out to 75 cm.
The quartz reef dips at 75o to the west and thins to a narrow stringer to the north.
Pits and shafts to the south have only minor quartz evident.
During December 2006 Integra undertook a RAB programme in the vicinity of the historic workings and returned a peak Au assay in LER004 of 19.35g/t.

It was considered that this mineralization may represent a different mineralized lode system as it occurs in weathered volcani-clastic material offset from the line of workings which are in a north trending quartz-filled shear.
Three holes were planned to test the down dip and down plunge components of the LER004 intersection and the forth hole was drilled to test beneath the line of historic workings.
The drill hole locations are presented in Figure 5 and the drill hole data, including the collar locations, surveys, lithology and assays are included in the digital appendix.
A total of 80, four metre composite samples were submitted to Genalysis Laboratories for the analysis of Au, As, Cr, Cu and Ni.
Gold analysis was by aqua-regia digest with solvent extraction and a graphite furnace atomic absorption spectrometry finish.
The multi-elements were analysed by aqua-regia digest and an optical emission spectrometry finish.
The drill location planning was heavily influenced by the need to avoid stands of dense vegetation and some steep topography in the local area resulting in less than ideal drilling coverage.
From the drilling it was concluded that the host lithology is an ultramafic, which appears to be proximal to a dolerite contact.
Only two significant gold intercepts were returned but did not match the tenor of the previous RAB intercept (Table 3).

No historical soil sampling has been located in the review of previous exploration within the planned soil program area.
Previous soil sampling in other areas over the tenement was assayed for Au only.
The samples in the proposed program will be analysed for Ni and associated elements.
The soil sampling program has been designed to evaluate the nickel and gold potential of the western half of the Randall Hills Project.
In particular areas underlain by ultramafic units and the conductors identified by the TEM survey conducted in the previous reporting period are being targeted.
It is anticipated that the soil sampling program will be conducted in early 2008.

The Randall Hills Project includes two granted exploration licences, namely E25/212 and E25/300 and one granted prospecting licence, P25/1808.
Details of the tenements included in the Randall Hills Project combined report are given in Table 2, below and in Figure 3.
The tenements are explored by Integra Mining Limited under an option agreement with Westex Resources Limited, the current registered holder.
TENEMENT PLAN 3.

At the Transfield Mining Centre the major part of the historical production is from the Transville workings with gold mineralisation in and along quartz veins within the felsic epiclastic metasediments.

The Curtin prospect and older workings to the north of Transville show gold mineralisation within variably porphyritic biotite monzogranite in and along north northeast trending pyritic shear zones with quartz veins.
The Juglah workings also follow quartz veins of similar strike in felsic volcanics volcanoclastics, but recorded production is very low (Walters, 2006).
The Lady Eileen workings are a series of shallow historic gold workings and are situated in eastern portion of E25/300.
They are described in GSWA Bulletin 56 (1914) as three shafts and a big costean.
Two of the shafts and the costean are in a massive porphyry and the other shaft in schists sunk on a ferruginous shear zone.
Gold production before 1912 amounted to about 3,000 ounces.

Drilling was undertaken to test for ultramafic lithologies identified by GSWA mapping and in historic drilling.
Results received for this drilling were encouraging, with anomalous Ni results being recorded and an ultramafic sequence being identified.
This ultramafic sequence was interpreted to be equivalent to the ultramafics which host Kambalda-style nickel mineralisation elsewhere in the Bulong anticline, such as at Blair and Carnilya Hill.
The anomalous Ni values are associated with talc schist and chlorite schist representing metamorphosed and sheared mafic and ultramafic volcanic rocks.
Some spinifex textures were noted in the talc chorite rock.
The maximum gold value reported from the drilling program was 4m @ 0.25ppm Au from 44m in hole RHR007.

During the 2006/2007 reporting period exploration conducted by Integra for nickel included a Moving Loop TEM survey (35.1 line km) over the full extent of the interpreted ultramafic sequence at the Randall Hills project, a fixed Loop TEM survey (12.35 line km) at three areas and two petrographic thin section examinations from the previous years drilling.
The result from the Moving Loop TEM surveys identified several EM conductors, three of which were considered prospective for further evaluation.
A fixed Loop Survey was conducted over each of the three prospective EM conductors.
Exploration for gold comprised RAB drilling of 21 holes for a total of 806 metres, mainly near the historic gold workings at Lady Eileen.
Best results at Lady Eileen include 4m at 7.37 g/t gold from 6m, including 1m at 19.35g/t gold in drill hole LER004.
The Randall Hills tenements are located on the Widgiemooltha and Kurnalpi 1:250,000 GSWA map sheet and on the Mount Belches and Kurnalpi 1:100 000 GSWA geology sheet.
The Randall Hills tenements are located in the Eastern Goldfields Province of the Yilgarn Craton.
The Eastern Goldfields Province comprises a series of attenuated Archaean greenstone belts intruded by, and interstitial to, similarly elongate granitoid plutons and gneisses.

The regional stratigraphy of the Randall Hills Project comprises a sequence of felsic volcanic and volcaniclastic rocks, with minor banded iron formation occurring within the upper portion of the volcaniclastic sequence (Jones and Hall, 2004), overlying an upper komatiitic basalt unit and a lower basaltic unit, that are separated by an intervening komatiite unit.
The komatiite unit is interpreted as a regional marker that extends across the Eastern Goldfields.
The supracrustal sequence was deposited between 2710 and 2705 Ma.
The tenements are located predominantly within the Archaean Gindalbie Terrane.
The Gindalbie Terrane is bounded on its eastern margin by the shallow west-dipping, deep crustal Randall Shear and Mount Belches Formation (Figure 4).
Belches Formation is a thick sequence of deep water submarine fan, flysh facies and turbidites, comprised of graded feldspathic sandstone and laminated siltstone and minor BIF.
Belches Formation contains the Randalls gold camp, a series of deposits that occur within folded quartz-magnetite-amphibole BIF units.
Economic mineralisation is localised at anticlinal fold closures within the BIF (Newton et.
This report details exploration carried out on Randall Hills Project tenements E25/212, E25/300 and P25/1808 during the reporting period 20th December 2006 to 19th December 2007.
The Randall Hills tenements are explored by Integra Mining Limited under an option agreement with Westex Resources Limited, the current registered holder.
The Randall Hills project is located approximately 70 kilometres east southeast of Kalgoorlie, on the Mt Monger and Cowarna Downs Stations (Figure 1).
The project lies predominately within the Juglah Domain which is located in the southeast of the Gindalbie Terrane.
The Juglah Domain lies on the eastern limb of the upright, regional Bulong Anticline.
The project area is considered prospective for highgrade gold mineralisation and Kambalda-style nickel sulphide mineralisation.
Work carried out by Integra Mining Limited during the work period included an RC drilling program and planning of regional soil sampling.
The exploration index plan is presented in Figure 2.
This report details all of the exploration activities undertaken within the Munro Bore project during the period ending 30th January 2009.

The tenement (M 51/338) that makes up this project, is currently held by Wanbanna Pty Ltd, and is located approximately 20 kilometres east of the Reedy Mining Centre and 70 kilometres north-east of Cue township, in the Murchison district of Western Australia.
Numerous disused haul roads and station tracks access the area, which is entirely within the Cullculli Pastoral Lease.

GEOLOGY 3.1 Regional Geology The project is located at the eastern edge of the Reedy Mining area, within the MeekatharraMt Magnet Greenstone Belt.
The belt has produced several multi-million ounce deposits and is highly prospective.
Gold production has recently commenced in the Burnakurra area (NOA deposits) within 5 kilometres of M 51/338.

3.2 Project Geology Munro Bore covers part of a poorly exposed Archaean greenstone sequence comprising acid to intermediate volcanics, volcaniclastic sediments and mafic intrusions and extrusions, with intercalated BIF and chert (also referred to as exhalites).
The sequence strikes in a north-east direction and is folded about north-east trending axes.
A set of north-east trending structures subsidiary to the crustal Meekatharra-Mt Magnet shear zone exists adjacent to the tenements.
Numerous historic gold workings manifest as both shafts and dry-blown plains.
3.3 Geomorphology The Munro Bore area geomorphology is typical of the Murchison District and mature, Archaean Terranes.
Deep weathering and erosional processed have stripped the profile producing a relatively flat topography with dendritic creek bed patterns.
Resistant quartz and ironstone float is common on the surface and outcrop is generally poor.
Open vegetation comprising various low level Acacia mulga shrubland and salt bush species dominates the area,

Various companies have held the ground covered by Munro Bore during the last thirty years, amounting to comprehensive systematic surface exploration but limited systematic subsurface exploration for both gold and base metals.
Samin Ltd/BP Joint Venture carried out geological mapping and RAB sampling in the main prospective zone during the 1970s.
They followed this work up with six RC holes.
During the 1980s, Poseidon completed mapping and costeaning, and drilled eleven RC holes.
Samantha did further mapping and grab sampling, drilled two diamond holes and three RC holes.

Central Victoria Gold Mines carried out shallow RAB bedrock sampling on a 100 x 20m grid over a shear zone on the western boundary, Giralia took over the lease during the 1990s, beginning with 40m deep RAB holes on eight lines, but then entered into a joint venture with Gold Mines of Australia ("GMA"), who continued with exploration of the tenement.
GMA continued a multi-element soil sampling program, air photo interpretation, mapping and rock chip sampling.

A 460ppb soil anomaly on the south-eastern corner was RAB drilled but did not return significant results (James, 1996b), however the profile intersected was deeply weathered and it is questionable if the anomaly was adequately tested.
RC drilling was carried out in 1997 focussing on the area south of the Munro Bore workings.
Previous exploration by MRA began in 2000 and is detailed by Nunn (2000) and Nunn (2001).
A summary of that work is presented in Table 2.

After the MRA withdrew from the JV agreement Giralia continued exploration at several targets with gold resource potential, particularly at Munro Bore North, an area of previous RC drilling where intersections include 12 metres @ 4.74 g/t gold, 24 metres @ 2.1 g/t gold and 10 metres @ 5.98 g/t gold.
At the Munro Bore Workings, an area of significant historical pits and open stopes has returned intersections including 2 metres @ 8.8 g/t gold and 20 metres @ 2.4 g/t gold.

At the Central Zone, 2002 intersections included 37 metres @ 2.09 g/t gold and 12 metres @ 1.12 g/t gold, whilst at the Southern prospect, 3 consecutive 100 metre spaced RAB lines returned anomalous intersections, including 16 metres @ 0.93 g/t gold and 5 metres @ 1.5 g/t.
Two phases of RC and aircore drilling were completed by Giralia in early October 2003 and March 2004 (total 30 holes for 1667 metres).
Significant intersections are shown in the tables below.
Coordinate datum is AGD 84.
The October 2003 drilling comprised 4 aircore holes for 270 metres and 9 RC holes for 569 metres.
Drilling was completed by Drillwest, with aircore samples collected as 4 metre grab composites, whilst RC holes were composite sampled with anomalous composites riffle split in one metre intervals.
Assays were by 50g fire assay at ALS Perth.
The drilling tested targets in all four prospective areas at Munro Bore; North, Workings, Central and Southern.
Intersections are shown in the table below.

The result from hole RCMB005 (18 metres @ 1.42 g/t gold including 6 metres @ 2.77 g/t gold from 18 metres) is significant in that it demonstrates the presence of a second parallel zone of gold mineralisation at the North prospect, whilst RCMB003 (8metres@ 1.68 g/t gold) confirms a western extension to the main North zone of mineralisation.

Aircore hole RAMB006 (18 metres @ 2.86 g/t gold from 28 metres) tested the Southern prospect, a 100 metre wide zone of supergene gold anomalism defined by previous RAB drilling in a zone of silicified, quartz veined, fuchsite altered felsic schists.
1 metre riffle split sampling, analysis by 50g fire assay Follow up RC drilling (17 RC holes for 828 metres) was completed in late March 2004 at the North and Southern zones.
Drilling contractor was again Drillwest.
Samples were collected each metre through a cyclone and riffle split.
Assaying was as above.
Intersections from Southern include 28 metres @ 6.71 g/t gold from 2 metres depth (includes 1 metre @ 148 g/t gold) and 13 metres @ 1.48 g/t gold from 22 metres depth.
These holes, along with the October 2003 intersection from the Southern prospect (18 metres @ 2.86 g/t gold), define an open-ended 150 metre long mineralised zone with clear resource potential.
This zone remains untested below 50 metres depth.
The potential for shallow oxide gold resources at the North, and Southern prospects at Munro Bore was substantially upgraded by work during 2004-2005.
An initial resource definition drilling program was carried out at the Munro South prospect.
This 12 hole phase of drilling also tested extensions of the known mineralisation.
Significant intercepts for this program are listed in full below.
Mineralisation at both Munro North and South is thought to be a stockwork vein system hosted within a felsic volcanic sequence.
The area is strongly weathered to depths of approximately 50 to 60 vertical metres.
Vein orientations are poorly understood.
Thus a broad moderate to low grade mineralised envelope was used to constrain the block models.
Estimates were carried out using Micromine software.
All data was validated and composited to standard 1-metre intervals, wireframes were then constructed to encompass the total mineralised envelope at both prospects.
Subsequently the wireframes were Block modelled and grade interpolated using ellipsoidal 2D Inverse Distance Wighting (ID2).
A default SG of 2.4 is used throughout (Mineralised package is stockwork quartz system within clays).
Both deposits were block modelled to approximately 70 metres below surface, with an estimated depth of weathering to approximately 50-60 metres.
Tables for the resource estimates are shown in Table 7 showing data with and without high grade cuts applied.

This report summarises tantalum exploration activity by Sons of Gwalia Ltd on the Pilgangoora Project exploration license E45/2308 for the period 14 February 2006 to 13 February 2007.

Twenty mostly very small chips 3mm to 15mm of iron-ore from the Lalla Rookh Trend were sent to Ian Pontifex in January 2008, for petrographic/mineragraphic description and particularly to check for the possible presence of asbestos minerals.
Samples were dominantly from Trigg, with some from Mullaloo prospect.
A report was received back on the 18th March and included photomicrographs and XRD descriptions.
Figure 8 below is an example of the detail of the accretionary textures seen in botryoidal goethite.

Initial macroscopic assessment indicated that approximately half of these samples are dominated by goethite-limonite, some plus apparent hematite, with perhaps another half composed of ferruginised cherty silica.

The extensive opaque component means that information from transmitted light microscopy (thin section) would be limited (including any recognition of asbestos minerals, which would be largely camouflaged by the opaque oxide).

Analytical procedures to provide the required information was therefore considered to be by polished-section mineragraphic assessment of minerals (as far as possible with such goethitic-limonitic material), also study of textures with an attempt to offer comment on genesis, together with photomicrographs.
Secondly, for XRD to perhaps more specifically identify the iron oxide minerals, and any other mineralogy, and also to check for any asbestos minerals.
It is noted that asbestiform minerals were not identified in any sample.
As indicated above, the samples examined in polished section are mostly very small and variously dominated by supergene goethite with corresponding supergene textures, or 23 dominated by chert.

Most samples do not have diagnostic in-situ pre-existing primary textures, (except for some microlayering) however pre-existing magnetite/martite BIF was identified in 3 samples, ABRC-63, 76-77m (possible); ABRC088, 79-80m and 089, 25-26m.

Considering all of the above, especially the small size, genetic interpretations offered in the descriptions are somewhat limited and difficult to always distinguish for example between possible oxidised, unmetamorphosed BIF, channel iron deposit material, or possible detrital colluvial/alluvial material.

The resource estimate is detailed below.

AAMHatch was commissioned to capture aerial photography over an area of approximately 20 km2 over the Lalla Rookh Trend at a scale of 1:10 000 in late 2007.
From this photography AAMHatch derived topographical mapping, including digital terrain model and 1m contours.
In addition orthorectified aerial imagery was produced with a pixel resolution of 0.15m.
The expected vertical accuracy of the DTM data will be +/-0.2m on clear open ground (1 sigma).
This job was flown using a direct airborne georeferencing device which enables the accuracy of the job to be maintained without the need for a large number of ground control targets.
Approximately 5 targets per site were need to be surveyed in prior to the capture of photography.
In addition a set of Check Points were required to be picked up over the project area and a GPS base station was required to be manned during the flight near the project area.
Photography and digital data acquired from AAMHatch has been used throughout the reporting period to assist in location and planning of exploration activities.
Location: The Abydos project is located 120 km south of Port Hedland, Western Australia.
Geology: The Abydos project comprises tenements covering a number of diverse geological domains.
The project area overlies the Wodgina, Abydos, Pincunah, East Strelley, and Soansville Greenstone Belts as well as the Lalla Rookh Basin.

Work Done: High resolution aerial photography flown, review of historic exploration, reconnaissance field visits, surface sampling, regional and prospect scale mapping, petrology, RC drilling, diamond drilling, resource estimation, scoping study, heritage surveys, native title discussions, rehabilitation.
The project area is located in the Pilbara region of Western Australia, approximately 70 km south of Port Hedland.
These activities included acquisition of high resolution digital photography and a review of historic exploration.
Two heritage surveys were conducted during the reporting period.
Initial misunderstandings over the type of surveys conducted were resolved and all surveys were conducted as line clearance surveys.
An initial resource estimation was announced for the Trigg Deposit of an inferred resource of 8570000 tonnes @ 57.3 % Fe.
Drill holes were rehabilitated however some holes were retained as fauna monitoring holes.
Further exploration is proposed for the tenements during the next reporting period and will include further rock chip sampling, geological mapping and interpretation, target generation and drilling.

67 077 165 532 Geological Consultants CSA Australia Pty Ltd SUMMARY CSA Australia (CSA) was commissioned by Atlas Iron Limited (Atlas) to carry out a Mineral Resource estimate for the Trigg Deposit, which is located 110 km south of Port Hedland, Western Australia.
CSA estimated a total iron Mineral Resource for Trigg as presented in Table 1.
The resource is quoted based upon blocks as stated in the Table 1.
Differences may occur due to rounding errors.

Refer to Figure 2 for a grade tonnage table for resource estimates at varying Fe% cut-off grades The CSA Mineral Resource estimate was completed according to the following criteria: The Trigg deposit is located in the East Pilbara Granite Greenstone Terrane, approximately 110km south southeast of Port Hedland, Western Australia.
The deposit forms part of the Abydos Project, within tenement E45/2362 (100% owned by Atlas).
The deposit is part of the Lalla Rookh Fe Trend, comprising Banded Iron Formations with localised hematite and goethite enrichment zones.
The mineralisation has a strike of 660m with a width varying between 60m and 100m.
The total depth has not been tested, with many holes terminating in iron mineralisation.
Drilling at the Trigg deposit consists of 26 RC holes, for a total of 1,737 metres, was drilled by Mt.
Twenty five of the holes are inclined at 60 degrees to the south.
Average spacing between drill sections is 80m, with a spacing of 40m along drill lines.
Section 718,520mE was not drilled leaving a 160m strike length with no drilling.
All samples taken were two metre composites, with 97% of the samples riffle split.
All samples were dry, with no water table intercepted during drilling.
Samples were sent to Ultra Trace assay laboratories in Perth for XRF analyses.
A QAQC programme was used to test sampling and assaying procedures.
Field duplicates were taken every 25th and 75th sample, with Fe%, SiO2%, Al2O3%, P %, S % and LOI % analytically tested.
Results indicate good correlation between the original and duplicate assays, indicating good accuracy with the sampling procedures.
A set of certified reference standards were inserted at regular intervals, testing the same grade variables as per the field duplicates.
The standards performed well within the nominated tolerance limits.
Drill collars were surveyed using a hand held GPS.
No down hole surveys were undertaken for any of the holes.
The limited depth of holes and the width of mineralisation suggests there will be minimal impact upon the volume of mineralisation if any hole deviation has occurred.
A 3D wireframe envelope was generated by Atlas representing greater than 50% Fe.
This wireframe and its associated cross-sectional strings were delivered to CSA.
Atlas also provided CSA with a validated drill database and a DTM of the topography.
CSA made minor adjustments to the mineralisation wireframe, to ensure all sample intervals were snapped to the wireframe envelope.
Samples within the drill hole dataset were flagged according to their location relative to the mineralisation solid.
The flagged drill hole dataset was composited down the hole to two metre intervals.
Statistical analyses from the mineralised population were documented for Fe, SiO2, Al2O3, P, S and LOI.
Variography was used to determine appropriate Kriging parameters and sample search ellipse dimensions and orientation.
Variograms were generated for Fe and P. Relative nuggets of 16% (Fe) and 6% (P) were calculated, demonstrating minimal variability at very short ranges.
Variogram ranges for Fe were 120m along strike, and 50m down dip.
It was acknowledged that the total sample population of 390 samples was insufficient to generate meaningful variograms.
The variogram directions were chosen according to the general geometry of the mineralised domain.
A volume block model was constructed in Datamine, using the mineralised envelope and topographic surface.
All blocks were coded according to their location relative to the mineralised envelope, using the same coding as used in the sample flagging and subsequent statistical analyses.
The block model contained parent block sizes of 40m x 20m x 5m (X x Y x Z) with sub cells down to 4m x 2m x 1m to better honour the geometric shapes.
Grade estimation was carried out using Ordinary Kriging.
Grades using Inverse Distance to the power of 2 was also estimated used as a cross check on the Kriged grades.
Grade was estimated into the parent block volumes.
A search ellipse of 120m by 60m by 60m, aligned along strike, was used in the estimation process.
Comparison of the block grades and 2m samples both showed similar mean grades for all grade variables except silica.
The mean model grade estimated for silica of 6.8% was higher than the mean sample silica grade at 6.2%.

Figure 1 compares the sample population with the model blocks; around 20% of the sample population has silica grades of sub 2%, however also has a long tail of high grade (+20%), during estimation the populations have been smoothed into the 2-6% silica grade ranges, thereby increasing the average grade for the silica model.
The low grade silica population may be better defined with increased drilling density, and appropriate modelling techniques used to reduce smoothing of estimated model silica grades.
A minimum number of 8 samples and a maximum of 24 samples were used to estimate the sample grades into each block.
The block estimates for P used variogram parameters derived from the phosphorus data; all other grade variables were estimated using the variogram parameters derived from the Fe population.
A bulk density of 3.2 t/m3 was applied to every block within the mineralised envelope.
This figure was provided by Atlas based on historical bulk densities for this ore type.
Table 2 presents the extents of the modelled resource.

Results from logging of drill chips recovered from nineteen holes drilled during March have significantly increased confidence on the extent and geometry of goethite and hematite mineralisation in the Trigg prospect.

At the western part of Trigg (718440mE & 718480mE) logging of drill chips showed that goethite and hematite mineralisation remains fairly consistent with pre-existing drilling both on section and along strike.
Shallow mineralisation occurs on the northern part of these sections and a flattish laying trend appears to reflect supergene mineralisation within a favorable host.
