The Abydos project comprises tenements covering a number of diverse geological domains.
The project area overlies the Wodgina, Abydos, Pincunah, East Strelley, and Soansville Greenstone Belts as well as the Lalla Rookh Basin.
Atlas Irons Abydos project has excellent potential to host both Channel Iron deposits (CID) and Bedded Iron Deposits (BID).
Extensions of known CID deposits occur within the Abydos Project (ie.
The Cinnamon Creek, Pincunah North, Pincunah South, and Lalla Rookh CID deposits held by BHPB).
Both the Strelley 1and Strelley 2 CID deposits occur wholly within the Abydos Project.
The main targets for bedded iron mineralization within the Abydos Project are banded iron formations (regionally correlated with the Cleaverville Iron Formation) within the Gorge Creek Group.

A number of exploration targets (Pincunah Trend and Strelley Trend) occur along strike from known BID mineralistion occurring just outside the Abydos tenements (ie Iron Mount, Lalla Rookh South and Strelley Gorge Deposits held by BHPB) as shown in Figure 3.

In the Pincunah Greenstone Belt, the Pincunah Hill Formation is located at the contact between arenites and conglomerates of the Corboy Formation and felsic to intermediate volcanics of the Kangaroo Caves Formation.
The Pincunah Hill Formation contains red and black thinly bedded banded iron formation.
Within the Abydos Project this sequence contains zones of enrichment in a region located to the south of Pincunah Hill (Pincunah Trend).
The Corboy Formation also contains a sequence of banded iron formation which has the potential to host zones of bedded iron enrichment.
The Kangaroo Caves Formation which outcrops to the southwest of the Pincunah Hill Formation in the Abydos Project contains interbeds of white-grey layered chert and minor banded iron formation.
5 The East Strelley Greenstone Belt in the northeastern portion of the project contains a sequence of Gorge Creek Formation underlying the Lalla Rookh Formation.
The rocks of the Gorge Creek Formation in this region have been assigned to the Paddy Market Formation.
The Paddy Market Formation contains a thick sequence of banded iron formation comprising thinly bedded black, white, red and grey cherty banded iron formation.

Substantial zones of iron enrichment (Strelley Trend) were observed within the Abydos Project located between the Lalla Rookh South and Strelley Gorge Iron deposits (held by BHPB and located along strike, and outside the Abydos Project tenure).
The Mount Iron Deposit (also held by BHPB) is hosted in the same Paddy Market Formation just to the south of the Strelley Trend.
In addition, the Coucal Formation of the Coonterunah Group contains banded iron formation within the project area to the south of the Lalla Rookh iron deposit (held by BHPB).
The Golden Cockatoo Formation metasediments are an unassigned metasedimentary formation of the Sulphur Springs Group that is confined solely to the Abydos Greenstone Belt.
The formation has been metamorphosed to upper-amphibolite facies and is subdivided into four units dominated by banded iron formation, metapelite, metaquartzite, and rhyolite.
Historic rock chip sampling has identified small zones of iron enrichment in the banded iron formation within the Abydos project which requires further evaluation.

The Wodgina Greenstone Belt located in the western region of the Abydos Project and comprises an unassigned sequence of ultramafic rocks, mafic schist, amphibolite, basalt, quartzite, banded iron formation, chert and shale.
The greenstone belt forms a distinctive synclinal keel within the Yule Granitoid Complex.
The greenstone belt is bound to the north by the Carlindi Granitoid Complex.
The banded iron sequence correlates with the Cleaverville Iron Formation which is a known host of iron enrichment within the East Pilbara Granite Greenstone Terrain.
4.6.1 Prospect Mapping Prospect mapping by Atlas Iron Limited has been carried out over the Lalla Rookh targets.
The basic polygonal data has been compiled and digitized though a more complete report on this work is yet to be compiled.
Mapping was drafted in the field on hardcopies of aerial photography at 1:1000 or 1:2000 scale.
Aerial photography is from a detailed survey flown by AATMATCH over the Lalla Rookh in December 2007.
At S2 (Figure 7) mapping has tightened up the known enrichment to two pods, one up to 300m in length and 70m wide, the other a smaller 150m x 70m more surficial pod.
10 11 4.6.2 Regional Mapping In late 2007 Atlas Iron and Shaw River Resources commissioned Compass Geological (Compass) to conduct regional mapping over the Abydos tenement project.
For ease of mapping Compass divided the tenement group into two blocks located either side of the Port Hedland Newman railway line.
A summary of the mapping and maps are detailed below.
The western block consists of a single tenement, E 45/2404, which totals 183 km2, in area.
It is located 10 km northwest of the Wodgina mine, and is accessed via the Yandeyarra road, which passes through the centre of the tenement.

The eastern block consists of several tenements centred about 30km north of the abandoned Abydos Homestead, and most of theses are accessed via an all-weather road network that extends from the from the Port Hedland Newman Highway (near the Wodgina turnoff) to Sulfur Springs and beyond.
The Atlas tenements that were mapped consist of two large tenement blocks occur either side of the Port Hedland Newman highway.

The Western tenements are dominated by granitic rocks, with greenstone rocks restricted to a single synclinorium that is increasingly attenuated to the east, squeezed between the Yule and Carlindi Batholiths.
The greenstones are dominated by mafics of the Warrawoona Gp and Cleaverville Fm sediments.
These are metamorphosed to amphibolite facies and are highly strained near the granite margins.
The Cleaverville Fm is represented by banded quartzite and banded iron quartzite (meta BIF).
There is some iron enrichment of the northern limb of the synclinorium.
Also there is some potential for Sn-Ta in pegmatites that intrude the greenstones.

The Eastern tenements cover a much larger body of greenstone rocks that occur within a more complicated synclinorium which is flanked by the Yule Batholith to the SW, the Strelley Granitoid to the SE, and which to the NW forms an attenuated limb projecting northward into the Carlindi Batholith.
Metamorphism is mainly greenschist facies except near granite margins.

12 The greenstones on the flanks are dominated by Warrawoona Gp mafic volcanics, locally with intercalated impersistent felsic units, and with interflow sediments mostly in the form of pelites and cherts.
The Lallah Rookh Sandstone dominates the centre of the syncline, and ranges in composition from siltstone to conglomerate.

The iron prospective Cleaverville Fm BIFs and banded cherts are present stratigraphically above the mafics along the southern margin and in the NE corner but are absent elsewhere, largely due to faulting.
A significant regional fault trends NE through the eastern part of the tenements, passing west of Sulphur Springs.
Two significant SE trending structures transect the area and merge together before being truncated by the NE structures.
The northern of these extends from immediately east of Lynas Find and the southern, marked by ultramafics, is interpreted to extend from the area of the Mt York deposit.
Iron enrichment of possibly economic scale occurs as in-situ iron enrichment stratabound within the Cleaverville Fm BIFs and cherts, and as transported laterite in palaeochannels.
The latter are mostly excluded from the tenements.
In addition to iron, potential exists for the following commodities: 1.
Shear hosted gold deposits cf Mt York, Lynas Find, Zanaka 2.
Gold in NNW to NE trending extensional faults 3.
VMS deposits in possible remnants of Gorge Creek Gp & Sulphur Creek Volcs 4.

Wodgina style Sn-Ta-Li in pegmatites in the southwest corner There is also the more remote possibility for Ni-PGE in layered mafic-ultramafic intrusives although the ultramafics that were mapped were not layered.

The Majestic group tenements lie within the southern portion of the Gindalbie Terrane of the Yilgarn Craton as defined by Swager (1995), within the NorsemanWiluna Greenstone Belt.
The geology of the area is dominated by a regional D2 fold known as the Yindarlgooda Dome (Figure 3).
The tenements lie within a parasitic anticline on the western limb of the Dome.
The tenements overlie a fault bounded, isoclinally folded package of rocks dominated by tholeiitic basaltic and gabbroic rocks termed the Glandore Mafic Succession.
The sequence extends from Glandore in the north through to Mt Monger in the south.
The Glandore Mafic Succession is regarded by Swager (1995) as a separated thrust slice (D1) of the Gindalbie Terrane, which has subsequently been folded (D2) and offset by crosscutting (D3) faults.
The regional geological setting for the Majestic group tenements is shown in Figure 3.
Two thick, parallel Proterozoic east west dykes cut through P25/1710 and range from gabbroic to doleritic in composition.
Gold mineralisation hosted in rocks of the Glandore Mafic Succession has been documented for a number of localities and mining centres.
Mineralisation in the Mt Monger area is summarised in Hickman (1986).
Past production from the Mt Monger mines has been in excess of 230,000 oz Au from over 1.1 million tonnes of ore mined.
The distribution of mines and gold occurrences suggest northwest to north-northwest trending structures as the major controls on mineralisation.
However, some stratigraphic horizons appear to be preferentially mineralised in the areas where they are crosscut by northwest and northeast trending faults.
Combined annual exploration report for C122/2004 for the twelve-month period ended June 16, 2008 for the Majestic Project.
Mineral exploration activities carried out comprised a technical review.
RAB drilling of calcrete auger anomalies at Majestic returned results that indicate elevated gold values are hosted by quartz veined mafic rocks.
These have undergone supergene enrichment in the weathered zone.
The distribution and thickness of the veins indicates that the gold concentrations were insufficient to generate the necessary indicated or measured resource.
Resources would have to be identified in order to retain the ground as a mining lease.
The area remains of interest for small-scale mining and prospector activity.
It was recommended that no further work be carried out on the tenements, many of which were due to expire in mid 2008.

This work included auger geochemistry and RAB drilling.
Dioro Exploration NL acquired the rights to the tenements as a consequence of the sale.
This report details the exploration activities completed during the twelve-month reporting period between June 17, 2007 and June 16, 2008.

14 SUMMARY This report details exploration work completed during the year ended June 16, 2008 for the Majestic C122/2004 combined tenement group.
An option agreement between South Kal Mines P/L and titleholder F. Saunders passed to Dioro Exploration NL in December 2007.
This agreement lapsed during the year.
Only P25/1709 remains under the management of Dioro Exploration NL and this expires in March 2009.
During the year prior to expiry of the tenements and the agreement, a technical review of previous geochemistry and drilling was undertaken.
It was concluded that while there were local strongly gold mineralised vein settings, these tended to be patchy and have limited strike and depth continuity.
A well developed supergene enrichment process in the mafic rocks of the area has generated strongly anomalous gold values in the soils and in the weathered zone.
Surficial coarse gold and nugget patches also occur in the area.
It was concluded that the area was unlikely to contain gold concentrations sufficient to support indicated or measured gold resources and was more likely to be suited to prospector scale activity.
The Majestic Project is located approximately 45km southeast of Kalgoorlie (Figure 1).
It falls within the southeastern quadrant of the Kanowna 1:100,000 sheet, a subdivision of the Kurnalpi (SH51-10) 1:250,000 map sheet area.
Access from Kalgoorlie is southeast via the Mt Monger Road for 25km, then east via the Trans Access Road for 20km.
The tenements lie immediately south of the Trans Access Road.
The area is flat to slightly undulating and is vegetated with eucalypts, acacia, eremophila and saltbush species.
The leases are located within the Bulong District of the East Coolgardie Mineral Field, and are within the Mount Monger pastoral lease.
During the year a technical review of previous geochemistry and RAB drilling was completed that resulted in Dioro Exploration NL downsizing its holding in the area.
The work was carried out by geologist G. Hooper.

The following is an extract from his report of March 2008: The Majestic Project is located approximately 45km southeast of Kalgoorlie and falls within the southeastern quadrant of the Kanowna 1:100,000 sheet, a subdivision of the Kurnalpi (SH51-10) 1:250,000 map sheet area.
Access from Kalgoorlie is southeast via the Mt Monger Road for 25km, then east via the Trans Access Road for 20km.
The package comprises nine granted Prospecting Licences and one section 120AA reversion Prospecting Licence application in two contiguous groups (see attached location plan).
Tenure details are included in the table below.
This review is limited to a group of three almost contiguous tenements, P15/1708, 1709 and 1710.
The tenements overlie a fault bounded, isoclinally folded package of rocks dominated by tholeiitic basalt and gabbro (the Glandore Mafic Succession, (GMS).
This mafic package is restricted to the western limb of the Bulong Anticline, extending from Glandore in the north through to Mt Monger in the south.
The GMS is regarded as a separate thrust slice (D1) of the Gindalbie Terrain, which has subsequently been folded (D2) and offset by crosscutting (D3) faults.
Gold mineralisation has been identified at a number of localities within the mafic package.
During the 2005-2006 field season a detailed regional auger geochemical survey was completed.
Samples were collected on a 160m x 40m spacing over the entire area of the three tenements.
Several discrete anomalous (>50ppbb) zones were identified with the best result being 0.6ppm Au with a further 22 samples returning results >0.1ppm Au.
A plot of the auger results is attached.
An initial shallow RAB drilling program was completed to follow-up the anomalous auger results.
One hundred and thirty one (131) holes (06MJRB001 06MJRB131) were completed for 5730m with holes generally drilled to refusal.

The holes were completed at 80m intervals along nine lines between 160m and 400m spacings angled at -60 0 towards 090 0 (AMG East) Based on the results from this program an infill RAB drilling was then completed with a further seventy four holes (06MJRB132 205) for a total of 3892m drilled.
The locations of all the RAB drilling is shown on the attached plan.
The drilling produced a number of patchy narrow intersections which are tabulated below.
The mineralisation appears to be confined to narrow relatively shallow west dipping zones within sheared basalts.
A plan of the maximum gold values from the drilling together with the best intersections is attached.
Early in 2006 a proposal was put forward to carry out RC drilling totalling 1120m in 10 holes to follow-up the anomalous results from the RAB drilling.
The RAB drilling intersected only narrow mineralised zones with only eight holes intersecting better than 1g/t Au.
The drilling is of sufficient density to rule out the likelihood of there being any significant shallow saprolite hosted gold mineralisation.
There is only one really significant intersection which was the 3m @ 12.2g/t Au in drill hole 06MJRB176 with the hole ending in mineralisation.
Any gold mineralisation is likely to be narrow and of limited extent.
At this stage I would recommend that no further work be carried out on these tenements.
Note that two of the three tenements (P15/1708 and 1710) expire in June this year and three of the other tenements in the group but not reviewed also expire at the same time.

The Mt Vetters project is in the Kalgoorlie region of the Norseman Wiluna greenstone belt in a district with a history of gold and nickel production, with the Cawse nickel laterite mine located to the south west of the project area.
The project covers the southern portion of the Cawse Monzogranite and is covered by varying depths of alluvium.
Limited previous exploration has been completed in the project area, with the extensive cover restricting the effectiveness of prospecting and surface sampling.
The broad spaced drilling that has been completed in the project area was successful in identifying anomalous gold associated with granite under cover.
Field inspection, GIS data compilation and interpretation and correlation with similar local and regional mineralisation styles and occurrences was completed.

This review suggests there is potential for the Mt Vetters project area to host gold in granite style mineralisation similar to that known in the area of the Broad Arrow project, however the extensive cover masks any potential surface geochemical response.
Modern exploration, incorporating geophysics, would assist in identifying suitable structural settings beneath the cover, based on knowledge gained from the Broad Arrow area.
This work would be followed by drill testing of specific targets generated, plus the previously drill identified anomalous gold zone.
Geophysics, combined with broad spaced drill testing, would also assist in defining any potential palaeo drainage channels in the project area.
Follow up aircore and/or RC drilling would be required to test the channels identified for any associated gold mineralisation.

Opportunity exists for the identification of gold in granite and/or palaeo channel style mineralisation at the Mt Vetters project, albeit that this project is at an early stage of exploration with only limited gold anomalism identified to date.

Location: The tenement area was in the Peak Hill Mineral Field of Western Australia, and 30 km south of the Peak Hill gold mine.
The nearest regional centre was Meekatharra, 75 km to the south.
Access from Meekatharra was northeastward along the sealed Great Northern Highway to the southern boundary of the tenement.
Access within the tenement was via station tracks.
Geology: The tenement covered Lower Proterozoic sedimentary rocks of the Capricorn Orogen located between the Goodin Inlier to the south and the Marymia Inlier to the north.
The rocks belong to the Bryah and Yerrida Groups and comprise rift-basin and sag-basin lithological sequences.
The region contains a wide variety and large number of mineral deposits, but exploration is hindered by areas of alluvial cover with poor outcrop.
Work done: Exploration consisted of blanket soil and lag sampling on a 400 m 400 m offset grid over a large part of the western and southern half of E51/1111.
A total of 303 soil and lag samples were collected.
A 247-hole shallow vacuum drilling program for 476 m depth was conducted over geological and structural targets interpreted from the detailed aeromagnetic data and 247 samples were assayed.
A subsequent 125-hole, vacuum drilling follow-up programme for 379 m depth closed selected areas to 500 m line spacing.
And 125 samples were analysed.

Results: The wide-spaced drilling identified several coincident east-northeasterly trending goldarsenicantimony trends up to 5 km in length and parallel with the structural trend of the area, which was tested by the subsequent drilling.
The subsequent drilling generally confirmed a series of subparallel gold arsenicantimonycopper trends.
Conclusions: The anomalies were not high enough to warrant further exploration and the tenement was surrendered.

To advance the project to the resource definition, and bankable feasibility stage a number of drill holes were planned around the old Number 2 pit area to confirm the interpretation of a east west trending, and shallow north dipping lense of zinc, lead, and silver mineralisation.
This drilling could not be undertaken without first gaining Department of Indigenous Affairs approval.
Drilling has been planned and once completed the results will be reviewed with a view to defining resources and reserves.
All available data within 100 metres of the Number 2 pit was reviewed to define a resource estimate.
The resource report is included in Appendix 1.
Image 5086 covers the majority of the Narlarla Project and was orthorectified so that desk top studies could be undertaken incorporating all available 13 geophysical data.
Interpretation of several fault structures from the aerial photos was completed.
Digital photos of the area were taken over three site visits so that a permanent record of the area was available.
The main areas photographed were the Narlarla Number 1 and 2 pits, the impacts of past mining, and exploration activities, the surrounding landscape, and vegetation.
The Pb, Zn and Ag grade was interpolated into the parent cells of the ore domain using inverse distance squared.
The ore domain solid, ore_interp_res1.dtm, was used as a constraint to ensure only the blocks occurring within the defined ore zone were filled with grade.
Using this methodology a hard boundary was defined for the ore mineralisation.
The interpolation was carried out using 3x3x3 cell discretisation.
Search parameters had to be increased to ensure each block, within the ore domain, was filled with grade values for Pb, Zn and silver.
These search parameters have smoothed the grade throughout the model.
The search parameters are listed below.

Minimum number of samples to select: 2 Maximum number of samples to select: 15 Maximum search radius: 25 Maximum vertical search radius: 3 Major/Semi-Major: 2 Major/Minor: 4 The bearing of 55o was selected based on review of the raw drill hole data indicating that this was the direction of maximum grade continuity for the high grade zone.
1.5.0 Air Photo Review and digital photo compilation Orthorectified data was sourced and compiled in MapInfo with all other digital geophysical data, as part of a project review.
A number of faults were interpreted from the aerial photo data.
9 Digital photos of the area were captured over three site visits during the year so that a permanent record of the area was available.
The pit area is characterized by a gossan on the north east wall see Figure 5, with the host rock, marginal slope facies of a Devonian reef complex (Ringrose, 1984).
The zones of massive sulphide tend to be surrounded by a distinctive zone of green chlorite and carbonate grains (Spivey, pers comm., 2006).
This observation was also supported by Ringrose (1984), who noted that the carbonate wall rocks surrounding the ore zones were strongly chloritised.
Ringrose (1984) has concluded that the lead, zinc sulphides resulted from warm, metal bearing solutions which were localized by faults and depositional structures.
These fluids interacted 9 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT with porous, fluid saturated zones and generated alteration and brecciation.
Primary sulphides may also have been remobilized later, and redistributed by other fluids resulting in secondary ore zones formed in situ, and in down dip cavities.
4.3a Ore domain geology An ore zone has been defined by RC drilling immediately west of the northern end of the number 2 pit.
This ore zone has been defined on three sections of drilling: 683650, 683570, and 683690, and is still open along strike, but appears to have been closed off, at depth.
The ore lense trends east-west, and has a defined strike extent of 33m, with mineralisation open to the east and west.
The overall geometry is that of a discreet flat lying to shallow north dipping ore pod.
This feature could represent a cavity filled with metal bearing fluids.
Each of the drill hole sections are shown below displaying the mineralisation interpretation, and block model Zn grades.
10 11 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT 4.3b Waste rock geology The entire Number 2 pit area is characterized by slope facies carbonates.
The dominant lithologies have been described by Ringrose (1984), as yellow-brown to red, partly dolomitised and fossiliferous, thinly bedded, Napier Formation packstones and grainstones.
A variable, but generally notable amount of argillaceous to rudaceous siliciclastic and carbonate detritus has also been observed.
Beds and lenses of intraclastic breccia and thicker, finely laminated, silty, stromatolitic boundstone are also present.
12 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT 5.0 HYDROLOGY The Barker River and Wombarella Creek drain an extensive catchment area of Proterozoic rocks forming part of the King Leopold Range.
Water flow through the Barker Gorge during the wet season rains can be significant.
In the local area these water ways drain from east to west.
Assays of water taken from the number 2 pit indicate that the water is of good quality (potable) and has accumulated from rain fall since the pit was dewatered for mapping in 1984.
Details from water samples taken from the pit on 8 September 2006 are shown in Appendix 3.
Some water has been noted, from RC drilling, proximal to the mineralised zones indicating that there is a perched water table.
However, with the deposit located on a plateau, water is not expected to be a significant factor during shallow open pit mining operations.
6.0 STRUCTURAL OBSERVATIONS AND INTERPRETATION The Napier Formation in the project area has shallow dips of 20 30o to the SW.
These dips are believed to be depositional.
The walls of the open pit are generally well jointed with two main orientations observed 360 030 o and 090 110 o.
A brief overview of the deposit specific structure is given in the following section, with persons referred to Ringrose, 1984, for a more detailed account.
Several fault zones have been noted in the walls of the open pit, and are shown in the following figure.
These faults do not appear to have any significant affect on the geometry of the ore lense defined by drilling and located immediately north west of the number 2 pit.
Ringrose (1984) noted when mapping the dry pit that fault offsets observed were generally minor, being less than two metres.
The main feature of interest, relative to the ore domain defined for this resource estimate, is the Fault 3 strike is sub parallel to a high grade trend observed from the drill hole assays.
The bulk of the ore zone defined appears to sit in the footwall of Fault 3, in which case this feature could be a controlling structure on the southern extent of the mineralised pod.
13 The main point to note is that faults have been noted at both the Number 1 and Number 2 pits, and appear to be a key feature in controlling ore location.
The faulting at the Number 1 pit is clearly the most dominant structural control on the ore location which is characterized by a fault defining the footwall ore contact.
The same critical fault controls are expected to be a feature in controlling additional mineralisation in the area.
7.0 EXPLANATION OF RESOURCE REPORTING
Following the grade interpolation and modeling process, analysis of the block model grades, was performed.
In general, the block model has smoothed the composite drill hole assay data.
When comparing the drill hole composite grades against the block model grades a good correlation has been achieved.
In summary, the grades returned for each commodity in the block modeling process, compare well with the original drill hole assay data.
The ore zone solid models were created utilising Surpac Vision software version 5.1F.
A three-dimensional solid model was created by digitising ore boundaries (polygons) in crosssection by snapping to drill holes.
These polygons were triangulated from section to section with the ends closed out to form a solid.
The ore boundaries were generally defined by a 2.00% Zn cut off over a minimum drill width of 2.0 metres.
Ore intersections were generally extrapolated 10m up or down dip of drill hole intersections.

If a drill hole had no ore grade above or below a mineralised intersection, and there was no indication of geological structural continuity, the ore block was terminated at the mid point between drill holes.
If there was no drilling along strike from a section with ore intersections the ore zone was extrapolated an additional 5 metres along strike.
It is common practice to extend zones of mineralisation that remain open along strike half the distance of the drill hole line spacing, in this case 10 metres.
However, given the discreet nature of the mineralisation defined thus far, the mineralisation was only extended five metres east, and west of the end sections of drilling.
The ore domain defined was saved as ore_interp_res1.
str and dtm.
8.2a Void Modeling No survey pickup of the number 2 pit has been completed, or is possible whilst it is full of water.
GPS positions of the pit, to an accuracy of +/-5m, are available.
The southern extent of the most eastern portion of the ore domain was extrapolated to the pit edge.

16 17 Follow up work on the project will require detailed density measurements to be taken from the mineralised, and waste rock, so that subsequent resource estimates can include more conclusive density data.
8.3a Oxidation Profile The bulk density profile related directly to the oxidation profile.
The area around the Number 2 pit is only shallowly weathered with minimal top soil, and extensive outcrop.
The oxide zone was defined by the base of complete oxidation (vox).
This zone was absent from the Number 2 pit area, but correlates with, from a surface mining perspective, the general limit of free dig.
The semi oxidised zone, or transition zone, was defined by the base of semi oxidation (sox).

This zone is characterised predominantly by saprolitic clays that contain an indication of the original rock texture and correlates, from a surface mining perspective, with the zone expected to require light drill and blast work (~five metres below surface).
The partially oxidised zones lower limit is defined by the top of fresh rock contact.
This zone contains recognisable rock with textures largely intact, but there are still obvious signs of oxidation, such as limonite staining (~12 metres below surface).
The partially oxidised zone would be expected to require a moderate drill and blast pattern.
The fresh rock zone has no signs of oxidation with all minerals clearly unaffected by weathering.
This zone is expected to require a heavy drill and blast pattern to be exploited by open pit mining.
The majority of the ore domain defined was logged as fresh rock, and as such the ore zone has been applied a constant bulk density value of 3.30t/m3.

The drilling completed by Coronet Resources around the Number 2 pit indicates that there is a flat lying, to gentle north dipping ore pod that is approximately 25 metres wide, and 2 to 14 metres thick.
The hanging wall contact is located from 8 to 20 metres of surface.
On a higher level of detail, Spivey (2005) notes that the sulphide mineralisation occurs as one to three sulphide lenses surrounded by thicker, disseminated sulphide accumulations.
This zone of mineralisation has been modeled to reflect the style of mineralisation, and zones that may be 20 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT amenable to open cut mining.
These key features, and how they relate to the data density, were considered when the resource was modeled and classified.
All available data was taken into consideration when classifying the resource.
Historical mining and exploration data was reviewed, however, only drill holes completed by Coronet Resources were used to define the Narlarla geological model for the main ore bearing structure.
The Narlarla Project is located in the Napier Range within the north west portion of the Lennard Shelf, forming part of the northern margin of the Canning Basin in the West Kimberley.
The Napier Range consists of a narrow and elongate complex of Devonian reef carbonates unconformably overlying Proterozoic metamorphic rocks (Figure 2).
The Napier Range is generally less than two kilometres wide and projects less than 150 metres above the surrounding black soil plains, but is very rugged and difficult to traverse.
The limestone range trends north west-south east and is cut at intervals by gorges draining the river systems flowing west into King Sound.
The Narlarla Project is centred on the Barker Gorge cutting the Napier Range.
The old Narlarla (Devonian) lead-zinc-silver mine is located on the east side of the gorge on an elevated limestone plateau.
The Barker River and Wombarella Creek drain an extensive catchment area of Proterozoic rocks forming part of the King Leopold Range.
Water flow through the Barker Gorge during the wet season rains can be significant.
In detail the Devonian stratigraphy in the mid Napier Range consists of a basal conglomerate unit (Van Emmerick Conglomerate) forming the Van Emmerick Range to the north west of Narlarla.
Thinner variants of this unit may be persistent throughout the area.

The Frasnian platform facies Pillara Limestone is locally extensive, although not in the immediate Narlarla area, where the Frasnian Lower Napier and Famennian Upper Napier Formation are the dominant limestone units.
Both are fore reef and slope facies carbonates containing locally abundant terriginous material in a variably bedded and dolomitised impure limestone.

The Famennian reef margin Windjana Limestone and back reef Nullara Limestone are associated with the Upper Napier Formation elsewhere, but not in the immediate Narlarla area where they appear to have been removed by erosion (Hocking and Playford 1998).
Bedded units dip on average 15 to 30 degrees to the south west; the steeper dips in fore reef slope areas.

A northerly change in strike in the Barker Gorge area in the immediate vicinity of the Narlarla lead-zinc deposits has been interpreted as a syn-depositional feature associated with active faulting possibly along the present Barker River gorge (Ringrose 1984).
11 Lead-zinc mineralisation broadly of Mississippi Valley Type (MVT) is present in the area from Narlarla to Wagon Pass located approximately 14 kilometres to the north west.
Although no presently economic reserves are known, the 12 area is considered prospective in the light of significant lead-zinc mineralisation elsewhere on the Lennard Shelf.
It has already been noted that the discreet resource that has been defined consists of only seven drill holes.
The hole that intersected the highest grade results was air core hole, NA1, which was the only hole located on the most eastern section, 683690E.

The influence of this drill hole on the resource estimate has been reviewed by defining the global resource from the midway point of the closest section of data (683680E) to the eastern end of the resource wire frame (see figure ).
The following table shows a comparison between the global resource, and that part of the resource most influenced by drill hole NA1.
Clearly the influence of this hole has a significant impact on the overall resource representing 16% of the total volume, and more significantly, 38% of the insitu value of the resource.
Additional drilling is recommended to confirm the high grade results from hole NA1.
However, it must be noted that high grade sulphide zones have been noted, at the base of the pit, with the majority located at the north western end (Ringrose, 1984).
This observation does help add confidence to the high grade Pb, Zn and Ag results returned from drill hole NA1.
22 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT The following graph demonstrates only a moderate drop in tonnes and increase in grade, at higher bottom cuts from 0.5 to 3% Zn.
However, there is a marked drop in tonnes, and increase in grade at cutoffs greater than 4% Zn.
Any detailed mine planning, and feasibility studies will help determine appropriate cut-off grades.

The metal content per vertical metre figure, below, clearly highlights that the zone between 88 RL (~12m below surface) and 78 RL (~22m below surface) contains significant metal content, 23 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT that based on current metal prices indicate a positive return from mining could be possible.
This factor is supported by the figures in the following table that show the insitu value of metal.
Detailed feasibility work remains to be completed to clearly demonstrate the robustness of the project, and define reserves.
But initial indications are very positive and additional work is recommended to define the full resource potential.
The following figure indicates that viable mining could occur down to the 78m RL (~22m below surface).
The average gold equivalent ounces between the 92m RL (top of ore mineralised pod) and the 78m RL (limit of >500 ounce gold equivalent) is 1,021.
More detailed mine design work is required to define final project feasibility, but initial indications point to robust open pit potential.

25 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT 10.0 CONCLUSIONS & RECOMMENDATIONS The base metal mineralisation defined at the north west end of the Number 2 pit, at the Narlarla Pb Zn Project, has been defined as a discreet pod.
This ore pod trends east-west, and has a defined strike extent of 33m, with mineralisation open to the east and west.
The overall geometry is that of a discreet flat lying to shallow north dipping ore pod.
Detailed feasibility work remains to be completed to clearly demonstrate the robustness of the project, and define reserves.
But initial indications are very positive and additional work is recommended to define the full potential of the Narlarla Pb-Zn Project.
The remaining lease area is also prospective for defining base metal mineralisation and has very good exploration potential.
Resources also need to be assigned to follow up on this potential.
Cash flow from future mining could be allocated to accelerate this exploration effort.

29 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT FINAL REPORT ON THE MINERALOGY OF THREE SAMPLES (FROM DRILLHOLES HOLES NCR08 AND NCR12) FOR CORONET RESOURCES AUTHOR: Sarah Barley DATE: December 7th 2004 30 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT SUMMARY OF MINERALOGICAL WORK Three sub-samples from drilling at a Pb/Zn deposit were submitted for polished thin section preparation and description.
Frank Nemeth in the Geology Department at U.W.A.
prepared the sections.
They were examined in reflected and transmitted light in order to identify ore and gangue mineral types and particle sizes.
The latter is based on the two dimensional observation of a section and cannot provide exact sizes of the irregular particles present.
The range of maximum dimensions of particle sizes is recorded here.
The degree of liberation of ore minerals i.e.
the percentage of ore minerals occurring as free particles in the sample is visually estimated.
Sulphide minerals appear to account for the Pb and Zn assay results.
The sphalerite (ZnS) ranges from honey brown to darker red brown.
The darker colour indicates Fe/Mn substitution for Zn.
Sphalerite particles typically have colloform banding which is a result of open space deposition.
Silver minerals were not observed; silver could be held in solid solution in galena, sphalerite or pyrite.
Secondary Pb and Zn carbonates, oxides and sulphates were not apparent from mineralogical observations.
However, to confirm no input from carbonate phases, microanalysis would be required.
It is more difficult to identify secondary phases in ground-up sample due to physical break-up of the sample and possible removal of secondary coatings on sulphide grains.

The broken up Pb-Zn ore appears to be made up of: 1) Relatively coarse-grained sulphide aggregates (90 to 95 percent of total sulphide) 2) Finer-grained brecciated sulphide 3) Sulphide disseminated in wallrock.
The brecciated sulphides typically comprise sulphide grains <500 ?m.
They rim the coarser sulphide aggregates in places (rims up to 1 mm wide).
They appear to be locked to a minor component of wallrock, so the S.G. of a brecciated particle would still be significantly higher than the gangue.

In all three samples, single-phase sulphide particles or composite sulphide particles that are <100 ?m comprise around 5 percent of total sulphide; those that are <500 ?m comprise around 10 percent of total sulphide.

37 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT APPENDIX 2 Summary ore domain drill hole statistics 38 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT
Zinc, lead and silver bearing gossans in the Narlarla area were discovered by a police patrol as early as 1901, with intermittent small scale mining activities taking place before and after WW2.
The main period of mining took place from 1948-1966 when Devonian Pty Ltd excavated an open cut over the outcropping Narlarla gossans.
Total production over this time was approximately 11,033 tonnes of ores and concentrates grading around 19.2% lead, 26% zinc, and approximately 105 g/t silver.
This material was shipped through the port of Derby (Cowan 1996).
7 Since the cessation of mining in the Narlarla area in 1966, the area has been subjected to sporadic exploration campaigns.
The first of these was by the Shell Company of Australia Metals Division who explored the Narlarla area as part of a larger Lennard Shelf exploration program during the period 1978- 1982.

Although this effort met with little success in the immediate Narlarla 8 area, significant lead-zinc mineralisation of a similar style to Narlarla was located at Wagon Pass, approximately 14 kilometres to the north west.
Fire Hills Gold NL undertook a limited campaign of percussion drilling in the immediate vicinity of the Narlarla mines in 1989.
Although some intersections of economic significance were returned, including 2 m @ 25.5% zinc and 14.7% lead, no additional ore positions were considered to have been located by this work.
This work was poorly reported, and details of hole locations are unavailable.
A proposal by the same party to treat stockpiled low grade material did not eventuate.
A review of the exploration potential of the area together with a photogeological study was completed by J.S.
Noakes and Associates in 1995.
The report concluded that the area in the vicinity of the old Narlarla mines remained prospective for carbonate hosted lead-zinc deposits.

Subsequent work completed by Coronet Resources Limited has included Enzyme Leach Partial Extraction soil geochemistry, which was mainly directed towards assessing the potential of the alluvial and black soil plain south of the Napier Range, to conceal Mississippi Valley Type (MVT) base metals mineralisation.

Drilling has totalled 24 air core holes for 699 metres, and 15 Reverse Circulation drill holes for 682 metres, guided in part by a high resolution gravity survey consisting of 336 readings on a nominal 20m grid around the No.
2 Ore Pit, where base metal sulphides are exposed in the floor of the flooded open cut.
In 2005 a gravity survey was completed with a total of 709 gravity stations read on a 200x200 or 200x400 metre grid covering the main portion of the Narlarla Project area.
The survey contractor was Haines Surveys Pty Ltd.

This data were subsequently subjected to terrain correction modelling by Stewart Geophysical Consultants Pty Ltd. Also in 2005 an area north of the Napier Range and a small area south of the range were selected for termite mound geochemistry.
A total of 74 ant mound samples were collected in the field and sieved to -200 microns.
The samples were submitted to Genalysis Laboratory Services Pty Ltd in Perth for low level geochemical analysis.
The samples were analysed by both partial and total digest methods.
All the drill hole information was composited to a minimum 1-metre down-hole interval.
This data was then intersected with the drill hole database and the ore domain solid to produce the composite data set used in the geostatistical review and the grade interpolation.
Summary statistics based on the Zn, Pb, and Ag composites are shown in Appendix 2.
The data set for the mineralised domain consisted of only 47 data points and as such, statistically, the results could be viewed as inconclusive.
However, the data for Pb, Zn, and Ag was reviewed, but no meaningful variograms could be modeled.

A lower cut of approximately 2.0% Zn was used when defining the ore zone contact, however, some lower grade zones were incorporated if they were located within a higher grade interval, and the logged geology was also taken into consideration.
No top cut was applied.
All available digital data for the Narlarla project was obtained from Martin Spivey in July 2006, with the drill hole data compiled into a MS Access database, narlarla_db.mdb.
A *.ddb file was created so that the data could be reviewed in 3D using Surpac software.
The database contained 56 drill holes that were completed using diamond, reverse circulation or air core drill rigs.
Seven of these drill holes were used in the resource estimation process, as they intersected the ore domain defined.
The drill data in the database ranges over an extended period of time, and was collected by several companies.
However, all of the data used in the resource definition was collected by Coronet, and as such a high degree of confidence is attributed to the results.
14 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT The following table lists a breakdown of the drilling episodes for the drill holes used in the resource calculation.
All of the holes were drilled by Murchison Exploration.
7.1a Drilling The Coronet RC drill data results were sourced from reverse circulation percussion drilling utilizing a 4 5/8 face sampling hammer.
The RC drilling was completed with a minimum hole diameter of 140mm.
One metre bulk samples were collected from RC drilling and stored in plastic sample bags attached to the cyclone.
The bulk samples were reduced to 2-3kg sizes using a riffle splitter and collected in calico bags for assaying.
Sample recovery was high, with very limited sample loss being recorded.
The vast majority of samples were drilled dry.
Good records, reports, plans and sections are available for the historical drilling.
Overall, the quality of the historical work completed, particularly by Coronet, who undertook all of the drilling and assessment work completed around the Number 2 pit, is very good.
This work has been summarized in the Coronet Resources Limited Annual Reports, specifically those ending 31 December, 2001, and 2004.
Hole NA1 was the only air core hole drilled in the Number 2 pit area.
Samples were laid out in rows of 10 metres, with scoop samples taken every one or two metres (Spivey 2002).

7.1b Logging During the Coronet drilling an experienced, competent geologist, Martin Spivey, logged in detail the lithology, veining, ore zone mineralogy, weathering profile, sample quality, recovery, and structure.
All drill logs are available in the Coronet head office and in the relevant annual exploration report with relevant data captured digitally in the Narlarla database.

7.1c Drill hole surveys No down-hole surveys were taken during drilling, but all holes were collared vertically, with minimal hole deviation expected as the holes were generally shallow (<50m depth), there was minimal surface weathering and the host rock was fairly constant, consisting of slope facies carbonates.
The drill hole collars were surveyed using a 12 channel GPS using MGA (GDA94) coordinates.
7.1d Drill hole spacing 15 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT The ore domain defined has been defined by drilling as extending from 683650, 683570, and 683690.
The drill hole data density varies across the deposit, but there is generally a 20 metre line spacing with 10 metre spaced drill holes on each line.
There are a number of registered Aboriginal sites on, or around the project tenements.
Due to this, no advanced exploration work, such as, drilling can be 10 undertaken on the Narlarla Project tenements, without Department of Indigenous Affairs (DIA) approval.
To gain this approval negotiations with the Kimberley Land Council (KLC), and traditional owners, Wanjina Wunggurr Willigin (Native Title Holders of the project area), were ongoing during the year.
In November 2006 a Mineral Exploration Agreement was signed between the KLC, and Coronet Resources Limited.
Following this a heritage survey was completed, and approval given for air core, RC, and diamond drilling to be undertaken.
Onset of the wet season prevented any field work from being completed after November 2006.

In order to be able to complete exploration work, such as drilling, over the project area, negotiations with the Kimberley Land Council (KLC), and traditional owners, Wanjina Wunggurr Willigin (Native Title Holders of the project area), were ongoing during the year.
In November 2006 a Mineral Exploration Agreement (MEA) was finalised between the KLC, and Coronet Resources Limited.
Following acceptance of the MEA by all parties a heritage survey was undertaken, and approval given to complete planned exploration activities, including: air core; RC; and diamond drilling.
This work is expected to commence in the 2007 dry season.

The relationships established during the year between Coronet Resources Limited, the KLC, and traditional land owners will be expanded upon, as the groups continue to work together so that exploration can continue over the project area.

Increases in base metal prices during the year saw the project focus change from grass roots exploration to resource definition around the lead and silver mineralisation intersected during earlier drilling around the Narlarla Number 2 pit.

4 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT 1.0 INTRODUCTION This report discusses the Narlarla Pb-Zn resource in the Napier Range area in the West Kimberley, WA.
An ore domain comprising zinc, lead and silver mineralisation has been defined around the abandoned number 2 pit that was last mined in 1965.
The resource definition project has been managed by Coronet Resources Limited personnel.
Whilst the area remains prospective for the definition of additional base metal mineralisation, this report will focus pre-dominantly on the resource area, and resource estimation process.
The long term outlook for base metal prices remains positive.
The prevailing market conditions have led to a change in priority for the project from exploration to resource definition.
The following text highlights the work undertaken in estimating a resource.
All orientations in this report are listed relative to MGA Zone 51 (GDA94), unless otherwise stated.
Magnetic north (MN) is located 3.38o east of grid north (GN) (to convert from MN to GN add 3.38o and GN to MN subtract 3.38o).
2.0 LOCATION & ACCESS The Narlarla Project is located approximately 1,860 km north east of Perth in the West Kimberley region of Western Australia (see figure 1).
The project area is centred on the Barker River Gorge across the Napier Range, approximately 120 kilometres east of Derby within the West Kimberley Mineral Field.
The project covers a portion of the north west corner of the Lennard River 1:250,000 map sheet (SE 51-8).

Access to the project can be obtained from the Gibb River Road from Derby to Yammera Gap in the Napier Range close to the present Napier Downs homestead, thence north west along pastoral tracks on either side of the Napier Range to the Barker River.
Vehicle access to the old Narlarla (Devonian) mine site on the limestone plateau immediately east of Barker Gorge is difficult.
Access to the project area is generally good during the dry season, although the Napier Range itself is very rugged.
Vehicle access to the project is often not possible during the northern Australian wet season.
The Narlarla resource area is located on top of a plateau in the Napier Range, 13km NW of the Gibb River Road, next to the abandoned Number 2 pit.

5 3.0 HISTORY Zinc, lead and silver bearing gossans in the Narlarla area were discovered by a police patrol as early as 1901, with intermittent small scale mining activities taking place before and after World War 2.
The main period of mining took place from 1948-1966 when Devonian Pty Ltd excavated an open cut over the outcropping Narlarla gossans.
Total production over this time was approximately 11,033 tonnes of ores and concentrates grading around 19.2% lead, 26% zinc, and approximately 105 g/t silver.
This material was shipped through the port of Derby (Cowan 1996).
Since the cessation of mining in the Narlarla area in 1966, the area has been subjected to sporadic exploration campaigns.
The first of these was by the Shell Company of Australia Metals Division who explored the Narlarla area as part of a larger Lennard Shelf exploration program during the period 1978-1982.

Although this effort met with little success in the immediate Narlarla area, significant lead-zinc mineralisation of a similar style to Narlarla was located at Wagon Pass, approximately 14 kilometres to the north west.
6 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT Fire Hills Gold NL undertook a limited campaign of percussion drilling in the immediate vicinity of the Narlarla mines in 1989.
Although some intersections of economic significance were returned, including 2 m @ 25.5% zinc and 14.7% lead, no additional ore positions were considered to have been located by this work.
This work was poorly reported, and details of hole locations are unavailable.
A proposal by the same party to treat stockpiled low grade material did not eventuate.
A review of the exploration potential of the area together with a photo geological study was completed by J.S.
Noakes and Associates in 1995.
The report concluded that the area in the vicinity of the old Narlarla mines remained prospective for carbonate hosted lead-zinc deposits.

Subsequent work completed by Coronet Resources Limited has included Enzyme Leach Partial Extraction soil geochemistry, which was mainly directed towards assessing the potential of the alluvial and black soil plain south of the Napier Range, to conceal Mississippi Valley Type (MVT) base metals mineralisation.

Drilling has totaled 24 air core holes for 699 metres, and 15 Reverse Circulation drill holes for 682 metres, guided in part by a high resolution gravity survey consisting of 336 readings on a nominal 20m grid around the Number 2 Ore Pit, where base metal sulphides are exposed in the floor of the flooded open cut.
In 2005 a gravity survey was completed with a total of 709 gravity stations read on a 200x200 or 200x400 metre grid covering the main portion of the Narlarla Project area.
The survey contractor was Haines Surveys Pty Ltd.

This data were subsequently subjected to terrain correction modeling by Stewart Geophysical Consultants Pty Ltd. Also in 2005 an area north of the Napier Range and a small area south of the range were selected for termite mound geochemistry.
A total of 74 ant mound samples were collected in the field and sieved to -200 microns.
The samples were submitted to Genalysis Laboratory Services Pty Ltd in Perth for low level geochemical analysis.
The samples were analysed by both partial and total digest methods.
A critical part of defining an economically viable mining venture at Narlarla includes treatment options.
One option being investigated is a toll treatment agreement to have the ore processed at the Pillara Treatment Plant.
Negotiations with Lennard Shelf Pty Ltd have commenced to confirm this option.

The first stage in realising the mining potential of the ore lense, at the northern end of the old Number 2 pit, is to define the extents of this currently open structure, collect core samples for metallurgical test work, density determination, and generate a revised resource estimate and define reserves.
Diamond drilling around the resource area has been planned.
The three dimensional modeling package Surpac Vision V5.1-F was used in the construction of the resource block model.

A block model summary is tabled below: Project name: Narlarla Pb-Zn Project Project description: Resource Model December 2006 Project date: 27-Dec-2006 Project domains: Domain Code Domain Name No Domain Description 1 Narlarla Main Lode 1 Main Lode immediately west of north end of Number 2 pit.
During the 2001 air core drilling, samples were submitted to Genalysis Laboratory Services in Perth.
Each sample was assayed by Aqua-Regia or 4 acid digest (Method Codes B/ASS, AX/MS, AX/OES) with results reported for Ag, As, Cd, Cu, Pb, and Zn.
The 2004 RC samples were submitted to Genalysis Laboratory Services in Perth.
Pb and Zn were analysed by Aqua Regia digest with an AAS finish (Method Code B/AAS).

Samples grading greater than 0.5% Pb or Zn were repeat assayed for Ag, As, Bi, Cd by multi-acid digest followed by analysis by Mass Spectrometry (Method Code AX/MS), and for Cu, Pb, and Zn by multi-acid digest followed by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometry (Method Code AX/OES) (Spivey, 2005).
During both programs the labs own internal standards, and checks were relied upon to ensure adequate QA/QC checks were in place to ensure assay sample reliability.

The available drill hole data was compiled in a Access database to help maintain long term data integrity.
All geophysical datasets were compiled into a MapInfo Workspace so that the project could be reviewed, and future exploration planned, and prioritised.

The digital datasets included: Drill hole data; Gravity survey data; Topography; 1:250,000 Geology Data; 1:500,000 Lineament Data; Black and White Aerial Photography; Enzyme Leach Partial Extraction soil geochemistry; and Ant mound sample results.

Based on an examination of the data available several exploration targets have been defined for future exploration.
Aside from the priority drilling planned around the number 2 pit the target of most interest was a gravity anomaly, co-incident with a creek line interpreted fault.
This feature represents a high priority target for future exploration, and is shown below.
Faulting is believed to play a critical part in the location of the Narlarla deposits (& most MVT style deposits).
The faults have helped act as a locus for the ore bearing fluids, and can also generate structural traps for mineralisation.
The presence of faults in, and around the mined Narlarla deposits provides clear support for this structural control model (see Figures 4, 5 and 6).

16 17 18 Future work planned, as a result of the data review includes: An extension of the ant mound, and soil sampling completed in the past; Ground truthing of geochemical anomalies, particularly those proximal to interpreted fault zones; Air core drilling; RC drilling; and Diamond drilling.
During the year the priorities for the Narlarla Project changed from exploration to resource definition.

This change was a result of the increasing base metal prices (particularly zinc) indicating that the zinc, lead, and silver mineralisation interpreted at the northern end of the old Number 2 Pit could potentially sustain a viable mining operation.
All available data was reviewed, and a global resource defined.
The Narlarla Project is located in the Napier Range within the north west portion of the Lennard Shelf, forming part of the northern margin of the Canning Basin in the West Kimberley.
The Napier Range consists of a narrow and elongate complex of Devonian reef carbonates unconformably overlying Proterozoic metamorphic rocks (Figure 2).
The Napier Range is generally less than two kilometres wide and projects less than 150 metres above the surrounding black soil plains, but is very rugged and difficult to traverse.
The limestone range trends north west-south east and is cut at intervals by gorges draining the river systems flowing west into King Sound.
The Narlarla Project is centred on the Barker Gorge cutting the Napier Range.
The old Narlarla (Devonian) lead-zinc-silver mine is located on the east side of the gorge on an elevated limestone plateau.
The Barker River and Wombarella Creek drain an extensive catchment area of Proterozoic rocks forming part of the King Leopold Range.
Water flow through the Barker Gorge during the wet season rains can be significant.

7 8 NARLARLA RESOURCE REPORT In detail the Devonian stratigraphy in the mid Napier Range consists of a basal conglomerate unit (Van Emmerick Conglomerate) forming the Van Emmerick Range to the north west of Narlarla.
Thinner variants of this unit may be persistent throughout the area.

The Frasnian platform facies Pillara Limestone is locally extensive, although not in the immediate Narlarla area, where the Frasnian Lower Napier and Famennian Upper Napier Formation are the dominant limestone units.
Both are fore reef and slope facies carbonates containing locally abundant terriginous material in a variably bedded and dolomitised impure limestone.

The Famennian reef margin Windjana Limestone and back reef Nullara Limestone are associated with the Upper Napier Formation elsewhere, but not in the immediate Narlarla area where they appear to have been removed by erosion (Hocking and Playford 1998).
Bedded units dip on average 15 to 30 degrees to the south west; the steeper dips in fore reef slope areas.

A northerly change in strike in the Barker Gorge area in the immediate vicinity of the Narlarla lead-zinc deposits has been interpreted as a syn-depositional feature associated with active faulting possibly along the present Barker River gorge (Ringrose, 1984).
Lead-zinc mineralisation broadly of Mississippi Valley Type (MVT) is present in the area from Narlarla to Wagon Pass located approximately 14 kilometres to the north west.
Although no presently economic reserves are known, the area is considered prospective in the light of significant lead-zinc mineralisation elsewhere on the Lennard Shelf.
Approximately one third of the project area is composed of outcropping limestone of the Napier Range.
The remaining area partially consists of recent alluvial deposits associated with the Barker River and Wombarella Creek.
Elsewhere, black soil plains extend both north and south of the Napier Range.
Locally, lower Proterozoic basement metamorphic rocks out crop north of the Napier Range.
All presently known lead-zinc showings in the immediate Narlarla project area occur within one kilometre of the Barker Gorge cutting the Napier Range.
Most of the known showings are located within M4/91, and include the No.
1 and 2 deposits which have been historically worked.

These were small irregular lenses of massive sulphide and sulphide breccia localised in faults and overlain by residual limonitic gossans containing varying amounts of cerussite, hydrozincite, smithsonite and copper carbonates.

Primary ore textures are typical of MVT systems and include botryoidal masses of galena and sphalerite with open space filling in breccias, and lesser bedded sulphides in replacement zones (Ringrose 1984).
West of Barker Gorge, minor oxidised occurrences of lead-zinc sulphides are present on the southern limestone escarpment at Kile's Find.
Despite a number of exploration drill holes collared to the west of the outcrop by Shell Minerals, no significant intersections were made.

Mineral exploration activities for tenement P24/3980 include project geological data review and field inspection by the new Operators who have recently exercised an Option to Purchase this mineral tenement.
The tenement, P24/3980, lies 36km north-north-east of Kalgoorlie just to the east of the Goldfields Highway.
It is located 2km south of the mining centre of Havana-Suva.
Vehicular access is best by existing dirt tracks from the Highway to the west of the tenement.
A thorough review of all geological data was completed with particular attention given to subsurface geology within drill holes to establish whether any palaeochannels were present.
Palaeochannels are regarded as an additional target for hosting gold mineralisation as found at Lady Bountiful and Mt Pleasant located some 30 kilometres to the west.
To achieve a suitable data review all data was interrogated in Mapinfo GIS, with additional data sourced from open file technical reports to establish a wider local and regional dataset.
Within the tenement a palaeochannel has been interpreted to be present although no significant gold has been noted.
Attached figures show data and interpretations.
Bedrock gold may remain undefined given the relatively wide spacing of drill traverses.
Additional datasets including Satellite photography and multi-client aeromagnetic data was also purchased to aid geological interpretation and planning.
Aeromagnetics were processed by Southern Geoscience Consultants and various registered tiff images produced.
A strong correlation of intersecting NW and NE trending structures with known mineralisation at HavanaSuva and Federal is interpreted and will influence future target definition.

3.0 INTRODUCTION AND TENURE Dalrymple Resources NL and associated companies became wholly owned subsidiaries of LionOre Mining International Ltd on the 30th October 2003 following the approval of the merger by the Federal Court of Australia.
This report describes the exploration activities conducted by Dalrymple Resources NL within the Hairy Legs E36/497 tenement during the reporting period 5 April 2006 to 4 April 2007.
A project location plan is shown in Figures 1 and 2.
Tenement details are shown in Table 1 below.
The E36/497 tenement is located approximately 15 kilometres southeast of the LeonoraLeinster highway towards the Darlot Gold Mine.
5.0 REGIONAL GEOLOGY The project area is located on the eastern edge of the southern truncation of the Yandal greenstone belt.
To the immediate west of the project area is the Weebo-Mt.
Clifford greenstone belt, a north-northwest trending folded and trust staked sequence of basalts, ultramafics, felsic volcanics and pelitic sediments, intruded by several granitoid plutons.
The nearest major structural discontinuity in the area is the Mt.
McClure shear zone which largely defined the granite-greenstone contacts in the region.
Most of the area is covered by hardpanised windblown sands and colluviums.
The regolith profile is generally thinner over felsic and granitoid lithologies and thicker over mafics and sediments.
Regional geology is shown in Figure 3.

Dissolution and analysis (SLA) Sodium peroxide fusion A 0.25 g aliquot of the sample was fused at 700C in alumina crucibles with sodium peroxide.
The fused material was dissolved in concentrated hydrochloric acid, diluted to 500 ml with water, and analysed by ICP -OES or ICP-MS. .
Four-acid digest A 0.3 g aliquot of the sample was taken up in nitric, perchloric, hydrochloric, and hydrofluoric acids.
The digest temperature was raised steadily to dryness.
The remaining solids were dissolved to a final volume of 50 ml in 10% hydrochloric acid and analysed by ICP-OES and ICPMS.
Aqua regia A 40 g sample was digested in concentrated mixed nitric and hydrochloric acids in plastic bottles.
The digest was diluted and mixed.
Analysis was by ICP -MS for Au, Hg and Cd (and semiquantitatively for Pt).

Fusion disc Fused discs for X-ray fluorescence analysis were made on a Labtec Essa robotic fused-bead system using 1.5 g sample and 10.5 g of Li borate flux (12 parts lithium metaborate and 22 parts lithium tetraborate) that were fused at 1050C.
Analysis was by Philips PW2404/2440 X-ray spectrometer using a 4 kW end window Rh X-ray tube.
Ni fire assay (PGE) A 25 g sample was mixed with a Ni-carbonate sulfurbased flux and fused.
The resultant Nisulfide button was pulverized and a portion was digested to remove the Nisulfide base.
Recovery of the platinoids was undertaken in a reducing environment coupled with Te coprecipitation.
The insoluble platinoid sulfides were separated by filtration, digested and the resulting solution was analysed by ICP -MS for Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru, Os and Ir, with a detection limit of less than 1 ppb.

The Irwin Bore Project is located approximately 800km north-east of Perth and 130km east of Wiluna in Western Australia Access is via Great Northern Highway to Meekatharra and Wiluna, then via the Gunbarrel Highway and Wonganoo roads.
Access within the tenement is provided by station tracks and fence lines.
Irwin Bore, E53/1137, covers part of the Archaean Mt Eureka greenstone belt (Figure 3).

Localised geology as described by Marymia exploration 2001 as follows: The Irwin Bore area is dominated by colluvial-alluvial cover, with low rises and ridges formed by outcropping granites, mafic and ultramafic volcanic rocks and BIF-chert horizons.
In the north, conglomerates containing granitic clasts have been interpreted as a Permian tillite deposit, preserved in a paleochannel, developed along a major fault zone.
The stratigraphy is dominated by a sequence if high magnesium basalts, with minor tholeiitic units and ultramafic rocks.
Shearing of these units has resulted in chloritetremolite-talc-carbonate schists, with zones of siliceous alteration.
Felsic units within the sequence vary from dacitic tuffs to volcanogenic epiclastic sedimentary rocks.
They are commonly sheared, with associated quartz veining, and locally outcrop as quartz-sericite schists.
Cherts and ironstone present in the area may represent interflow sediments in the sequence.
The greenstone sequence is bounded to the east and west by massive to gneissic granitic plutons, varying in composition from granite to granodirorite.
Quartz veining and quartz sericite alteration are commonly associated with sheared contacts.
One sample of ferruginous lag (iron segregation) and four samples of lateritic gravel (pisoliths and nodules) were collected from a 1km x 1km area in the centre of E53/1137.
This sampling was part of a regional laterite survey aimed at identifying dispersion haloes of Ni and/or Au mineralization that had not previously been recognized (Figure 2).
The laterite samples were sent to Ultra Trace Laboratory in Canning Vale, Perth, for multi digest and multi element analysis.
Two samples were also analysed for the full suite of PGE elements by Ultra Trace, using a Ni fire assay digest and ICP-MS finish; the detection limit is 0.2 ppb.
Sample locations and results are tabulated in Appendix 1-digital file E5301173_WASG3_SURF_2007A.txt.

LATERITE SAMPLING RESULTS Chromium concentrations in four samples exceed the 75th percentile (1750 ppm) for laterite on greenstone terrain based on approximately 330 analyses from the YIlgarn Laterite Atlas (Cornelius et al., 2007).
These Cr concentrations suggest the presence of ultramafic bedrock nearby.
Nickel and Cu concentrations ranging from 68-1240 ppm and 93-478 ppm respectively, may indicate the presence of base metal sulphide.
The platinum group element concentrations in two samples show a degree of fractionation more similar to that of intrusion-related sulphides than that of komatiite-hosted ones.
Iridium, Ru, Rh and Pt concentrations in one of the samples all exceed the 75th percentiles for these elements based on laterite data for granite and greenstone terrain (Cornelius et al., 2007).
Five laterite samples, taken as part of a larger regional reconnaissance survey, do not show the presence of komatiite-hosted Ni sulphide or Au mineralization.
However, elevated (>75th percentile) PGE, Ni, Cu, Au, As and Sb concentrations in some of the samples may indicate the presence of more distant mineralization.
Follow-up geochemical exploration could be by a combination of different sample media (laterite, biota, groundwater) depending on availability and regolith characteristics.
The Irwin Bore Exploration Licence, E53/1137, is located ~800km north-east of Perth, Western Australia, in the Archaean Mt Eureka greenstone belt.
Work during the reporting period included collection of one sample of ferruginous lag (iron segregation) and four samples of lateritic gravel (pisoliths and nodules).
The Apollo project is within the Kurnalpi Terrane of Cassidy et al.
This terrane was originally defined by Swager (1997) but has since been expanded to include the former Gindalbie and Laverton Terranes.
It is currently defined as being bounded by the Ockerburry Fault System to the west and the Hootanui Fault System to the east.
A significant part of this revised definition is the separation of the former Gindalbie terrane into north and south components.
The Kurnalpi Terrrane is now considered to compirse of the Bulong, Gindalbie, Menangina, Murrin, Laverton, Edjudina and Linden Domains.
This terrane comprises a series of thin, linear north-north-west trending fault bounded domains of dominantly mafic-feslic volcanic sequences with prominent lateral facies changes.
Komatiite horizons are thin and discontinuous, and more common to the west, with the major occurrance centred on the Bulong Anticline.
Locally regions of calc-alkaline volcanic, epiclastic deposits and BIF are found.
Cassidy et al.
(2006) divide the Kurnalpi terrane into seven domains, the Bulong, Gindalbie, Menangina, Murrin, Laverton, Edjudina and Linden Domains.
The Murrin Domain extends from Karonie in the south to the Spring Well area in the north is bounded on the west by the Kilkenny Fault System and on the east by the Celia Fault System.
It pinches out to the north between the Terrane boundary and the Laverton Domain.
Most of the Apollo Project lies within this domain.

The Murrin Domain comprises dominantly mafic to ultramafic volcanic and intrusive rocks with significant proportions of intermediate volcanic and associated volcaniclastic rocks and lesser felsic volcanic, volcaniclastic and sedimentary units (Association 2 of Hallberg, 1985).
It is apparent from the current study that a generalised regional stratigraphy can be inferred for the Murrin Domain.

The general sequence, disregarding overlap and tectonic interleaving, consists of widespread tholeiitic basalt followed by komatiite, and felsic volcanism occurring throughout but becoming more dominant in the later stages (Swager, 1997).

On the basis of stratigraphic relationships in the Yarri-Wallbrook and Karonie districts, tholeiitic basalts and dolerite and gabbro sills constitute the lowermost parts of the greenstone succession, and either underlies or represents lateral equivalents of calc-alkaline rocks interpreted to be the base of the succession in other parts of the domain (e.g., Welcome WellMinerie district; see Groenewald et al., 2006).
Cross-cutting high-HFSE granites (Nelson, 1997) provide minimum ages for the basalts of c. 27102700 Ma, i.e., similar ages to the oldest known parts of the Association 2 sequence.
At Outcamp Bore and Yarri, strongly foliated, high-HFSE-type tonalites have emplacement ages of c. 2710 Ma (Nelson, 1997).
Calc-alkaline volcanism is restricted to discrete centres that overlapped in time with the tholeiitic volcanism.
A series of calc-alkaline felsic (andesite with lesser dacite and rhyolite) volcanic complexes (Welcome Well, Edjudina) occur throughout the domain.
They are the lowermost part of the regional stratigraphy in the Welcome WellMinerie district, although they overlie tholeiitic basaltic rocks in the YarriWallbrook district.
Overlying these complexes are extensive mafic and ultramafic volcanic rocks and intrusive equivalents.
In the uppermost parts of the succession particularly in the Murrin Murrin and Eucalyptus districts are komatiitic basalt and lesser low-Mg komatiite and extensive ultramafic cumulate units.
In the Spring Well district in the northern Murrin Domain, calc-alkaline felsic volcanism and associated sedimentary rocks are inferred to overly the mafic volcanic rocks.
Detailed studies in the Welcome WellMinerie district have resulted in a stratigraphy being defined for this part of the Murrin Domain.
The Minara Group (Groenewald et al., 2006), a calc-alkalinetholeiitekomatiite succession, equates with Association 2 of Hallberg (1985).
Accordingly to Groenewald et al.
(2006), the lowermost part of the succession is the Welcome Well Formation that consists of volcanic and volcaniclastic rocks that are predominantly andesitic in composition.

Felsic volcanism is best preserved in the Welcome Well complex, which is dominated by felsic volcaniclastic rocks with subordinate felsic (andesite) and mafic (tholeiite) volcanic rocks and intruded by regionally extensive dolerite and gabbro sills (Giles & Hallberg, 1982; Hallberg, 1985).

The Welcome Well Formation is overlain by the Minerie Formation that consists of tholeiitic to komatiitic basalts, with extensive dolerite and gabbro and interlayered with epiclastic sedimentary units.
The basaltdominated succession is characterized by lateral and vertical transitions between massive coherent facies, pillow lava and autoclastic facies (Doyle et al., 2004).

The uppermost Murrin Murrin Formation consists of komatiitic basalts associated with layered mafic-ultramafic cumulates and felsic volcaniclastic rocks, principally in the Kilkenny syncline and adjacent areas and in the western limb of the Eucalyptus anticline.
The ultramafic cumulates are interpreted to be komatiitic in origin and their regolith is host to the Murrin Murrin lateritic Ni-Co deposit (Hill et al., 2001).

In the south of the domain, are several fault-bounded successions of basalt with minor komatiite and dolerite and gabbro sills overlain by felsic volcaniclastic and metasedimentaryfelsic epiclastic units, and are truncated against the Kilkenny fault system.
Small-scale trust duplexes and possible larger scale bedding-parallel faults imply repetition and/or juxtaposition of various supracrustal packages (Swager, 1995).

In the DarlotSpring Well district in the northern part of the Murrin Domain, the greenstone succession consists of a basal basaltic package with rhyolite volcanic and volcaniclastic rocks and minor interflow metasedimentary units, overlain by felsic volcanic rocks of the Spring Well complex and more voluminous metasedimentary rocks considered to be distal equivalents of the Spring Well complex.
A series of dolerite sills intrude the stratigraphic sequence at all levels.
Ultramafic units have not been identified in the DarlotSpring Well district.

2.2 PROJECT GEOLOGY The Apollo Project area is topographically low-lying and largely covered by variable thicknesses of quaternary alluvial and colluvial sediments adjacent to the playa lake, Lake Raeside, which lies in the middle of the project area.
The project straddles the Keith-Kilkenny fault zone.
The Keith-Kilkenny fault zone is a zone of deformation and strike faulting extending over 350km in the Kunalpi Terrane and trending SSE through the middle of the Apollo project area.
As a result, the Apollo project area is dissected by multiple shear zones aligned adjacent to the Keith-Kilkenny lineament trend.
Bedrock can be interpreted from isolated exposures of outcrop throughout the project area.

To the south of the Apollo project area a small monzogranitic pluton is intrudes into the Bulyardie Anticline, this pluton is hosted by a sequence of granodiorite porphyry, felsic volcanic and felsic volcano-sedimentary deposits.

Further to the north the sequence comprises mainly mafic and komatiitic mafic to ultramafic volcanic rocks, with some intermediate tuffs and minor intercalated black shales and later intruded by quartz feldspar porphyry and granitoid.

Principle lithologies exposed within the Mt Kildare area consist of a thick sequence of mafic and lesser ultramafic metavolcanic rocks with associated doleritic intrusive and sill units, and volumetrically lesser argillaceous arenaceous metasedimentary lithologies of distal felsic derivation.
