The Menangina Domain is bounded by the Emu Fault System to the west and the Kilkenny Fault System to the east.
This Domain pinches out to the north between the Murrin and Gindalbie Domains.
The western extremities of the Apollo Project fall within the Menangina Domain.
The stratigraphy of the domain is influenced by the Steeple Hill Syncline and younging directions therefore vary.
The stratigraphy of the syncline shows a basal basalt-dolerite with thin discontinuous komatiite towards the top, overlain by a felsic volcanic-volcaniclastic period.
This is followed by fine-grained metasedimentary rocks including grey slate and BIF.
In the west of the domain a second later mafic volcanic unit is apparent, and the komatiite is cumulate and thicker (Swager, 1995).
Younging in this region is to the west.
In the north the sequence dips and youngs to the east.
It shows several mafic-felsic volcanic and volcaniclastic packages with substantial lateral variation in the mafic and felsic volumes.
The greenstone association comprises tholeiitic basalt and minor komatiite, interleaved with and overlain by felsic volcanic and epiclastic rocks.
Komatiitc volcanism is dominated by olivine cumulate rock with minor gabbo, komatiitic basalt and some olivinespinifex flows.
It is possibly repeated and is truncated in the north east by the Yilgangi Fault (Swager, 1995).

The Cosmos North Project is situated in the northern Part of the Eastern Goldfields Terrane, and is underlain by the greenstones of the Yakabindie Greenstone Belt.
Specifically, tenement E36/501 covers the basaltic and doleritic units of the Mt Goode Basalt Unit.
Lower parts of this basaltic unit comprise porphyritic tholeiitic basalt.
Upper parts are typically plagioclase-phyric within a fine grained basaltic matrix.
Localised pillow structures may also be present.
The geology underlying the tenemet is bounded to the southwest by the Yakabindie Shear zone and to the northeast by the Miranda Fault.
To the southeast of the project area, separated by a fault, lies the Cosmos nickel mine.
To the north, northwest and southwest, numerous gold workings (including the Kathleen Valley Gold Camp) are located.

Due to the limited time available in which to review available data and plan any subsequent work program, it was recommended that GNI surrender the peripheral sub- blocks of E36/501 (Figure 3; 3031 s, x, u, z and 3103 d and e GDA94), preserving the bulk of an as yet untested gold in soil anomaly, to be drilled in the following reporting year.

Perilya acquired the broader Fortnum Project from Homestake in 1993 and maintained an exploration focus in the immediate mine area, delivering a total combined reserve and resources of 6.35 Mt @ 2.3g/t Au by May 1995.
In 1995 Perilya commenced a regional exploration program, incorporating the Fortnum NWN Project area, which involved mapping, soil geochemical sampling and drilling.
A geophysical survey flown in late 1997 identified a series of targets across the area, some of which were located on the Fortnum NWN Project area.
Soil and spot BLEG programmes were completed over areas that had anomalous BLEG values from the earlier sampling program or were determined prospective from geophysical targets.
Perilya completed first pass RAB drilling at some of these prospects, with RC drilling completed on prospects that warranted follow up.
Big Billy was the most intensely drilled of these prospects with a number of phases of RC drilling completed on at least two grid orientations.

The Fortnum NWN Project tenements are adjacent to and partly surround the Fortnum Project tenements, also held by Grosvenor Gold Pty Ltd. E52/1655 is located to the north and east of the Labouchere deposit and to the north of the regionally significant Fortnum Fault.
The geology is dominated by Labouchere Formation sediments, with rocks of the Bangemall Basin located to the north west.
E52/1659 surrounds the Fortnum Wedge area to the north, east and south.

The Fortnum Wedge consists of a series of deformed volcanic, volcaniclastic and sedimentary rocks of the Narracoota Formation which form a deformed and relatively uplifted sequence within Ravelstone Formation rocks of the lower Bryah Basin.
The Fortnum Wedge is a regionally significant source of gold mineralisation and hosts amongst others the Starlight Group, Yarlarweelor and Toms deposits.

E52/1659 is located on the western limb of a folded sequence dominated by Ravelstone Formation rocks of the lower Bryah Basin and includes Horseshoe Formation banded iron in the north east the core of the fold and the south west.
Labouchere Formation sediments occur in the south west corner of the tenement.

E52/1671 is located to the south of E52/1659 and contains the nose of the folded sequence, with a stratigraphic sequence that consists of Ravelstone Formation rocks in the central north, containing zones of Narracoota Ultramafics, then Horseshoe Formation banded irons trending in to Labouchere Formation sediments.
The Labouchere Formation sediments dominate the western and southern portions of the tenement.

Mineralisation appears to be associated with zones of Narracoota Ultramafics adjacent to the contact between the Ravelstone Formation and the Horseshoe Formation and proximal to the fold nose, highlighted by the discovery of the Forrest Gimp prospect.

This report details exploration carried out on the Fortnum NWN Project during the reporting period 1/1/2008 to 31/12/2008.
Grosvenor Gold Pty Ltd is the beneficial and/or registered holder of the tenements.
The tenements are located on Milgun Station (Pastoral Lease No.

398/639), approximately 780 km north northeast of Perth, in the Peak Hill Mineral Field (Figure 1) Road access from the regional centre of Meekatharra is via the Great Northern Highway for 76km, and thence 75km northwards along the formed, unsealed Ashburton Downs Meekatharra Road and thence 22km to the west along the Fortnum Mine access road.
The Project area lies in the predominantly low scrubby mulga country between the Murchison and Gascoyne Rivers.
The climate is semi-arid, with an average annual rainfall of 220mm.
Topography is subdued, with low ridges of banded iron and quartzite which rise tens of metres above the plain.
Mining has been carried out intermittently in the region since the 1890s.
The Horseshoe Lights mine is situated 30km to the east and the Peak Hill mine 50km to the south-east of the Fortnum Project.

Gleneagle Gold Limited, the previous beneficial and/or registered holder of the tenements was placed in to Voluntary Administration on 3 May 2007, following which the tenements were sold to Eagle Gold Mines Pty Ltd.
The sale of the tenements settled on 17 December 2007 and the tenements were transferred to Eagle Gold Mines Pty Ltd on 2 January 2008.
On 8 July 2008 a Receiver and Manager was appointed to Eagle Gold Mines Pty Ltd.
The tenements were transferred to Grosvenor Gold Pty Ltd (formerly Eagle Gold Mines Pty Ltd (Receivers and Managers appointed) on 12 February 2009.
The tenements are subject to the ILUA Native Title conditions.
Subsequently, during the reporting period, Eagle Gold Mines Pty Ltd did not conduct any field based exploration activities.
Work was limited to desk top studies.
A desk top review of all the existing data over the project area has outlined a number of prospects and conceptual target areas that warrant follow-up and initial phases of exploration.
Homestake acquired the broader Fortnum Project area in 1983 after it discovered anomalous gold values in outcrop as part of a regional evaluation of the Glengarry Basin.
The main focus of exploration was around the outcrop discovery at Toms Hill and the immediate environs, which by the end of 1988 had yielded a total resources of 4 Mt @ 3.2 g/t Au.
Regional exploration activities, including the Fortnum NWN Project area consisted of wide spaced surface sampling and geological mapping, which defined a series of low order anomalies.
The Fortnum NWN Project is located within the Bryah and Padbury Groups, which comprise the now-superseded Glengarry Basin of Gee and Grey (1993).

The Bryah and Padbury Groups comprise Palaeoproterozoic rocks that are bound to the north by the Bangemall Basin, to the west by the Archaean Narryer Terrane, and the Archaean Marymia Terrane to the east.
A complex assemblage of Archaean rocks of the Yilgarn Craton and Proterozoic rocks lie to the south.
Deposition of the Bryah and Padbury Groups is interpreted as occurring between 2.0 and 1.65 Ga (Gee, 1987; Meyers et al., 1996).
Rocks of the Bryah Group are interpreted as a rift succession with mafic-ultramafic volcanic rocks.
The Padbury Group unconformably overlies the Bryah Group but most contacts are faulted.
Metamorphic grade increases from east to west.

The Bryah-Padbury Basin forms part of the Capricorn Oregon, a collision zone between the Archaean Yilgarn and Pilbara Cratons, and was subject to regional compression, under two progressive deformation regimes between 2000Ma and 1600Ma (Pirajno et al., 2000; Davis, 2005).
The earliest, D1-D2 event involved NNE-SSW to N-S compression, resulting in a broad, approximately east-west structural arch through the core of the basin.
The D3-D4 event involved ESE-WNW to E-W compression, resulting in N-S trending folds and thrust belts.
Metamorphic grade throughout the Bryah Basin comprises prograde assemblages up to greenschist facies, post-dated by retrograde overprints within high-strain zones.
Mineralisation within the Bryah Basin mainly comprises orogenic lode-gold and volcanogenic massive sulphide Cu-Au deposits.
To date, the majority of exploited gold mineralisation is structurally controlled, mesothermal, epigenetic lode systems, formed during the D3-D4 stages of regional deformation.
These deposits are spatially associated with high-strain zones in metasedimentary and/or metavolcanic rocks, and are characterised by narrow zones of hydrothermal alteration.
The regional geology is presented in Figure 3.
Gold mineralisation is widely distributed throughout the area and is hosted in quartz -filled faults and shears in tuffs, porphyries and black shale; also disseminated in calc-slicate units.
Historic RAB drilling has located gold mineralisation in several regional aeromagnetic targets.
Coogee is the largest known deposit.
Gold occurs in metasomatically altered calcsilicate sediments within a sequence dominated by intermediate volcanics and subvolcanics.
Metamorphism and metasomatic alteration of the rocks have produced a skarn-like mineral assemblage in which the principle distinctive minerals are garnet, actinolite, magnetite and pyrite.

The alteration has been termed skarnoid or regional metamorphic skarn in the published literature and also has the following additional characteristics: high garnet/pyroxene and pyrite/pyrrhotite ratios, occurrence of intergrown pyrite-magnetite, K-feldspar, biotite and haematite.
An Open Pit Optimisation study of the Coogee Gold Deposit identified a lack of drilling north and south immediately along strike, as well as up dip, and an infill RC 10 of 15

The historic Hogans Find Gold Mine, which is immediately to the northeast of the Project area, has a recorded production of 314.5 tonnes of ore, at an average grade of 27.35g/t gold up to 1904, together with 909 ounces of alluvial gold.
Previous work by Terrain Minerals has focused on the Coogee Gold deposit, to the east of the Aztec Dome, and various geophysical targets to the west of the Aztec Dome.

This report documents all exploration activity on those tenements (M26/477 & E26/97) that comprise the combined reporting group C148/2001 that was approved by the Department of Industry and Resources on 16/01/2001 and amended to include E26/97 on 30/01/2006.

Exploration activities undertaken during 2009 included block model review, mining studies, and information memorandum update for the Coogee Gold Deposit (M26/477), and ground IP surveying, geophysical imaging, modeling and interpretation, RC drilling and sample assaying at the Aztec Dome Prospect (E26/97).
Report preparation, including data validation, drafting and plotting, were also completed.
2.0 LOCATION AND ACCESS The Coogee Project is located 20km northeast of Kambalda, and 55km south of Kalgoorlie, on the north side of Lake Lefroy.
E26/97 straddles the boundary between the Woolibar and Mt Monger pastoral stations.

The Coogee (East Kambalda) Project, comprising M26/477 and E26/97, covers an area of 49.6km2 (previously 103km2 in 2008 and earlier) in the East Coolgardie District of the Coolgardie Mineral Field of Western Australia.

Access to the Project is via the well formed Carnilyia Hill to Kambalda unsealed haul road (to the north) and a series of four wheel drive station and exploration tracks, and several old abandoned woodline rail tracks.
Alternative access from Kalgoorlie is via the Mt.
Monger road to Mount Monger Homestead, and thence south to the Carnilya Hill mine site.
The southern part of the Project area straddles Lake Lefroy.
The historic Hogans Find Gold Mine is located to the immediate east of the Project area and is accessed by way of a series of tracks from the north.
Most of the area is impassable in wet weather as it is traversed by a series of drainage channels and flood plains which feed in to Lake Lefroy.
3.0 TENURE The Coogee (East Kambalda) Project comprises one Mining Lease and one Exploration Licence (Figure 2 and Table 1) covering 49.6km2.
Transfer to Terrain Minerals Ltd was completed on 05/02/2009.
A 50% compulsory surrender was completed in April 2008.
4.0 REGIONAL GEOLOGY The Project area lies within the Kalgoorlie Terrane in the southern part of the Eastern Goldfields Province of the Archaean Yilgarn Craton.

Separated from other greenstones in adjacent terranes by either major faults or granitoid intrusions, the Kalgoorlie Terrane is conventionally divided into four major and two smaller domains which despite being separated by shear zones and structural breaks have common deformation histories and similar regional litho-stratigraphic successions.
The Project falls within the northern confines of one of these smaller divisions, the Parker Domain.
The Parker Domain is bounded in the east and west respectively by two major regional north trending structures, the Mount Monger and Lefroy Faults.

To the north, the domain limits terminate south of the Carnilya Anticline at the east trending Talcum Fault, a major thrust that separates the Parker Domain from its northern neighbour, the Boorara Domain.
One hundred and twenty kilometres to the south-southeast granitoids of the Norseman Terrane close out the Parker Domains southward continuation.

Regional mapping of the domain, combined with interpretation of aeromagnetic data, indicates the presence of quite extensive areas of metamorphosed tholeiitic and high-Mg basalts, ultramafic rocks, sediments, felsic volcanics, and volcaniclastic rocks intruded by granitoid plutons.
The outcropping greenstones of the Parker Domain appear to relate regionally with the upper basalt unit and felsic volcanic-sedimentary unit of the adjacent Kambalda Domain.
However in the east, the sedimentary rocks contain magnetite-rich BIF horizons which may be more closely associated with the adjacent BIFbearing sedimentary rocks of the Kurnalpi Terrane.
Any comparisons drawn are tenuous as much of the Parker Domain, to date, has been only lightly explored and cursorily mapped.
The structural trend is northwest.
Northwest trending isoclinal folds, with some overturning of the east limbs, are cross folded into a series of elongate domes, the largest of which is the Aztec Dome.
These folds are dislocated by north trending faults that are truncated by major regional shears sub-parallel to the geological strike.
Late north-northeast trending faults affect all earlier structures.

The regionally significant Parkeston Dyke, which cuts the Aztec Dome in to two geophysically distinct portions, is possibly an early structure which has been reactivated by later tectonic activity, and also intruded by dolerite.
The weathering profile is a truncated laterite profile where upper saprolite is overlain by thin (<10m) of Cainozoic transported cover.
Rocks are relatively fresh in the areas of outcrop.
Lithologies and structure are largely concealed beneath the shallow Cainozoic cover north of Lake Lefroy.
The saline clays and muds of Lake Lefroy are of unknown depth as all exploration to date has been limited to the onshore area of the exploration licence.

3 CGC1482001A2009 Coogee Project 2009 Annual Report 5.0 COOGEE GOLD DEPOSIT 5.1 BLOCK MODEL REVIEW As part of the mining studies undertaken by AMC Consultants, and reported below in Section 5.2, a review of the Terrain Minerals 2006 RC drilling assays and the historic Coogee mineral resource block model (that used by Cube Consulting for a View Resources 2003 resource estimate, and subsequently used by AMC Consultants) was completed in mid-2009.

This review concluded that the assays from the Terrain Minerals 2006 RC , which were not incorporated in to the original 2003 Cube Consulting mineral resource block model, would have no impact on the current AMC pit optimisation study (see Appendix 1) 5.2 MINING STUDIES In May 2009, Terrain Minerals commissioned AMC Consultants Pty Ltd ("AMC") to conduct a concept level set of open pit optimisations for the Coogee Deposit (Appendix 2).
The pit optimisations were carried out using 2m x 12.5m x 5m parent blocks.
All resource categories were allowed to generate revenue.
A processing cost of $23.00/t ore, cartage cost of $8.00/t ore and a metallurgical recovery of 93% were applied.

It also lies on the cusp of a drop in undiscounted cash flow.

6.0 AZTEC DOME PROSPECT 6.1 GROUND IP SURVEY Following a review of the 2008 induced polarisation (IP) and electromagnetic (EM) surveys it was concluded that IP was the most appropriate method for nickel and/or gold mineralisation in the Aztec Dome.

A three man geophysical crew from Zonge Engineering and Research Organisation (Australia) Pty Ltd (Zonge), South Australia, completed IP surveying on the cleared historic BHP grid lines 12000NW - 19000NW (excluding 13000NW - surveyed in 2008), covering a portion of the southern Aztec Dome, between 27/08/2009 -12/09/2009.
The survey was a continuation of that which was partially completed in November 2008, and previously reported in the 2008 annual report.
Zonge completed dipole-dipole complex resistivity induced polarisation using a Zonge GDR32 receiver and Zonge GGT-30 geophysical transmitter.
Dipole length and station spacing was 100m on all lines and data were recorded using a roll-along configuration providing a maximum n-spacing of n=8.
Data collection along 7 grid lines amounted to 1,282 points over 17 line kilometres.
Survey planning and geophysical consulting were performed by Bill Robertson of Value Adding Resources Pty Ltd to whom the data was sent for interpretation and modeling.
Data quality and repeatability were monitored throughout the course of the survey which ensured that the best possible data were acquired given local conditions and time constraints.

The IP survey was designed to locate small volumes of massive sulphide mineralisation surrounded by appreciable volumes of disseminated sulphide mineralisation of the Kambalda style of nickel deposit, as well as any type of disseminated and/or massive sulphide mineralisation, be it gold or base metals, hosted by mafics and ultramafics of the Aztec Dome, or sediments and volcanics in adjoining sequences.
However, it is unclear how deep an IP survey can effectively see through the outcropping basalt cover sequence in to the underlying ultramafic sequence.

From a Kambalda style nickel sulphide targeting point of view the thickness of this underlying ultramafic sequence, which is currently unknown, is critical, and in particular, also is the depth to the prospective basal contact of this underlying ultramafic sequence.
The location of the survey lines is shown on the geology map in Figure 5.
The Zonge survey logistics report is shown in Appendix 6.

Clay silt, sand and gravel in CCl channels and on floodplains.
The nickel mineralisation occurs at the contact between the host serpentinised komatiites (Kambalda Komatiite unit) and footwall basalts (Lunnon Basalt unit).
The sulphide ore zones are usually less than 6m true width.
Some of the mineralisation is massive, but there are larger volumes of disseminated mineralisation.
The mineralisation can be traced for kilometres and is of variable width.
The economic ore zones have dimensions of 100m to 150m.
These ore zones have small geophysical footprints and therefore are difficult geophysical targets.

In the Aztec Dome the thickness of the outcropping basalt cover sequence - equivalent to the hangingwall Devon Consols Basalt and the thickness of the underlying potential host ultramafic sequence equivalent to the Kambalda Komatiite are not accurately known.
Therefore, the depth to the base of the potential host ultramafic sequence will be a limiting factor in the effectiveness of any geophysical survey for nickel sulphide ore bodies.
It is expected that the IP footprint of a nickel sulphide deposit will be larger due to the disseminated halo surrounding the massive mineralisation (which should also have an EM footprint).
The expected IP signature is of a phase anomaly with an associated conductive zone.
The footprint for gold mineralisation is expected to be variable.
The expected IP signature is a phase anomaly with an associated resistive zone.
Four IP anomalies were interpreted (Figure 6) - Zone A is located on the northeastern margin of the surveyed area.
Low grade nickel mineralisation has been intersected in historic core hole ASD001 on line 13000NW and associated with a weak IP response.
Zone A is a stronger IP response to the northwest.
This anomaly is rated as a low order nickel target.
Zone B is associated with the Parkeston Dyke.
The Parkeston Dyke has most likely intruded along a major structural feature.
It should be noted that the IP response associated with the Parkeston Dyke is discrete.
The best response is on line 15000NW.
The IP response is associated with a resistive zone and is rated a high priority gold target.
Zone C is located further west on the western flank of a magnetic unit in a structurally complex area.
The IP response is associated with a resistive response.
Zone C is rated as a moderate to high gold target.
Zone D is located on the western margin of the Aztec Dome magnetic feature and on the flank of a magnetic unit.
The IP response is associated with change is resistivity (slightly more conductive).
Zone D is rated a moderate to high gold and/or nickel target.
6.3 REVERSE CIRCULATION DRILLING Reverse circulation drilling was completed at the Aztec Dome Prospect during 1st - 18th December 2009.
A total of 9 holes, numbers AZRC001 - AZRC009, were drilled for 2,691m, with all but one reaching the planned depth of 300m.
All holes were drilled at -600 towards 0450 or 2250, along historic cleared grid lines (which had also been used for 2008 & 2009 geophysical surveys) - see Table 5.

At the same time it was hoped that ultramafic rocks below the 2008 interpreted high density gravity isosurface might be intersected in several areas under cover, and add further confidence to the Aztec Dome geological model, ie being analogous to the Kambalda Dome.
The drill contractor used was Kennedy Drilling of Kalgoorlie, WA.
The rig used was a Schramm T 685, utilising 6m long 4 inch (115mm) diameter rods and a 5 inch (140mm) hollow face sampling bit.
The depth capacity of the rig under ideal conditions is 400 metres.
The rig was fitted with a Sullair Rotory Screw Combo 1350 cu.ft.
min, 500 psi compressor air pack, with a support truck housing an Sullair Rotory Screw Combo Open Frame 1350 cu.ft.
min, 500 psi auxiliary compressor and a Hurricane 6.7 276 booster with a 1000 psi output from 2400 cu.ft.min.
A rig mounted Sandvik Sampling System with Rotaport Splitter produced 3kg samples.
A stainless steel start drill rod was used to reduce magnetic interference for downhole camera shots using a GlobalTech Pathfinder Single Shot Survey Probe.
A Works Programme approval from the WA Department of Mines and Petroleum was obtained prior to drilling.
Cleared drill sites with excavated sumps, to contain the groundwater, were prepared with a loader.
Access to the project area, and to individual drill sites, used existing tracks and old drill lines wherever possible.
Drill chips were logged at one metre intervals, corresponding to the sample interval.

The sample for logging was taken, from the split sample residues in green plastic bags, dry sieved to plus 1.6mm, washed, examined by X10 hand lens, and the details were entered on a Panasonic Toughbook computer.
Lithology codes used for logging are shown in Appendix 8.
A record of each sample interval was kept in twenty compartment plastic chip trays.
The lids of each chip tray were marked with the drill hole number, metre interval and box x of y.
The end of each tray was labeled with the hole number and depth interval.
The interior lid of each tray was marked with the from and to metre interval.
The drill hole number was entered at the top of the lid interior opposite the first compartment.
A portion of each washed sieved sample was placed in its corresponding metre interval compartment.
A complete record of each reverse circulation drill hole has been kept.
All drill holes are stored in a wire rack cabinet in a storage shed, Steele Street, Leonora.
The rig was supervised by a geologist.
The rig was approximately lined in by driving along the old BHP grid lines until the back of the rig was adjacent to the drill site peg.

For logistical reasons, a few drill sites were shifted a few metres to tens of metres from the original drill peg 8 CGC1482001A2009 Coogee Project 2009 Annual Report to better accommodate the layout of all of the drilling equipment/vehicles and the drilling sump.
Daily rubbish was removed from the site on drill hole completion.
The collars were capped with plastic or concrete plugs.
The PVC collar was marked with the hole number, depth, and inclination, and the same information and the collar co-ordinates were written on a wooden grid peg placed next to the collar.
After a slow start to the drilling program, due to hammer problems and equipment failure, good daily production rates, >180m/day, were achieved.
A maximum day rate of 294m was achieved on the last day of the drilling program.
Drill hole locations are shown in Figures 5 & 6 and cross sections are shown in Appendix 9.
The 2009 RC drill program, whilst focusing on IP anomalism, has also partially tested the high density isosurface in several localities, with mixed results.
Deeper core drilling is required to test the sequence at depth below the interpreted high density isosurface.
7.0 DISCUSSION & CONCLUSIONS Mining studies have confirmed the economic viability of open pit mining at the Coogee Gold Deposit.
A potential cash surplus of >$6M is estimated for the deposit.

The Coogee Gold Deposit remains on the market and should a commercially viable offer be received then it is highly likely that the deposit will be sold to allow Terrain Minerals to focus on other high priority projects, such as the Aztec Dome, and the Bundarra and Dodgers Well Projects, near Leonora, WA.
The Aztec Dome 2009 IP survey successfully generated four anomalies for gold and/or nickel.
RC drilling of these IP anomalies returned mixed results.

Whilst disseminated pyrite was intersected in all RC holes, and is most likely the source of most of the IP anomalism, it is unclear if the quantities and distribution of this sulphide in 11 CGC1482001A2009 Coogee Project 2009 Annual Report every hole explains all anomalies.

Most of the IP anomalies occur in the overlying mafic cover sequence (Devon Consols Basalt equivalent) and are unrelated to a deeper source in interpreted high density rocks (the Kambalda Komatiite equivalent)?
This may not the case for IP anomaly A?
IP anomaly B, centred on the Parkeston Dyke, has multiple zones of disseminated and blebby pyrite (sometimes >10%) in mafic rocks in holes AZRC001 - AZRC003.
It seems obvious that this pyrite is the source of the IP anomalism.

IP anomaly C is situated in a magnetically and structurally complex area, and whilst disseminated pyrite occurs in all three holes in this region (AZRC005, AZRC007, AZRC008), it is currently unclear if the distribution of sulphide is sufficient to explain all of the IP anomalism?
IP anomaly D occurs on the western edge of the Aztec Dome, and widespread disseminated pyrite in mafics and intermediate rocks in holes AZRC007 & AZRC008 is the probably source of the IP anomalism.
Hole AZRC009 in IP anomaly A unexpectedly intersected a mixed ultramafic-mafic sequence on the eastern sheared edge of the Aztec Dome.
Some weakly disseminated and vein pyrite intervals are associated with wide zones of quartz veining and carbonate alteration and veining and may possibly explain some of the IP anomalism?
However, the IP anomaly remains open at depth with only narrow zones of pyrite logged between 142-232m, and no sulphides logged below 232m.

Hole numbers AZRC001-008 mostly intersected the monotonous mafic cover sequence (Devon Consols Basalt equivalent), dolerite of the Parkeston Dyke (IP anomaly B) and some of the surrounding intermediate and sedimentary sequence (eg, IP anomaly D), but no ultramafics.
These holes returned low Ni, base metal, and precious metal assays.

Hole AZRC009 in IP anomaly A, some 300m to the north of historic core hole ASD001, on the eastern edge of the Aztec Dome, unexpectedly intersected a sheared ultramafic-mafic sequence with anomalous Ni and Cr.
Most of the AZRC009 ultramafic lithologies are non-magnetic to only weakly magnetic.
); there is an erratic correlation between S and Ni values, however, it is likely that Ni may be associated with oxides as well as sulphides?

the geochemical signature is swamped by high Ca values up to 20%, associated with carbonate alteration & quartz veining (as logged in drill chips), between approx 75- 208m, then erratically carbonate altered down to 235m.
In broad geochemical terms the AZRC009 sequence seems to comprise high-Mg basalts and komatiitic pyroxenites?
The absence of SiO2 analyses makes this statement problematic?
They may be part of the Kambalda Komatiite sequence, or an unrelated ultramafic sequence?
Petrographic studies will be undertaken on the AZRC009 lithologies in 2010 to help determine any regional correlations.

The following preliminary observations can be made concerning the drillholes and the high density gravity isosurface under cover - Hole AZRC009 (drilled in to IP anomaly A) should have intersected the high density rocks below the isosurface, which it did - confirmed by the presence of high Mg basalt and komatiitic pyroxenite.

However, komatiitic pyroxenite intersected high up in this hole occurs above the isosurface, but may not have a distinctly different gravity signature from surrounding basalts due to shearing and carbonate alteration?
Most of the ultramafics in this hole are also unusually non-magnetic.
Holes AZRC001, AZRC002, and AZRC003 (drilled in to IP anomaly B), targeting the Parkeston Dyke, all terminated just short of the high density isosurface - deeper drilling required.
No ultramafics were intersected in any of these holes.

Holes AZR005, AZRC007, and AZRC008 (drilled in to IP anomaly C) should have intersected the high density isosurface at depths of approximately 150-250m downhole, but failed to intersect any ultramafics.
These holes intersected a mafic sequence dominated by basalt and lesser dolerite and (in AZRC008 only) intermediate intrusive.

Some magnesian basalt was logged in hole AZRC007, 128-166m downhole, which is approximately at the correct depth for the high density isosurface, and a similar magnesian basalt was logged high up in hole AZRC008, 10-83m downhole, well above the high density isosurface.

The lithologies intersected in the three IP anomaly C RC holes cannot be equated with the high density isosurface, suggesting that the isosurface - is wrongly interpreted in this locality, or; does not equate to the presence of ultramafics in this locality, or; may reflect a higher density source at greater depth than the current drilling.

Holes AZRC004 and AZRC006 (drilled in to IP anomaly D), targeting a geophysical anomaly on the western edge of the Aztec Dome, skimmed the edge of the high density isosurface and, not surprisingly, failed to intersect any ultramafics.
Further reinterpretation of IP, gravity, and magnetic data is required to better explain any lithological and geophysical correlations.
The area around ASD001 and AZRC009 is shaping up as a priority area based on geology, geochemistry and geophysics.

The current feeling is that the anomalous Ni, Cr, S geochemistry of holes ASD001 & AZRC009, may reflect remobilisation of Ni sulphides at depth, and hydrothermal alteration associated with the intrusion of the lithologically and geophysically distinct granitoid (syenite) intrusive plug near the sheared eastern margin of the Aztec Dome?
Deeper core drilling in at least two localities is required (say IP anomaly A and IP anomaly C?

), for stratigraphic as well as geological/geophysical targeting purposes, to test the extent and nature of the ultramafic sequence at depth, and to confirm the validity of the Kambalda type model that the gravity isosurface does indeed represent the top of a high density lithology (favourable ultramafic nickel sequence) below the current land surface.

The Coogee Gold Project is located in the East Coolgardie District of the Coolgardie Mineral Field of Western Australia, 20km northeast of Kambalda, and 55km south of Kalgoorlie, on the north side of Lake Lefroy (Fig 1).
It is located on the Mt Monger pastoral station and lies on Lake Lefroy (3235) 1:100,000 map sheet.

Access to the Project is via either the well formed Carnilya Hill to Kambalda unsealed haul road or the Kalgoorlie to Mt Monger road, both to the north, then via a series of four wheel drive station and exploration tracks, together with an old abandoned woodline rail track.
Figure 1: Location and Tenement Map
The Project comprises of one Mining Lease: Terrain also holds the adjacent E26/97 (Fig 1).
Digital WA State photography was purchased from the Central Map Agency of the Department of Land Information.
These images were geo-referenced, merged and cropped to a photo-mosaic of the tenement.
Historic, largely unrecorded, gold mining activity took place at Hogans Find, 2km north of the Coogee gold deposit and at Cutters Rush.
Extensive alluvial deposits have been worked in the vicinity of and to the north and northwest of Hogans Find.
In the late 1960s / early 1970s the area formed part of BHP Co Ltds extensive Mt Monger nickel/copper-zinc exploration program.
This work resulted in the discovery of the Carnilya Hill nickel deposit.
Croesus Mining NL with JV partners Aztec Exploration Ltd in the west and with Eldorado Resources NL and Genesis Resources NL in the east, held the ground from 1985 to 1993.

Aztec located two significant gold anomalies to the west of Coogee; first pass drilling at the Southern Anomaly, close to the shore of Lake Lefroy, revealed primary gold mineralisation associated with sheared and altered basalt/dolerite.
In the east there was little effective work undertaken.
Croesus undertook a detailed magnetic interpretation of the area immediately north of Lake Lefroy and identified twenty six target zones for further work.
The target zones included a range of structural features including fault splays, flexures and intersections as well as magnetic features and anomalies.
Sovereign Resources (Australia) NL commenced work in the district in 1992 and began to test the airborne magnetic anomalies.
Five of these targets contained significant gold anomalies of which one has gone on to become the Coogee gold deposit (Anomaly A).

Work at the Coogee gold deposit included RC drilling on a 25m by 10m spacing, interpretation of detailed magnetic data, metallurgical test work, geostatistical analysis and preliminary mining studies, incorporating a number of Whittle optimisation studies and pit designs.
In the late 1990s Sovereign changed its focus and sold its interest in the project to an unlisted company, Kambalda Mining NL.
Harmony Australia investigated the Coogee deposit in 2002, drilling a number of confirmatory holes and undertaking some metallurgical test work and mining studies.

All the available drilling and rock chip data have now been validated and entered into the digital database.
All the digital data have been reviewed and a number of inconsistencies, errors, mixed data and omissions have been corrected.
Data validation has been a time consuming exercise.
During the course of drilling, and at the end of each drill hole, wide spaced (generally 50m intervals) camera shot surveys were taken downhole by Kennedy Drilling.
A stainless steel start drill rod was used to reduce magnetic interference for downhole camera shots using a GlobalTech Pathfinder Single Shot Survey Probe.
Unfortunately, this survey probe malfunctioned several times, such that part of hole AZRC007 and all of hole AZRC008 had no downhole surveys.
Also, azimuth readings for several downhole survey shots were clearly wrong, either due to instrument problems or the presence of magnetic lithologies.
6.5 SAMPLING One metre face RC hammer samples were collected through the rig mounted Sandvik Sampling System with Rotaport Splitter.
A split sample of approximately 2-3kg was collected in a pre-numbered calico sample bag.
The remainder of the sample, the residue, approximately 10-15kg, was collected in a green plastic bag and laid out in rows.
Thus, for each drill metre interval there was a split calico sample and a split green bag residue sample collected (both with depth from and to marked).
Individual holes were initially sampled as 4m composites and some composite intervals were later resampled as single metre intervals.
Four metre composite samples were taken by scooping (using an aluminium scoop) the one metre interval residue sample in the green plastic bag, to yield approximately 0.5-1.0kg of sample per metre.
This process was repeated for the 4 single metre samples comprising a 4m composite interval, to yield a composite sample weight of approximately 3kg in a calico bag.
In some cases 2m, 3m or 5m composite samples were collected to allow for different intervals at the end of a hole.
Composite sample calico bags were also renumbered with an appropriate six figure sample number, eg 100498, which was also recorded on the geological log sheet.
9 CGC1482001A2009 Coogee Project 2009 Annual Report Most of the samples were dry and sample recovery was generally good.
Small samples and wet or damp samples were noted during logging.
The green bags and numbered calico bags were checked before the commencement of drilling.

The metre interval (depth from and to) on the residue bag, and the sample number were checked throughout the drilling of each hole, and at the end of the hole, to ensure that the correct sample had been taken at the correct depth.
The drill rig sampling system was cleaned between holes and when necessary during drilling to maintain the sample quality.
Due to interesting geology or geochemistry some composite samples were resubmitted as individual single metre resamples.
For 1m resamples the previously collected single metre split calico sample was renumbered with an appropriate six figure sample number, eg 100493, and submitted for assay.

Where previously split single metre calico samples were not available, the single metre residue bag was laid flat and the green bag was speared, from corner to corner, through the whole depth of the sample, with a PVC spear, to yield a sample weight of approximately 2-3kg which was deposited in to a new numbered calico bag.
Where the samples were damp, or wet, the spear was washed after taking each sample.
To date no inter-laboratory check sampling has been undertaken.
6.6 ASSAYING All of the assaying was performed by the Kalgoorlie Assay Laboratory of the Kalassay Group.
After samples are received at the laboratory they are matched to submission documents, entered in to the Laboratory Information Management System and barcode tag numbered.
Samples are then oven dried at 1200C before crushing of a maximum sample size of 3kg to minus 3mm in a vibrating jaw crusher, eg Jacques, Nugget, Rhino, or Boyd.
Over-size samples are split down to 3kg using Rotary or Riffle Splitters.
Post crushing, the samples are pulverised and homogenised in LM5 Ring Mills to >90% passing 75 microns.
Pulverising bowls are cleaned by a high-suction vacuum system between samples and at the end of each batch of samples the bowls and pucks were cleaned by pulverizing barren silica sand.
Pulped sub-samples are taken for analysis, as required, and residual material is retained for several months.
Within a standard laboratory tray of 50 samples there are at least 42 unknown (client) samples, as well as several repeats, blanks and standards.

Every sample batch is checked for analytical performance against known standards, reproducibility of repeats, the analytical performance of blank samples and the distribution of anomalous elemental values.

For all elements other than gold and silver a sub-sample of 0.2 grams is taken from the homogenised pulped sample and digested in a four acid mixture where the acids are added to the sample in the set order of nitric, perchloric, hydrochloric and finally hydrofluoric acid.
The digest solution is then heated to 2000C until dry and powdery and then leached back into solution using hydrochloric acid.
Water is then added to bring the solution up to the required volume, after which it is homogenised and analysed by ICP-OES or ICP-MS as appropriate.
Internationally recognised certified reference materials are digested and analysed with each sample run.
10 CGC1482001A2009 Coogee Project 2009 Annual Report Initially all RC samples were analysed for a nickel suite, as well as being assayed for gold and silver.
For the nickel suite of elements the samples were subjected to 4-acid digest and ICP-OES finish.
All AZRC009 single metre samples were then analysed for Al (10ppm), Ca (5ppm), K (20ppm), Na (50ppm), and Ti (2ppm) by 4-acid digest and ICP-OES finish.
Selected sample pulps from various RC drill holes were also subjected to 4-acid digest and ICP-MS finish and analysed for La, Nb, Zr (all 0.005ppm), and Sm, Th, U, Yb (all 0.002ppm).
For gold and silver determination a 40g sub-sample of the homogenised pulp is placed in a disposable container and subjected to an aqua regia leach.
A set amount of the pipetted clear solution is then analysed by ICP-MS to 1ppb and 0.05ppm detection limits for gold and silver respectively.
6.7 GRAVITY DATA MODELING During 2008 imaging and modeling of Aztec Dome ground gravity survey data were performed by Fathom Geophysics.

3D gravity inversion modeling of the gravity data was isosurfaced to determine the shape of the top of a denser rock unit interpreted to be ultramafics - possible top of the nickel prospective Kambalda komatiite sequence?.
This surface was visualised using FracSIS and is estimated to be approximately 200-300m below the current land surface?
Details of this work are presented in the 2008 annual report.

The data previously collected was incorporated into a geological compilation of the tenement geology at a scale of 1:25,000.
For Anomaly A, the Coogee gold deposit, the RAB data were used, in conjunction with RC drill cross-sectional geology, to compile an interpretive geology plan at 1: 5000 scale.
The area is isoclinally folded with overturning of the east limbs.
The folds are doubly plunging giving an interference fold pattern of elongated domes and basins.
Minor folding is common and the overall structure is an anticlinorium trending northnorthwest and disrupted by faults that are almost coincident in strike direction to the folding.

The prospective calc-silicate horizon, which hosts the Coogee gold deposit, has been traced for approximately 800m, northeastwards through the North Coogee area, where the horizon also hosts gold/copper mineralisation.

The mineralised lode has the distinctive skarnoid assemblage of magnetite (coarse grained) + pyrite + others.
Albite or albite-quartz is often the dominant mineral with lesser biotite, sericite, K-feldspar, apatite and epidote.
Gold is directly associated with the pyrite but not the magnetite although pyrite and magnetite can be intergrown.
High-grade shoots within the lode are characterized by increased pyrite-magnetite content.
Occasional very magnetite rich zones have been intersected but these are not mineralised in gold.
The lode varies between 2-8m thick and is reasonably continuous for over 800m strike.

Dip is towards the southwest between 30 and 45 (depending upon which fracture set the lode follows) and there appear to be a number of high-grade shoots for which variograms show the direction of maximum continuity as being 26 towards due south.

SUMMARY During August and September 2009, Zonge Engineering and Research Organization (Zonge) mobilised a three-person geophysical field crew to the Aztec Dome prospect near Kambalda Western Australia to conduct a Dipole-Dipole Induced Polarisation (DDIP) survey for Terrain Minerals Limited.
This survey was a continuation of a previous survey conducted for Terrain Minerals by Zonge in 2008 (Job 825).
The survey commenced on 27 th August 2009 and was completed on 12 th September 2009.
In this time Dipole-dipole data were collected along seven lines at 100m a-spacing, producing 1282 points of data over 17 line kilometres.
Survey planning and geophysical consulting was performed by Bill Robertson of Value Adding Resources Pty Ltd to whom the data was sent for interpretation and modelling.
Data quality and repeatability were monitored throughout the course of the survey which ensured that the best possible data were acquired given local conditions and time constraints.
IP INSTRUMENTATION A Zonge multipurpose GDP-32 ii receiver was used to take all of the data for this project.
The raw data from each day was downloaded every evening from the receiver to laptop computer and emailed to Zonges Adelaide office.
Preliminary processing and plotting were completed in the field.
Final processing and plotting were completed in Zonge Engineering's Adelaide office.
DDIP transmitted fields were generated with a Zonge GGT-30 geophysical transmitter which was powered by a ZMG-30 generator system.
Signal frequency and synchronisation were controlled directly by an XMT-32 controller which was synchronised daily to the GDP-32 ii receiver.
Porous ceramic pots filled with a saturated copper sulphate solution were used as non- polarisable receiver electrodes.
Transmitter electrodes were constructed using steel stakes in pits filled with salt water to aid conduction.
Receiver and transmitter wires were insulated 2.5mm 2 multi-stranded copper wire.
IP SURVEY PARAMETERS All data recorded during this survey was taken using Zonge's CRIP frequency domain IP program using a fundamental frequency of 0.125 Hertz.

Phase and magnitude data are collected for the 1 st , 3 rd , 5 th , 7 th and 9 th harmonics with the 1 st , 3 rd and 5 th used in the interpolation of a DC equivalent or 3-point decoupled apparent resistivity and phase response.
Dipole length and station spacing was 100 metres on all lines.
Data were recorded using a roll-along configuration providing a maximum n-spacing coverage of n=8.
Coverage was designed so that full n=8 coverage was attained over the ends of the lines as provided to Zonge by Bill Robertson.
Line numbers reflect those provided to Zonge by Bill Robertson.
Station numbers reflect distance along line in metres and were chosen by the Crew Chief so that station 1000 roughly corresponds to the start of each line (SW end).
Actual coordinates and elevations associated with line and station positions are recorded in .stn text files accompanying the digital data with this report.
As actual cleared line positions varied slightly from those provided, station positions were recorded by the crew using hand held GPS.
Elevation data as provided in .stn files was applied to station positions by Zonge and is extracted from NASA SRTM data.
Coordinates as provided to, and recorded by Zonge are in MGA 1994 zone 51.
PRODUCTION ISSUES Minor delays were encountered due to:- ATV (Quad bike) problems on 4th September.
The vehicle was returned to Kalgoorlie for repair while the remaining crew continued work on site.
Up to a days delay occurred whilst the bike was repaired.
Vehicle tyre damage was repaired on site by the crew on 6th September Very windy conditions were experienced on 10th September which affected data quality and delayed reading.
Highly conductive ground on several lines reduced signal strength and compromised data quality, in these instances additional time was taken to record additional data.
Soft sand on the south east end of Line L12000 resulted in vehicles becoming bogged.
None of these events had a significant impact on production rates.
More detailed information on daily production may be found on the accompanying disc under "Production Reports".

DATA PROCESSING The quality of each block of raw PDIP data was examined before being averaged to create a single record for each data point.
Blocks or channels that were considered of poor quality were skipped before averaging each stations data.
All raw data taken during this survey are included on the accompanying disc so that this data may be re-averaged if necessary.
Edited, averaged and decoupled resistivity and phase data were then used for plotting and modelling.
The 3-point decoupled phase is a DC or zero frequency phase interpolation using the 1 st , 3 rd and 5 th harmonic phase data to remove coupling effects often seen in raw phase data.
NASA SRTM topographic data were applied to data before both resistivity and chargeability 2D inversion models were produced using Zonges TS2DIP software.

These models are produced using default model constraints and no attempt has been made by Zonge to improve model fit to data or geological information, as such plots of these models are provided at no charge.
Panel plots of these models as well as observed data are presented in Appendix I.
Final data modelling and interpretation was performed by Bill Robertson.
EXPLANATION OF FILES Digital data is provided on CD along with paper plots of the data.
Data from each surveyed line are placed in the following directory structure on the accompanying CD: Processed_Data\line#.

Terrain undertook the surveys to locate small volumes of massive sulphide mineralisation surrounded by appreciable volumes of disseminated sulphide mineralisation (Kambalda nickel style mineralisation) and potential gold mineralisation.

The IP surveys were a follow-up of the 2008 IP and TEM surveys collected on lines 13000mN and 15000mN which suggested that IP was the most appropriate method to detect potential nickel and gold mineralisation within the Aztec Dome Project area.

During September 2009, Zonge Engineering and Research Organization (Zonge) mobilised a three-person geophysical field crew to the Aztec Dome Project area in Western Australia, too conduct dipole-dipole complex resistivity induced polarisation (CR-IP) surveys.
A total of 15.1 line kilometres (7 lines) of CR-IP of data were collected.
Data quality and repeatability were monitored throughout the course of the survey.
The survey logistics, instrumentation, survey parameters and specifications are detailed in the logistic summary report produced by Zonge.
The location of the IP and TEM surveys are shown in Figure 1.
A summary of the lines is shown in Table 1.
The nickel mineralisation occurs at the contact between serpentenised ultra basic rocks and greenstones.
The sulphide zones are usually less than 6m true width.
Some of the mineralisation is massive, but there are larger volumes of disseminated mineralisation.

2009 IP Survey Traverses The mineralisation can be traced for kilometres and is of variable width.
The economic ore zones have dimensions of 100m to 150m.
These ore zones are small and therefore are difficult geophysical targets.
The footprint of the nickel mineralisation for IP is expected to be larger due to disseminated halo surrounding the massive mineralisation.
The expected IP signature is a phase anomaly with an associated conductive zone.
The footprint for gold mineralsiation is expected to be variable.
The expected IP signature is a phase anomaly with an associated resistive zone.
2009 IP Survey The 2009 IP was collected with 100m dipole-dipole array, using Zonges Complex Resistivity frequency domain methodology.
The IP anomalies observed in the data are shown in Figure 2.
The IP data is shown in Figures 3 to 16.
The figures show the observed data together with the 2D inversions.
The 2D inversions have been weighted to produce moderately biased vertical solutions.
Proposed drill holes are also shown on the model depth sections.
The proposed holes are tabulated in Table II.
It should be note that the IP method is not sensitive to dip.
The IP sources are steeply dipping and could be drilled tested with 180 swing in azimuth.

Zone A Zone A is located on the north eastern margin of the surveyed area.
Low grade Ni mineralisation was been intersected on line 13000 (see Figures 17,18,19) and associated with a weak IP response.
Zone A is a stronger IP response to the north west.
This anomaly is rated as a low order Ni target.
Zone B Zone B is associated with the Parkeston Dyke.
The Parkeston Dyke has most likely intruded along a major structural feature.
It should be noted that the IP response associated with the Parkeston Dyke is discrete.
The best response is on line 15000 (see Figure 8).
The IP response is associated with a resistive zone and is rated a high priority Au target.

M26/477 includes the opportunity for: Mine production from the Coogee gold deposit.
The top of the deposit is only 25m from the surface and includes a significant proportion of high grade, supergene mineralisation.
The potential for developing an underground mine based on the known resources outside the open pit design has not been investigated (Fig 6).
A potentially larger repeat of the Coogee mineralisation lies 1.2km to the west of the Coogee deposit.
The zone is untested due to its location beneath the margin of Lake Lefroy.
A significant number of other ore deposits have been found and mined beneath the margins of the lake at Kambalda and St Ives.
A previous pit optimisation was updated in May 2006.
The pit design includes 101,000t @ 3.86g/t gold generating an undiscounted cash flow of $5.86m over twelve months.
The Coogee Gold Project is located 20km northeast of Kambalda, on the north side of Lake Lefroy.
The project consists of one Mining Lease, covering a total area of approximately 3km.

The tenement is wholly owned by Terrain Minerals Ltd, with a royalty payable to Kambalda Mining NL of $10.00 per ounce of gold, up to the first 10,000 ounces produced from the tenements and thereafter $5.00 per ounce of gold.
Gold mineralisation is widely distributed throughout the area, in a variety of rock types.

The largest known deposit is the Coogee Prospect, with a resource of 230,000t @ 3.27g/t gold (24,000 oz), which is associated with a skarnoid calc-silicate alteration assemblage in sediments and volcanics.
The top of the deposit is <25m below the surface and the primary mineralisation has been affected by supergene enrichment.

A pit optimisation study and open pit plan completed on May 2009 outline a mineable inventory of 101,000tonnes @ 3.86g/t gold (~12,500 oz) generating an undiscounted cash flow of $5.86m over a twelve month mine life.

Drilling has closed off the Coogee deposit, but interpretation of the detailed airborne magnetic survey has also identified another, larger Coogee style target 1.2km to the west, under the margin of Lake Lefroy.

The Project area lies within the Kalgoorlie Terrane in the southern part of the Eastern Goldfields Province of the Archaean Yilgarn Craton.

Separated from other greenstones in adjacent terranes by either major faults or granitoid intrusions, the Kalgoorlie Terrane is conventionally divided into four major and two smaller domains, which despite being separated by shear zones and structural breaks, have common deformation histories and similar regional litho-stratigraphic successions.
The Project falls within the northern confines of one of these smaller divisions, the Parker Domain.
The Parker Domain is bounded in the east and west respectively by two major regional north trending structures - the Mount Monger and Lefroy Faults.

To the north, the domain limits terminate south of the Carnilya Anticline at the east trending Talcum Fault, a major thrust that separates the Parker Domain from its northern neighbour, the Boorara Domain.
One hundred and twenty kilometers to the southsoutheast granitoids of the Norseman Terrane close out the Parker Domains southward continuation.

Regional mapping of the domain, combined with interpretation of aeromagnetic data, indicates the presence of quite extensive areas of metamorphosed tholeiitic and highMg basalts, ultramafic rocks, sediments, felsic volcanics, and volcaniclastic rocks intruded by granitoid plutons.
The outcropping greenstones of the Parker Domain appear to relate regionally with the upper basalt unit and felsic volcanic-sedimentary unit of the adjacent Kambalda Domain.
However, in the east, the sedimentary rocks contain magnetite-rich BIF horizons which may be more closely associated with the adjacent BIFbearing sedimentary rocks of the Kurnalpi Terrane.
Any comparisons drawn are tenuous as much of the Parker Domain, to date, has been only lightly explored and cursorily mapped.
The structural trend is northwest.
Northwest trending isoclinal folds, with some overturning of the east limbs, are cross folded into a series of elongate domes, the largest of which is the Aztec Dome.
These folds are dislocated by north trending faults that are truncated by major regional shears sub-parallel to the geological strike.
Late north-northeast trending faults affect all earlier structures.
The weathering profile is a truncated laterite profile where upper saprolite is overlain by thin (less than ten meters) of Cainozoic transported cover.
Rocks are relatively fresh in the areas of outcrop.
Lithologies and structure are largely concealed beneath the shallow Cainozoic cover north of Lake Lefroy.

Hole collars were sited using a hand held Garmin GPS76 (estimated accuracy +/- 5m).
An interpretation of the airborne magnetic data was completed by consultants, Integrated Geophysical Solutions in January 2007.
The Coogee gold deposit is marked by a discrete magnetic high up to 750m in length.
A similar, but larger magnetic high is located 1.2km further to the west, beneath the margin of Lake Lefroy (Figs 3 & 4).
Gold mineralisation in the Mosquito Creek Belt exhibits strong structural and lithological controls, from the regional scale through to the outcrop scale.

Although structural timing relationships and wall-rock alteration paragenesis imply that mineralisation occurred late in the tectonic history of the belt, during D4, it is clear that the reactivation of earlier generations of structures also played an important role in controlling ore-fluid flow and the localisation of gold mineralisation.

At the regional scale, the gold deposits along the Middle Creek line lie close to the northern margin of the D4 Kurrana Shear Zone, and, in the western part at least, are spatially associated with the series of mafic/ultramafic lenses that mark the trace of the D1 Middle Creek Fault (Figure 4).

In detail, most of the gold deposits are located immediately north (<250 m, <1000 m) of the mafic/ultramafic lenses and the boundary Kurrana Shear Zone, within a domain that is characterised by closely spaced D2 faults and quartz tension veins.
Most deposits in this domain are characterised by gold located within or immediately adjacent to D2 quartz veins.

The unifying characteristic of the mineralised quartz veins, and that which distinguishes them from the large number of barren D2 quartz veins further north, is the extent of modification by superimposed D4 deformation.

Richly mineralised veins are i) strongly recrystallised, ii) commonly cut by late-stage, quartz and carbonate filled fractures, and iii) are surrounded by zones of D4 chloritisation, carbonation and faulting, that link ultimately to the margin of the Kurrana Shear Zone.
11 The exception to this style of mineralisation is the Golden Eagle deposit, in which there is no clear association between gold and quartz.
However, there is a strong association between gold and late-stage, chlorite and pyrite rich, quartz filled fractures, which are attributed to deformation and fluid flux during D4.

A working model for the gold deposits along the Middle Creek Line involves regional scale fluid transport within the Kurrana Shear Zone during D4, with secondary fluid flux into more discrete structures in the domain immediately north of the shear zone (i.e.
pre-existing D2 faults and veins).

The D1 Middle Creek Fault, which is marked by the series of mafic/ultramafic rock lenses, probably played a role in regional fluid flux also, albeit in an indirect manner, by controlling the development of the D4 shear zone.

Reactivation of D2 faults and vein margins in the vicinity of the boundary of the Kurrana Shear Zone was likely to have been promoted by high fluid pressure within the shear zone, and fluid flux into the secondary D2 structures was probably enhanced by their relatively higher permeability (due to a component of brittle behaviour).

The main mechanism for gold deposition appears to have been declining temperature as the fluid moved away from the shear zone because, in detail, the richest gold mineralisation is generally not located directly in contact with the margin of the Kurrana Shear Zone.

An alternative mechanism involving gold deposition due to decreasing or fluctuating fluid pressure at the shear zone boundary appears less likely given the distal position of the richest mineralisation.
The gold deposits along the Blue Spec Line do not show an obvious association with a major ductile structure as is the case with the Middle Creek Line and the Kurrana Shear Zone.
However, they do occur near the Blue Spec Fault.
This belt-scale D1 fault, and second-order D1 and D2 faults linking with it, are characterised by strong shearing, chloritisation and carbonation over tens of metres due to reactivation during D4.

Another feature of the faults along the Blue Spec Line is the widespread occurrence of fibrous, quartz-carbonate veining, which points to crack-seal behaviour in response to extreme fluid pressures within these structures.
Most of the gold deposits on the Blue Spec Line occur in quartz veins or minor faults adjacent to the obvious fault zones, in a manner akin to the deposits along the Middle Creek Line.
Again, the larger faults probably represent the primary fluid conduits, and fluid fluxing into subsidiary structures was responsible for gold deposition along the Blue Spec Line.
Declining fluid temperature was unlikely to be the main mechanism for gold deposition because of the narrow width of the faults carrying the ore fluids.
Given the evidence for crack-seal behaviour, a model involving gold deposition in response to pressure fluctuations at the brittle-ductile transition may be more appropriate.

This model is in keeping with the generally higher crustal level features of the Blue Spec Line, such as the limited width of the primary conduits and the association of antinomy with gold mineralisation.
At depth, the Blue Spec Line may be underlain by a broader zone of D4 shearing centred on the D1 Blue Spec Fault.
Following the implementation and ultimate success of a revamped soil sampling technique in 2005, sampling programs were conducted throughout the Nullagine project area between 2005 and 2008.

The sampling methodology incorporated compositing (ideally) 5 x 20m spaced samples (to produce a 100m composite) of 425-850m sized material, resulting in an approximately 500 gram sample (100 grams from each of the 5 sample sites).
All composite samples were submitted to Ultratrace Laboratories, Perth for analysis.
Each sample was pulverised in a vibrating disc pulveriser, digested in Aqua Regia and analysed for Au, As, Cu, Mn, Mo, Sb, Sn, Te and W using ICP-MS.
Throughout all soil surveys, sampling of alluvial fill in creeks and rivers, as well as areas of transported sheetwash material was avoided.
Hence, compositing of samples was governed by the local terrain and the number of sample sites in each composite sample ranged from one to five.
Soil sampling was conducted throughout the entirety of P46/1454.
Sample lines were run along 800m spaced lines oriented at 335O magnetic, with one composite sample taken every 100m along each line.
A total of 25 composite samples were taken from 108 individual sample points.
Soil sampling found no significant surface gold or base metal anomalism within the tenement.
All soil sampling assays are found in Appendix 1 and Plate 1 is a sample location plan for each sample site.
The Nullagine Gold Project encompasses a large part of the Archaean Mosquito Creek Belt, which is situated near the south eastern margin of the Pilbara Craton of Western Australia (Figure 2).
The roughly east-west trending Mosquito Creek Belt extends for about 65 km along strike, and 25 km across strike.
Submarine, siliciclastic sedimentary rocks of turbiditic origin are the main components of the belt, and these rocks are separated by thin (<200 m thick) units of mafic and ultramafic volcanic rocks.
7 Geophysical data indicate that the rocks of the Mosquito Creek Belt extend under the Hamersley Province, 20km to the East and 20km to the southwest of the exposed portion.
Along the northern margin of the belt, the base of the Mosquito Creek Formation lies unconformably on the Warrawoona Group.
The Kurrana Shear defines the southern margin of the belt.

Although the attitude of layering within the Mosquito Creek Belt is largely upright, the number of prominent strike and oblique faults that occur within the belt, the lack of stratigraphic marker beds and evidence of structural repetition means the true thickness of the Mosquito Creek Formation cannot accurately be determined.
Recent age dating of detrital zircons in the sedimentary rocks indicates that sedimentation occurred after 2926 29 Ma.

Mylonitic fabrics in pegmatite dykes that surround the 2838 6 Ma Bonney Downs Granite (which in part abuts the southern margin of the Mosquito Creek Belt), suggests that regional shearing continued in this part of the Pilbara Craton until at least ca 2840 Ma.
Mapping by company geologists in 2005 show that the mafic-ultramafic rocks in most cases appear to be juxtaposed against sedimentary rock units by faults.

It is proposed here that there may be only one sedimentary formation within the Mosquito Creek Belt, and that the thin units of mafic-ultramafic rocks may represent fault-imbricated slices of a volcanic basin floor upon which the sedimentary rock were deposited (probably as a prograding submarine fan system).

This mapping also supports an interpretation that the Mosquito Creek Formation can be subdivided into two parts; the upper part characterised by interlayered shale, siltstone and thinly bedded, fine to mediumgrained sandstone, and the lower part containing a greater abundance of 1 to 10 mthick coarse-grained sandstone and conglomerate beds (interlayered with shale, siltstone and fine to medium-grained sandstone).
Routine geological/structural mapping and traversing was conducted throughout the Nullagine Project between 2004 and 2008.
Mapping within P46/1454 was limited to a few mapping points in the SW portion of the tenement.
Mapping methodology incorporated the use of Panasonic Toughbook laptop computers utilising ArcGIS9 by ESRI.
Locations for each mapped point were derived by using a GPS receiver plugged into the Toughbook and synchronised with ArcGIS9.

Lithology, alteration and structural information were captured at each point and each data point was transferred from the mapping Toughbook to an ArcGIS9 geodatabase located on the companies server based in Nullagine.

The Mt Alexander project area is situated approximately 20 kilometres south of the Nanutarra Roadhouse and 275 kilometres south of Karratha.
It is within the Ashburton Mineral Field.
The project area comprises 5 tenements covering an area of approximately 130 square kilometres.
Mt Alexander Resources Pty Ltd, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Vital Metals Limited, is the owner and operator of the tenements.

During the reporting period an aeromagnetic interpretation generated following a survey conducted in the previous year, which included the generation of a 3D inversion model, was further evaluated with the objective of delineating new target areas.
In addition track and drill pad establishment and upgrade was completed for the central parts of the project area and a geological review was undertaken.

A large banded iron formation [BIF] outcrop within E08/1410, delineated in the 2007 magnetic survey, was subjected to preliminary assessment as a potential iron resource and preparations were made to apply for authorisation to explore for iron within the tenement.
Further evaluation of the BIF outcrop (extending over 7000 metres) by RC and diamond drilling is planned in the following year.

An aeromagnetic and radiometric interpretation of the southern part of the project area (E 08/1410 and E 08/1074) completed by consultant geophysicists, Southern Geoscience Consultants in 2007-2008 was further evaluated in the reporting period.
The 3D Inversion model evaluation referred to above generated a total of 11 geophysical targets.
These present as magnetic lows and are interpreted to be attributable to buried granitic bodies that have the potential to contain associated tungsten mineralisation.
The geological model involves a carapace of potentially mineralised rocks above the buried granitic bodies.
A total of four of these geophysical targets coincide with known tungsten prospect areas.
Tungsten mineralisation at depth has been intersected in drilling at three of these prospects.
The evaluation of the 3D Inversion model and the geological model for Moodang Well has resulted in the formulation of a proposed drilling program involving 16 new drill holes.
It is proposed these drill holes will test a combination of geophysical targets and extensions to known mineralisation delineated by historic drilling campaigns.
The proposed drill hole locations are shown in Figure 2 superimposed on the - 75m depth slice of the 3D Magnetic Inversion model image.
The 3D inversion modelling conducted over E 08/1074 (Moodang Well Prospect) by Southern Geoscience Consultants was evaluated further during the period.
The objective of this work was to generate targets for drill testing.

Data from the aeromagnetic and radiometric survey was incorporated into the model with historic drilling data, satellite imagery, digital terrain model data, historic trench locations, geology, and aeromagnetic and radiometric survey targets.
Zinc Co conducted evaluation of base-metal mineralisation at the Mount Alexander prospect during the period.
A total of 1400 analyses, collected by XRF analyser in the field, of the potential base-metal mineralised dolomite-shale horizon at the Mount Alexander prospect, were undertaken.
Sampling of an associated ironstone horizon for its manganese potential was subsequently undertaken.
A total of 190 rock chip samples were collected.
Characterisation chemical analyses of an indicative batch of these samples yielded sub-economic values for manganese oxide but iron values between 37% Fe and 68% Fe were returned.

Zinc Cos planning drilling program at the Mount Alexander base metal prospect, for which drill pad and track preparation was completed in the previous period, was placed on hold, following these sampling campaigns.

The recognition of a major banded iron formation sequence immediately west of the Mount Alexander prospect base-metal horizon, the extent of which was confirmed from the 2007 aeromagnetic survey, stimulated a field inspection aimed at evaluating the iron mineralisation potential.
Preliminary mapping and rock sampling was initiated in the period.

8.0 CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS The aeromagnetic and radiometric survey interpretation showed the geology of the area to be dominated by intrusive granites, quartzites, metasediments, schists and lesser marble, amphibolite and BIF units.
Structural trends vary between the northwest to the northeast, with dextral offset of BIF units interpreted in the northern part of the area.
An evaluation of the aeromagnetic and radiometric survey interpretation and 3 D inversion model of the Moodang Well prospect has delineated exploration targets requiring drill testing.
A 16-hole drilling program is planned for the following year.
A Heritage Survey has been completed in anticipation of planning for this program.
A large banded iron formation sequence delineated in the northern portion of EL E08/1410 has potential for iron deposits.
This potential will be further evaluated by drilling and other relevant testwork in the next period.

Table 1 Tenement details 6 1.0 INTRODUCTION The Mt Alexander Project comprises 5 tenements that cover an area of approximately 72 square kilometres, situated approximately 20 kilometres south of the Nanutarra Roadhouse and 275 kilometres south of Karratha (Figure 1).
The project area is situated within the Uaroo and Nanutarra Pastoral Leases and is in the Ashburton Mineral Field.
This report provides the details of exploration undertaken by Mt Alexander Resources and Zinc Co Australia Limited within the project area for the year ending 31 August, 2009.
The tenements have group reporting status GSWA Reference No.

2.0 LOCATION AND ACCESS The Mt Alexander Project is situated approximately 20 kilometres south of the Nanutarra Roadhouse, which is on the North West Coastal Highway and 275 kilometres south of Karratha.

The principal access to the project area is provided by the North West Coastal Highway, to the southwest of the Nanutarra Roadhouse and station tracks, which usually needed to be upgraded following the summer cyclone season.

The Loves Find Prospect, situated about 2.5 kilometres southwest of the Nanutarra Roadhouse, is accessible to the west of the highway via unsealed tracks approximately 1 kilometre south of the roadhouse.

Access to the Moodang Well and Mt Alexander prospects is gained via the Uaroo-Glenflorrie Road, which leaves the highway approximately 20 kilometres southwest of the roadhouse and then by unsealed station tracks.
The terrain is characterised by rugged ranges rising from broad plains.
The area is semi-arid and has a sub-tropical climatic regime.
Average annual rainfall is approximately 350 mm, most of which results from tropical depressions during late summer.
Vegetation is typified by open, spinifex grassland with scattered trees and shrubs.
The project area is located within both the Yanrey and the Wyloo 1:250,000 Geological Map Sheets, published by the Geological Survey of Western Australia.
3.0 TENEMENT DETAILS The Mt Alexander Project comprises three granted Exploration Licences and two prospecting licences (Table 1).

The tenements are all held by Mt Alexander Resources Pty Ltd. On 9 March 2007, Mt Alexander Resources entered into a Split Commodity Deed with Giralia Resources NL (Giralia) Zinc Co Australia Limited (Zinc Co) a spin out of Giralia, subsequently purchased Giralias rights to 100% interest in all commodities other than tungsten and molybdenum over 9 blocks of E 08/1410.
In March 2009 a partial (50 per cent) relinquishment of the Exploration Licences was undertaken.
A total of 17 of the original 35 blocks of E 08/1410 were relinquished and two of the original 5 blocks of E 08/1411 were also relinquished.

4.0 REGIONAL GEOLOGY The Mt Alexander project area encloses metasedimentary rocks of the Ashburton Formation, which comprise part of the Palaeoproterozoic Wyloo Group, intruded by granitoids, also of presumed Palaeoproterozoic age.

The Ashburton Formation comprises mudstone, sandstone and calcareous sediments deposited within a craton margin sedimentary basin developed between the Sylvania Dome to the east, the Gascoyne Province to the south and the Hamersley Basin to the north.
The sequence was subjected to regional metamorphism, giving rise to the Morrissey Metamorphic Suite.
Metamorphic grades increase towards the west and southwest, ranging from quartz-muscovite schist through to amphibolites, marble and localised migmatite.
The Kilba Granite has intruded the Morrissey Metamorphic Suite, producing extensive contact metamorphism and the local development of skarn and marble.
Two main phases of deformation are recognised in the Wyloo Group: D1 deformation resulted in steep dipping bedding and a well developed schistosity coincident with the peak of regional metamorphism.

Grantioid, including the Kilba Granite, was emplaced late or after D1 D2 deformation is responsible for most of the large scale folding observed within the Ashburton Formation, and has folded earlier fabrics into open to tight folds.
In the vicinity of Mt Alexander, tight F2 folds have a northnortheast trend and steep north-northeast plunge.
5.0 LOCAL GEOLOGY The project geology is dominated by northeast trending, folded metasedimentary rocks of the Ashburton Formation, which are intruded by two large masses of Kilba Granite.
Numerous small exposures of granitoid are present throughout the area, representing cupolas of underlying granitoid.
Local zones of contact metamorphism also indicate the presence of granitoid at shallow depth.

The Mount Alexander prospect, situated at the northern end of tenement E08/1410, encloses a folded sequence of dolomites and banded iron formations (BIFs) as part of the Ashburton Formation within the Gascoyne Province geological terrane.
Mineralisation, with affinities to Broken Hill Pb-Zn style, occurs sporadically over a six kilometre strike length of the sequence.

Major known mineralisation occurs at Cyprus Gossan, where drill intercepts of 8 m of 2.83% Zn and 0.95% Pb and 4m of 3.15% Zn have been recorded beneath the main siliceous gossan that has returned 42m of 1.36% Zn, 1.08% Pb and 17.2 g/t Ag from surface sampling.
At the Galena Cave-Dozer Cut area sporadic exposures of the target dolomite/shale horizon containing sporadic galena mineralisation is coincident with a 1500 metre long zone of Pb anomalism.
6.0 PREVIOUS EXPLORATION A summary of previous exploration within the project area was provided in the Annual Report for 2008 and the reader is referred to this report for details.
