DHTEM surveys were read in two holes (LLRC0002 and LLDD0001) drilled to test the Nessie conductor.
The LLDD0001 survey was read in two parts the original survey was read in the RC pre-collar LLRC0001, and a subsequent survey was read in the diamond tail.
Unfortunately, the two surveys were read at different base frequencies and with different channel windows.
Consequently, it is not possible to merge the datasets into a single set of channel profiles.
Furthermore, John Coggon noted some effects that are consistent with steel casing remaining in the drill hole below 275m, which can be seen in the cross-hole components.
Key points to note regarding the DHTEM results are: The response recorded in LLRC0002 is consistent with a conductor lying below the end of the drill hole (Figure 6 and Figure 7).
This is also consistent with the location of the minimum coupling position in the surface MLTEM profiles.

This provides a useful constraint on the possible location of the conductor it cannot lie to the north of the end of LLRC0002, otherwise the polarity of the response would be opposite to what we have observed.
A highly complex DHTEM response (Figure 8) consistent with multiple zones of intersected and off-hole conductive material was recorded in LLDD0001 drilled underneath LLRC0002.
It has not been possible to devise a model that fits these data, but the key conclusion remains: the hole has intersected the stratigraphy responsible for the observed response.

Given the known geologic dip, the constraint on the conductor position provided by the DHTEM data recorded in LLRC0002, and the complex conductive response observed in LLDD0001, we can conclude with some certainty that the source of the observed MLTEM response has been at least partially tested.

The fact that the conductive zone responsible for the observed MLTEM response is thick does leave open the possibility that LLDD0001 has not intersected the full width of the conductor, but this seems unlikely.
E15/852 lies within the Parker Domain of the Kalgoorlie Terrane.
Numerous regional geological descriptions and interpretations are available in the published literature (e.g., Swager and Griffin 1990, Swager et.al.
The Archaean rocks over which the tenement lies form part of the Kalgoorlie Terrane.

It is dominated by a sequence of northwest to southeast striking greenstones, comprising mafic and ultramafic lavas, overlain by high-Mg and tholeiitic basalts, with thin interflow sediment horizons of shale and chert.
This, dominantly mafic sequence is then overlain by felsic lavas, tuffs and agglomerates with associated porphyry intrusions, and finally by metasediments.
Locally E15/852 is almost completely covered by Cainozoic sediments, comprising alluvium from the Lake Lefroy tributary system.
There is a small area of subcropping tholeiitic basalt and minor felsic sediments in the northern part of the tenement, (figure 2).
E15/852 is located 26km east of Kambalda, near Lake Lefroy in the Eastern Goldfields region of Western Australia.

The tenement is accessed from Kambalda by travelling east along the Carnilya Hill access road, and then south along the Mt Monger Station access track, parallel to the historic woodcutter tramway, along the eastern side of Lake Lefroy, (figure 1).
Under the JV agreement IGO are required to complete SQUID geophysical surveys on the tenement, and meet a minimum expenditure commitment within the first 12 months of the tenement being granted.
IGO may earn an 80% interest in the tenement by meeting a further expenditure commitment over the next 3 years.
Upon meeting these requirements both parties will contribute toward further exploration and development on a pro-rata basis.
If either party chooses not to contribute they will dilute their interest to 5% which would convert to a 1% royalty.
IGO will manage the tenement on behalf of the JV.
AAEA have certain rights and obligations under the SQUID licensing agreement.

The main conclusion reached is that the conductor detected by the surface SQUID MLTEM survey has been adequately tested by diamond hole LLDD0001.
A small program of detailed FLTEM using the SQUID sensor has been designed, to reconcile the surface and down-hole EM data.
The DHTEM data provide strong evidence that the source of the Nessie MLTEM anomaly has been intersected by drill hole LLDD0001.
If a more detailed reconciliation between the surface and down-hole EM survey results is required, a FLTEM survey may be read using the Anglo American SQUID sensor.
This will provide a more precise estimate of the conductor location, which can be compared with the surface projection of the graphitic shale intersections in LLDD0001.
The proposed transmitter loop and station layouts are given below in Table 2, Table 3 and Figure 9.
The transmitter loop is identical to that used for the DHTEM surveys, and the line of stations has the same azimuth as the drill holes, centred on the collar of LLRC0002.
E15/852 forms part of the Independence Group NL (IGO) and Excalibur Mining Corporation Ltd Lake Lefroy Joint Venture.
It is situated 26km east of Kambalda, near Lake Lefroy in the Eastern Goldfields region of Western Australia.
During the reporting period IGO has completed a geophysical review and interpretation of the deep RC and diamond drilling conducted at the Nessie Prospect in 2007.
This has enable IGO to plan further infill SQUID MLTEM, to better define the anomaly and determine whether the drill holes were a definitive test of the strong bedrock conductor.

Key points to note regarding the Nessie anomaly are: The layered host response due to conductive lake sediment and regolith material is quite strong in the late channels where the Nessie anomaly begins to become apparent.
The superposition of host and target conductor response makes modelling more difficult and the estimates of model parameters less accurate.
The stratigraphy at Nessie is known to dip steeply, which is consistent with the twin-peaked shape of the in-loop EM anomaly profile.
The local minimum between the two anomaly peaks roughly corresponds to the surface projection of the top of the steeply dipping thin conductor (or the middle of the top of a thick conductor).
The station spacing of the MLTEM survey was 100m, which limits the resolution of the conductor location to about 50m.
However, the DHTEM data now provide a fairly tight constraint on its location.
Detailed FLTEM surveying may further assist in constraining the interpretation.
The decay of the Nessie response is characterised by a power law (Figure 5), rather than an exponential function.
This indicates that the source of the anomaly is not a discrete thin conductor.

The apparent limited strike length of the anomaly itself is not sufficient to constitute a discrete target: an electrically thick conductor composed of several sub-parallel layers will give rise to a power-law response, even if it is strike-limited.
The limited strike length of the observed MLTEM response has puzzled some geoscientists involved in the project, given the fairly unremarkable lithologies intersected by LLRC0002 and LLDD0001.
There is apparently no reason why black shale that forms an extensive planar surface should become conductive over a strike length of 200m or so, but remain non-conductive elsewhere.
Nevertheless, this is a common phenomenon that has frustrated explorers for as long as electromagnetic techniques have been used to target drill holes.
An internal geophysical review of the existing data acquired at the Nessie prospect was conducted by IGO geophysicist David Johnson.
This surface EM and down hole EM data was included in the 2007 Annual Report.
This report covers exploration completed within tenement E15/852, during the period 21st June 2007 to 20th June 2008, and forms part of the IGO Lake Lefroy JV project.
Work conducted by IGO has been focused on potential economic occurrences of Ni sulphide mineralisation.
E15/852 is however, completely covered by the Lake Lefroy salt lake system.

The most suitable geophysical method for this conductive environment has been the B-field SQUID EM sensor (Super Quantum Interference Device), developed under licence by Anglo American Exploration (Australia) Pty Ltd (AAEA).
IGO has a licensing agreement with AAEA for the use of the SQUID sensor in this area.

The project is located between Yorkrakine in the north and Bruce Rock in the south in the central Wheatbelt area of Western Australia.
2.0 Project Location and Tenure The location of the exploration licences are shown in Figure 2.
Licenses are in the Southwest Mineral Field.
The licences are situated in the Shires of Trayning, Kellerberrin, Merredin, and Bruce Rock.
Access through the project area is via a good network of bitumen and formed gravel roads.
The land is subject to intense cropping and sheep farming, small blocks of land have been placed into conservation reserves for preservation.
Most of the land is this area is private and is subject to negotiation with the land owner to gain access.
It comprises 61 graticular blocks, an area of approximately 178.6km2.
Some small conservation blocks that fell within the initial tenement application boundary have been excluded from the granted tenement.
3.0 Physiography & Regional Geology The Geological Survey of Western Australia has mapped the area at 1:250 000 scale.
Below is an excerpt from the explanatory note for the KELLERBERRIN sheet relevant to the project area.
The topography is gently undulating, broken only by isolated hills which rise to 50 m above the surrounding country.
Valleys are generally broad and flat bottomed.
They contain braided and meandering stream channels and extensive chains of salt lakes with marginal lunette dunes.
An extensive cover of lateritic soil developed on the plateau during the Late Cretaceous and Tertiary.
This surface is still preserved along drainage divides but elsewhere it is extensively eroded to form an etchplain, (Fink1 and Churchward, 1973).
A lower erosion surface was formed by chemical weathering at the base of the soil profile and is now exposed where the overlying laterite is eroded.
Kellerberrin Project E70/2917 Kellerberrin Two 2008 Annual Report for the period 19th of October 2007 to the 18th of October 2008.

5 of 8 The Project lies within the Swan-Avon palaeodrainage system which is thought to have developed during the Late Cretaceous and ceased regular flow in inland areas by the mid-Miocene (van de Graaff and others, 1977).
There is now little surface flow through the major trunk valleys and drainage is internal.
Large, smooth, steep-sided dome-shaped hills of homogeneous rock are abundant in the general area of the Project.
They pre-date the laterite duricrust which is now largely stripped from them and are being modified by subaerial weathering.
The Darling Plateau is capped by an undulating sandplain (now largely eroded) which overlies a Tertiary duricrust.
The duricrust mainly consists of massive and nodular laterite (Czl), developed as an in situ soil profile, and is mainly preserved as remnants on drainage divides.
This profile is characterized by a hard iron-rich crust which grades downwards into a leached kaolinized zone of deeply weathered bedrock, in which pre-existing textures are generally preserved.
The transition from weathered to fresh bedrock is narrow.
White to yellow sand (Gs) occurs widely along drainage divides.

It is the remnant of a former continuous sandplain, now extensively reworked so that the sand veneer is much thinner on the top of hills than on the flanks, where it accumulates as colluvial deposits.

Where there are extensive deposits of recent alluvium, it is difficult to determine whether Tertiary alluvium also occurs in the valleys, and a distinction between the two alluvial units Qa and Cza is uncertain.
Tertiary alluvium (Cza) is identified as a flat surface on valley floors, on which present-day river meanders, braided drainage, and lake systems are developed.
There is a sharp change in slope at the foot of the adjacent hills.
Recent alluvial sediments (Qa) are distinguished in the upper portions of drainage valleys and in more steeply sloping minor valleys.
In major valleys they overlie Tertiary alluvium, and are there included with this alluvium as Cza.
Playa lakes and their sediments occur in many valleys, where the drainage is ponded; they generally overlie alluvium.
The lakes are usually inundated after heavy rain and are centres of deposition of silt and clay (Ql).
Evaporation leads to the concentration of brine within the sediments; gypsum crystals are precipitated within the mud and a hard residual salt crust forms during dry periods.
Stabilized dunes of quartzose and gypsiferous sand (Qd) occur on the eastern and southeastern sides of playa lakes.
The dunes are considered to have formed during a more arid period 15 000 to 20 000 years ago (Bowler, 1976) under the influence of prevailing west-northwesterly to northwesterly winds.
Areas of eolian silt and sand, with numerous small claypans and irregular meandering channels, are also included in this unit (Qd).
Colluvium and minor alluvium (Qc) are a mixture of silt, sand and gravel, derived from Tertiary deposits and from Precambrian basement.
Much of it is derived from Tertiary duricrust and sandplain.

6 of 8 4.0 Work completed during the Reporting Period Mindax with Quasar Resources (affiliate of Heathgate Resources) is searching for roll front uranium in palaeochannels of south-western WA.
Mindaxs other projects further upstream have demonstrated very significant uranium anomalism in ground waters to >1000ppb U and suitable carbon traps within the drainages.
The Kellerberrin Project is another potential trap site within the palaeodrainage for the accumulation of uranium mineralisation.

A detail GPS gravity survey has been carried out in an area approximately 20kms north of Kellerberrin in Western Australia.
The survey was conducted in October by Haines Surveys on behalf of Mindax Energy Pty Limited.
This work formed part of a larger survey of 1681 detailed gravity stations on 11 traverse lines.
The lines are coincident with GDA94 Zone 50 with station intervals of 100m.
Some of the stations may have been slightly offset from their planned position due to vegetation and terrain.
The Bouguer anomaly processing has been performed using a country rock density of 2.67 g/cc.
A total of 371 gravity stations were visited within E70/2917.
The gravity survey was conducted along selected road traverse to try and characterise the morphology of the paleochannel to help target drillholes.
A modified version of the full report and all data for the tenement is included in Appendix 1.
The location of the survey lines is shown in Figure 5.
This data has not yet been applied to the exploration model.
The Kellerberrin Project tenements lie along paleochannel tributaries to the Salt River that drains into Yenyening Lakes.
Mindax intends to explore these paleochannels.
It is our intention to explore these tenements concurrently utilising the same exploration techniques and ranking targets identified within the tenements against each other.
The project is located in the central Wheatbelt area of Western Australia.
Mindax with Quasar Resources (affiliate of Heathgate Resources) is searching for roll front uranium in palaeochannels of south-western WA.
Mindaxs other projects further upstream have demonstrated very significant uranium anomalism in ground waters to >1000ppb U and suitable carbon traps within the drainages.
The Quairading Project is another potential trap site within the palaeodrainage for the accumulation of uranium mineralisation.
Work to date has concentrating and sourcing any available historic bore location and water sampling data.
This work is ongoing and is in the process of being validated.
Results from this work will be used to generate a list of suitable bore holes that Mindax will sample the groundwater from.
Mindax has also conducted a gravity survey along selected road traverse to try and characterise the morphology of the paleochannel to help target drillholes.
Work has also begun to identify relevant landowners where we may wish to carry out exploration work on their properties.

5.0 Conclusions and Recommendations Most of the work to date has concentrating and sourcing any available historic bore location and water sampling data.
This work is ongoing and is in the process of being validated.
Results from this work will be used to generate a list of suitable bore holes that Mindax will sample the groundwater from.
A gravity survey was carried out very recently to hopefully aid in our interpretation of the paleochannel morphology.

Dataset are being collected and collated from a variety of sources to try and determine what bore holes may be available for Mindax to sample the groundwater from.
Datasets have been obtained from CSIRO, Department of Agriculture, Department of Rivers & Waters and various local landcare groups.
Most of this data is historic and has a varying degree of accuracy.
We are in the process of combining these datasets and removing the duplication.
A list of potential bore sites for water testing is being generated and will be field checked before sampling.
Results from this work will be integrated with similar work on Mindax Energys Mukinbudin Project further upstream, and the Quairading Project which is downstream from the Kellerberrin Project.
